Posted: May 20
I want to recommend this game. So badly. But I cant in good conscience. I know this is published by 2K games but, the microtransaction situation in this game is absolutely abysmal. And horrifically predatory. Especially for a full price game aimed at kids. The first time you load into the main menu, after you make/login to your 2K account, you will likely be immediately greeted by a prompt to buy the "battlepass", just to give you an example. You earn a decent amount of currency doing the campaign but once you finish everything your essentially forced to open your wallet if you want anything. As multiplayer races give chump change (Around 10 bucks per race if you win, when cars cost 10k and above). The thing I was most excited for, the vehicle building, is really awesome. But if your given a relatively limited selection of parts to begin with. And you cant make your own chassis. And even more disappointing still, the vehicles you unlock during the campaign dont unlock the bricks used on them for you to use on your own vehicles. And if you want to get more parts, your going to have to buy them from the store. Same with buying the engines that dictate how fast or strong your vehicle is. Which makes your own homebrew vehicles useless if you cant afford a good engine.

The racing is enjoyable, aside from the rubberbandy catchup mechanics. Which remove the skill element of the game, and makes it more based on RNG. And the story is fun. Its got the signature lego humour and jokes which will give you a good chuckle. However the story is very very short. You could probably get it done in one sitting if you tried.

Overall I really wish I could recommend the game, but I just cant in its current state. The game itself feels like it has passion put into it. But having to pay full price, only to have to open my wallet again to get the other half of the game in terms of vehicles and building parts, is just ridiculous. This games probably going to have a short life unless something changes. Im hoping Lego will step in and tell 2k to calm the farm a bit and make things actually earnable in a reasonable time. Cause Im not spending hundreds of hours grinding multiplayer just to get 1 car, that Im likely not going to use anyway aside from the parts it has.

This games likely going to just sit on the shelf once I finish finding all the collectables, and be a waste of my money. Which is really sad, because this was the first game I was actually kind of hyped for in a very long time. But I got burned for it thanks to what I mentioned above. If you really like lego, stick around and see where things go. But I wouldnt jump in and buy it now.

I like this game. It's a fun game, and it's got a lot of character. I can't recommend it in good conscience. It's another live service game by none other than 2K Games, the forever runner-up in the "Worst game company of all time" competition.

If you're ok with grinding or spending money on a game you already paid premium full price for, by all means this game is for you. If you have enough creativity to work with a limited parts pallette out of the gate, you can have plenty of fun with this game without grinding for even a moment. If you want to just play the story mode, sure, go for it! But I can't in good conscience say "This is a game for everybody and should be given praise for everything it does right" because the one thing it does wrong it does to an egregious extent, and will likely only get worse over time.

Overall, it's a fun game marred eternally by Microtransactions and a pretty apparent lack of single player content (which the game expects you to grind pretty endlessly to buy the items in the shop since multiplayer races are worth a fraction of the payout).

In summation: LEGO Racers 3, but at what cost?

Posted: June 5
Never, in all my years, have I been so glad that a game has received little-to-no attention. This crock of wasted potential is insulting not just to LEGO fans who have long-waited for a spiritual successor to the Racers series, but to anyone with a functioning cerebral cortex, and it's all to do with its disgusting, predatory monetisation system.

LEGO 2K Drive is out to get your money in any way shape or form in what is quite possibly the most exploitative microtransaction system I have ever seen for a game which costs anywhere from £50 to a LAUGHABLE £105 at launch.

First of all, the game is literally designed to have no replay value – not only do many of the single player activities serve no purpose other than to frustrate you for single-digit payouts (cars in this game cost anywhere from 10,000 to 20,000 Brickbux) but rewards for races and quests that are actually worth anything drop significantly in value after the first go-around, meaning that, once you've completed all the races, there is virtually no point in playing the game anymore.

Multiplayer payouts are even worse – players have claimed it can take at least 167 hours of multiplayer matches to buy a single car in LEGO 2K Drive, but in reality it's likely much longer thanks to its dwindling player base.

I'd also like to remind you that this is a game targeted at kids. Even the premium shop, dubbed "Unkie's Emporium" is designed to look welcoming and inviting to young people in the way it shows off its premium currency and the LEGO cars which, if bought with premium currency, can reach up to £10 for ONE vehicle.

It's a buggy mess, too. Several of the bricks don't have studs for some reason, it crashes frequently, the premium shop is often non-functional, and it has soft-locked so many times it's not even funny.

What's truly upsetting is that there is a fantastic arcade racing game underneath all of this mess, with tight controls, an interesting power-up system, and an enthralling car-building mechanic which would be something to cherish if it wasn't in this game.

Do not buy this game even if it is discounted, the intentionally frustrating mechanics designed to split you with more of your money are not worth it. This game should remain a monument to 2K and Visual Concept's disgusting business practices and LEGO should be ashamed it ever allowed these notoriously deceitful companies to sully its brand even further.

Posted: May 29
I really didn't wanna leave a review, let alone a bad one, but at this point, I feel it's safe to say the game has lost it's charm to me.
I pre-ordered the game as soon as the trailers dropped cause I bought in to the hype cause the autism in me needed this game, after a childhood of playing Lego Racers 1, 2 and Lego Island 2, I got super excited for a new Lego game that wasn't the usual Travellers Tale's style or a minimalistic puzzle game. I was so excited in fact, that I chose to ignore the fact that 2K were publishing it, and forcing their name in the title.

Then I got to play the game and I loved it! It feels great to play and the customisation is so in-depth yet easy to control! I wonder if I can get more pieces from the store so that I can... Oh... The in-game store. And that's where it goes downhill. Where some of the odd features start to make sense. To get a brick pack that will contain 3 or 4 bricks or so is 6000 bux, I believe the highest paying race, the last one in the game, gives a one time payout of 2500 on the highest rank, after which the bux reward for the race is significantly dropped, removing any desire to want to do it again. Although you can complete it on the lower ranks for lower one time payouts, they too, drop their cash rewards immediately, this applies to every race in the game... We can agree this discourages you from racing and replaying the game right?

At the 30hr mark, I have 100% in all but one area, each having their selection of quests and array of collectables(from which I'm missing 7 bux), got gold on every on-the go challenge and completed every race on each difficulty/rank, and believe me, everything rewards you money, however the most I got for collecting all the collectables or finishing a quest was 1,000 bux. In this time, of doing everything I can to complete all this game has to offer, I have bought about... 2 cars? Why? cause they cost 20k each, 10-15k if you want a more simple one. You'd have to replay the last race, the final boss of this game, the Sky Cup, 8 times to buy one car, but that's not even true since after the first time you'll only get around 800 bux for doing that race, so really the maths would be... 23 times, to buy a car, you would need to play the same race 23 times, since that race gives you the most "bang for your bux".

This is why I spent my time making my own cars which is great! However you can't even have that for free since you have brick packs you need to buy, so that you can have the freedom of choice. And When I say buy, I do say buy, because a lot of the brick packs have seemed to been withheld so that they can be put in the Drive Passes! Woo! Now you can pay real life money for the ability to earn your digital plastic bricks! And how do you earn them you ask? By playing the games that has a short lifespan by design.

I must confess, I bought the Awesome Rivals edition of the game, and I'm ashamed, not even my humble choice discount could make the purchase cheaper, the £90 it cost me ain't coming back. I should have paid more attention, read the signs. Because this wasn't gonna be a Forza Horizon, where buying the special edition with all the DLC nets you with new areas to explore, hundreds of cars to pick from the get go, cosmetics, No. This edition of the game gets you 4 Drive Passes, 500 coins (which gets you 10k bux, enough to buy a cheap car), a Pizza Oven car, that's already in the game in a different category, and 3 days early access (void now). The kicker is that you have to wait for these drive passes to come out, the main DLC for this game, and that's normal, DLC has staggered releases. But these drive passes don't add new stuff to do, just new rewards to the base game. And I'm already done with the base game. Before Drive Pass 1 even started.

The game has too many issues and caveats. I feel sorry for the Dev team behind the game, since the base game, and story were incredible, it's just 2K's interference, and monetisation tactics that have soured the experience.
I paid £90 for this game, and all it told me was that it wasn't enough :(


ADDENDUM/EDIT/POSTMORTEM: It's been close to a month since the first Drive Pass dropped, no one plays the multiplayer still, I just got around to playing the game again to see what it has to offer and... my opinion of the game has worsened.
They did in fact add new things to do in the open world, roughly 2 On-The-Go Challenges and 3 World Challenges, all of which aren't particularly new or rewarding, they're the same as all the other challenges in game, other than a couple world challenges taking place on floating platforms above the map, which I'll give them, is more than nothing, but that's not saying much.

We now have a separate form of XP for the Drive Pass levels, it's not as common as the plain ol' XP and you need a lot more of it.
I had saved my last few achievements in this game for when the Drive Pass came out, so that I could have something to do while trying to level this damn thing up. But I didn't foresee two quite important things:
1. The achievements I have left are just meaningless tedium, e.g. Drive 3,000 miles, Drive 6,000 miles, Talk to 150 people.
2. I don't want 99% of the rewards from the Drive Pass anyway...
So I gotta say, as a freak for achievements, these are wild, I've played this game for 40 hours (it took like 12-15 hours to complete the story, for reference) and I haven't driven 3,000 miles. The only way you can move is driving, the only thing you do in this game is drive. After 40 hours of driving, I haven't driven 3,000 miles, and they want me to double that afterwards? Do they want me to play this game for 80-100 hours? I mean I knew they put too much faith in this game when they sold 4 Drive Passes, but to drive for 80 hours in a game that has like 20-30 hours of content is insane.
I dread to think how long it would take to get all 400 levels of these drive passes. Not that I think anyone could want to do that. As the only real value is the levels that give brick packs, just because they at least serve a purpose. I don't know why I'd want a Lego Dodge Charger? If I wanted to drive a Dodge Charger I'd play any other racing game? And that's the final reward of the Drive Pass, level 100, along the way you might get the odd thing of note, like a boat that kinda looks like a train, but really you'll only care about the brick packs. You won't care about engine noise #45, or Boy Wearing Red Baseball Cap, or even the odd 1,000 Brick Bux that they kindly bestow every now and then as it's own level, which just sorta says it all really. Some levels give you a car, others give 10% the cost of one.
What f***s me off is that I still can't play as a Lego Skeleton, although really, thinking about it, the real Lego Skeleton was the game I played along the way.

Anyway, I'm sorry for the long edit to essentially say, the DLC we knew was gonna suck, sucks, but I just felt some might care to know the details.

Posted: May 21
I love LEGO, I love all sorts of racing games, and have played thousands of hours of them. However, for LEGO 2K DRIVE, 2K tried to take both roads with the pricing model and ended up turning a lot of people away. You either make a game that's $60 with **NO** MICROTRANSACTIONS, or you make a game free-to-play with microtransactions that are cosmetic at most. As they say, you can't have your cake and eat it too.

The game itself is a true blast, it's got a lot going for it. It's like a mix between Forza Horizon and The Crew 2's open world, with the Lego Racers aesthetic, aimed at a younger demographic. The game's story is quite fun for me so far and its car editor/builder is a huge time-waster that works surprisingly well on a controller. It's got a good open world that's fun to explore, it's not as big as I expected it would be but it's big enough to be worthwhile to just drive around in finding collectibles and destroying everything. The big thing holding that aspect back is that they developed this for last-gen consoles (notably Switch) so instead of it being a true, seamless open-world, it's five worlds that are each an area/biome. That's fine, but it makes me wonder what that aspect of the game could've been if it were a seamless open world.

However, for a game aimed at kids, the microtransactions & in-game shop in this game are quite predatory. It takes quite some time to be able to buy ONE vehicle, and honestly you should be able to buy your first microtransaction vehicle by a couple of hours into the game, not take about 20 hours to get a ton of BrikBux before buying your first vehicle. The grind itself doesn't bother me personally, I play a lot of games with it. However, the intention of 2K and Visual Concepts is to make you get frustrated enough while playing the game to just give in and spend more money on a car instead of spending time unlocking it. That is by design, especially as this game is built for and marketed towards children, who naturally have less patience than adults.

In conclusion, the gameplay itself is fun but the business model from 2K and Visual Concepts is not. I'd say I expected better, but in 2023 that would be a lie. It hurts me to not recommend this title because the core gameplay is there, but I cannot in good faith recommend it because of the way its business model preys on children. If you want to buy it, wait until it is on a deep sale, which will probably be pretty quick based on what I have seen of previous 2K first-party titles. At the same time, only buy it and go in knowing that you will be spammed by menus asking you to buy microtransactions, so avoid them at all costs.

PARENTS: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME FOR YOUR KIDS. However, if you feel so strongly that you have to, PLEASE stay in the room with them and supervise them while playing it. THIS GAME'S IN-GAME STORE IS AIMED AT CHILDREN, and they WILL fall for it if they are not careful. I hate that I have to say something like this for a video game, especially one based off of such a fun pastime such as LEGOs, but 2K has forced my hand to have to say something like this.

EDIT 05/30/2023: Just when I thought 2K could not stoop any lower, they do just that. In a recent patch, they fixed a crash that happened when going into Unkie's Emporium. That's the only thing they did. The catch? That's where the cosmetics and microtransaction shop is. The fact that they found it necessary to release an update to fix that and only that in a fully-priced game should tell you all you need to know about 2K and Visual Concepts.

Posted: May 20
Hey! People working at 2K Games! Are you reading this? Good! The following is just for you.

Lego 2K Drive is a fun game, like a REALLY fun game. Creating your own Lego vehicles and driving around with them in various worlds is great. Give the team at Visual Concepts gold medals for the gameplay design. They made something incredible here.

However, you clearly want this to be a live service, so I will give you some advice. New vehicles and vehicle cosmetics mean NOTHING if the only ways that players can utilize them is by doing the same races they've already done dozens of times and by driving around in the same zones they've already explored. That's not going to interest anyone into a purchase. The things that will engage players in the long-term as well as attract new players are
1: new race courses
2: new explorable zones
3: new unique minigames

NOT the battle passes and NOT new purchasable items in the micro-transaction store.

Many people dislike live service games is because too many publishers and developers have fooled themselves into thinking that adding content to the “store” counts as adding content to the “game.” It doesn’t. Store content only exist as a side offering to the actual playable game content that you need to be adding as well.

You've already turned away a lot of potential players by making this a live service game. But since you're committed to it, make sure that this live service at least benefits customers and players with more things to play, NOT JUST more things to buy. Maybe then it’ll be great and more people will love it. I’m telling you this because Lego 2K Drive is too good of a foundation to ruin by making the same mistakes as far too many other live service games. Use this advice well.

Posted: August 10
The shady Toy Car Salesman

Inside my Childlike fantasy, I once travelled across the city carpet to the 2K Motors Dealership, looking to acquire a sweet new Toy Car to wreak havoc on many different city carpets with. I knew that a good toy car could theoretically reach the hundreds of Euros Price Range, but I was ready to pay up if the Car delivered.
The salesman, Microel Transanton, was very friendly and seemed just as childlike, as if we were on the same wavelength.
He managed to sell me on a model called LEGO 2K Drive, even got me to waive the ability to return it by offering me a 25% discount on the Key.

I was completely scammed.
Sure, the car controls great, and recklessly driving for hundreds of centimeters while disregarding traffic, public safety and physical laws is great, and it's directly compatible with most PC and Steam Deck Systems out of the box, unlike most prestigious cars these days, but it was nowhere near worth the price.
The customization options are severely limited unless you plug your Credit card right into the dashboard, which completely goes against the Car Brand's ethos of unending imaginative power, and after just a handful of hours, I needed to take it to a mechanic to install new and expensive DLC Parts.

The Junior Recreational Automotive Industry has become a total money-making scheme, completely spitting on its legacy of the legendary LEGO Racers it brought to fame.

This was a literal and (Mini)figurative Highway Robbery.

Posted: June 26
Well, this one was a trip...

LEGO 2K Drive is (kinda) a spiritual successor to LEGO Racers 2. Note that I specifically said LEGO Racers 2, not LEGO Racers 1. That's because the story mode is an open world racing game with slight RPG elements, just like in LR2. The building system has significantly evolved and I'd argue it's on-par with the now-defunct LEGO Digital Designer in capabilities. Most smaller objects are destructible in typical LEGO game fashion. Character animations are actually designed to resemble stop-motion, which is a nice attention to detail.

There are four world maps, although one of them is just a tutorial area you can revisit. The themes for the other three are: American Southwest Desert in the 60s, Yukon Territory in the late 1800s but with modern infrastructure, and classic pulp horror fantasy. Oh, and then there's an ultramodern sci-fi track with slight Japanese influences, probably as a bit of a homage to Ninjago. Honestly, this could definitely use some variety.

The powerup system is a bit of a half-and-half between LR1 and LR2. While there's no upgrade bricks and many powerup pickups are random, there are also fixed pickups in plenty of different places allowing you to strategically select what powerup you want to use. You can't exchange powerups by running over another pickup, but you do get instant access to your powerup even if it's at random.

The powerups themselves are, honestly, kinda weak for the most part, but honestly with how chaotic this game gets it doesn't need broken powerups. There's a couple powerful ones, like a warp boost or one that makes everyone's wheels square, but they're rare (I've personally never picked them up).

Now, time for the good, the bad and the ugly. Oh boy, this one's a particularly interesting one.

The good:
The game has an impressive attention to detail. The devs went above and beyond with the animation and building systems, they could have just made this solely focused around prebuilt cars and used similar animations to previous LEGO games both during the TT era and before it.
The physics are pretty tight for the most part. There's a bit of jank in some places and you will run into it, but the general driving model is pretty spot-on for a kart racer.

The bad:
The PC version specifically feels like a hastily made cash grab port, but at the same time apparently the console versions have keyboard and mouse support so I can't really tell which version is the original. I can say that keyboard and mouse support is a bit janky even in the PC version .
This game has some nasty rubberbanding, and while it needs at least some simply because the AI drives like a drunk donkey, the shear amount of it gets annoying. And it gets doubly bad after a while if you have difficulty assist turned on, which tightens up the AI's driving a bit but mostly just ramps up the rubber banding even more. The result is that this game has a significant amount of fake difficulty of the "player's input doesn't matter" type, and races can often come down to simply not getting hit by a spider on the final stretch.
You're limited to 50 custom vehicles even on the PC version. This is a massive step backwards as both LR1 and LR2 allowed an infinite number of custom vehicles on PC.

The ugly:
Oh god, where to begin. You know, I'm personally not actually that bothered by the monetization system, but that's because I mainly focus on custom builds and only buy flairs and vehicles as needed, and everything can be bought with in-game currency earned from gameplay alone. The only things that are must-buys for me are brick packs and those are cheap. But holy studs on a brick, who the 1x1 modified brick with one side stud thought that having both a full-release price tag AND F2P-like microtransactions on the same game? Again, you can get around it since the microtransaction system is just "pay to skip the grind", but for anyone who wants to collect all the prebuilt vehicles, you're either going to have to grind like crazy or cough up real-world cash.

Summary: A love letter to LEGO wrapped in the crap-colored wrapping paper of greedy business practices with a ribbon of poor quality control on top. But at least you're allowed to tear the wrapping paper off if you want.

I'm going to take the time to bring back an old review part that I used to do:

Recommended for: Fans of LEGO who don't mind massive amounts of grinding.

Neutral: Anyone else

Not recommended for: Completionists

Posted: May 18
167 hours to get a DLC Car

Won my first multiplayer online race on Xbox which paid out 5 brickbux. Some of the cars cost around 10,000 brickbux. I estimate with loading a new match, filling lobbies, and finishing the race at a generous 5 minutes per race.

This means you'd need to win (not just complete) 2000 races, which at 5 minutes per race you'll complete in about 167 hours to get that 10k DLC car.

Needless to say I refunded the game. I can't imagine how anyone can find this anything but predatory.

I understand you get decent payouts for single player events, but that's only on the first time you complete the event. Payouts for subsequent completions of the same event are far less.

Also, no cross-progression. I started out on Xbox and thought PC might be more enjoyable with small sessions on the Steam Deck. This means you'd need to buy battlepass, all DLC, and complete all the content again.

Game is also running awfully on my i7-11700k and 3080 with 64 GB RAM. No excuse, and my utilization never went above 13 percent in with processor, memory, or video.

Posted: May 19
Pros:
Vehicle Creation. The brick selection is good (but not perfect) and many of the bricks function properly. You can choose from many Lego colors including transparents and metalics, but you can also make bricks glow. You are not forced to include the driver minifig and can make micro vehicles or ones without interiors. There's a large selection of technic and hinged pieces. Being able to manually angle bricks is also a great addition.
There is a very large selection of engine sounds to properly portray your creation. The most fun I have had is building both real sets but also crazy things like Mame Bus from Tamagotchi.

The Gameplay. Similar to Lego Racers 2, Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed, and Forza Horizon. There is not only racing but also hub worlds with events and trials in the enviroment. There are many collectables in the different hub worlds which unlock different things such as minifigs, engine sounds, or bricks. You can actually attempt every challenge with any vehicle you are using unless it's, for example, a boat specific event.

There's a decent variety of missions and quests to play. You can try for gold time on a hill climb or smash mushrooms in the time limit between races. Mowing weeds actually affects your races because they are replaced with boost fuel when you clear them. I enjoyed the events more than Horizon 5's class locked events or trials with players ramming. Each hub world has its own mini-biomes and each area has its own set of collectibles. The bat collectibles are usually in the air, while the treasure chests require dolphins to dive and get them for you.

Despite most of the races taking place in the hub worlds, the tracks you race on are changed slightly. The variations take into account your chosen class but also change time of day and weather. The ability to fully jump on demand is interesting and adds depth to combat.

The graphics look great on everything, although less decent on some of the enviroment. Having the studs properly rendered through transparent pieces, different finishes on the bricks, and glow bricks lighting up is great. There are a few specific places in the hub worlds that could look better. Seeing all of the Lego sets is cool and the ability to destroy almost anything on the track is satisfying as well.

You are only given 6 chassis for street, 5 chassis for off-road, and 5 chassis for water. You are forced to build off of these chassis and you cannot edit the pre-placed bricks or axle locations. There are other chassis specifically made for the developer and Lego vehicles you unlock, which can be used as a "psuedo base" if you clear the bricks that it allows you to. A majority of the vehicles actually seen in the game driven by NPC or AI drivers can't actually be created by the player due to both the chassis system but also many bricks not even being available to players. If the vehicle you want to make doesn't follow the very specific chassis layout the game allows, then you can't make it. Not a single 90's or early 2000's Lego jetski or boat is possible without major redesigning.

This artifical restriction is done intentionally so that players are forced to buy more vehicles to increase their usable chassis pool. Both of the basic 6 wide Speed Champions chassis have pre-placed bricks and moved axles so you can't even make most official sets without redesigning them. Even incredibly basic Lego Racers 1 cars can't be properly remade because of this asinine system.

You are given a few premade minifigs to play as but you cannot create your own. You unlock more minifigs as you complete races and challenges... or you can buy more in the store. You cannot edit them in any way. The amount of minifigs is incredibly limited even after unlocking or purchasing them all. There are no classic minifigs playable. (other than the redesigned Rocket Racer)
Once again this artificial restriction is in place to force players into buying a minifig they want in the store. Even Lego Racers 1 let you create your own minifig. These restrictions are honestly unacceptable in a full price game.
I would also like to specifically mention an issue I have had. When playing certain minifigs in certain vehicles the game will remove their headgear and replace it with a standard racing helmet. I'm assuming this is to prevent clipping however the race helmet already clips and removing the fire fighting helmet from my fire fighting minifig that I bought is incredibly stupid, especially when the vehicle is open top.

The AI rubberbands aggressively. For comparison, it is almost as bad as Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed. Even with a full top speed and boost power build (never stop boosting once) the AI in 2nd and 3rd will keep some pace with you. In this situation I actually found the lower difficulty harder than the higher difficulty as I can no longer run perks to compensate against the AI. The AI have infinite boost but will slam the brakes if you get hit or they lead by too much. They will violently push you out of the way if you sit on their line, similar to Horizon 5 AI. The Sky Cup Grand Prix race is probably the strongest example. The rubber banding is so bad especially during the final turn that it's almost comical. The AI drive poorly and will fly off the track only to respawn in 1 second on top of you and violently send you off the map.

The music in Lego 2K Drive is mediocre. None of the music is "bad" but compared to the incredibly iconic Lego Racers 1 soundtrack, there is little competition. The two best songs in Lego 2K Drive are the stock disco and halloween music played from the boomboxes in the hub worlds. While driving through Hauntsborough, I often found myself ignoring the game's music and playing the "Halloween World" theme from Sim Theme Park in my head... The first 3 notes of Big Butte County's theme sounds like Elinu's Dance from Tera Online and I'm briefly jumpscared by great music.

Lego Racers 1 and Lego Racers 2 both include a minifig editor, and virtually every other Lego game has a significantly better roster of premade minifigs to choose from.

The items/powerups are standard for the genre, but nothing great like Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed. For those that haven't played that game, virtually every offensive item can be avoided if you're skilled enough. Lego 2K Drive specifically includes the ability to dodge missile, but you can dodge other items and hazards by jumping. I wish the system was closer to Sonic.

Once again I would have enjoyed a system like Sonic's or even Mario Kart Wii. Hitting jumps during a race just makes me want to land sooner. A similar issue is found with Mario Kart 7 and 8's boring gliders.

At the price they are asking I would love to see something like ModNation Racer's editor but I would at the very least expect something as basic as Forza Horizon's eventlabs.

While Sonic's boat sections were at the mercy of a water physics demon, the flight sections were actually great. In Lego 2K Drive there are tons of official Lego sets landed or flying around the hub worlds but players are stuck with car, car, and boat.

I enjoy the hubs included in the game but a complete lack of Pirate, Arctic, and Medieval is ridiculous. Life on Mars and Mars Mission have a few cameos, but space isn't properly represented either. Lego Racers 1 and 2 both handled this better. Not even a Rock Raiders cameo in Prospecto Valley. I'm going to assume they're holding these themes for later updates.

I enjoyed the game despite the flaws, but I highly recommend waiting for a sale.

Posted: May 24
Great game but terrible rubber-banding destroys the entire experience. If you do not care for rubber-banding then go ahead and buy it.
Also for those who do not know, rubber-banding is basically a way to make a race feel always close, if you drive slow or crash and fall behind, the AI will drive slower so you can catch up, and if you drive perfectly and get ahead, the AI will speed up.
Every race in this game feels super close and you always win or lose by a single second or at most a few seconds. Each race comes down to the last turn. At first I thought it was thanks to their super advanced difficulty technology, which allowed the AI to be just as good as myself. Yes, you heard me, there is no difficulty option in the game but rather and option auto selected that adjusts the game difficulty based on your performance. In reality that is just a fake option in order to make you think each race is close because of the adjusting difficulty, but they really just slapped a rubber-banding code and a fake difficulty option and called it a day. I tested the game with this option toggled on and off, and there is absolutely no difference in difficulty or AI racers times. The only thing that effects the speed of the AI is your own speed. If you crash a million times and never use boosts and drive slow, guess what? The race will be super close right until the finish line. You can drive perfectly with insane shortcut skips and boost perfectly and drift perfectly and then fumble in the last 100m and lose the raise. Or that very same race, you can crash a million times and win. I have tested this on many modes and races and with both the adjustable difficulty toggled on and off, and its the same. I can drive super fast and the AI will be 1 second behind me or I can drive 30 entire seconds slower and the AI will be 30 seconds slower. This means that the only thing that matters is the last 100m. Jut save all your boost and an item for the end of the race and use it and you will never lose, ever. Once I found that out, it ruined the entire game for me because now I know it doesn't matter at all how I drive throughout the entire race, I just save my boost and win at the end. I went from driving perfectly and sweating these close races to barely paying attention to the game and winning at the end with boost.
I figured out that the game was using rubber-banding because I would sometimes lose a race in which I drove perfectly but slightly messed up at the very end of the race and then replayed the race and crashed a million times throughout the race and ended up winning that very same race I had lost. This and the fact that every race felt super close right until the end, prompted me to start testing the game to see if there was rubber-banding.
If they added difficulty options like easy,medium, and hard, and removed rubber-banding, this would be an instant recommend. The game is great aside from that, but that issue really plagues the entire experience.

Purely from a creative building perspective, it falls short. The building is just awkward enough to detract from having fun.

It's alright but asking $60 for this is a stretch.

Good:
Doesn't require a 3rd party launcher or leave a process running after quitting the game
Good performance, not a buggy mess
Runs perfectly on Linux
Local splitscreen
Lego

Bad:
Multiplayer requires creating and linking a 2K Account
Excessive DLC and microtransactions (although not having a 2K account prevents you from buying much)
The highest framerate cap is 120 FPS even though the game could run much faster
Can't create a custom minifigure? This seems like a super weird omission so I'm genuinely not sure if I just missed the option, or if it's something to unlock later on...
Singleplayer seems pretty short

The vehicle physics are heavy and clunky and just not very fun to drive, although the ability to jump, drift, and boost makes up for it somewhat. There's also an upgrade system and the ability to tweak some stats, so it could be that late game physics feel much better than the early game physics. I wasn't really feeling it so I've requested a refund.

It's not completely terrible or anything, just a little bland. Kinda bummed that this is the closest thing we'll get to a third Lego Racers game.

I don't recommend buying it at full price. Knowing 2K the game will likely go on sale for extremely cheap next year in order to bring fresh players into their cash shop and boost their quarterly earnings, I'd just wait until then.

Posted: May 21
While I enjoyed my time with the game and played through it rather quickly, I can't recommend this game.

If you are a huge fan of the old Lego Racer games and just love building cars you might enjoy Lego 2K Drive. The open world can be fun to drive around and explore. There are various challenges to mix up the game play and keep things interesting. As far as the story goes, if you have played Lego games in the past it feels about the same along with the humor. Building cars feels great, I spent a good amount of my playtime in the garage making Lego cars I had as a child or trying to recreate real life cars that I love.

The reason I can't recommend this game is I don't see this game having much of a life span. For one the racing itself can feel pretty awful at times. The AI rubber bands like crazy, but it does go both ways I suppose... Falling behind or getting ahead does not really mean anything in this game. The Item pick ups are pretty standard which is fine but a lot less creative then Lego Racers. Many of the tracks feel very much the same. I loved the tracks that were a sprint to the finish line rather than just doing short laps on the same track 3-6 times, but there are only a handful of the sprint courses.

Second, its a live service game. Personally I don't think that HAS to be a bad thing, but in this case it is. You earn a currency in this game that you can pay for but you can also earn it by playing the game. Playing through the story I ended up with about 70k, that seems like a nice amount but that's only because you get a huge bonus the first time you beat each race on each difficulty in story mode. After that the income is much weaker. Most shop items cost between 4k-20k. So maybe grinding out money in multiplayer would be a better option, since that way it would keep people playing online and keeping the game alive right?

NOPE.

I played 10 online races. In total from those races I earned 37$ (And that's from winning most of the races.). That took a little over an hour probably. Already the game feels dead. Posted: June 21
TL;DR - Fun racer, needs some balancing, little buggy gameplay, decent builder, IN-GAME CURRENCY GOES *POOF*, buy on steep sale.

I was so ready for a Lego Racers successor, but there are some shortcomings that I can't gloss over.

The game play is fun. You won't be disappointed with the general racing. As you unlock the higher racing classes (B & A) you may find that the boost mechanics get out of hand with several tracks supporting infinite boosting. To me this warrants adding a "blue-shell" and/or re-balancing the boost system.

There are some funky launching physics when crashing at high speeds, especially in water areas. Also on water, you can lose all forward thrust when holding the pedal down in sharp turns. Boosting can't remedy this. You have to release the gas a moment for it to kick back on.

I've spent a lot of time in the builder, and it works fairly well though I'd love an option to lock the camera in place.

The "Brick-bucks" have issues. I don't give a hoot about the micro transaction system. In this day and age, I was just glad to see that no items would be truly held hostage behind a pay wall. I'm happy to grind out some currency for the extra brick packs and few other items I buy. HOWEVER, I take exception to having large sums (>10k) of earned currency vanish between game sessions. Multiple instances of this issue prompted this review.

I really wanted to like this game. :/

PS - A month in and at max story mode level; I still have no idea what my Drive Pass DLC bought me.

Posted: May 24
UPDATE: nearly two months later, they added the creation hub. The battle pass launched before that and it's worse than you'd hope. I hope you like stickers, I.E, the worst part of any set ever.
You cannot share your builds. You CANNOT share your builds in-game on launch. This is a LEGO game and there's no venue in-game to share your creations. They give you all of the Technic pieces, but you're limited to the same 5~6 frames for each category. This would be fine if when you unlocked a new vehicle, you unlocked a new frame to work with, but the most the game is willing to compromise is letting you strip a frame of most of its components, just not all of them, like say, the biggest, most obtrusive pieces that make the frame impossible to build something original with. Your Burger Kart will ALWAYS have the bottom bun. this is NON NEGOTIABLE. If a BOTTOM BUN can serve as the foundation for any sandwich, it can serve as the foundation for your Lego AMOGUS.
There are three and a quarter maps. The quarter is the starting map, the smallest, dinkiest map, and the other three are decently sized, they offer fun racing environments, but given their size, the price of the game, the brands associated, and the money they're continually asking for, it's a pitiful amount of content. They're not even made of Lego, not consistently, at least, they're bog-standard 3d environments which facilitates the construction of more tracks, but there's only ~30 tracks, and 24 of those are Forza Horizon-esque circuits and routes on the open world maps. The 5 cup races are completely original tracks. This isn't to say the non-cup tracks arent fun, they are, that's the game's saving grace aside from the (arbitrarily limited) building, in tandem with the fun, arcadey racing.
Wait until the Game releases it's battle pass. There's supposedly something in there, maybe the game's pitiful rewards system is due to the rewards being arbitrarily ripped out of the core gameplay loops to be sold off at a later date. I'd say it's nice that the Battlepass is going to be evergreen content, meaning there's no FOMO for that aspect, but the in-game store features a weekly rotating set of items that will never return until some nebulous date in the far flung future without warning. If the first update doesn't bring any meaningful content or system updates, then don't bother. If this game makes a change for the better, wait for it to be at least 30% off, $40 would be far more appropriate for what feels like a middle-budget arcade racer.
I think a good way to sum up a review for this game would be to assess the multiplayer offerings. As it stands; online lobbies are sparse. Barren. That's due to a multitude of factors. First, the rewards for racing online are non-existent. There's no incentive to compete in more difficult races for less rewards, there's no ranking system, no levels, no challenges, no prizes, there is ZERO incentive. Second, The online infrastructure is BROKEN. There's no lobby browser, meaning you're constantly dropped into lobbies with 1~3 other players who will likely disconnect as you're connecting, often times in the middle of a race, right on top of another Player or Bot. You'll be stuck on a loading screen while the Race begins, and will only be allowed to participate when the race is halfway through its second lap, and you're just sat at the starting line. Third, the failure spiral. When a game doesn't get traction quickly, it's unlikely it will ever find its footing. People who were suckered into buying this product will go online and find lobbies populated by one or three other people, and they will never see a full lobby. they will assume that trying to find a match online is futile, and will find other avenues to try and enjoy the game, or they will find a different game to play altogether. They will go online, onto forums or the Steam Reviews, and shout from the rooftops that this game is "dead on arrival," to dissuade other consumers from repeating their mistakes. 2K dropped the ball with this one. I'd like to update this review in the future but I am highly doubtful I'll be given a reason to do so.

Posted: May 19
Product received for free

LEGO 2K Drive is a great game.

I was very personally excited for LEGO 2K Drive as I have always been into cars, racing games, and LEGO nearly my whole life - so this game seemed like it was made for me. It does nearly everything right. Even under the LEGO skin, the driving physics & handling is great, and the way the open world is executed is top-notch. It's the game that has come closest to the Burnout Paradise since 2008. The building system feels natural and intuitive, which is difficult to execute. There's a couple issues with it, such as some bricks only being a part of car presets that you have to modify or some baseplate options lacking - but overall, the editor is amazingly well done. I'm a big fan of the tone of the game, too. LEGO City Undercover no doubt has better writing, but the overall feel of the game feels much in line with what you would expect. It's a feel-good experience with a couple of genuinely funny, self-aware lines.

So why can't I recommend it - at least for now?

I feel like this game got everything right, only for 2K's own greed to mess up a few areas of the game. I shouldn't feel FOMO for not grinding the game to get the ice cream truck before it leaves the shop in four days. I should not only win 25 in-game credits for winning an online race. This is a $60 ($70 if you're on 9th gen consoles, and more if you bought the deluxe versions) that is treated like a F2P game as soon as you enter the shop. I would feel ripped off if I didn't get this with a $100 Steam gift card I got for free with my new graphics card. It isn't acceptable, and that's why I cannot recommend it for now. It's so sad that every time this game will be brought up we will think "oh yeah, that game was great, sad that it was messed with by 2K", It's really good, and to see something designed so well get slapped in the face by greed is such a shame. I hope the numbers get adjusted, and the shop rotation just goes away. Even if you love the game like I do, please don't recommend this on Steam so we can lower the rating - and then, maybe 2K, or LEGO, will listen.

Posted: May 29
I cannot recommend this game. For those who are looking at my steadily growing hours of playing, allow me to explain. However, if you're just looking for the TL;DR, here it is:
The game appeals strongly to a very specific type of player, but has such predatory Micro-transactions that I CANNOT recommend it. Hell, I'd have trouble recommending it if the base game was free.

Okay, with that out of the way, here's a more in depth breakdown of my opinion:

First, you're noticing that I have a lot of hours, still growing, and I haven't refunded this product, even after calling out the bad stuff. There's a reason for this. This game strongly appeals to the sort of person I am. The kid who grew up playing with and building random stuff with boxes full of assorted Lego bricks. The sort of person who gets lost in character creator for hours as I try to tweak it exactly the way I want. The sort of person who happily gets lost for hours, days, even weeks in open world games while ignoring the main quest as much as possible. This is the sort of person I am. If this also describes you, then you might (emphasis on MIGHT) enjoy this game too. So the game will strongly appeal to a narrow slice of gamers, of which I happen to be a member of. The sort of person whose first action on booting up the game that first time, was not to enter the world and start racing, but to enter the creator to bang out those tutorials and start tinkering with my first project. Only after seven attempts, at least three of them suitable to use in the open world, did I even look at the other game modes and start banging my way through them. That was admittedly 2 days after I first started. The purchase was... mostly worthwhile for me.

But let's talk about why I am warning everyone, even those like me, away from this game: Micro-transactions of the predatory kind. This game isn't just predatory, it's just this side of Korean/Chinese MMO/Diablo Immortal levels of predatory. To explain: You earn "BrickBux" in game at a very slight pace. It SEEMS good, until you realize that in order to 'buy' more bricks for creator mode, it takes 4,000 BrickBux. Yep, 4K for just 3 to 6 new brick types to use in creator mode. This is to say nothing about the vehicles you can buy, which include new stats you can use (for a BrickBux fee) and body types you literally cannot make in creator mode, often with parts you don't have access to (not event to purchase). These new vehicles start around 10,000 BrickBux, and go up depending on artificial rarity with the highest I've see at 14,000. It has Bundles, usually consisting of a car and driver with some other odds and ends, but can come with less or more, that have prices covering a wide gamut, but some at the 100,000 mark and even higher. Yep, they added a rarity system to all this. And in game, you earn these Brickbux at a few hundred for events, maybe 1k (if you're lucky) for 1st in a race, and in the single digits as you wander the map and do things, which makes the act of unlocking anything extremely tedious. Of course what they want you to do is to pay real money for "Coins", and then exchange said coins for BrickBux, so you can afford these shiny things. This is an extremely scummy practice that has unfortunately been proven to work, because it hides the actual cost of the purchase by obfuscating it behind a secondary currency. And this is just the start of the predation. Let's not forget that if you buy the deluxe version, you get access to the first 4 packs... these are literally battle pass packs (which haven't been released at time of writing). So it's not DLC, they're selling you the 'chance' to 'earn' new stuff, and of course spend more BrickBux. Oh, and let's not forget the cycling store with a variety of timers bringing things in and out to encourage that FOMO as well. Gotta layer on all the BS freemium strategies, don't we? There's more I am sure I'm forgetting, but these are what stood out the most to me.

So yeah, that's my opinion of the game. I hate that it appeals so strongly to me. It has things I dearly love in it, but surrounded it by the most predatory, customer hateful (not unfriendly, this is downright spiteful of it's customers) practices I've seen outside of a free phone game. The only way it could have been worse was to add multiple currencies with specific unlocks, but I wouldn't put it past 2K to add that down the line. What's sad is you can see the love and attention the makers of the game put into it. You can see their original intent too, to make those BrickBux easy to acquire to unlock new stuff as you went at a reasonable pace. But then the accountants swooped in and messed with the economy until it became the dumpster fire that it is. I hate that I love this game, but this is a case of please do as I say, not as I do. I recognize the horrible predatory nature, and have chosen to do my best to avoid it so I can enjoy the game for what it is. But even I realize I'm going to slip. For instance, don't bother with the starter pack, it's useless. I paid the $5 for it and feel ripped off because of it. Unless you have the stomach for the battle pass system, don't bother with the deluxe edition, the vehicles it provides ain't worth it.

Just don't do as I do. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME until it's at least %50 off, if not more. 2K doesn't deserve to charge full price for this predatory skinner-box construct it made. Let it shamble itself into the grave, and maybe we can get a real Lego game without this BS monetization. I'm not holding my breath tho.

(( edit note: Minor edit made for accuracy. The price of Vehicles are 10-14K, I misattributed the higher "bundle" prices as part of their cost. I've split that up for better clarity. ))

Posted: May 19
Just another reason why I shouldn't let nostalgia drive my purchasing decisions. Forza Horizon 4 did LEGO so much better even with everything it was missing. Here's all the bad stuff up front.

-Micro Transactions
-After completing story you will only be able to purchase about 4 vehicles. Everything else will need to be a grind to unlock or purchase with real currency.
-Bricks for building also need to be purchased.
-Physics
-This is more a preference but I wasn't a fan of the physics, I didn't find the controls intuitive at all. The game uses the typical brake to drift mechanic. Cars oversteer even at the slowest speed so the handbrake is needed for tight turns. When drifting if you let go of the gas at all the drift stops so you can't feather the gas. There is also a jump button that is required a lot. Had they just fixed the oversteering problem they probably could have gotten rid of the handbrake.
-Building cars is limited, many bricks are locked behind a paywall and the default bases don't seem to be standard. Also a lot of classic pieces that are meant for cars are missing.
-No four player Split-Screen
-So sick of battle passes and service games. This game is full price so passes and Micro Transactions shouldn't be required for the content. I think for most people this games pricing far outweighs it's worth.
-Rubber Banding/catchup is awful. Seems this can be turned off a little with one of the options but I saw no difference. The rubber banding is trash and most of my races came down to rubber banding luck at the end. This completely ruins the feeling of having any skill. I know that this is meant for all skill levels but find a better way.

As far as positive points go the game is lacking because everything gets overshadowed by the bad. I only had a few bugs during my playtime and it works ok on the Steam Deck as well. The atmosphere is pretty cools and some of the LEGO jokes are funny. The Story itself isn't anything special but is funny at times. The maps are great too. For a Full price game though this should include so much more. At the time of this review I'm at about 16 hours in the game and find it hard to turn back on.

Overall if money is no object and you're fine with micro transactions and all the other nonsense in these types of games then have at it but even then it feels like a shell. LEGO could have done so much better.

Posted: May 22
So I like the game and I will give it a thumbs up. The people who gave it a thumbs down for micro transactions are not wrong. It is horrible 2K put this in the game with a heavy price for an already full purchase price game. Especially when kids are the target audience. It should be noted, even though there are micro transactions, I find them completely unnecessary for playing the game. Here is why.

1) The races aren't too hard. They can be challenging at times, but you don't need to buy a better car to beat them. What you unlock throughout the game is good enough.

2) If you find yourself needing an upgrade, it's better to build/modify a car. The best thing to spend cash on in my opinion is the vehicle stats in the customization menu. These can be unlocked throughout the game by doing races and side quests. You can also modify current vehicles with better stats, making a lot of the cars basically cosmetic.

3) Cars can be unlocked throughout the game as well. Do not neglect side quests. They give excellent rewards, cash, and experience. If you see a new side quest, do it. It is worth the time.

Because of what can be unlocked by just playing the game, micro transactions seem mostly cosmetic. But I agree, the fact they exist in the first place is horrible. Achievements would have been a much cooler system for unlocking certain racers/vehicles/brick packs.

As far as game play, I really enjoy it. It is relaxing to just drive around and do quests. The story has made me laugh from time to time. It is a really fun racing and rpg game. Racing feels really smooth, variety of options for different racing load outs, and an overall balanced feel. It is also enjoyable to build a car, being creative and trying out different looks is a lot of fun. I feel that is what Lego should be. It is worth the money. Just don't allow yourself or your kids to fall for the horrible micro transaction scam.

Posted: May 19
From my experience with the full release and the beta...

Overview

+ A lot of Destruction!
+ Lego Editor is fun
+ Performance is good
+ Very few Bugs

- Extremely Repetetive
- Rubberbanding/Cheating AI
- Race Rewards are terrible
- No sense of Progression
- The Open World is tiny
- Very Short and boring Campaign
- Story Progression is gated behind the player level
- Overall there is way too little content in the game



So in my playtime on the live serves I got myself 4 Vehicles out of the Store, all with in-game earned bucks. But all of that money comes from the first completion bonus you receive. After that, you need to grind very boring activities for tiny rewards for hours on end. If you purchase a car in the store you also receive the stat-kit it comes with, which you then can apply to any car. I don't think the game is P2W, as far as I know, you can get all stat-kits (of which there are maybe 10) from playing the game. In the Store are largely just cool "skins" of cars.

A lot of the customization for the Editor is also to be found there, so if you want to have all the cool stuff to put on you probably have to grind a lot (a lot lot). Overall I don't really think the Store is the biggest issue or really a breaking point, it really delegitimizes itself as all cars/boats are basically the same. Without exclusive stats, it's hard to imagine me buying something for real money. You can only buy with in-game bucks btw, so everything can be earned through playing. Or you can buy said in-game money for real money.



I would say that except for the Lego Editor, you are better off buying Horizon with the Lego DLC. It has better driving, Progression, and a much better open world. Speedtraps (and its leaderboards) alone are more fun than anything 2k Drive has to offer in their world. It's borderline insulting to ask for such a price when there is little to back it up. Every Vehicle feels the same in 2k Drive, I never felt like "Oh cool, this is something new!!" here. Largely because all vehicles come with stats (there are maybe 10 kits/variants) which you can also apply to all the other vehicles. So well.. your starting car can be a carbon copy of a McLaren you get in the Story at the end. Only the looks are different, it's just not feeling rewarding.

And Why exactly is this game always online? At least in Horizon you can see Drivators, and other players, and can play pretty seamlessly with others in events. Here you can't do that, it's completely single-player focused. The Multiplayer is literally in a different menu and has no leaderboards or something that would keep you playing. And on top of that the rewards are a joke.

I was fooled, as a LEGO fan myself I thought we got something along the lines of the Lego DLCs of Forza Horizon just now in a dedicated game. But absolutely everything is a downgrade compared to those games, its really not worth the money, sorry.

Posted: September 4
(More honesty than your doctor recommends on my Curator page.)

A lot of us have fond memories of Lego Racers. The Forza Horizon 4 Lego add-on was pretty amazing and really delivered, but it wasn't quite the Lego Racers successor we wanted.

Now, there's this game. Is it the Lego Racers successor we wanted?

Hell no. "Play Well"? More like Pay Well.

What it is is a posterchild for exploitative anticonsumerism, a pre-order-focused multiple-'edition'-selling DLC storefront with free-to-play-style monetization, including a 'starter pack,' cash shop currency (yeah, a full-priced eighty-Canadollar game has a cash shop), an excised-content 'season pass', and a pay-to-grind system. Not sure if there's literal gambling, but this paragraph alone is enough to avoid this. Start 'em young -- force anticonsumerism onto kids who have no knowledge of when the industry used to respect its customers and you can get away with literally anything, isn't that right, trash-tier publisher?

What does this game do right? Precious little.

In the Controls menu, we can use the Custom tab to remap all of our keybinds, and can map them to our mouse buttons, as well. Yep, that's some praise -- functionality that should be a staple.

Another thing I like is the powerup system. Powerups are mapped to the mouse's scroll wheel (with the LMB and RMB being Boost and Jump, like Rocket League, complete with anticonsumerism): scroll forward to launch an item forward, or back to attack behind you. Honestly feels pretty good; more natural than aiming the steering stick back to dump a shell behind you in Mario Kart or using your look behind and fire keys together like in that Sega kart racer or that GTA V mode.

Another positive: the 'jump to lightspeed' item might be a reference to Lego Racers' max-level boost item that did just that:


The vehicle building system seems promising, but the pieces you have available to you is minimal, since you're expected to keep shelling out real-life money for parts, it seems. Luckily with the user-built vehicles being better than anything we'd be able to make ourselves, that issue is lessened.

The only other good thing I have to say about Lego 2K DLC Storefront is that there's a user-built vehicle browser, which luckily means I have no incentive to pay any additional money for any of the nickel-and-dimed content the scumbag publisher tries to con kids into getting their moms' boyfriends to pay for.

Your car transforms -- or I guess, rebuilds -- from street vehicle to off-roader to boat, and it's loads of fun to have rocket-boosting K.I.T.T. from Knight Rider switch to Optimus Prime offroading and then to the flying DeLorean to fly over the drink. Not fun enough to make up for the shortcomings and exploitative monetization, mind you.


As for the rest, well, it's pretty much all downhill. We can't even build our own custom minifigure driver, which Lego Racers let us do in, what, '99? '00? No, now we're expected to pay some kind of currency to choose from a minifigure driver, or be expected to find one we like in the pay-to-grind system, and then pay, and then grind (or pay more) to get the minifig at all. It would be funny to me that there are parodies of Mulder and Scully among the minifig drivers... but considering I made them in Lego Indiana Jones and can't here, I'm not laughing.

Even the short-lived and never good Lego Universe MMO wasn't that boneheaded.

The driving, controls, and camera controls all feel awful. You're forced into doing side quests to level up to continue the story progress (like Saints Row 1 & 2), but the sidequests aren't fun (like Saints Row 1 & 2) and the requirements for beating them feel way too tight (like Saints Row 1 & 2). The camera controls are just awful, as is the vehicle handling, rendering missions to push a ball somewhere a why-bother-at-all level of difficult. (Seriously, why can't vehicle-focused games have free cameras as functional as UT2004? Even GTA V didn't mess that up.)

When you destroy an enemy racer (with powerups, by colliding with him, by landing on him which is pretty satisfying), the game tells you you've "bricked" him. Out of all the terms they could've chosen, they had to pick one that's sexual slang? I don't care how pretty that minifig lady is (or how much you paid for her on the pay-to-grind cash shop), please refrain from bricking all over her. Please.

Obviously the story and writing can't be expected to be anything even close to good (nor do they have to be), but for them to be this wince-inducing is an accomplishment. The writing will make you cringe and many of the voices are just plain annoying, like the robot guide guy or the monkey characters. Don't get me wrong, the Lego games never had great writing, but the slapstick antics of the TT games or the absurdist comedy of Lego Island didn't cause this level of facepalm-worthy irritation.

I have concerns about how long the game is. How few races are there that they want us to artificially pad out our playtime with forced non-fun sidequests? Or are we expected to just slog our way through the pay-to-grind system to unlock cars that aren't as cool as the user-built ones?

It's a shame it's not better, but damn, I didn't expect it to be this bad.

Posted: May 26
I like this game a lot, BUT it has some pretty big drawbacks too.

For a premium-priced game, it has way too much additional content that you have to purchase within the game to unlock. And not just cosmetic stuff—really fundamental building pieces that should absolutely be included in the parts drawer by default simply are not. Some you have to unlock while playing, and others you simply have to buy. And while you theoretically could get anything from the store with the Brickbux you earn by playing, the rate at which you earn is so incredibly slow that you'd be grinding forever to get even the tiniest thing.

Second, while the building mode is very good on the whole, you are limited to fixed predetermined wheelbases on which to build your vehicles. I expected to be able to build whole vehicles from the ground up using whatever wheels I wanted wherever I want them to be. A very reasonable expectation that I was not alone in having. The wheelbases available by default are very limited, and totally wrong for most of the builds I had hoped to make. And while you can get additional wheelbases, that requires—you guessed it—additional purchases from the store. And even then, you don't exactly get new wheelbases, but whole vehicles you can strip down and modify. And in many cases, you're left with way too much baggage from the original car that you can't remove. But of course you can't tell exactly what will be left until after you've already purchased the vehicle.

Finally, it's really buggy. I'm hoping it's just because it's a new release and that they'll fix the many glitches soon, but in the meantime, it's really annoying. At the moment, I can't even get into the store to make those unfortunately necessary purchases, because the game crashes the moment I enter "Unkie's Emporium" (the store).

Anyway, I'm still giving this a positive rating on the whole. Other than my listed gripes, this is a fantastic and super fun game. It's exactly the sequel to the Lego Racers games many of us have been wanting for a long time. I just wish they'd sort out the issues.

Posted: September 5
Tried this out during a free weekend. It's a cute and fun game, story is heavily reliant on Lego Movie comedy-style, good powerups, good vehicle builder albeit with clunky controls, has some huge core problems that are impossible to disregard.

- AI blatantly cheats, speeding up and slowing down arbitrarily. That said, winning is not that hard. Most tracks have "secret routes" that you more or less have to use to be able to win. Specifically, in some tracks, if you don't take a "secret route" your rival racer in that specific race will teleport onto it regardless where they were previously, taking the lead. This is not a "fair" racegame.

- Some of the minigames haven't been properly playtested, making them unnecessarily difficult and frustrating compared to other sections of the game.

- Any speed/handling/weight stats of a vehicle seem to have little to no effect. It's a good thing in the sense that you aren't limited to min-maxing your vehicle to be a specific size to win, but it's bad in that in a game where each vehicle is supposed to have their own stats which gives bonuses to performance, that aspect is entirely negligible. Why bother having it in the first place.

- The vehicle builder offers you a lot of standard bricks to use for building, but a lot of detail bricks are locked behind a paywall or only available in brick packs for thousands of in-game currency, which becomes increasingly time-consuming to attain. The fact that a lot of the vehicles you unlock use these bricks, but you yourself can't use them unless you pay money, is frustrating and impedes creativity.

- Vehicle builder is limited in that you can only select from a premade chassis/hull either from 5-6 standard ones or through taking a standard car and removing all blocks, leaving you with a chassis/hull. You can't do one entirely on your own, making your own vehicle with e.g. 10 functional wheels.

- Vehicle builder is limited to 350 bricks, which initially comes off as fair but becomes limited when trying to build larger or more detailed builds. It's further frustrating that premade chassis/hulls add to this count, so depending on your chassis/hull you are already "weighed down" by several bricks.

- No minifigure customization. You are given a roster of 5 or so minifigs to choose from to have as your racer, after that you can unlock more through playing but the vast, vast majority are locked behind brick bucks or an outright paywall. You don't unlock parts and can't customize your own minifigure, which has been a huge staple in past Lego games including Lego Racers and Lego Racers 2.

- Overall in-game economy is predatory. Every time you start the game you are incentivized to pay money to unlock further features. The game is extremely expensive for what it is and has ridiculous "premium features" for an even more ridiculous price, up to 119,99€. You are still expected to pay more for premium currency to unlock further features unless you are willing to dedicate hundreds of hours.

This is a freemium game with a triple-A price tag on it. As bad as that is, it makes it several times worse that this game is mainly intended for children. After checking, it seems like the online community for this game is essentially dead, only temporarily being boosted by the free weekend. I don't see this being maintained for that much longer. Don't buy this game.

Posted: May 20
This game, while I do enjoy it, emanates that classic 2K funk that permeates and ruins everything it comes into contact with. Another live service, season based content drip feed targeted at children that I would argue is more predatory than fortnite.

The main currency of the game, brickbux, is tedious to get with some of the larger events only dishing out 500 or so, while vehicles can cost up to 10-14k. Of course, you can't buy brickbux with real money, but you can buy coins, which are ONLY used to trade for brickbux.

You can buy them in in quantities of 500, 1100, 2300, 3600 and 6500. The price of them isn't shown to you in-game. These coins can only be traded for brickbux, with the exchanges being 50 coins for 1k brickbux, 500 for 10k, and 4500 for 100k.

This, to me, is obviously only to make how much you're going to be spending as confusing as possible, especially to children who don't have a good grasp of real money. As much as I do enjoy the game itself, the store feels gross, predatory and downright pathetic. I'd say 2K should feel ashamed about putting this in a lego game, but we already know corporate suits don't feel anything but greed

Posted: October 23
Builder oriented review: see bellow

Edit: Turned the review to positive since I enjoyed the rest of the game much more that I thought I would. So much so that, frustrated by the lack of in-game information, I created the L2KD Encyclopedia:
https://r0levrai.github.io/l2kd-encyclopedia/
(actually much of my play time was dev time :D)

---

Builder oriented, old review (at 15h of playtime): mixed, could turn positive from future improvemens! TL;DR:

+ I like the gameplay, graphics and humors!
- But not the price/monetisation (w.r.t. the content), lack of QoL on PC, and more importantly, very constraining build system (which is mostly why I bought the game for).
-> Had I discovered that less than 2h in, i would have probably refunded.
-> If you like building vehicles, you might be better served by something like trailmaker for now.

---

Long version:

gameplay:
+ drifting, transforming, smashing pieces from the decor to regain nitro is a blast
+ activities diversity, humor
+ split screen on nearly everything
+ playable offline, for the most part (good for occasional play, bad for unlocking stuff since you don't have the shop and solo rates past the story are abysmal)

build:
+ some cool features: materials, hinges (even if they are statics)
+ beautiful
- you cant chose where the wheels go:
- each car/boat have a different, non-editable base (which sometimes amount to a very big chunk of the vehicle)
- they lose their unique stickers (=decals) when edited (sooo you paid for the game, paid for the battle passes, and still can't really edit your super shiney car... urgh).
- most building blocks are locked behind story, battle passes, temporary rotating shop, lots of bux grinding (multiplayer), and assembling cars by following instructions (can be fun in small doses, if not for pc clunky controls). Considering you also unlock vehicles, minifigures, stickers, engine & horn sounds, and flairs (an animeted, inseparable group of bricks), I would at least have given all or more essential bricks from the start.
- no custom figudres/stickers. as for base stickers... I can't stack them (wtf ?!), can't scale them like I want, can't color them like I want (paint is only multiplicative, but most are with strong/dark colors... would need hue shift or at least an additive option), lack diversity, some part can't even accept stickers where it would be logical... urgh
- don't have flexible parts (could do with splines)
-> makes redoing most things you loved, from lego or another reference, mostly impossible (you can still do a lot, but maybe 10% of my ideas turned feasible)

collection:
- no archive/list of (un)olocked parts and how to(/how you did) unlock them. Because the community is very small, it doesn't make for this missing info (at least it's not on the wiki yet)
- in the shop, it's not clear what is the type of object you are buying (parts, flairs, vehicles, sound ?), and if it's a vehicle, what does it unlock - surplus parts (no way to know in advance), stats (yes), base/sounds/stickers (no, which is a shame)...
-> make choosing (where) to invest very hard, especially for the surplus parts.
- no powerup explanations
- no multiplayer rank RP requirement / rewards info

QoL/attention to detail:
- some collision can send you implausibly fast in reverse
- impossible to search other creations by name (could be in a separate website with build ids)
- building mouse/keyboard controls are very clunky. edit: cut examples, was too long ^^
- crash on/after some alt-tab (3 times in menus and 1 time in race in ~15h)
- blocking highlighting bug in the advanced building tutorial ch16 (edit: can't repro)
- no workshop support, nor any external share feature - having 2d, 3d and/or sharing code embeded in the same place could really help with this game discoverability/virality in my opinion.
- no mod support
- denuevo, which is very concerning for security and privacy
