Posted: May 6
Not worth 40$

Mid game sadly, The RTS aspects of it are severely under balanced and there's not much for you to do after you beat the campaign. In the campaign mobs don't really fit a specific archetype and you can just throw anything at anything. There is a lack of underlying strategy in the game. Even then once you unlock redstone launchers, it turns the game and makes it unbelievably easy. In your campaign world there's nothing to do after you beat the game as well.

Pvp:
The pvp isn't that good because nobody knows what they're doing and seemingly if you just rally enough troops after placing a few upgrades the game is over. I haven't had any matches which were long or difficult.

Monetization?:
Game is not worth 40$.. full stop. If there comes paid DLC.. not worth it either. It took me 12 hours to beat the campaign on normal difficulty. I spent extra time fortifying the WellSpring (do not do this it will get deleted by the final boss.) And i also collected a bunch of the power towers. All useless.

Posted: April 18
>>If you are on the fence about this title Steam allows you to refund a game as long as you have 2 hours or less in it! Grab a copy and give it a go, you're going to make reasonable progress in two hours easily and be able to tell if its your cup of tea or not. It's also on Xbox~PC Game Pass for maybe 12USD a month? Check with Discord friends, they probably have free trials for Game Pass in their gift inventory on Discord.<<

Honestly it's a pretty fun and cute little game. You lazy-harvest some resources, you quick spawn some units and buildings, you run around razing a bit of hell here and there. It's just enough action to be fun, just enough base building to be comfy, and just the right dash of Pikmin-like army logic to make you think.

It's a Minecraft spinoff, it's aimed at the younger players more than the older players but the older players will have some fun here too I feel, I know I did and I've been happily enjoying Minecraft since 2009!

Also Blackbird Interactive is the team behind the most recent Homeworld game (DoK) and the upcoming Homeworld 3, and I have complete faith in their ability to make a comfy child-friendly RTS-like game.

Oh and before anyone panics about any concerns of it "being too easy" the game starts your first world off on the easiest difficulty "Fabled," swap to "Mythic" for a more common difficulty curve.

I'll be editing as I go:

The banter and characters are cute. Despite the bad scenario going down the world you're trying to save is basically Minecraft Peaceful but enemy mobs spawn and just want to exist. All interactions between the non-Piglins is pleasant and fun, lots of laughing and cheer with lots of comfy vibes.

The controls are more than simple so I'm not really sure the complaining so far unless maybe someone has a rough time with the keyboard. You have your few keys to hit right next to each other for what building category you want to hit, you have two main buttons to hit to command or call your army to you, and everything else is easily hit even in the middle of a fight. This isn't ARMA levels of needing to know how to keybind in the slightest bit.

The world is vast and pretty for campaign though it also supports coop so this would make sense. PVP worlds are quite a bit smaller for obvious reasons but campaign things take time to get between though there is a portal system that just speeds everything up from what I've been told.

At this point I am experiencing no bugs to speak of. Sounds work, FPS is great, keys all working, mouse response is fine, everything doing what it visibly should be doing as far as I can tell, no visual glitches, alt-tabbing just fine, no disconnects, no audio popping, literally zero bugs at this time. I've seen some people clamoring "oh it's a half-bake launch, blah blah" but honestly I'm not experiencing a single problem like I've been seeing in reports. Please be sure to mention bugs found in the Steam forums though and I have no doubt that Microsoft will do their best to help out with getting them solved, but good chance they are more clientside than global bugs.

Sounds are great, music is cozy, I think forty dollars is honestly a fair price.

If anyone has personal questions feel free to put them in the comments and I'll do my best to answer.


Possible final edit:

Alright so I beat the campaign, took me about 13ish hours. I had a great time, sure it was a bit sloggish after a while as the gameplay is straightforward but I still had a great time all the same. Ending of course left just enough of a "what if" cliffhanger so I'm sure they'll try to do some more story stuff down the line.

Posted: April 18
Not recommended, at least for now. I can't speak to the campaign mode--I tried it briefly and it seems fine?--but they really messed up the PvP. Most importantly:

YOU CANNOT HAVE YOUR FRIENDS ON YOUR TEAM in public games.

Invite them into your lobby > half will be assigned to the opponent team. So even if you have 3 friends on, and invite them all in, the lobby will configure itself to be 2 of you versus 2 other of you, and when you search, it'll add random players to the other four slots, two per team.

No voice chat, no real ping system, YOUR TEAMMATES CAN UNBUILD YOUR UPGRADES.

Maybe in a week or two there'll be a great patch to fix some of this stuff, but for now, don't buy if you are here for the PvP.

Posted: April 21
As a guy who grew up playing Starcraft 1 & 2, this isn't the best RTS out there but it's trying... sorta

This game has its issues, like I feel like the campaign could use a little more variety in some things like random events of some sort to spice it up other then, Siege a base and Defend a village.

The unit variety is fine but could use some more stuff like maybe they could bring in the Iron Golem for some sort of Heavy Infantry like unit or add the spiders. Small thing but it can be better.

I wish the player character had more upgrades for them specifically, like your gonna be in the heat of battle most of the time so why not add an unlock-able ranged attack option or the ability to repair buildings with an upgrade. small things to let the player interact with their base and world more ya know? of course I understand that some of those mechanics might get delegated to campaign only but hey, can make campaign more interesting atleast.

Multiplayer has some Desync issues here and there but its not the worst and happens rarely for me.

I do see the problem and dislike for the Cosmetic store and I do agree its not a great thing but in the long term its not the worst thing here, its all optional cosmetics and can be ignored if you wish.

The worse thing with the game imo is the fact the game has too little content for it to be worth 40$. The campaign is not super long and pretty repetitive. I feel like they ride on the fact its a randomly generated world on each new save a bit much, while that adds some replayability, its not a great value with the campaign in its current state.

As for the PvP, I haven't done that yet so I wont leave an opinion here as it wouldn't be right.

But despite its problems, its still pretty damn fun for me as a casual. Its far from perfect but the Campaign being co-op is really fun and I enjoy coordinating sieges with my friends.

Though are if you want to buy it, wait until its on sale imo. 15-20$ I feel is what its proper price should be with its current content. Overtime I'm sure they will add more things but if those are required to make the game feel worth the 40$, the game shoulda been delayed a bit.



Overall not the worst RTS game but not the best either, kinda middle of the road and I feel the current Mixed Ratings is correct.

Oh and the game is cross platform so there is that, def was a selling point for me since I have some friends who only have PC and others that only of an Xbox, PS, or a Switch. So this was added to the small pile of games where my friend group can all hang out together.



P.S. I do recommend reading other reviews, you were probably already gonna do that but I just want to ensure you get informed of any other pros and cons the game has.

Posted: April 21
It's graphically charming the game functions for the most part, but it feels very hollow.

It feels like an RTS in name only. The outposts you build are usually just going to be for fast travel purposes. The villages already make resources for you. Due to how enemy mobilizes (or rather, how they don't mobilize) their armies in this game, you don't have to really think about building outposts to hold off the enemy from occupying a space or to cut them off from resources. Besides the attack and occasional new base every night, the piglin army are just sitting there waiting for you.

In terms of action and combat tactics the game also feels very limited. Defensively, the upgrades you can get to your building feel like they're just an afterthought when just spamming walls and arrow towers already suffices. Offensively, it's just a cycle of leading a bunch of stone golems to rush a few buildings in the enemy base, retreating to make more, and then bringing out your creepers to nuke the nether portal when the enemy's defenses are down.

Where I think the game could've salvaged itself was to have a lot of interesting side content in the world and a good campaign. Sadly, I found that the game failed on both these fronts too. Besides some admittedly helpful mounts, you just find some resources laying around + some golems and towers that I really never got much use out of. The story feels like it's aimed strictly at an extremely young audience. Nearly all the cutscenes featuring the horde being the exact same joke of a commander Piglin bullying the smaller ones. Your allies has scripts written on wooden that hasn't been turned to paper yet, with only one of them even attempting to say even slightly amusing things and still fumbling at that.

My biggest problem right now is the structure limit. I know I'm not the only one. I don't think the game told me about it until I ran into the "Too many structures" error. The thing is, like some others, I made triple layers walls so that the enemies have a hard time getting through. Apparently each individual wall counts as a structure. So, if you triple layers walls, you'll only be able to do that for a smaller area because you'll eventually run into the "structure limit" and you won't be able to place any towers or other defenses. I found this out 10 hours into the game and now I can't get a refund because I've played for more than 2 hours. Also, this is just one out of multiple other problems I've had with this game but this "Too many structures" error just did it for me. Hopefully, this one little review out of thousands of others will contribute to the devs fixing the problems so many people are running into.

Posted: April 19
It appears as if reviews for this game are mixed... Mixed as in split between people who came to it for the RTS side, and people who only came for the Minecraft side.

This game is very much, an RTS game. it's convoluted nature is commonplace with alot of RTS out there, and due to the attempt at being toned down, It most likely won't be as bad as other RTS games. I'd say the co-developer 'Blackbird Interactive' are trustworthy, as they seem to have developed games such as Homeworld 3 and Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak.

The main complaint is the lack of content, I saw someone saying that the campaign lasted for 2 hours, which is abnormal since it took me an hour and a half to even complete the tutorial? but the game does change from a storied linear pattern to a open world RTS where you defend against a 'Dynamic' enemy. so they might of thought that the game ended once the tutorial finished.

In terms of outside the length of the campaign, it's a live service game. I'm gonna expect more stuff to come in the future. hopefully in the form of free updates, with income generated from the marketplace instead of DLC. but for now, it is slightly limiting on unit choices, with only 8 standard units, excluding 'Super' units. but as with all RTS games. units are for purpose, rather than just to exist. so there might be no need for other units, as most RTS game's basic spam units are basically the same amount, going for upgrades or stronger units later to add diversity. It's not something you should care about if you're going into this for an RTS game.

I however have one issue with the game, that has the possibility of not being fixed, and that's the AI in this game. the AI is workable. but 'Stupid' you tell them to go attack a base across lava with a bridge beside you, they'll go into the lava unless the bridge is directly in front.

There's no 'Call all troops to follow you' button though. which, I can't decide whether it's a positive or a negative. Singleplayer, it's tedious and annoying. Multiplayer however, it allows for both players to micromanage an army as the other player can control the army that's not following you. the recall button on a spawner seems to only recall those not following others though. so in the middle of an attack move, your guys may vanish.

In summery, the game has a few faults. which are commonplace for RTS games, and will be manageable for those who actually play RTS games. So I'd totally recommend this game to those who do play RTS games.

Posted: April 26
Honest review.
Cons:
The campaign on the recommended difficulty (2nd lowest) takes around 8-12 hours to complete. Higher difficulties just have more starting piglin bases and they only do slightly more damage. After you finish the campaign there is no reason to play your world anymore. You cannot build for style (only like 12 buildings for defensive and the rest are for upgrades). While there's plenty of units you can control most of them are passive mobs (wolves etc.) that cannot attack buildings. The 8 spawnable mobs and 4 legendary ones don't offer alot in the way of customizable armies. I found I was constantly just making armies of one or two units depending on what I was fighting. Every base you destroy feels super repetitive. PvP is more about making a base near you enemies right off the bat and then attacking as soon as your able. Massive lack of strategy in its current state.

Pros: Game is light hearted and the graphics are beautiful and computer friendly. There are many pieces of minecraft lore spread around that gives depth to the minecraft timeline. The controls takes a while to get used to but once you learn them it becomes second nature. Super good filler game (for those times where you can't get a full online game in, except PVP can last awhile depending on the teams understanding of the game). Cross platform play suggests that the companies are going to expand the pvp. So far its not pay to win. There are micro transactions for cosmetics for your character and mounts, but it would be nice if there were skins for buildings too.

Overall I wouldn't say its isn't worth the $50 especially if you aren't interested in co-op or pvp. The single player aspect is lackluster to say the least. While I enjoyed the experience, I can't help feeling disappointed in the game. I've sat in the menu and thought "what is there to do thats fun" and then closed the game multiple times. I would suggest waiting for more content for both single player and PVP.

Posted: June 27
I had really high hopes for the game since I'm a huuuuge Minecraft fan. But what broke it for me personally are the following points:

- Playing online is really hard to set up. You wait in lobbies forever. People join and leave again and it is really hard to join with your friends. It just doesn't work half the time. Even if you manage, you'll be in the opposite team and not in all modes can you change the team or you have to be super fast and then you wait obviously again because the team size is not equal and then people leave again. There is no way to fill up lobbies with bots or to play with your friends against bots.
- If you you finally manage to get a game going, it's either super short because your teammates leave midgame or it takes up to two hours, which is just not fun. The only reasons i played games that long was because I didn't want to go through the whole waiting for a game process which sometimes took like half an hour already.
- Besides the story mode which was fun at start but then gets repetitive with being very restricted at the same time there is not much not online for single player, like a game with bots or a free game.
- There is no way to communicate with your teammates fast, easily and effectively, which means win or lose for a game where cooperation is key.

It breaks my heart to write that for something Minecraft related. But this game could have been an amazing experience with my friends but it turned out to be annoying daunting. But hopes die last, so I will check in with it in a year and see what has come of it :)

Posted: August 9
PRICE
I think the game is kinda over priced $40 a little much (the deluxe edition just gives u like a few extra skins)

MAIN CAMPAIGN
the main campaign is ok its not to bad I would recommend playing it as it teaches the mechanics and what different things do

VERSUS
the versus mode can be very painful (no chat, all resources shared, team leavers common-ish, game will put you in an in-progress game if someone leaves it as well as that people on your team can deconstruct you buildings easily and there is no ranked mode or barrier of entry to versus so some people just don't know what there doing.)

if u want to play versus I would suggest playing with other people your in a voice call with (the Minecraft legends discord server has a looking for group section if u need it although I dont know how well it works)

also it is only 4v4 (in public games) and there is no party system so if u want to play with a friend you have to host a game as that's the only way to make sure your on the same team

LOST LEGENDS
the lost legends (monthly challenges) I think are very fun

FRIENDS
minecraft legends lets your friends join your campaign and your lost legends (although you can make a world private as-well)

MECHANICS
some of the mechanics can be confusing/you might not realize you can use some of them here is a list of somethings that might be easy to forget
1.
in the ctrl menu (hold ctrl) left click will make mobs target a mob/building but will attack other things to while right click will make them only target the mod/building and nothing else, also you have to old right click/left click to send all your mobs and only tap to send one
2.
if you press r it brings up a notebook which you use for rearranging the different hot bar layouts but you can look on the right side of the book and click the feather quill icon to look at what all the things mobs/other things do
3.
on the map (press m) if a piglin base or a village has a sign or a flag over it it means that location will do something at nightfall

WOULD I RECOMMEND?
I would recommend this game to you if you think that the price isn't to bad and if you plan on also playing this game with friends

If you like Pikmin's exploration but wish you could build fortifications anywhere and the units had more clear roles in battle, then this is the game's Campaign mode is for you.

Layered walls are clunky to build, but everything else feels polished. I also like how the whole world persists, so you can set troops to finish off a building, quick travel away, and the fight will finish without you present. Co-op mode is also good, just open up a separate chat because you cannot talk in-game. The cut-scenes from starting or ending big fights are charming and help with immersion, but are safe to skip if you are in a hurry.

I'm honestly mixed on this. While I genuinely had fun, there's glaring issues with it that's holding it back, including but not limited to:



GENERAL:
-Primitive pathfinding AI (aren't smart enough to use bridges to cross lava rivers, so you MUST position both yourself & your army across a clear path to ensure they don't do a stupid)
-You can't dismiss or get rid of unwanted units in your army. Only way to do so is to let them die by enemies or by lava.
-Company says they advocate for diversity, yet the skin options consist of 2 warriors of unknown gender in a full knight armor & helmet (face is covered,) 2 black male skins, and 7 female skins, and no white male skins! Where's the diversity?!? Hypocrisy!

SINGLEPLAYER:
-Can't pause single player session
-According to some YouTubers, even Singleplayer sessions operate on a dedicated server. What? Leads to issues where sometimes your character will randomly teleport.

MULTIPLAYER:
-No option to either join a new match or an ongoing match (game lobs you into either one of it's own choosing)
-No chat in a team-based multiplayer game (kid-friendly game is NOT an excuse!)
-Terrible connection optimization: Hero vs hero (player vs player) combat feels terrible, cuz you can die to an enemy that's clearly 200 meters away from you. You're better off sending your own army to fight enemy players.
-Sometimes common resources such as stone are unreasonably scarce
-Matches are an hour long ON AVERAGE



While I will personally continue playing the game, I can't in good conscience recommend this game to other people. It'll probably be of better value if you like strategy game AND the game is on sale for like 50%.

====================

Otherwise this is a pass. If you're looking for good RTS (Real-TIme Strategy games,) I strongly recommend:

Beyond All Reason (must download on their own site)
Tooth & Tail
Airmech Strike (dead game but you can still play vs AI)
Starcraft 2
Mindustry

Posted: April 18
The lack of an in-game chat feature isn't that great. Minecraft Dungeons was the same way, and this game is the same exact thing. Such a basic and simple thing any co-op/multiplayer game has nowadays, yet this doesn't have that. Not everyone likes being in a VC playing all the time and tabbing back and forth to Discord all the time just to talk with people that they're playing with.

Other than that, the gameplay loop gets stale and old really fast, really not a fan of how it is in its current state. There's no means of exploration, and this is very lackluster. The only time you're exploring is gathering more recourses or heading towards an objective point in the game, where you're mostly spending your time playing at/around. The shared recourse thing is also a big bummer when playing with people, especially with what I had also said formerly with this review. This is also why being able to better communicate directly inside the game with others that you play with is a must-have, especially where there are public games you can join, not even just friends only. Recourse management can easily just be a mess due to this.

The charm of the game and art is very well done, though, I'll give the game that.

Is the game worth 40 dollars? No. The game is at most a 20 dollar game in its current state. I would say paying as much as Minecraft Dungeons for this would be fair and what I would pay for it. If you're wanting to get this game, then I would hold off or wait for a sale or a price drop to happen, which I'm sure is likely going to happen in the foreseeable future.

There's a lot more I could say and or critique about this game, but don't care much about writing out such a really long review. There are other reviews that already mentioned other things I would have to say that are either wrong or aren't that great about the game anyway. I just hope the devs listen this time around and try to improve upon this game, unlike what unfortunately happened to Dungeons, which had a lot of potential.

Currently as of this time and review I wouldn't recommend this game, but I would love for that to change.

Posted: April 18
It's a fun game but it has a lot of issues, campaign is simply just not that interesting or engaging past learning the basics.

Multiplayer PvP is where the game shines but with absolutely no way to communicate with people it's impossible to coordinate or tell people what you need. This leads to simply a rather frustrating experience.

Not to mention there's not a reliable way to play PvP with a friend in a normal 4v4 scenario it's a confusing and once again frustrating experience in order to be on the same team as your friend while still playing 4v4, because you can't switch teams prior to starting the game for some weird reason.

Multiplayer systems and mechanics also feels like they were designed in a LAN setting, with no consideration for how it would carry over to playing with other people across the world.

Players can literally steal your units you are in the process of commanding when you send those units to attack something. I frequently ran into that issue as well as wanting to spawn units but you can't because you reached the 40 unit limit with no idea where those units are.

Add in the fact you cannot under any circumstances communicate with your teammates during the match and it's a recipe for a frustrating experience.

Very good game, but multiplayer feels incredibly bare bones and needs serious work before it's going to be an actual enjoyable experience for those who don't have a group of 7 or 8 people to play with.

Posted: April 24
I have to say, this game is being negatively reviewed for little to no reason. This is an incredibly fun and charming action strategy game with only minor issues that prevent it from being a great game. I think this is a very good game regardless of any flaws, and a lot of fun overall.

Let me start by saying this, I played through the campaign in co-op, and had such a blast. The world is sprawling, beautiful and has plenty of things to do. On top of that, the map has some element of procedural generation, meaning no two maps will be exactly the same. The beauty of the large open world and the sprawling epic battles with hundreds of units feel absolutely awesome. The sound design is also particularly good, making you feel evermore present in this epic world. We finished it in 15 hours at our own leisure, something we found out that less than 15% of players have done at the time of reviewing this. I just find it baffling that so many people decided to

When you play this game, you will realize that this game doesn't excel past it's peers in either the action or strategy formats. I think this is the wrong lens to view this game through. It's the way that this game combines elements of both genres that feels great. This type of gameplay might have a niche audience, but for that niche, I think it's going to be absolutely awesome.

In terms of strategy, this game offers a limited number of buildings and units to the player, however, what it does well, is it makes everything in the sandbox useful. Every unit has it's place and time to be used effectively. Every building is the same.

When exploring the map, each point of interest is going to be an important factor in slowly stopping the Piglin hordes. You can find special golem units, special towers and extra resources for some crucial upgrades you will need to use back at homebase, the Well of Fate. There are a wealth of resources, and you will need these to slowly expand your arsenal as the piglins get evermore destructive. Some of the epic sieges took an hour to complete.

Another thing you will notice about this game that I think differentiates it a little, is how much this game emphasises temporary structures. The game is about slowly expanding your battle lines and in the process you will lose plenty of buildings, all while slowly gaining ground. It's quite fast paced. In co-op, this works great as the game offers so many ways for players to work together, even while being on the opposite sides of the world.

As for negatives, I didn't like the limited number of structures that could be built at the well of fates. While I understand the need to limit the number of units in the game, everything else should have been relatively unlimited in my opinion. On the flipside, with the structures offered, the current gameplay for the campaign felt well balanced.

Another negative is the potentially stupid AI. Countless times the units miss the bridges you built and fall off. This wasn't too big of an issue, but a minor nuisance nonetheless.

There were also minor bugs and some minor issues with the controls which can be a bit finicky at times.

I think the biggest error for this game was the marketing. Frankly, most people had no idea what this game was even after the first 2-3 trailers. I had the benefit of listening to reviews before purchasing this product. I knew exactly what I was getting, and got exactly what the reviewers I listen to said I would get. I feel like the same can't be said for some others. I think people should take the negative reviews with a grain of salt and go and watch actual reviews for the game on Youtube before deciding if this game could be for them.

Aside from this, had a really positive experience. Look forward to upping the difficulty before another run through the campaign.

I am putting this game as not recommended. The game itself has no bugs I am aware of, the game play is repetitive, but it's definitely the co-op that ruins this game. Posted: June 29, 2022
I've never written a comprehensive Steam review for a game, but then again, I've never been so pissed off by a game, either.

Sonic Origins is the biggest letdown imaginable. Before I get into that, though, let's talk about the good parts of the game.

The new Anniversary Mode lets you play through all four games with infinite lives. It's pretty well-known that lives, as a mechanic, kind of suck. They're a holdover from the era of arcade games, made to squeeze money out of you back then and to squeeze playtime out of you on consoles. Lives are replaced with Coins, which you can use to retry Special Stages or unlock art/music/video content in the new Museum.

The cutscenes before and after every game in Anniversary Mode are, likewise, really cool! They clearly had a lot of heart put into them. Tyson Hesse and Powerhouse knocked them out of the park.

The new Mirror Mode lets you play each game in reverse, flipping the screen and changing the game from left-to-right to right-to-left. This is a cool new touch that mixes up the gameplay for veteran players. It's neat.

The also-new Mission Mode throws you into courses with set objectives. This is essentially identical to Sonic Generations' missions - you have set objectives (time, rings, etc.) and you're ranked based on how well you complete those objectives. This is... fine.

That's the end of the good part of Sonic Origins. Now for the bad.

Sonic 1, Sonic CD, and Sonic 2 are almost entirely unchanged from their mobile ports (and Steam port, in CD's case), with a few exceptions that I'll get to later. If you bought and played these earlier ports, though, you might notice something strange about Sonic Origins - namely, at launch, Sonic 1 and 2 on mobile devices were both 3$ a pop, and Sonic CD on Steam was 5$ before it was delisted. Origins is . If you're being generous and want to bump the other two games' prices up to match CD's price S3&K similarly, this game should be 20$ maximum. This alone is ridiculous. On top of that, there's a confusing and predatory-feeling bit of DLC that gives you exactly two pieces of meaningful content - 100 Coins (seriously?) and access to harder missions in Mission Mode. Sega's really going out of their way to nickel and dime you on this one.

Sega also did a lot of advertising relating to "new playable characters", which is a flat-out lie. Tails and Knuckles have been playable in Sonic 1 since 2013, and Tails has been in CD since 2011. They couldn't even bother adding Knuckles to CD here, which would've been the easiest "new character" to add... but the promotional material and in-game movies focusing on Amy makes me think who they wanted people to assume was playable.

of the aforementioned "few exceptions" to the unchanged ports made the games overall. Sonic 1 features the addition of the Drop Dash, except you can't turn around in midair after using it and jumping, so you can't chain it the way you can in Mania. Sonic CD has had Sonic and Amy's single, half-second voice lines removed for... some reason; the Drop Dash was added here, too, and it works much closer to Mania's version.

CD has also had its entire Steam achievement list nixed in favor of Origins's mediocre "Play the game! Time travel once! Beat Metal Sonic! Beat the game!" ... and that's . Normally, I'd call this a nitpick, but CD's Steam port from had a better achievement list. Why, Sega. Why.

Sonic 2 has Sonic 1's halfassed Drop Dash, as well as at least two minor level layout changes - one in Metropolis 3 that makes a set of spikes borderline unavoidable (seriously!), and one that breaks Wing Fortress's intro. Good job, Sega.

Sonic 3 & Knuckles is the most tragic case of all here. Sega contracted Headcannon (of Sonic Mania and Sonic 1+2 Mobile fame) to develop the remaster, which sounds all well and good... until you read about how Headcannon was treated during development.

S3&K's good features include the Drop Dash ( implemented this time, likely since Headcannon actually knows how it ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ works), a bunch of additional rotation sprites for objects like the Marble Garden spinners and Carnival Night's barrels, and a few new flashy level transitions that add a lot of polish and heart to the game. Thanks, Headcannon.

S3&K's not present in the original game are numerous, to say the least. Its music hasn't been remastered at all; the tracks sound like low-quality playbacks of the Genesis tracks. It bears mentioning that this only stands out so much because the other three games high-quality remastered tracks. The Special Stage music doesn't speed up to match Sonic's speed like it did in the original game, and the new Super Sonic theme is to listen to, almost as bad as the original.

Actually, none of the new music is good. I'm no Michael Jackson purist, either; I played Sonic 3 A.I.R. with all of the prototype tracks enabled, and they all sounded fantastic there. ; the tracks he wrote should've been arranged and programmed into the game by someone who's more familiar with Genesis sound synthesis. The tracks that made it into Origins are watered-down, inferior versions of the original, pre-MJ tracks.

Miscellaneous annoying differences from the original S3&K include differing in-game physics (hold down when Marble Garden 1 starts and keep it held - the speed cap behaves differently so you fly into a wall, unlike in the original); the end of Act 1 signposts not falling in the same places, so they don't unearth monitors consistently anymore; a vine in Angel Island 2 forcing you to swing into spikes and take damage; an unnecessary vertical screen lock during Marble Garden 2's falling-ceiling section; and the Super transformation animation not halting you in midair, which cancels it in certain circumstances.

I wanted to like this. Sonic 3, in particular, is one of my favorite games of all time; as it stands, though, I can't recommend this garbage fire of a "remaster" to anyone. Sega hasn't learned anything from their previous mistakes, and they've now stained Headcannon's reputation by forcing an unfinished product to meet an unneeded deadline. Mania was delayed on PC to add ♥♥♥♥♥♥ DRM back when it released - why couldn't Sega have done the same here to let Headcannon actually finish and polish their game?

This is especially insulting given the runaway success of Sonic Mania. Sega didn't touch that game - they published it, sure, but Christian Whitehead, Headcannon, and PagodaWest were the actual . Sega themselves can't even handle rereleasing the ports previously released by Christian and Headcannon, let alone developing an actual ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Sonic game on their own, as evidenced by the past few years of blunders. It feels like Sega thought they earned some goodwill with Mania, thought "hey, people will probably pay big money for classic Sonic games even if we put zero effort in!", and released this ♥♥♥♥.

Zero disrespect for Headcannon, by the way. Their work on Sonic 1, 2, Mania, and this 3&K port had a lot of love put into them - there's plenty of tiny fixes and details peppered into this port that weren't in the original. God bless you, Headcannon, and ♥♥♥♥ you, Sega.

Go get a Sonic CD key online or something to play the superior PC port of that game, and go play Sonic 1 Forever, Sonic 2 Absolute, and Sonic 3 A.I.R. for the good PC versions of those. Don't let Sega scam you out of your money for this. I won't be coming back to Origins unless it gets major patches, whether official or unofficial, and major community mods to boot.

What a cluster♥♥♥♥.

Posted: June 28, 2022
Have you ever heard of a game where the developer had to save its integrity on Twitter and call out the publisher for how rushed, unfinished and buggy the final build of the game is? No? Well, then you're in for a ride.
After Sonic 06, Sonic Boom Rise of Lyric, Sonic Forces and Sonic Colors Ultimate, SEGA released another game riddled with bugs and low quality. SEGA rushed this game and didn't want to delay it, because they thought it might be neat to release it on the same day Sonic 1 released, which is a nice homage, but they still don't get that a rushed product is a problem for the devs and the actual buyers. It is like using washing powder for your cake each time, wondering why it tastes bad.

Now, before I get into it, I will mention the actual positive side.

This game is great in terms of presentation. It is so nice to have the actual islands Sonic ventures on be visualized. They make the Sonic world seem way more connected. Furthermore, the cutscenes are still wonderfully animated. They clearly love the Toei Sonic style, and I wouldn't have it in any other way. While most of the cutscenes shown are only for the opening, others are for the start and ending of the games, which leads into a connected story.
The mission mode is also pretty fun. I haven't played all missions yet, but it seems like each mission has its own stage, reminding me of Sonic Generations, and what can I say, they do their job in delivering some extra challenge.
The last good thing is that you can retry special stages if you fail. Back then it was quite frustrating, but this way it actually is fun to hunt the Chaos Emeralds/Time Stones.

Now, let's slowly dip our toes into the depths.

The Sonic CD cutscenes weren't re-animated. I think it would be a nice novelty to keep the original cutscenes in the museum, unfortunately the game uses the old 4:3 cutscenes for the story itself too. That is quite inconsistent and makes it seem like a fan mod.

Next is the drop dash, while it's nice to have the drop dash, I just cannot fathom how bad it is in this game. The drop dash in Sonic Origins is more of an instant spin dash rather than the actual drop dash from Mania. Meaning, you lack air control, you cannot redirect Sonic. That is quite frustrating to use. It is nice to have it, but the way they implemented it makes him feel like a car.

Now.....the bugs. I would've hoped not to encounter bugs, since I rarely do, but in this game I actually got the most annoying and frustrating bugs possible. If Tails in Sonic 2 is flying whilst you jump into the Special Stage, you'd be able to hear his flying sounds the entire stage's time. Even worse was the fact that I beat Sonic 2's final boss, and when the end screen appeared, I started to realize I was softlocked. I couldn't continue in any way. I was stuck, waited 2 minutes and then just gave up, restarted the game and had to beat the final boss A G A I N.
Next is Sonic 3. Sonic 3 is a mess. Next to Sonic changing into the foreground layer, even though during the cutscene he should've been in the background, he also clipped through multiple objects, through layers of the stages, leaving me softlocked a good few times, but they also completely messed with his physics. Sonic in this game is way too fast. He bonks his head against walls he never was intended to hit, ruining the flow of the stage. He also isn't able to reach the heights he used to. I wasn't able to reach, for example, a Special Stage because they messed with Sonic's jump, leading to him not gaining enough height.

The DLC for Sonic Origins is such a cash grab. Remember when they tried to monetize Super Sonic in Forces? They literally just put a few missions in here, add an island camera view which should be in the base game, and rip the old models from Generations/Forces, put them in here, stiffly animating them. These extra 5 bucks should've been in the package, even the price is question worthy. Sonic Mania released for half of that and was more of a new game than this is. Hell, I'd even say it makes more sense to buy Sonic Mania and Sonic Generations instead, since you get the best out of both worlds with both being half original/half remake-type games.

Also, where is the time attack mode? I mean....for a Sonic game there should be a time attack mode, where you can actually pick the stages and speedrun them individually, just like in Mania.

Last, but not least, is a direct question. Where is the new character? You featured Amy so prominently in literally each promotional material, even the ending clearly hints at Amy maybe being playable, but she isn't. It feels like the devs really wanted to make her playable, but realized there wasn't enough time.

Sonic Origins might be the 22nd way to play Sonic 2, but it is far from the best. SEGA should learn to stop using Sonic like a GTA free money glitch, 5/10.

Posted: September 19, 2022
I made the mistake of pre-purchasing this before it was released. Usually I wouldn't do such a thing but I thought "its the Christian Whitehead/Stealth Android ports finally brought to the PC, this'll be great". Simply put, I didn't think there was a way to screw this up. Sadly it turns out although it uses some Headcannon content, these ports are mostly made by Sonic Team who haven't got a clue. These ports are full of bugs I've never seen in my 25+ years of playing these games. Last time I played I saw two completely new bugs in Angel Island Act 1 alone.

The UI is also wildly inconsistent, Sonic CD's menu from its previous port is still lurking in there despite the other games having nothing similar.

"Story mode" is a fun concept but really doesn't add anything different to just playing the games sequentially. In fact if you treat the 4 games as a continuous campaign then the difficultly curve is frankly god awful. By my count there are 34 zones to play through if you want to beat "story mode". Of these 34 levels arguably the most difficult, Labyrinth Zone, is the 4th you'll play. I'm not critiquing the games for not working with the story mode format, its not why they were made, I just think that if this is Baby Timmy's first experience playing the classic Sonic games then Story Mode is going to be a bad time.

These games aren't *unplayable* and only the most hardcore of Sonic nerds will notice the discrepancies but the real tipping point is that the collection is comically overpriced. I tried to argue a justification for having pre-ordered Sonic Origins but frankly I feel stupid. Don't make the same mistake I did. Go get one of the fan made ports. Sonic 3 AIR even has a native Linux port and works great on the Steam Deck.

Posted: June 24, 2022
Sigh...After Mania was such a smash hit, I was hoping for Origins to be an utter slam dunk as well. I had a lot of hype going into this. The CW versions of Sonic 1 and 2 on PC, finally. Sonic 3 getting the same treatment FINALLY after Whitehead was denied doing so a decade ago, fancy new intro/outro animations for every single game to provide context for each game's story and a bunch of neat little extras, such as concept art, animatics, extra songs, etc.

All of that sounded great, even if I think the price for it is way, way too steep for games that are nearing 3 decades in age. But where does it crumble apart? Behind the scenes is where it crumbles apart.

Playing any game in Origins, you can immediately tell corners were cut. The physics, while remarkably close to the original games, still feel slightly off. For example, in Sonic 3's Launch Base Zone, you can't enter the pods if you're standing right next to them because your jump is just ever slightly too high. In Sonic 2, the Aquatic Ruin boss fight becomes weirdly difficult due to the aspect ratio, making it feel more like an oversight. In Sonic 1's Green Hill Zone boss fight, you can effectively cheese the boss by standing under the platforms (which wasn't possible in the original, you still had to dodge).

The one thing that gets me though, is the music. Yes, I'm partially talking about the songs in Sonic 3, but I just mean the quality of the songs overall. Again, launching any game aside from CD, you can just hear the compression and crunch of every song. The quality of the songs is astoundingly low quality. It feels like they're using heavily compressed 128 kbps YouTube rips for every single song, and that's genuinely a shame. You don't need to be an audiophile either to hear the low quality, you can just immediately notice it as soon as it transitions from the Origins menu to the game.

And of course, Sonic 3's changed music. Contrary to what others may think, I don't hate the replaced tracks. And if you don't know - they replaced the songs with compositions from Sonic 3's November 1993 prototype. Except, for some reason, they based the songs off of the MIDI compositions from the S&K collection on 1997. Zones like Ice Cap and Launch Base sound fine, if anything I think they genuinely recomposed the 1993 proto. ver of Ice Cap and cleaned it up, and it sounds legitimately wonderful, but Carnival Night Zone...god, it sounds awful.

And then Sonic 3's Super Sonic theme they added. It's...awful. It sounds like something ripped out of Sonic 4. The baffling bit? They included the Unused Theme in the game's Museum Mode for Sonic 3's soundtrack. Why...couldn't they just...use that? It's just baffling. They can include it in the collection but apparently not use it in the game?

I don't wanna keep going. Sonic Origins is a disappointment. I pre-ordered the Digital Deluxe edition by selling my CS:GO knife to buy it, and honestly - I kinda want my knife back now. The animation work done here is incredible and the extras they gave in the game are nice, but none of it makes up for what feels like shoddy ports of mobile games, poor audio quality and just overall lack of polish.

I read some behind the scenes stuff on Origins' development, including and it just saddens me how Sega continues to mistreat its developers and its beloved properties.

Shame on you, Sega. Shame on you.

Posted: June 23, 2022
An absolutely disgraceful collection but I did not expect anything more since it was made "internally at SEGA"

CONS:

Most important - NO integer scaling, meaning all 4 games look just as blurry as Sonic CD 2011. What was the point of finally releasing the 2013 remasters on consoles if they look worse than when they did on mobile?

Mission Mode is comprised of bite-sized, generically-designed levels that would make the most amateur platformers blush. I could tell it was made by Sonic Team cuz the mode features grey X-blocks like Forces and they're EVERYWHERE with no slopes in sight

Knuckles isn't playable in CD (a primarily exploration-based game). Don't get me started on Amy - a character that's been promoted since the Archie Mega Drive days as part of Team Sonic. Then in Mania Adventures, then in IDW comics, and now here. So you'd think they would finally make her playable? Lol, you want them to make a NEW sprite-sheet (which they did back in CD 2011 for Tails)? You're asking for too much

No customizations. After all these years, after fan projects like S1 Forever, S2 Absolute, S3 Complete, S3 A.I.R., OR EVEN Sonic Mania, our boys at SEGA couldn't be bothered to add the most BASIC options between all 4 games like fans do. No peel-out in S3, elemental shields in S1/CD/2, max control, Jam difficulties, can't disable the Drop Dash, no option to use lives/timeouts in Anniversary Mode or collect Tokens in Classic Mode, etc.

Island Tour DLC just allows you to zoom-in on each island, not even rotate them. Money well spent. And that "animated characters on island" DLC? All of them are ripped from Gens/Forces

Super Sonic isn't in S1. Now you might say "What are you talking about, obviously he isn't". Yeah, umm... except some Japanese promo images showed him in Scrap Brain. So I thought "Oh, so he, alongside a 7th Special Stage are in Anniversary Mode, nice bonus". And he isn't. You can only access him using cheats, just like on mobile. Is this a nitpick? Yeah, but maybe they shouldn't have blatantly lie to consumers, then

The "Drop Dash" is a pure lie. What do I mean? It's actually a disguised Spin Dash animation that happens for a split-second? Doesn't sound bad, except the AGES version of S1/S2 natively added it to their ROMs. Oh! And in Origins it BARELY moves you after you execute it. Best part? S1/S2 have a fixed jump arc, so if you try to do this move in those games and jump, you won't be able to control yourself mid-air (think Castlevania)

The Museum... god, remember those so-called "never-before seen concept arts" they promised? Well I'm here to tell you there are like 6 of them, everything else are Harmony covers and character sheets. The Video section has none of those cool 90s ads, promo videos or even documentaries, just a few pieces of the Sonic Symphony they threw in at the last hour, Origins' cutscenes and every episode of Mania Adventures (and their respective animatics). Both Normal and Premium sections offer very little content, especially if you pre-ordered the game which gives you a 100 Token bonus, you can literally unlock everything in under 2 hours. Not to mention it's complete silence, no remix of History or anything like that, no feeling of nostalgia. Just cynical, corporate silence as you browse what little they offer. Only ""new"" track here is a remix of Sonic World from Jam that plays everywhere except the Museum. Classy

S1/2/CD are straight mobile versions, so they haven't been touched up at all. Meaning the missing rolling SFX in CD hasn't been fixed, and the extended camera is still absent

Horrible audio quality. Believe it or not, they REMOVED the remastered OSTs for S1, CD and S2 from mobile. Why? No clue. As for S3&K, y'know... the only new thing here, it isn't given the same treatment so its OST is really muffled, and ON TOP OF THAT, CD's 2 OSTs are super quiet and also in bad quality. How did they screw it up? idk, but it is hilarious

Your Score in S3&K resets to 0 if you click the Restart button. This doesn't happen in other games

The music DLC (Chaotix, 3D Blast and Spinball) misnamed countless tracks. For example; Chaotix's bad ending theme (Destructive Power) is Door to Summer, while 3D Blast's Invincibility theme is the Menu theme. Incompetent? Very much. Funny? Absolutely

No Chaotix island. You might notice how Origins' gallery features stuff from Chaotix, 3D Blast and Spinball, the OSTs from those games they repackaged as DLC at the last minute, as well as the islands from Spinball and 3D Blast in the hub menu and... wait a second... where's the Island of Miracles from Chaotix? You telling me, the island from a game that is the closest to Sonic's gameplay of that era isn't here... but islands from 2 US-made games, one of which is a pinball spin-off made to promote a show that never aired in Japan, are here? Not only is this sorta insulting, I'm like 1000% sure it was supposed to be here as an Options island, they just didn't make a model of it in time, and plastered Options in the Museum of all places

Screwed up physics. Due to S3&K here clearly being made on Mania's engine, it had a lot of ramifications on the game's internal logic. Some stuff is cool like all elemental shields function how they did in Mania, making the bubble shield fun to use. Others... because the game now controls exactly like Mania, there are a LOT of collision/physics bugs that weren't present in the OG game

CD's ending animation. While the restoration team did really well with remastering the original opening, I... have no idea what happened with the ending. It looks like one of those interpolated anime clips. Worst part? It's sped up by 3x and there are no SFXs in the beginning, so it instantly plays the credits theme. The Gallery also plays it off-sync and it doesn't feature the bad ending version. Actually a joke

Even though I'm not one of those people that plays S3 and S&K separately, it's kinda absurd how they initially advertised this collection with those 2 games in mind. Final release? You can't play them separately. Oh well

The new S3&K tracks. I don't know what sound chip Jun Senoue (same guy who composed S4EI) used but it sure wasn't a Mega Drive one. Tracks sound muffled, quiet and overall don't fit the game. It's especially insulting to CNZ Act 2, its prototype track is EASILY one of my favorite Sonic tunes... and Jun completely butchered it. They should've asked Yuzo Koshiro to recompose them. But you wanna know THE coolest part? Origins is made on Criware, meaning the audio is encrypted, meaning it'll be really hard to mod music in. Just a neat thing, y'know :)

Denuvo. No need to explain, you already know the game runs poorly. Countless stuttering too

PROS:

Cutscenes look great, but what did you expect from Tyson Hesse and Powerhouse, you knew they'd pull it off with flying colors. However they haven't animated any of the bad endings, meaning if you get one in any of the games, it would still play said game's true ending

The restoration group they hired to scan various pieces for the Museum and clean up the CD opening (not the ending) did a really good job

The S3&K remaster, despite the collection's flaws, is alright. Nowhere near the level of AIR, which is odd cuz I know Stealth and his crew can do WAY better than this. At least it wasn't done by SEGA

Classic games on PC, so your usual "Hope modders will fix it" mentality will continue yet again! You expect SEGA to do all the work? Pfftt, yeah right

Notice how all the collection's positives I listed were outsourced to 3rd parties and not done by SEGA? That should tell you how much they care. In the end you're left with:

Sonic 1 (the Spin Dash is still present in the so-called Classic mode)
Sonic 2 (with a horrible, downright game-breaking Tails AI)
Sonic CD (they use leftover UI from the mobile version I kid you not)
and Sonic 3&K (with its muffled, MJ-free OST)

Happy 31st Anniversary, Sonic. I can't believe I'm still a fan of your franchise

Posted: July 20, 2022
Unfortunately they removed some of the original songs and replaced them with beta songs or new songs. You can get the original music back by installing "thedefinitivesonic3ost" from game banana.

1. Open the zip file so the two music files, “Music03_3SK.acb” and “Music03_S3K.awb” are visible.
2. Navigate to your steamapps/common directory. Find the SonicOrigins folder.
3. Navigate to image, x64, raw, and then sound.
4. Replace the music files in the folder with the ones you have in the zip.

The other thing I had to fix was latency. The game suffers from a frame or two of delay on button presses. The only way I was able to fix this was by switching the window mode to borderless fullscreen.

With those fixes out of the way, this is an amazing game that adds a new coin system, boss rush, mirrored mode, wide screen support, and you can play as all three original characters in any of the games. I was able to do some of this to a degree in the original games but this game makes it so much easier. Get the super uber big pp deluxe version BUT wait for it to go on sale for $25 or less.

Posted: March 23
Note: Sonic Team is releasing Origins Plus in June as of posting this. The game will be $40 USD, include all the "DLC" of Origins, as well as having a bigger expansion with Game Gear titles and a playable Amy and Knuckles in every Genesis game. The game might be worth it to you when that time comes, but as of now, save your money for when it's worth the price, because they will sell you these upgrades in June if you buy this version.I've held off roasting how this game has been handled in hopes that the huge issues with it would be fixed in future updates, however not only is there no word on any more fixes, Sonic Team just announced a Sonic Origins Plus, which will cost an additional $10 for current owners of Sonic Origins. While I would love to play as Classic Amy (and honestly expected her to be an end game unlock for THIS version) and would love the Game Gear titles, for fans of the Genesis games, this collection does a rather poor job at replicating the feeling of the older games. The game ports are for the most part "satisfactory", but this is replacing perfectly fine emulations on Steam, which were ALL taken down before this came out (and retailed at a cheaper price for all 4 games). The cutscenes are the best part of this collection, as they're lovely additions to introduce you to the world of Sonic and are very nonobtrusive. However, some issues crop up when you investigate the games themselves. (Some physics issues I believe have been patched but I can't confirm all of them due to how random they seemed in the first place.) When I played, sometimes you'd ramp off of something really fast and slam into a wall a little too hard, crushing you. While this is a very realistic scenario in real life, this does not happen in the classic games. Also, in Sonic CD, Sonic no longer has voice clips. There weren't too many in the first place, but they were cute and added to the charm of the game. The more problematic parts that bothered me the most though was how the audio was handled in S3&K. I have no idea why they did it, but the audio sounds very muffled on every stage. I don't mind the replacement tracks (even though they seem worse quality than the old PC port of the 90's), but the audio is just so poor it makes me never want to play the Origins version of this game again. Don't get me started about how poor all the sprites look. I don't know how they messed up the blurring of pixels, but something just looks so off with it.The worst parts are honestly that this game does not preserve history as it was originally, and it instead tries to overwrite it with poorly implemented "upgrades" for the newer generation without considering what makes the original version so timeless. Even the classic modes of the games are just Anniversary modes except modified to "feel" more original (no widescreen, lives system, etc, yet still poor pixelation, bad audio, and weird physics issues). The marketing for this game was also awful with the DLC which amounted to a bunch of basic features of a menu being ripped out and sold to you for extra. Maybe when Plus comes out, this game will be worth your money, but until then don't be like me. Wait until the game is worth buying, and even then wait a few days for reviews. Who knows? Maybe they'll release a nice overhaul that fixes many of the issues I pointed out.Edit 2/25/23: It has come to my attention that Sonic Team actually does tend to patch the game again when the Plus edition rolls out in order to fix more bugs and improve the overall quality of the game. This doesn't change my review, but is something to keep notice of when the game gets its update in the future.

Posted: August 25
So. Sonic Origins. It's a game!

PROS:
- All 4 Genesis games are CLASSICS, and are genuinely worth playing whether you're a seasoned Sonic veteran or a new fan.
- The missions are actually fun, and some of them are quite challenging!
- The animated cutscenes are glorious and beautifully tie the story together.
- Amy! Kind of. She's got her own moveset and everything.
- All 4 games can be played in widescreen and without the hassle that is a lives counter. I really like the coin system- in place of an extra life, you'll earn a coin. These can be spent on bonus items in the Museum.
- With Origins Plus, you get the Game Gear games. These haven't had an official re-release in a while (since the early 2000s), so it's nice to see them here. They're not GREAT but they are a fun little piece of Sonic history that should be preserved.
- They fixed the blurry anti-aliasing... after a year.


CONS:
- Denuvo DRM. It's a very useless "anti piracy" software that uses up SO MUCH processing power that the game is unplayable on low end computers. It was removed from Mania after backlash, but clearly they didn't learn their lesson here. I'm not sure why anyone would pirate Sonic Origins specifically, but go off, Sega.
- The Genesis version of Spinball isn't here, for some reason. It seems like it WAS planned, due to the presence of a fully-modeled Spinball area used as the menu screen for missions and story mode, but not the game itself! That's weird.
- Unskippable cutscenes and intro. They're good, but it would be nice to be able to skip them upon replaying a game.
- The audio is screwed up six ways from Sunday. Low quality, incorrectly pitched audio, sped up audio, and that nasty un-MJ-ified Sonic 3 soundtrack. Really. It's not fun to listen to. I had to install a mod to reinsert the original soundtrack.
- Bonus/museum content is lacking. There isn't much there that we haven't seen already, and some info relating to music track titles is straight up wrong.
- The mouse cursor doesn't close when you open the game. That's like, literally the bare minimum.
- Amy does not come with the base game. She comes with Origins PLUS. There's a lot of stuff locked into Plus, which used to be split up into several other DLCs. It's not really worth the extra 10 dollars unless you're a diehard Amy fan. Which I am. Basically, content locked behind a paywall. Boooo.
-Overall, some weird choices were made that makes this compilation feel rushed. A lack of individual save files for some games, weird character select screens, reused menu audio from other games...

I'll still play it because I'm a filthy completionist and a dedicated Sonic fan, but I wouldn't really recommend this collection to fans OR casual players. I would, however, recommend the fan-made remasters (available for PC, Switch and Android), which are free to download but do require Legally Obtained APKs (of the 2010s mobile remasters) or the no-longer-in-circulation Steam roms (for Sonic 3 and Knuckles). Or, y'know, don't legally obtain those roms and APKs. I'm explicitly NOT endorsing piracy, but I also can't stop you. So do what you will.

TLDR: $30 for an unfinished, low-quality compilation isn't worth it, even if it does have Amy.

Posted: October 2, 2022
Games like these are why I wish there was a neutral thumb-up. But I suppose I’m 63% thumbs down.

When this was first announced I was like, "haha okay yeah sure make me buy the classics again, Sega."

And then I did.


Some Good things:

>Intros/Outros are absolutely phenomenal and are nice addition next to Sonic CD usually only having the only intro/outro.

>There's new custom sprites in some games. I was overjoyed when Super Sonic sprites weren’t just recolored regular Sonic sprites anymore.

>All games come with drop dash and spin dash (I realize the spin dash isn’t such a big deal as most Sonic hacks have these, but the features are nice.)

>The debug menu is actually fully incorporated and there's no buggy sprites or missing objects/things. Weird controls though.

>The mission mode? FANTASTIC. Probably my favorite thing about this collection. The missions were really creative and they just work perfect with the gameplay of classic sonic. And the hard ones never felt unfair. Tornado Flyby is cancer though. I hardly got frustrated because 95% of the missions is testing your ability and control to accomplish a small task and not relying on a gimmick you just got introduced to.

>Coin system is great for newcomers. They can play the game without having to worry about being sent back to the title screen and you can redo special stages if you happen to spill spaghetti on your hands while Blue Sphere is at max speed. And if you do all the missions and get S ranks you can buy all the things in the museum and still have a ton of coins leftover. It's a really nice reward for sticking your neck out and trying your best on the missions.

>If somehow you didn't have internet to scour the internet for classic sonic music, you could extract them all from this game.

And then there is the obviously bad stuff:

>No Knuckles for Sonic CD. C'mon dude...

>DLC content is so minuscule that it should've just been included. DLC should warrant, "Playable Mighty/Ray/Amy, completely new original zones as secrets, etc." Smash puts out a completely new character for $6.

>Sonic Origins music pack is just listening to an extra sound test of games they didn’t bother putting in the Origins collection (Chaotix/3D Blast/Spinball). Kind of a slap in the face when a sound test is a FREE feature in each of these games.

>The fun pack? It’s just little things like some extra music, harder missions, more models on the islands, and new borders for your screen. What does that sound like to you? “Unlockable content through completing certain parts of the collection” is the first thing that comes to mind. But in this day and age, instead it’s “pay for it”. For Christ’s sake...

>Should be waaaaay cheaper. By comparison, Crash N. Sane Trilogy, CTR Nitro-Fueled, and Spyro Reignited are inspired by previous content but *completely rework* the content, while Sonic Origins just straight up uses old content with slight modifications — and all of them are the same price on launch. Mission mode, animations, and everything else new doesn't mean it's the same level of dedication that went into the previously mentioned games.

>Achievements are hilariously easy. The game’s like, "Congratulations! You opened the game here's an achievement. Oh? You used the level select to go to the final stage and cheated? No problem! Here's another achievement for beating the whole game! Now destroy 10 moto bugs! You can just use debug to spawn them." It took me only 8.7 hours to get every achievement. And that’s because Sonic CD was the only game you had to play through because it doesn’t have access to debug mode from the start. That’s a good thing though! You have to play the game to unlock the achievement, which is what it should be for each game!

>Removing the MJ tracks and, pfffft, on top of that, replacing the already really good sonic 3 beta music with worse versions was baffling. And I really respect MJ’s music outside of Sonic, so it hurts even more they’d disrespect him like that.

Overall, this was an okay package, but it pales in comparison to Sonic GEMS Collection/Sonic Mega Collection Plus. These games were top-notch and had scanned original instruction manuals to read through, hundreds of comic covers, the sheer number of games AND unlockable games, developmental cut-scene videos — all freely included in the package and the point of extra content was that you, the player, had to work for it.

UPDATE: Well we got Sonic Origins Plus. And SEGA handled in the most typical, money-grubbing way possible.

>Amy is now playable.

Cool.

>Knuckles is in Sonic CD.

Pretty cool.

>All game gear titles were added.

Ahh, taking a page from Sonic GEMS collection and Sonic Mega Collection Plus, I see. Nice.

>Because I was a loyal fan that purchased the original game for $39.99... if I want these features, I need to spend the $10 for the upgrade resulting in a total purchase of $49.99?

WAIT NOT COOL.

So get this - Sonic Origins Plus is $39.99, meaning that people who didn't pay into it previously are getting a better deal. Plus, it includes all the previous DLC, saving you $16 if you only bought Sonic Origins Plus.

Here's a breakdown of price differences:
-------------------------------------------------------------
>Sonic Origins was originally $39.99.

>Premium Fun Pack was $3.99.
>Classic Music Pack was $3.99.

>Sonic Origins is now $29.99. The other packs have been removed from the store page.

>The Plus Upgrade is $9.99.

>Sonic Origins Plus all together is $39.99.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Worse, if you paid $46 to get all the extra features, now you're paying $56. Almost retail price...

Are you kidding me? Because we believed in your product, you're making pay more than people who didn't originally buy it?

Not like it's a ridiculous price increase, but c'mon, it just shows how much they don't care about treating fans with respect.

Posted: December 13, 2022
Product received for free

Completed as of writing this review: All Achivements.

Since the original ROMs for the trilogy were delisted and I have no option to review them, I'll leave my reviews for the originals here:

Sonic The Hedgehog: The first, but not the best. On the good side, we need to thank this game for creating the franchise, but on the other, it's really not what it was advertised to be. So-called Blast Processing was a good marketing technique that made this game stand out. However was it really all about the speed? Sonic may be the fastest thing alive, but not in this game, since only a fraction of the zones is speed-based at best. The special stages were also really challenging and not really rewarding. However, giving this game a shot is also a good suggestion because it's not bad, it's just... not all that fast.

This game is just.. cool. I don't know how else to describe it. It's definitely one of those games that have a love-hate relationship in the fanbase. Some people like it, others hate it. And you can really see why. If we're talking a Good Ending route, it's a really unique game for Sonic's gameplay style. However it's not about the speed, it's more about exploration, which destroys Sonic's momentum. Visually this game is gorgeous with very colorful stages and the best music in the series (I'm talking JP of course).

The game each MegaDrive owner loved. This is one of the best examples of how to make a sequel. It has new zones with a good sense of speed and progression that doesn't make you feel bored. If not the development crunch, probably that would be the best Sonic game in the series. Well, objectively it is one of those, but for my taste, the third one is better.

An absolute gem of a game. Since this game was split into two halves, it really gave the developers more time to create the best Sonic game for the SEGA MegaDrive. Really cool stages with catchy music and also a unique approach to how the story progresses. And yeah, this time this game has a lot more story and character than previous games. Also, new flashed-out art style makes this game just ooze with a cool attitude.

Now for


An another way for SEGA Marketing department to have us in their handcuffs, as they delisted the originals and forced us to buy this half-assed version, while emphasizing on the fact that we begged the remasters to be ported to consoles and PC for almost a decade. The first two MegaDrive games are ported... ok? I don't remember major issues with them. Sonic CD though was a really mixed bag. They decided to upscale the opening and ending, while ruining the ending's original feel that was done the best in the 2011 release. I'm still disappointed as hell at them for removing the satisfying good ending sound that always gave me goosebumps because it was so good. Sonic 3 & Knuckles though? This is the most unfortunate, as the developer of the remaster stated that the engines' clash introduced the new bugs and also there was no time to fix them as this was rushed for anniversary. Also new renditions of so-called "PC collection" themes are barely listenable. The menus also are badly optimized because of Hedgehog Engine 2 without the option to do anything besides lowering the resolution. Not to mention the boldness of them to sell the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ animations for menus in real money. Missions are also lackluster in some way. The challenge itself is fine, but the presentation feels unpolished with all those boxes meant to stop the player from getting out of bounds. And the "classic mode" is just 4:3 aspect ratio (not correctly centered btw) with lives. No emulation, no original experience. I don't have access to this game anymore as I played through Family Sharing, but I don't miss this game at all. I have bought the originals before that, so I'm fine playing them and only them.

Posted: October 11, 2022
I'm a HUGE Classic Sonic fan but this collection here is a giant disappointment and I'm gonna give out criticism on why I hate this collection.

My main criticism about this collection is the pricing, 55 CAD is too much for four Classic Sonic games, especially when compared to Sonic Mega Collection which cost 20 dollars with 12 games. Sega even decided to delist the four Classic Sonic games on the digital store when the trailer came out and decided to lock some content behind DLCs such as extra missions and some island additions, That is very disgusting since it's a collection of four 30-year-old games.

You even can't play as Metal Sonic or Amy Rose despite them being featured in the collection and can't even play as Knuckles in Sonic CD which is just very absurd and a big missed opportunity. Speaking of missed opportunities, It even sucks that Sonic 3D Blast, Sonic Spinball, and Knuckles' Chaotix aren't even in the collection despite them being available as soundtracks by DLC (Classic Music Pack).

Sonic 3 and Knuckles is by far the biggest offender here in this collection, asides the glitches and bugs, one of the things about this version that made me upset is the fact there aren't any MJ tracks in this version especially Ice Cap as it's replaced by the earlier music from the beta version of Sonic 3, don't get me wrong for two things, The Sonic 3 Prototype music is very catchy and Jun Senoue is a great composer for the Sonic games, The Prototype music in here sounds awful, especially Carnival Night, therefore, wasting Jun's talents in remixing those beta tracks which is just very sad. It still didn't make sense to remix when they could just port the music from the Prototype version. I pretty much doubt if one of the updates will bring back MJ tracks and I'm not exactly sure why they can't get the MJ music to this version, probably it's the licensing issue. That music changed especially Ice Cap sure did give fans hard times.

While Super and Hyper Sonic finally got their own theme in Sonic 3K instead of using repetitive invincibly music but literally sounds like Sonic 4 music which doesn't feel right for Sonic 3K because of its instruments and it's a shame that it's not using the Unused version (But yet the Unused version music was used in the New Blue Spheres results).

Going to Sonic CD in this verison:
Remember how the 2011 port of Sonic CD, the music of it uses the unused loops in the Japanese OST but for unknown reasons, they decided to use the music based on the original version of Sonic CD in the Origins version which I also noticed on Day one when the collection was out. The US OST loops weirdly as it's also based on the original version of Sonic CD as well.

Going back to Sonic 3 in this collection
As we got the music out of the way, I even ended up getting those issues in S3K EVEN WITH PATCHES. I ended up getting soft-locked multiple times, the first time I got soft-locked in Carnival Night by a barrel (or should I say Barrel of Doom), and the second time I got soft-locked in the Knuckles Battle in Hidden Palace after defeating him. There have been many glitches in this version especially at Launch.

There are still some things wrong with this collection,

Classic Mode - Adding Classic mode in this collection sounds like a perfect idea on paper but it's executed poorly as it's just the remastered versions at a 4:3 ratio, Sonic 1 still has the spindash while the original Sonic 1 didn't have a spindash, Sonic 2 in Mystic Caves still takes you to Hidden Palace when falling in the infamous pit, and Sonic 3 still have Sonic and Tails fight Big arms while in the original S3K you don't unless if you play as Knuckles. Couldn't they just have it emulated using the original Sonic versions when using Classic mode

Anniversary Mode - Nothing to say much about it but there is another missed opportunity for an option where you can turn on lives.
The games (Except for Sonic 3K) don't even have save slots, instead, when about to play the game, a character select will just pop up, even the Mobile ports of Sonic 1 and 2 have file selects. Same thing with the Sonic CD 2011 remake where it even has file selection and options but in Origins, you can only change settings in the title screen (I even noticed it resembles the original Sonic CD selection in Origins)

Sonic CD in Origins has voice clips removed, removing "I'm Outta here" and"Yes" voice clips, Classic Sonic being muted is pretty stupid. (If you are wondering, Classic Sonic has gone voiceless since Sonic Generations)


In General, This collection is just worthless with big letdowns,
This collection is not a definitive way to play classic Sonic games, if you want a better remaster of those Classic Sonic games, I recommend Sonic 1 Forever, Sonic 2 Absolute, Sonic CD 2011, and Sonic 3 AIR. Those remasters are way surpeior

I gotta admit that I really love the little animation cutscenes here, and it feels so nice to finally see Sonic 3 and Knuckles getting a rerelease officially although I'm better off with those fan remasters like Sonic 3 AIR and the original version of the classic Sonic games

I would rate this collection a 2/10. I recommend not buying Sonic Origins. It's not really worth it.

If there's anything I'm forgetting, let me know.
