Posted: July 2, 2022
Sonic Origins is the result of Sega milking nostalgia, the success of the Sonic Movie and my childhood at it's finest.

Sonic Origins is one of those few cases where I wish an option between positive and negative would be a thing for Steam reviews, however the negative backlash and certain tweets from developers explaining their situation on the game being a rushed job, as well as playing it for a few days now, put me into a mood where I just had to write down my complains and worries in a small review.

I've been dying to play the Christian Whitehead's Retro Engine remasters in an official way on PC for almost a decade now and while the new animated cutscenes add more flavor to each individual game got me crying inside, as well as new QoL improvements being something that people new to the series will appreciate, the core gameplay shows some rough edges such as:
Tails AI not respawning in Sonic 1 and 2.
Collission issues throughout all games, especially Sonic 3. Sonic CD having the least issues.
Sonic 1 and 2 having a jump roll lock, making the games harder than they should be.
Sega apparently not caring or didn't bother getting the licensing for the original 1994 Sonic3 OST.
Sonic 3's physics being totally different compared to the other remasters and original genesis game.
Sonic CD lacks Knuckles as playable character.
Sonic CD missing some sound effects compared to the 2011 rerelease.
You can't replay a completed save, if you wanted to go back and collect all the Emeralds in 1, CD or 2.
Audio mixing is all over the place.
Denuvo DRM will force the user to have an online connection to play the game once in a while, despite it being singleplayer.
And much more.

It's more so concerning that they delisted the original genesis games on Steam and on other console platforms, forcing people to buy Origins. While all these games play good, they are far from perfect and sadly I don't think it's worth the $40 price tag at the moment. Again by no means is Origins a bad game but it's lacking polish.

For now I recommend playing the fan decomps for Sonic 1 and 2 and wait for a sale. You might also want to play Origins with mods to enhance the experience and fix some of the issues that came with the game by default. It's still unclear if Sega is gonna support the game in the long run, fix leftovers or will just run away with everyones money.

Posted: June 22, 2022
Okay, so I'm gonna break down what this game entails here...

Pros:
-Sonic 1, 2, 3, and CD in a single package
-Anniversary Mode with Infinite lives and the ability to play as Sonic, Tails, or Knuckles in ALL the games (Edit: Knuckles not available in CD)
-Spin dash and Sonic Mania's Drop Dash available in all games via Anniversary Mode
-Ability to choose between Classic and Anniversary modes
-Additional mission mode and coin system
-New animated cutscenes to watch in Anniversary Mode

Cons:
-Older versions of these games that had mod support have been removed from Steam in order to release Origins
-90% of all new features were previously available as mods for the aforementioned old versions
-Denuvo Anti-tamper may hinder performance (I did not experience this) and may prevent you from playing in Offline Mode

It's fine, but if you have all the older versions, you will probably want to avoid this.

Posted: June 25, 2022
I have a ethical responsibility to write a negative review for this compilation. the games look nice in widescreen and it's great to be able to see these on a marketplace. I like being able to waddle over to my computer after a long and exhausting day at work and just hit thoughtlessly hit the "play" button on this and play some old sonic games.

The problem is, unless you're absurdly affluent and like throwing money away for no reason, there's no reason to purchase this. As a computer owner there are already ways to play these games in 16:9 on PC for a lot less than 40-45 dollars, and they have less bugs and have way more customization options than this offers. I don't need to tell you this since you've probably already read a bunch of reviews but go check out the decompiled ios/android ports of sonic 1, 2, and CD, and of course, check out either sonic 3 complete or sonic 3 AIR for a far superior experience than what this offers.

So basically what you're spending money on here is the compilation goodies and the fact that this natively launches from the steam platform and you can collect achievements for it. The crappy part here is that the achievements are baby stuff. I felt pretty great about having all six chaos emeralds by the end of Spring Yard Zone in Sonic 1, but the game didn't give me any sort of pat on the back or reward for doing so. In fact, the inability to toggle infinite lives off in anniversary mode doubly makes it feel like there's zero incentive for playing these games at a higher level or trying to learn more about them. That sucks!

The extras in the museum are sorely lacking. I remember Sonic Jam on the Saturn way back in 1997 having the original commercials for the games from japan and neat stuff like that. The museum offerings here are presented well and some of the art is in unprecedented resolution which is super cool but it's a lot of what you've seen already! It would've been nice to get some developer commentary tracks on levels, or maybe some options to configure custom playlists to enjoy while playing these video games. Yknow, some sort of offering that you can get here and not in other, superior versions of these widescreen ports.

I don't need to mention the music, we all know its terrible, but I should mention that there is a mod to restore the original soundtrack already. I don't know if there was any way around this. Michael Jackson's estate is notoriously difficult to work with and probably wanted sega to pay out the ass for a game that came out like thirty years ago. I don't really blame them for not wanting to pony up the money. What I can blame them for is how awful the replacement music sounds. Custom playlists or new compositions from guest composers like Tee Lopes or something could have cool but instead we have Jun Senoue offering the worst-sounding "genesis" remixes of those godawful prototype tracks i've hated for decades. The situation sucks, but it certainly could've been handled in more thoughtful and creative ways. I also think it's cowardly of them to have done their best to hide the soundtrack replacement news until shortly before launch.

Ultimately, don't buy this game. I bought it because I'm a stupid idiot and I like buying stuff because it makes me feel better about my dumb life. Go donate 40 dollars to an abortion fund or something and just google "sonic 1 widescreen android pc port" or something like that. Sonic is an anti-fascist and that's more in line with what he would want you to do, if he was real. I don't think he is though. (God I wish he was).

Posted: June 24
I feel like a lot of people really don't seem to understand just what Sonic Origins is....
It always felt to me as if it wasn't really intended to be this massive collection of Sonic games like Mega Collection Plus or Gems Collection was. It was never meant to be anything beyond: "Hey, we're bringing the HD Remasters of Sonic 1 and 2 to PC, and here's CD and the never before seen an ACTUAL re-release Sonic 3 & Knuckles, all in glorious widescreen. Remade from the ground up in Sonic Mania's retro engine." Just giving us a nice refreshing take of 4 classic Sonic games packed with some neat things from Sonic's history that should surely reflect it's title as Sonic Origins.

This should have been the explanation right? Well not quite. It seems like the higher ups at Sega didn't exactly know themselves how to market this game. As a result it is unclear to us the consumers, casual gamers and Sonic fans alike what this game really is. Couple that with the absolutely terrible price guide and "DLC" additions (which were all later included in the PLUS DLC) and it's very easy to understand why this title's reception is mixed. That being said, what is Sonic Origins. Is it a smash pack of classic Genesis games like the many collections we've seen for decades? Or not.

This is a debate that I'm very tired of seeing because all of the people who know are overshadowed by the loud vocal majority that wants Knuckles Chaotix or Sonic 3D Blast to be included in this pack of remastered Sonic games. (I can understand why, Chaotix hasn't had a release at all and is probably the only 32X title worth playing in my humbled opinion.) If Sonic Origins seemed lackluster already, adding these games will honestly make things even worse. "Why is Sonic 1, 2, 3 and CD only in HD, why can't we get other genesis games in HD!?" Sure, if they had competent emulation developers who are able to reverse engineer the code on these old games and then modernize it for today's standards then SURE, games like Sonic 3D Blast or Chaotix would be a no brainer. However it just simply doesn't work like that. As stated previously the titles included in Origins were remade from the ground up. This is not your average Sega Genesis collection and should have been marketed as such!!

Don't even get me started on the quality of the remastered games that we got... It just screams corporate meddling. Every game is full of it's own unique flaws and things that we haven't seen in other Retro Engine remakes. Which is another reason why Sonic Origins has a mixed reception but I want to talk about the elephant in the room. The PLUS DLC.

I applaud them for listening to that loud majority that wanted more content for this game. I feel like it's especially beneficial to the game's reputation as a whole especially given it's strange launch price, this makes people feel as if they're getting their money's worth. Is what I would say if there wasn't another big elephant in the room, THE DIGITAL DELUXE EDITION. (Which I myself pre-ordered when it was available for purchase.) Do you know what we get in the Digital Deluxe Edition?

More coins? - Yes.
Music unlocked from the start? - Yes
More Content to unlock in the Art Gallery? - Yes
Plus DLC? - Ye- No. No?

NO!? The game was a whole $15 extra dollars at launch for people who purchased the Digital Deluxe Edition why are those people not being compensated!? We paid $45 DOLLARS FOR THIS GAME. Okay so you give the people what they want, more content but at the same time you're ripping off the people who pre-ordered the Digital Deluxe Edition!? $55 DOLLARS TOTAL!?For a game that's being listed for $29,99!? Come on now.

Originally I was content with whatever they offered for this game because I was just happy to see those retro engine ports of Sonic 1 and 2 being playable on more than just mobile phones. I was happy because Sonic 3 and Knuckles was FINALLY getting that treatment as well as being the only title to at this point has NOT seen a re-release since Sonic Mega Collection. If I had known that there was a possibility of this game getting a PLUS update and that THIS kind of strategy would be pulled I would have never pre-ordered it because ALL OF THE PRE-ORDER CONTENT COMES IN THE PLUS DLC!

Sega, Sonic Team and their marketing team really dropped the ball on what would have been a decent collection of remastered Sonic games. Is Origins bad? No, not at all. I can tell there was some love put in to all this. While uncredited, part of Mania's dev team helped Sonic Team learn the Retro Engine. But with Orgins and it's troubled backstory, abhorrent marketing and business strategies makes this game just plain bad. Do not buy this title at a high price, wait for it to go on sale. Steam always has really good Sonic The Hedgehog sales and chances are you might even get a game bundled in if you don't have it already.

Till then I'll be laying low til the price inevitably drops and I can purchase the plus DLC. (Too bad it's 1 year TOO LATE for me to get a refund.) I'll be playing the BETTER Sonic title that released last year, Sonic Frontiers which GAVE US FREE DLC ON THE SAME DAY THAT IMPROVED THE GAME IN WAYS ORIGINS COULD EVER DREAM OF. Do yourself a favor, wait for a sale. This collection can wait.

So for now, this game's recommendation is a no from me.

Posted: June 9
Pre-Plus review:
Sonic Origins needs to be reviewed from the perspective of the devs who worked on the games in the background, namely the Headcannon team, such as Whitehead and Stealth, because seeing Sonic 3 and Knuckles playable with the framework of the iOS/mobile ports of Sonic 1, CD and 2 is something they have wanted for a LONG time. The music change and legalities regarding the soundtrack have understandably prevented this from being a reality, and given official ports have used the new music before, I'm totally fine with the change.

So from the stance that this was a LEGAL NIGHTMARE, I cannot offer anything less than respect for the transparency and determination for the devs pushing for this port to even exist. While the menus, extras, and bonus features are products of SEGA internal, the amount of fan service, classic acknowledgement in the 3D Blast and Spinball islands, and even 1st month patches to fix music labelling errors in the music player, give me great hopes for the longevity of this collection as the ideal way to enjoy these games.

Yes, there is a level of conflict in the community by those who feel the individual games or ports should not have been delisted for this collection, but the goal of this collection is not to eliminate game preservation but rather promote accessibility across the board, and offer these games in their technically most optimised state. And at the end of the day, if people are turned off from this collection because of the Sonic 3 soundtrack changes, the modding community is so vast that the number of free alternatives negate 90% of all critiques.


Post-Plus review? Well, Amy is now in all four games, Knuckles was added to CD, and they're both present on the islands too. If I can discuss my thoughts on the GG additions and whether their consistency with previous collections still holds up in 2023 - they do.

While accessibility is a monumental importance, I don't think the MasterSystem versions offer technical and gameplay advantages, and genuinely cannot understand people wanted OLDER builds of 8/12 8-bit titles as only some games had SMS versions.

But I highly recommend you #PlayTripleTrouble16bit by Noah Copeland if you want HC quality for that game too.

Posted: June 26, 2022
Update: New review for version 2.1

Main Game: I am more positive about the game now due to the new DLC and the patches fixing many of the main issues, so overall I will give the game a B rating. I think it could use a DLC pack for Sonic 3/K music (ideally both Sonic 3 and & Knuckles as two types of OSTs) as well as another general patch. The game was price reduced so that helps.

Some general issues are many features like extra characters, emeralds, and new items being hidden in cheat code menus, as well as no ability to replay the games from stage select like Sonic 3/K for the other games even though I know the mobile versions allowed for that. The final special stage in Sonic 1 if you use 7 emeralds is new and very bad so I think it needs to be redone. The lack of many CRT/etc filters is also strange as Mania had this prior.

Classic mode should also allow you to select widescreen optionally to play with lives instead of coins.

Sonic 1: Physics are way off in the special stages. Sonic shoots around so rapidly. It is much harder than it used to be. At least coins exist to let you retry, however. Tails also has some jumping glitches and seems to freeze the game in Labyrinth Zone Act 1.

Sonic CD: Here we mainly have cutscene issues. Why is the volume different in every part of the game? It is very strange. Also the ending has the towers falling over yet no sound effects for them? They used to have sounds. Sonic and Amy cannot talk anymore either. All unappealing changes.

(Tip: Before playing story mode, you can go to the regular game, skip the cutscene intro, then set the game's music to JPN for the other soundtrack. It will play that version of the OST in story mode then.)

Sonic 2: Probably the best game here, nothing really bad about it anymore overall.

Sonic 3/K: The sound is totally off and low quality. I own a Genesis/Mega Drive and played it right next to it to confirm the music is messed up (all tracks). They are too muffled and scratchy. There is a better Sonic 3 beta OST out there. Just check around. They should use that version if they need the original songs. The Super Sonic music is just awful and should be replaced with the regular invincibility song.

Game Gear Games: These are fine if you play a portable version of the game. The best games are Sonic 1, Triple Trouble, and Drift 2. I think every game has some sort of appealing aspect if you give them a chance, at least.

Posted: June 23, 2022
Initial Reactions for Sonic 3 and knuckles (spoilers)

I grew up with the Genesis Games and I even have the damn strategy guide for Sonic 3 when it first came out. I was a huge Sonic Fan and I would still be if this series was just treated with the respect it deserves from its creators. Instead, once again, for the THOUSANDTH time since we've all started playing sonic. "Just barely good enough" is Sega's motto when it comes to these games.

The Good
-Widescreen
-Supposedly scales up to 4K, I have yet to even try that out
-Coins are a good incentive to travel throughout the whole game and grab as many rings as possible
-Super Sonic is Mapped to the Y Button like in Sonic Mania
-Tails Helper Controls are nearly perfect
-The camera controls seem to function better than the default controls in Sonic A.I.R, and you can now outrun the screen again. it's quite cool
-Ice Cap Act 1 and 2 and Launch Base Act 1 use their prototype music without many changes

...And the Bad

- The Music does not start or stop correctly in stages. Everything has a strange fade-in and fade-out effect.
- Special Stage Controls are tweaked, so if you're used to timing from S3/S3Air you will need to adjust
- For that matter it's sort of difficult to use the sound effects from the special stage as a reference point for when you need to turn because of how delayed they are
- The Special Stage music never speeds up as you play. So we went from S3 speed up too fast, S3K speeding up slower, and now S3K origins not speeding up at all... why?
- Many Sound effects are seemingly added in all over the place for no good reason, It makes some parts feel like I'm watching a flash/youtube fan movie
- Instead of letting you fruitlessly attack the first miniboss, they now arbitrarily lock you in place.
- The Super Sonic Music is absolutely terrible and I would've rather them played the invincibility theme if it was going to be this bad
- The Sonic 3 invincibility music is gone.. BUT they let you listen to it in museum mode for some crazy reason!
- Absolutely no gameplay customization options whatsoever as far as I can tell (not surprised...)
- Marble Garden's Crushers can now kill you from ALL SIDES rather than you needing to be under them... Ugh!
- Marble Garden's swinging spikeball hitboxes are bigger for some reason?
- A lot of things break really easily for the experienced players zipping through all the zones: Effects that are supposed to last for moments instead glitch out and last the entire level (For instance Marble Garden Zone when you first encounter the mini boss has debris falling and then it never stops if you run past it).
- Carnival Night Act 1 and 2 and Launch Base Act 2 music is god awful which is weird because the prototype music that was recently dug up would've been perfect to use. Either they used the wrong versions or Jun just plain out screwed up.

The worst offender of them all

-They list and let you listen to the "unused music" for sonic 3 in the museum mode, which the community has already agreed on being probably the prototype super sonic music, but Jun made his own track for the game that screams sonic 4 levels of bad and you cant. turn. it. OFF.

I'll update this as I go along but I really hope they fix the music up...

Edit: So supposedly the entire game is built up as a modification of Sonic Mania. That's interesting but what's REALLY screwed up is sega took these ports and forced them to run alongside the hedgehog engine that powers their 3D games. They hacked into the sound engine part of the Retro engine that powers the game and... absolutely butchered it.

So to break it down for you guys, and please leave a thumbs up if this makes sense...

Sega used their 3D game engine to replace the perfect sound that these games had to begin with on the retro engine... and on top of denuvo you are running a 3D game engine at the same time as these 2D engines. This isn't some sort of "Haha technically..." or "Gotcha". This is what's actually happening, does it now make sense why the game runs like ♥♥♥♥?

Posted: August 22, 2022
I like this game, a lot actually, BUT
The question being asked is: would you recommend this game to other players? My answer is a big NO.
Dropping $40 isn't a big deal to me, but I understand many find that unfair, especially if you're on a budget. My biggest question is why does this even exist?!

But before I get into that, I will explain why I bought it. I got it because of the widescreen, achievements, and the ability to easily mix and match mods without having to patch a dedicated rom. That's honestly it. Classic Sonic is a childhood favorite, literally, so this collection has something special for me.

Now onto why I could not, and will not recommend this game. It's honestly a waste. It's a waste of money and talent. There are many iterations that exist for each of these games. I grew up with the original cartridges and the Sonic collection on PC many years ago and that did enough for me. The games have been available for pretty much every console ever, and I think you would save money if you just got them individually. Back in 2007 I got the lock-on for only 99 cents online!

Honestly, I don't see how this is worth it for anyone, even for those who are new to Sonic. Just get each game one at a time, and see if you enjoy them. Why buy a $40 lifeless collection if you have no idea if you will even like a single game. This collection was clearly for people who already love Sonic, and love the classic games. But here's the thing, if you don't like just one of the included games, instantly the collection becomes a complete rip-off. Personally, I don't like Sonic CD at all, so already I'm screwed, but as I mentioned before, it didn't bother me.

This collection is certainly nowhere near perfect. As many have stated, it's filled with bugs that certainly didn't exist in the originals, and there was certainly odd things that occurred that I know didn't happen in the originals. One thing that bothered crap out of me was the jumping felt off. If you were to jump and land and try to jump again the instant you landed, it doesn't register your input. I have no idea what's that's about, but that has costed me rings more than I can care to remember and certainly wasn't an issue I had with the original. As mentioned the physics felt a little weird as well.

When this game was announced, I had no idea why people were so hyped up about it. It just looked like a lazy cash grab. Even from the trailer it didn't look special.

In conclusion, honestly, do yourself a favor and just get the games individually. Don't waste your time with this piece of crap of a collection. It really has nothing special to offer for anyone.

Posted: June 26, 2022
Unfortunately I did the dumb thing and preordered the deluxe version of the collection like the sonic simp I am. Welp.


MOANING AND COMPLAINTS:

-Sonic 3&K is my favorite 2d platformer of all time, but Sonic 3 AIR is a far better port than Sonic Origins. This collection hardly adds anything worthwhile outside of cutscenes and Mania's drop dash.

-All of the animated segments heavily feature Amy, but she still isn't playable in this for some reason.

-The DLC is ridiculous, and mission mode is hardly worth mentioning.

-I really wish the insta-shield was available in Sonic 1 & 2 outside of the stage select cheat. Having the insta-shield, elemental shields and drop dash in all the games is my favorite way to play the games, but I wish I could save when doing so.

-After all these years, Sonic CD is still incomplete. Don't get me wrong, CD's my second favorite game in this collection, but that game really needs a reason to collect all the timestones/destroy the generators, outside of the small part of the ending cutscene that changes when you do so. I'm hoping someday someone adds the cut finale, Final Fever, to Sonic CD.


WHY I'M STILL OK WITH IT:

-Coins are actually a neat replacement for Lives. As they function like lives, but for special stages only. You also use them to unlock concept art, videos and music. (Still, wish there was more to unlock with them.)

-Like any toxic relationship, I have hopes that Sonic Origins will pick up its act and include updates addressing most of my complaints. Should I hold onto that hope? Probably not, but I do so anyways.

-What I do like about Sonic Origins is that it's an easy all-in-one package to get normies into classic sonic. Not everyone is willing to hunt for all the individual fan remasters of all these games. These are some of my favorite games, and I think all the remasters included are pretty solid. Widescreen is how 2d sonic should be played.



QUICK INDIVIDUAL GAME REVIEWS:

Sonic 1
-----
-Remove(or redesign) Marble Zone and you got yourself a good game. I think Sonic 1 gets way too much flak. The game is still good after Green Hill.



Sonic CD
-----
-You gotta play this with the JP soundtrack or you're missing out on probably the best game OST ever. The levels here are all great playgrounds for sonic's movement.

-As I said above, I love this game but it feels incomplete. I wish there was just a bit more of a reason to explore all the versions of the levels. Like finding the chaos emeralds in the good future or something.



Sonic 2
-----
- The first 2/3rds of this game is great. But man, everything after Oil Ocean is rough.


Sonic 3 & K
-----
-The game that got everything right imo, the best of the series. Especially if you're just taking the original versions of each game into consideration. It had saves, let Tails fly, added Knuckles, elemental shields, act 1 bosses, the best special stages, bonus stages at checkpoints, great (story) pacing and some of the best level design. I used to think the only sore part of the game was Sandopolis Act 2, but maybe stockholm's syndrome has hit, and I don't even think that anymore.

Executive meddling messes up everything, as par for the course with Sonic. On one hand, there's finally an official modern port of Sonic 3 & Knuckles, but on the other hand, there's too many issues to ignore including new bugs that weren't present in the previous ports of Sonic 1, 2, and CD, the completely unnecessary use of the resource-hungry Hedgehog Engine for what should only really be a lightweight 2D user interface, lack of customization options in terms of settings (no filtering options, can only choose between "classic" or "anniversary" modes, only one save file per game contrary to the mobile ports, etc), and many more issues which would take forever to describe; a "death by a thousand paper cuts" type of scenario, basically. Posted: November 1
I've been thinking about how to start my review for a long time. As a long-time fan of the series who has been playing since Forza Motorsport 2, who has played every game since then (including the Horizon series), who has pre-ordered the Ultimate Edition of every game, and who has invested thousands of hours of playtime in the series, I am at a loss for words.

This is my first Forza that I've played mostly on PC, where I can switch between PC and Series X thanks to Cross Progression.

Turn 10 has promised a lot in the past, the trailers often looked better than the finished games, but never has the gap been as wide as it is with this installment. At no point does the game look even remotely as good as the original trailers, even with the maximum details on PC it doesn't come close to the video footage shown in marketing events.

Visually, the game fluctuates from "quite respectable" to "really bad", the latter especially when a vehicle model appears again somewhere that was copied over from an old game. "From the ground up new" this is not.

The "career mode" is one of the most boring campaigns I've played in the genre, the AI drivers are dumber than ever and the content has been greatly reduced. Fewer tracks, vehicles and features but more bugs than ever. Crashes, disappearing track textures and geometry etc. are part of the game experience here, the list of known bugs is longer than some PhD thesis.

Something must have gone wrong during the long development time. It remains to be seen whether Turn 10 can pull it out of the mud. At this point, I wouldn't recommend the game even to fans.

Posted: October 14
Worst £90 I've ever spent.
I've been a big fan of the FM series since FM2 on the Xbox 360 but this is a let down in so many ways. I'm sure this review is just echoing what others have already said but here's my thoughts after 17 hours of play time

The Good
- A good choice in cars from day one.
- Graphics look decent on the cars.
- Large choice in wheels for customisation.

The Bad
- Career mode is awful ("a mile wide but an inch deep"). You never actually see any proper racing, and in a game designed about track racing it seems like its more focused on being a "take your daily driver to the local track day" simulator than a full blown racing simulator.
- The steering wheel glitches/stutters constantly when racing using the driver's helmet cam. Almost like the steering wheel is being displayed at 10fps compared to the rest of the game.
- Car progression system is . Seriously, stop it. Change it. You should spend MONEY on car parts, and they should be unlocked at DRIVER level across the board. The reason you've done this is to force people to play the game more. You can't force player retention. Make a game that people WANT to play, not one they feel they HAVE to play.
- Money is pointless because of the aforementioned point, having to use CP to buy parts instead of money.
- Low resolution rendering of car images regardless of graphics settings when browsing the paint designs.
- No Nordschleife circuit at launch. Like the game has been in development long enough already and now we're expected to wait almost a year for arguably the most iconic track in all of motor sport??
- The AI is abysmal. They have zero track sense, will randomly turn into you (which then gives you a time penalty), push you off track, slam into you and pile up at the first turn in every circuit, and seemingly have impossible levels of grip once they manage to break away. If you DO manage to get out in front it seems they immediately forget how to drive at all. There's no middle ground.
- The penalty system is seemingly random and decides how much time to penalise you by (or if it even is a penalty at all) by a random coin flip system. Sometimes you run a tyre width over the rumble strip on the exit of a turn and get hit for a +2:00 penalty, other times you can completely ignore chicanes and cut them in a straight line for zero penalty.
- Online racing qualification system is also broken because of this. The game does not issue penalties but will randomly flag your lap if you go a pixel off the track, resulting in you being 3-5s faster than the entire field but having to start in 6th place,
- Handling of cars is very hit or miss on gamepad. Some A class cars handle like they're on rails and other S class cars (which should be already built as a "racing" car) seem to drive like they're on ice constantly.
- Animation of the steering wheel always seems to lock out at around 40 degrees from TDC in EVERY car, regardless of the steering angle, or any adjustments made.
- People abusing the self-driving car system online to give them a false safety rating is very annoying to deal with, might as well stick to career mode if I wanted to race against AI

Steam will not refund me this game (I tried) so it's going to sit in my library as a reminder to not buy games on launch day ever again. Wait until next year when they've released a load of DLC and fixed the game issues before buying.

Posted: October 11
Have played every Forza title since FM2 and huge fan of the series. Highly recommend finding a grey market FM7 copy and waiting for the devs to release content that's clearly being intentionally held back from this game to pad "seasonal" content schedules.

Pros:
+ The 'ground up' physics engine and handling feel noticeably better, if familiar.
+ The weather system is good, but not perfect.
+ The sound design is excellent relative to past Forza titles.

Cons:
- Bizarre car catalog, bizarre removals, bizarre amount of recycled models from 12 years ago.
- Leveling mechanic makes sense but is a forced constraint that ultimately needs tuning.
- The upgrading menu lacks a ton of information, no more dyno charts, no ability to preview sound, no ability to see details/changes at a glance (eg +13hp)
- Did I mentioned the recycled models? This game is the most offensive yet in terms of model inconsistency
- Menu system is awful
- Overall content is about 50% of what it should be

On its strengths alone, the game is legitimately a 7/10, but knowing how many egregious missteps there are, them charging $70-100 for this title means that, at best, it's a 6/10 overall and in terms of sheer value. This is the most disappointing entry for the Forza franchise by a landslide.

Posted: October 9
I paid 100$ so you don't have to.
Making the review after playing the pre-release Premium Version for 35 hours.

The Good:

Forza Motorsport has the most realistic and consistent gamepad handling on PC money can buy right now.
The driving experience is sublime with highly adjustable difficulty, suitable for newcomers and veterans alike.
Multiplayer is solid and "Rivals" is amazing. Time trial leaderboards now allow you to copy tunes from leaders then try to match their pace.

The Bad:

The curated career is shallow. Some of the cars you can chose from for each event are underpowered, which is problematic with the current leveling system. Considering the wide range of cars available in the game, there are no dedicated Touring Car, GT3 or Endurance type of races, based on real life Motorsport events.

The car leveling system is extremely slow, considering the number of available cars. 3-5 hours per car to be more precise. This needs to be reduced significantly as it now resembles a free to play mobile game levels of grind. On top of that the order of the unlocks leaves many cars with useless upgrades in the early levels (more power to muscle cars but no handling upgrades for the first levels?)

The Ugly:

The current version of the game is poorly optimized, leaving majority of PC users struggling to get smooth gameplay experience. Many of the graphics settings simply don't work. On my 6800XT I couldn't get FSR to work. I couldn't even switch resolution from 1440p to 1080p. Changing settings requires restarts. On each restart the game recompiles shaders for 5 minutes. I've had about 20-30 crashes in 35 hours and 2 BSOD.

To pour salt in to the wound, the jump in visual fidelity compared to FH4&5 and even FM7 and Project Cars 2 from 6 years ago is arguable, considering that playing with Ray Tracing "on" at the moment seems to be reserved only for top of the line PC users.

You can find video comparison between Project Cars 2 and Forza Motorsport here ->

Posted: October 9
The good news is the driving physics, fuel and tire mechanics, and multiplayer design are the best the series has ever been. However, the overall package, performance, and presentation are significantly lacking in this game at launch. Unless you're desperate, hold off on purchasing this game until the developers have had time to put in additional content and fix the numerous bugs and the odd design choices they've made that I think may need to be changed. There's a lot of work that needs to be done on this game for it to be considered a complete racing game.

The performance on an 8700K+RTX4070 has been inconsistent at 1440p. While playing with frame rate unlocked at a mix of ultra and high settings I can get FPS into the high 80s but this is accompanied by regular drops of about 20 FPS so I felt it required the 60 FPS lock setting which was a bit disappointing. The other disappointment comes in how the game looks, which frankly is not visually pleasing even at the highest possible settings and generally just not a sharp enough picture no matter what you adjust.

So overall it’s a bit of a mixed bag. The racing itself is engaging and fun but the choices the developers have made with this game for presentation and functionality leave much to be desired. If it receives good post-launch support it may correct a lot of those issues but at launch it’s a bit disappointing and I do not recommend buying it.

If you're new to Forza, it could be a good place to start. If you're not new to Forza, it's definitely an awful place to continue.

Weather artists killed it though. Still images look incredible. Too bad about the rest of this anemic cash grab.

Posted: October 10
We waited 6 years… for this? It’s crazy that Microsoft managed to undercook a cake that has been in the oven for 6 years. What’s supposed to be the definitive Motorsport experience is now walking on the same path as Halo Infinite: Release it buggy & incomplete, finish the game later.

“BUILT FROM THE GROUND UP”

Build from the ground up this, built from the ground up that.... It was by far the most stressed quote during Forza Motorsport’s marketing. Here’s what’s improved:

- Massively improved physics & handling model, including 8-point contacts for tires with 360hz update rate & better wheel support
- Fuel & Tire Strategy
- A new penalty system (which sometimes punishes the rammed instead of rammers)
- Challenge the grid for singleplayer, where you can choose the starting position before a race.
- Improved multiplayer with practice laps, qualifiers, Safety & Skill rating, spec races where everyone drives the same featured car with same upgrades & tuning.
- Skip lap in Rivals
- FOV slider for PC & XBOX
- And more…

And here are what's not:














My RTX 3060 laptop is struggling to maintain a stable 60 FPS even on lowest setting with DLSS on quality, meanwhile this mid-tier laptop has no problem getting 120+ FPS on the same lowest setting with no frame drops or stutters in FH5. And it’s not just my issue. People have been posting images where their RTX 4090 even fails to reach 40 FPS.

Even if I pretended that the game is well optimized & this is the max performance my laptop could produce, it’s still unacceptable. Not everyone has access to a RTX4090 & I9-13900K, and they shouldn’t cause even the mid-tier PCs to suffer even on lowest settings, just to make their game 10% more beautiful like Starfield. Remember, “diminishing returns” exists.

Visit , you’ll be stunned with the incredibly long list of issues. From the buggy replay system, infinite loading screen, to career mode not saving progress, people have been posting bugs & glitches everywhere on social media for the last few days. It makes me beg a question: What the hell have they been doing during the last 6 years? Where’s quality control?


Forza players have been asking for better career progression for years. They want to start with low-level/economy cars then slowly work towards high-end hypercars. Instead of that, Turn 10 gave us a Call of Duty-esque CarPG progression, Where instead of buying upgrades with credits, you have to level up to earn Car Points for upgrades. It’s a very controversial system. Some like it, while many others (including me) don’t.

Here's the good:


So why is it bad?







CarPG must've been made not to be fun & engaging, but with the sole intention to please investors by having players always repeating the same grind and prolonging the player numbers, hours played or whatever metric they aim for to present it to their investors.


Forza Motorsport is literally a great example of bad live-service games: release an early access buggy mess that meets the bare minimum of being playable, then improve it later with updates. While the core gameplay is still intact & incredibly fun, almost everything else is half-baked. It’s like a gem covered in stinky poo poo, when the owner doesn't respect its value. I recommend not giving them money & not pampering them for just passing the bare minimum, but instead buying this game 1 year later while on a sale, when the game is fixed.

Posted: October 10
Sadly this is another one of those AAA rated games that held promise, but ultimately didn't deliver. This game has got some serious issues.

The car upgrade system, while a lot of people hate it, I can understand why it was done like this. It is to encourage longevity in the game, to keep people on that gristmill, grinding the next car. This is fine if you enjoy that sort of thing, but for a casual racing game, time gating upgrades, where people will often just pick up the game and play, seems like a poorly thought out idea.

The penalty system is good and an innovative implementation, but is an inconsistent disaster. There a huge issues with application of penalties, where an innocent party could be driven off track, or punted from an unsafe rejoin, only to be slapped with a huge time penalty for an "avoidable collision". This is while the person who rammed you off or caused a 3 car pile up receives no penalty at all in the view of our AI overlord.

This might be the best physics that Forza has to offer, but if this is 6 years in the making, I would rather get a PS5 and play GT7. The understeer is horrendous, every car in the game has it to varying degrees, which makes me think this is physics related. I understand that this makes it easier for controllers (i.e. the vast majority of the player base) but it seriously detracts from the overall "driving" experience.

The career mode unfortunately follows the Call of Duty trend of lacking anything meaningful. It feels like an after thought, an opportunity for those who don't want to play online to engage in some light racing with the AI. Talking of which, the AI is also pretty embarrassing; slow, clumsy, and irrational at the start of the race, but mega fast once the race opens up.

It isnt all bad however, the game itself looks really good, with some excellent particle effects and some very detailed tracks and the rating system seems a good enough implementation.

The game has its good points, but I feel Forza has missed the point; it has tried to be this compromise between being a casual experience and a proper racing title, but at the minute I feel it is neither. If the upcoming Assetto Corsa 2 builds on the promise of Assetto Corsa, Forza better watch it's back...

Posted: October 22
In the current state FM is in, I don't think I can recommend this. I've been dying to have a controller-suited experience on PC for a while now, and I thought FM would be the good PC alternative to Gran Turismo since that isn't on PC either (love it though).

Way, way, way too many bugs right now. PC optimisation for this game is equivalent to putting your wiener in a spinning fan blade. The track can disappear in front of you, the frame rate is the most inconsistent thing ever no matter the graphics preset, and don't get me started on the infinite loading bugs. Seriously, it's insanely baffling that you can be a flagship franchise under Microsoft, be a triple AAA company, and vomit up something not nearly enough to satisfy the majority of your playerbase. I'm one of the die-hard few, although, it's more accurate to just call me one of the desperate ones.
As for positives about the game, there are only a few touches of grace here and there which primarily come down to the racing itself. Multiplayer racing is killer. It's got close-racing action and for the most part, cars are balanced. Penalties as related to the racing itself though... not so fun. You can get rammed by someone then hit into someone else and it can be your fault. Track limits too, but I feel this can be ironed out.

I don't think I've hated it hard enough. Even if you're looking for something to play, don't let yourself get convinced by the fun racing to be had. There's not enough content, no free play/server browser, campaign is bleak... even with the progression change, which the final upgrades required you to get your car to level 50 and could take 3-5 hours, getting your car to Level 25 still does not fix it entirely. Car points still restrict a lot, they really should have fixed this progression issue before launch. Everyone says the same stuff about who could have possibly QA'd this and said it was fine lol.

I'll still hold my breath. The devs got a lot of work to do to fix the important issues.

Hey Folks,

Not sure what Turn 10 has been up to but this game is an absolute train wreck. The game is poorly optimized, riddled with bugs, and has limited series available on multiplayer. The CONSTANT reloading and disconnections associated with this game are completely unacceptable. I can appreciate the attention to detail with the vehicles, they definitely look very pretty and the new upgrading mechanics are something I've come to like. However, I feel like half the game is missing right now.

Hear me out... I can't believe that a bunch of effort went into the race tracks. The vast majority that are within the game right now are existing and have been in each Forza game since 2005. I imagine that some time went into the physics engine for those tracks and I can appreciate the effort. I cannot understand how so little time (perceived) went into the front end or the match making process or QoL.

I've been playing Forza since it's inception in 2005. I loved it, played it to death with the boys, and made some great memories. It's extremely disappointing to purchase ANOTHER game from a Microsoft backed studio that is simply not finished. Halo Infinite wasn't finished, Starfield wasn't finished, and now Forza.

Microsoft, stop selling unfinished products for full price. If you're going to send a half baked game out into the world, charge a price similar to an indie game.

TLDR - this game isn't ready for consumption right now. Save your money, go play the last Forza, wait until you see the "User Reviews" change to 'Mixed'. That'll be your signal that the game has finally been adjusted when new reviews come up.

Posted: October 23
Let's be clear. Is this game perfect... No. Is this game fun... Yes.

I'm a casual PC sim racer who mostly plays iracing and ams2 with the occasional dirt 2. I do have a full wheel and cockpit with triple screens. This is not a sim, but it is a simcade and for me scratches that itch when I want to race, but don't want to take it too seriously or only have enough time for a quick race.

I did a lot of research on some wheel settings to use in my Moza software along with in game and then have been tweaking from there. It definitely isn't as bad if you have a good starting point. I never expected it to be sim level and was actually surprised it wasn't as bad as people were making it out to be.

On that note, the cars, especially the starter ones are super understeery. As you level it up you can unlock things to improve that. I just learned to adapt to it and give the car what it needs and I have been able to hit all target times on level 5 difficulty with expert ruleset in place.

You'll read a lot of reviews about bad AI. I honestly think that aside from iracing AI in private sessions this may be one of the better ones. If you aren't a perpetual dive bomber who expects everyone to get out of your way even if the corner isn't yours you often will have clean races. I do admit that the race starts are a little odd, but it's easy to adapt to if you have some racecraft. You don't win the race on turn 1.

I personally enjoy slowly upgrading cars as you get experience with them. It can be a grind if you are Uber competitive and want everything right away or play nom stop, but for casual fans who like to learn their car and just enjoy the race it really is quite fun.

Multiplayer is hit or miss and I haven't done much of it yet, but honestly had cleaner races with AI so far.

The main bug I've ran into is that I have to rebind my pedal inputs from my Moza pedals every time I log in. It is irritating, but takes 3 seconds and doesn't break the game for me.

Overall, I enjoy the game and think many casual racers who don't always have the time or energy for iracing/acc, but think FH5 is too arcadey with not enough proper track races or proper racing rules in place.

I hope this helps someone as I'd like to see people having fun with this and continue to get updates and attention for a long time.

Posted: October 9
Most entertaining racing experience I've had in 20 years. This is a terrific bundle of potential that can only get better.

Pros:
Is the ANNOYING HELICOPTER there from FM7? He's still here but NOT NEAR AS LOUD. Most of the time I can't even hear him but when I do it is subtle. I don't recall seeing him during practice.
Tire model is absolutely fantastic. All the people saying this game is just another Forza must be using a gamepad because with a wheel in full simulation mode with no assists, the game is terrific and light years ahead of the previous titles.
Suspension geometry in general is vastly improved. Drive the '73 911 in FM7 then drive it in this game and see for yourself.
The previous titles were so arcadey when it came to the race cars and anything super fast that I exclusively drove the production cars under 700hp because the grip was unrealistic and the cars didn't compare anything to a true sim. Comparing this game to my real life '20 Mustang and my buddy's '15 Charger, my hats off to Turn 10 for finally getting it right.
Each tire type really feels different which I love. Comparing stock, street, sport and racing is a highly noticeable change in feel.
Turn 10 has always been really good about sound design and that hasn't changed. The cars appear to all have unique sound effects and are very high quality. Changing exhaust or increasing the size of turbos or SCs is highly noticeable.
The previous games were bad about giving you too many free cars and tons of money but then making everything extremely expensive. This game is the opposite with cars being cheap and parts free but money is harder to earn.
Part are a divisive topic: the new car progression system, I personally love it. You have to drive a car to level it up and unlock part availability then use car points to equip them. You can never lose those points so you can swap around different parts without blowing money on something you wish you didn't buy. It creates a sense of development almost like an RPG or something which I like.
I used to get bored and struggle to think of what to do but now I know I have constant projects/goals that I want to achieve.
Career races are another divisive topic. When I am playing singleplayer, I just want a fun race. With this system, I turn some laps to see about how fast I am at that track and then adjust the difficulty as needed to guarantee a close race then adjust where I want to start out in the race and fight for a podium finish. I think it is a terrific system that guarantees a close and fun fight. Multiplayer racing still has qualifying which makes more sense.
Gone is that stupid homologation system from the last game. Now you customize your car as you want and the AI drivers match you by using as many points as you did so it is always a fair race. It also means, you can see 10 of the same car in a race and all 10 could be totally different. One might have racing slicks and a wing but another might have a wide body kit and a turbo. Totally random and I love it. The cars aren't just different colors too, some have liveries even with drivatars turned off.
AI: I was skeptical when the video came out demonstrating the game for the first time. They said it was their best AI yet and then in the same video the idiot AI all drove a single file line with no use of a racing line and even go off track. But that must have been an early version of the game before the AI was ready because the AI is actually really good. Not the best, but still very challenging. There is one caveat which I explain in the cons below. Above all, the AI doesn't cheat anymore and that was the biggest flaw from the last game.

The cons:
Practice sessions exclusively start you out on a rolling start.
Career races are WAY TOO SHORT! Sometimes just 2 laps around an average size track.
Free play races can still be created so you can come up with your own custom races that are as long as you want, BUT...they don't have the same modes as the Career races. There is no practice and you can't choose your starting position. It is like the free play mode from FM7 where you either choose to start at a random spot or you all get in order of PI. They desperately need to make the career style racing available in free play AND they need to add in custom championships if they want to truly compete with folks like Automobilista and the like.
AI issues: while I praised them up above for finally following a racing line and not cheating...they practice collision avoidance a bit too strongly. They aren't perfect and there are still racing incidents...but here is what I mean. They are overly passive. They fight you right up until you are about a half car ahead and then they straight up pump the brakes...not let off the throttle and let you by, I'm talking straight up pump the brakes and end up like 2 seconds back in a heartbeat. On one hand, they finally show they are smart enough to be aware of your presence, but on the other, they are soft, no other way to put it. We need an aggression slider or at the very least, we need them to let off the throttle instead of hitting the brakes to create distance as it makes it too easy to win a corner.

Performance gets its own section:
Stability: I never had a crash in a race in 64.7 hours. I had one single crash in free play mode testing various settings and constantly reloading the same race over again to see the driver lineups. That was likely self-induced so I ain't worried about it. I had two instances of an infinite loading screen, one trying to start the game up on like day 3. No biggie, killed it and tried again and it worked. The other was when changing parts on a car, it said saving forever and I had to kill the game and start it back up. Lost my changes but it didn't happen again when I made the same changes so it wasn't a repeatable bug tied to any of my changes. Game consistently runs at 90-120fps for me and I love it.
Ray tracing: Bugged at the moment and has horrible stuttering at certain tracks and in certain lighting conditions. I can play with it on but it is too annoying so I turned it off until they patch it. I am not mad, it is a brand new game, let's let them fix it up some.
In addition, the optional ambient occlusion part of ray tracing is awful and causes certain wheels to look like blurry plastic. Wouldn't be a problem if you could turn it off separately but it is linked to the ray tracing mode that effects the track lighting and environments so this is a problem that NEEDS to get fixed.
The V-sync drama - For me, the game will not let me turn V sync off. Normally I want it on but it causes the whole game to lag like crazy and becomes unplayable. I tested at lowest possible settings and still couldn't get a steady 20fps. When I switched to a window it all the sudden ran perfectly. I tested some more and found out that the setting to disable vsync doesn't work and it stayed on no matter what when switching back to full screen. Weird!? Doesn't happen to my buddy so I am annoyed. There is NO BORDERLESS WINDOW MODE so I had to use the NVidia control panel to force vsync off so that I could play it smoothly.
With vsync forced off and ray tracing off, the game is gorgeous and works flawlessly. I run 1440p ultrawide with DLSS at ultra quality with DLAA on and everything is on high or ultra. Even at night and in the fog or rain with 24 cars on track. Running a 3090ti / i9-12900k / 32GBs-DDR5-5200 / 4thGen-NVMe

Conclusion:
The game is not perfect but is extremely fun and has loads of potential. Compared to FM7 on launch which was so bugged and had memory leaks so bad that I couldn't even browse the wheel selection, this game is a godsend. Are you looking to replace something as advanced as iRacing? This isn't it. Are you just looking to get your simrig out of the closet and have a blast with some awesome cars? Join me my friends and have a great day ;)

Posted: October 15
To begin with, I'm an experienced sim racer (iRacing, ACC, GT7, F1, Project Cars, AM, etc.) and had cautious expectations going into this title. I've been trying both controller and wheel (TGT-2) and have some thoughts to help those of you curious about FM. I race with no assists.

For the wheel, the FFB is actually pretty decent once I got the wheel working which isn't supported annoyingly. The FFB accuracy is a touch under GT7 if you consider it a direct competitor and of course ACC/iRacing but way better than the likes of F1 2023 (feeling the limit is important). To my surprise, I could feel the edge of the grip, the weight transferring around, and what the car was doing most of the time. Update 1.0 added some good improvements especially with the tire/tyre model. Throttle control and trail braking are a thing which is nice for the more experienced racers.

The RPG system is so-so but I did feel like a proud papa raising my cars up in career mode, feeling the changes the racing components were making on performance. I can see how many racers don't want to deal with that for every car though but it is what it is. Just make a free race and turn all assists on for auto drive quick leveling while not actively playing.

Speaking of tuning, I'm usually pretty lazy about this in other sims and get setups other tuners but I'm actually liking figuring out my own setups with a loose front for rotation to get that corner exit boost. This is where I believe the RPG system has a purpose in that as you upgrade components and tweak your tune, you see the changes and understand the puzzle in how to piece together a competitive set-up. Shameless plug, look for my tunes in game.

The tracks all look amazing. For now, there are only 20(?) with some variations in layout but according to T10, they will be doing monthly updates so I imagine things like the Nordschleife, Monza, Fuji, Daytona, etc will be added incrementally. Yes there is a bug where the track and/or environment disappears, reminiscent of Rainbow Road in Mario Kart, which I think is really just the shadow realm invading my reality. It's super fun when it happens on the last lap or two but my muscle memory accepts the challenge!

For the AI, P1 and 2 are surprisingly quick sometimes and the others have some pretty liberal driving standards but it kind of adds to entertainment value during the race. Choosing to look at this as an opportunity because lets be honest, I've never met an A.I. that didn't want to punt me off to the realm of shadows, I consider these A.I. races as more practice for "chaos avoidance" in multiplayer. By racing smart and choosing the right opportunities, I've been able to put their shenanigans in my rear view mirror, watching as they fly off into Barry R's firm embrace.

For controller racing, I think with practice, anyone can be just as fast with the wheel if not faster, especially with that birds eye from behind view. The inputs have that same nice feeling as the Horizon series without the "twitchiness" of F1, GT7, and well pretty much everything. Forza is the best out there for it's amazing controller handling.

For the sound design, the engines are a 7/10 with similar characteristics that I'm used to from other sims. The contact sound would benefit from some variation as no matter the degree of impact, it's always the same "clunk."

For multiplayer, I found even at a 4700+/5000 rating there are still bozos everywhere in lobbies but I've had some really good clean battles too. Either put it on pole or employ maximum chaos avoidance by starting from the back and letting all the clowns fly off into Barry R in the races opening turns and you'll be good. The level of competition isn't as stout as iRacing, ACC, or GT7 but driving cars other than meta is always refreshing (finally the WEC Champion Corvette!). Hopefully the skill level improves and the top split races can be better in the future. With the Netcode pretty stable, it's definitely possible to have some thrilling wheel to wheel races with fellow skilled sim racers even with the dreaded low latency warning. Coming to a close with a final note on the format of the races, there are multiple series with multiple tracks per series instead of the same track all week. Variety is the spice of life and it's sure tasty presented in this fashion.

Overall, not being overly entitled and ignorant to the complexities of designing a multi-platform video game, I'm more forgiving when I'm mostly having fun. I don't expect my racing sims to hold my hand through some story arc (I'm looking at you F1) so I don't care about that as I'm just here to go flat out. It's nice to have something to just pick up and race without so much seriousness around my rating like iRacing, ACC, and GT7. Is it perfect? No i.e. bugs, crashes, mid-tune freeze ups. Is my fun factor outweighing these cons? Not anymore after 70+ hours of heartache with all the bugs, especially on the wheel. There is a good foundation that just needs more polishing.

Posted: October 22
Product received for free

Many bugs.... Road disappearing completely, I mean actually disappearing so that you see the void underneath as if the texture is no longer there, and you are still driving on the surface of what was visibly a road. Some artifacting on shadows, surfaces and even the sun beams have artifacted into my face. Very disorientating. Manual+clutch still feels sticky but it is workable, by no means a simulated experience because why would you have some one with a wheel set up be slower than using a controller? Their "advanced ai" are no more than children told to drive real fast, they'll slam into you for no reason, run you off the track... Overall a garbage experience there. Similar to online, really. Only difference is in solo, you are playing a fair field. Online though, if you haven't grinded out your car levels, you'll be matched with players who have properly maxed their cars and be easily left behind 20+ seconds, even if you drive the line perfectly. I know because I maxed out my car(s) before going in and stomped all the stock cars... which would just ram you at their first chance they got. Haven't been able to play a proper race with damage, fuel and tires on because it doesn't feel like anyone wants to play it that way. Go back to FH5, that is the arcade experience you are looking for.

All in all, the game is quarter-baked for a premium price and it definitely shows. Execs should have kept it from the public for another year.

Edit: Patch 1.1 only fixed one or two instances of infinite loading/saving. Still experiencing such in other various scenarios. FPS is better overall, though.

Edit 2: Attempted a long race (100 laps on le man) only got through 60ish laps before the game began to stutter and chop immensely. I know it was the game as this is on a fresh install of windows 11, my hardware is much more than adequate for what graphics settings I was running it on. Thankfully didn't have any issues before this. However, at around lap 88, things began getting really choppy and slow before I received a blue screen of death. All hardware is known working without any issues or over heating problems (memtest and other monitoring programs tell me so) It was meant to be an endurance test of my abilities and the update they released. If I could downvote further than simply saying no, I would. Even though I received this for free, I wish I could receive a refund any way.

Edit 3: November 14th, 2023; Patch seems to have fixed several complaints that I had with the game, namely not being able to run at native aspect ratio/resolution (32:9 5120x1440) and frame rate has been improved (capped 120fps) However, cut scenes are now quite choppy some times. Not a huge deal.

As a long time Forza fan who has played every Forza Motorsport & Horizion series since Forza Motorsport 2 release.. it's hard to recommend FM 2023 in its current state.

I haven't experienced any major performance issues (playing at 4K 60fps w/ 7950X3D & RTX 4090) on Ultra settings with RT on. I've never once dipped below 60fps and I've been playing since early access day one. There were few minor texture bugs here and there but nothing too serious.

My biggest issue with the game is BORING campaign, NOT ENOUGH tracks and the whole leveling up system which is an ABSOLUTE PILE OF ****!!! Leveling up cars entirely ruins the game for me without being able to mod cars, swap engines, swap drivetrains until you grind endlessly and by that point you want to drive something else. Also! Posted: October 16
So far I love the game. The physics are definitely a step up from FM7. That being said, they're a little tricky at first to get a handle on especially on wheel. I'd suggest looking at HokiHoshi's wheel setting guide to get that fixed up. Another tip, throttle control in this game is pretty essential that way you don't hit the gas too hard and eat a barrier on T1. On breaks, same thing. Don't slam them too hard, especially with ABS off that way you don't go sliding off the side of the track.

Graphics/Performance: Its a bit heavier than I'd like on my PC but after messing with the settings, I can push 60 frames at 1440P pretty nicely. The graphics are iffy but I'm hoping with the fact that they're a live service, that they'll fix the issues asap. The lighting is very good in some cases especially in darker scenarios like while its raining or at night. Sometimes the cars lack quality even by Forza standards when going around the tracks, the harsh lighting blotting out some of the detail on the vehicles.
When in regards to crashing, I haven't crashed once or had many issues, if at all playing the game. However, I may be an outlier as I've heard of people having issues with this game. It runs decently well, for me, for the most part. I will say I've had frame drops both before and after Nvidia released nee drivers. I found that racing in the rain with many AI is what hits the game the hardest, especially with LMP and Prototype cars on the track.

Sound: The car sounds in game are very interesting to say the least. Higher pitched car sounds like the 4-rotor in the 787B or the K24 in the CTR sound great. Other cars, like the 2016 Camaro ZL1 are a bit shaky and while the supercharger does sound nice, the exhaust has a muddy sound, even while using a higher end pair of headphones. The turbo sounds are very good, they DO still have that weird "instant spool" the franchise is kind of known for, but the BOV on touring cars or other turboed cars sounds very clean. The RS3 LMS and RX8 single turbo is proof of this. Cars also seem to sound like they properly idle which isn't something I expected but its a nice touch.

Cockpit sounds something that was pretty good in FM& have been greatly improved in this game. They sound much more true to life, and admittedly, I've found myself using the cockpit even more than I'm used to doing in a Forza game.

Camera: There are quite a bit of different camera angles in this game. Chase close, Chase far, cockpit with wheel, cockpit with gauges only, hood, and bumper orientations. Each and every one can have their FOV changed but remember to turn on said setting. There is also a drift camera mode in cockpit, I haven't used to just yet but I feel like it can help with finding the Apex on a track. The sense of speed honestly isn't too bad, better than what FM7 offered.

Menu/UI: For the most part I'm alright with it. However, for someone that's just playing this game, they might not be able to find the "Restart race" button right away. At the time of writing this review, you simply go as if you're quitting a race and it happens to pop up in a sub-menu, along with, the ability to quit the race right below it. There's other gripes too like I also have a weird flickering line on the border of my screen but its not enough to bother me, plus I only ever see it whilst on the main menu.

Customization: Here it comes. I love the game and the fact I have to actually level up my car like a proper RPG. Why? Its proper progression and I'm relieved that I can't immediately go in and toss a centrifugal supercharger or a new engine in my RX8 for example. Yes, its not for everyone, but for something that lacked progression in its previous game in the series, I think this is a step in the right direction. I do think its a shame though it takes a while to earn things like bodykits for the car. I do wish we had more body customization, but I'm relieved to see a wide variety of rims.
The Car Point aspect (I'm not abbreviating that lol) is a mixed bag for me as I do enjoy balancing out my points across car stuff, but on the other hand, it can frustrate me a bit whenever I have to debate whether to go for handling over speed constantly instead of a mix of both.

Physics: AS I said before, its a bit shaky to start with at first, but overtime it becomes much easier to drive once you get the hang of it. I suggest changing the deadzones for the breaking and acceleration when you first get the game. It helps quite a bit and makes the game enjoyable. "its not super realistic!!!!" Well, its a sim-cade. Its got simulator aspects and arcade aspects combined into its physics style. While the physics themselves are much more realistic than FM7, its clear that they didn't push too far into sim category to the point where Controller people wouldn't be able to enjoy it. That being said, the "Simulation" option for steering feels much better on a wheel, especially once you adjust settings for it whether you got a Direct-drive or a gear-driven/belt-driven wheel. I use the G920 and after adjusting some settings, I found the game very enjoyable. I love driving around Spa, Mid-Ohio, and the Hockenheimring.

Track selection and car selection: The track selection isn't too bad to be honest. Its a shame Nordschliefe isn't in the game, but the tracks overall HAVE been redesigned so I suppose it does makes sense that brutal of a track doesn't exist in the game just yet. They do have the GP circuit for the Nurburgring though. For cars on the other hand, this being Motorsport means there is a lot more Motorsport oriented cars in the roster. So far, I've been enjoying the LMP cars quite a bit. Some other cars I expected to cross to FH5 originally like the RX-3 and the Pininfarina Battista. Oh yea, for 22B lovers, they remodeled or at least improved the models on the Subaru 22B.

Overall I rate this game a 8 out of 10. I love it but many issues or oddities within the game itself me from pushing it to a 10/10.

Posted: October 10
Is it fun? Oh yes it is, very fun. The driving is lively, the gamepad controls are tight and after 3 hours it reminds me of a fun crating day with my mates. It's arguably the best FM game in driving and racing department since... Ever? Great job, lads!

Is it broken? Oh yes, it's a Yugo Zastava of gaming at the moment. Let's ignore server issues altogether (they can be fixed fast). The car leveling system is grindy, abysmal, rewards you with BASIC FEATURES IN OTHER GAMES, and kinda useless. The visuals is all over the place. It's stuttery, assets and overall presentation are inconsistent and to be quite honest, you need to retire half of car models already. Sometimes it's kinda pretty, but overall it looks like an Xbox One game with added (and broken) RTX mods.

And just like the liquids in Yugo it's prone to leak (memory). It's also crashes a lot, like a test dummy. Like Yugo's speedometer FPS is floating around solid 30's. On an 3080 in 2K with RTX off. There are a lot of visuals bugs too, like broken LODs, broken car spawning and othe Cyberpunk 1.0 worthy type of weirdness.

AI acts like your mates on M25: hit or miss. Usually they hit you and miss apexes to javelin into your rear. AI is prone to cheat at difficulty 3+ with better tyres too and career balance feels broken to be honest.

Launch content is simply barebones as a Soviet-era Lada Riva. Career is 40+ something races and that's it. Finished like 20% of the entire SP in 3 hours. And no Green Hell on launch in 2023? COME ON!

Wheel support is hot trash, it is so counterintuitive to calibrate T300RS that I've gave up. Gamepad support is good though.

Overall, there is somewhat engaging driving sim that is buried somwhere beneath this early access title, but you should consider it only after Turn10 performs a few long pit-stops. It's clearly not worth your time now.

They have killed Halo, and now it's Forza.

I've been a Forza Player ever since the first release. I've played every single major release (Motorsport+Horizon) and I am confident in saying that this game only has 1 thing going for it at launch.

And that's the driving simulation. They have really enhanced the simulation quality and the cars feel very nice to drive, you can even get to that point.

Because, the mingin' performance makes the game unplayable, the graphics, ironically, look really bad, don't deliver on promises made in the initial marketing push for the game, and don't properly work and the car models vary widely in quality.
Almost every single enhancement Forza Horizon 5 brought has successfully been ignored, as evidenced by the old photo mode, barely functioning RT+Upscaling features, old car models and very bad sounds for a lot of the cars.

Adding to that, the progression in the career is controversial at best and a complete show-stopper at worst.

And all that while the game isn't nearly feature-complete at a price of 80€ or more?

I'm not even accounting for all the features lost. Stuff like a proper choice of body kits, proper visual damage, visually consequential upgrades, good engine sounds and MUCH more.

Don't even consider buying this game, like, ever. Not, if you're a Forza fan, not, if you're in desparate need of a new racing game. Just don't give them the light of day, for this pile of vile slideshow.
And, while others aren't exactly wrong about recommending FH5 instead, it's easy to see, where this game went wrong, because that game has its fair share of issues, as well, even though its launch has passed a while ago.

For this amount of money, you can easily buy a stack of very good older and indie games. There are so many good games you might have never heard about. ~15 fun experiences vs this waste of time and money. Or even better yet, spend that money on yourself. Your choice.
