Posted: October 7
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I hate to downvote a game this cute, but to be honest, I was surprised about all the upvotes it's getting. The gimmick of building a city on the back of the six legged turtle is a fun idea, but it really has almost no actual gameplay impact - the world map seems interesting at first, but it surves no real purpose and doesn't really add much to the game due to everything being so random and so repetitive. If there was a larger view, maybe you'd have to think and consider going to a forrest for a few years or something like that, but the way it's now it's just 'pick the path that doesn't lead to a biome that will hurt your people' and that's it. Any interaction with the overworld also quickly turns into a mindless chore - send out endless exploring parties who with almost zero interaction return with resources you don't really care about and repeat, over and over.

That would be fine if it was an aspect of an otherwise good city builder, but that's just it - the base game is not a good city builder. It gets the mechanics right, but its like a soulless bureocrat was told about city builders and designed one - gather wood, gather stone, build homes, gather food, get more people, build farms, improve wood and stone, research better buildings. If someone held a gun to your head and forced you to come up with the most generic city builder, this is what would come out. None of it is done badly, it's just very bland and in no aspect have I seen anything inventive or interesting to set it apart from other games in the genre.

At $5 I would probably still have been left somewhat disappointed. It is by no means a bad game, just also not a good one.

Posted: September 19, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I'm honestly a bit torn on this game.

First of all, it's quite fun to play. The mechanic to basically keep your mount "alive" is interesting, there's a lot of different buildings you can utilize and the "world map" feature in which you can basically send out scavenger squads to harvest resources (like in frostpunk, for example) is good and fun and. The building system is also quite simple and not very complex, which might be a plus for many people, personally, I'd prefer a little bit more depth.

I did have a lot of fun with the game, but there's also major gripes:

First of all, while the "keep your mount alive" part is interesting, it's also unnecessary - you have to feed the thing once every 30 minutes and that's it. I've build the doctor hut for it and not once did I have to use it besides healing a poison once, and I could've just not done that. It's a badly balanced mechanic that doesn't really serve any purpose and just occupies a handful of villagers, you have to manually turn the buildings on and off to free them so they can do something more useful.

Second, the graphics. While they are not bad by any means and the creature you're riding on is gorgeous, the village and the villager itself are all 2D and this vastly downgrades the visual fidelity. I don't know why they made the decision to create the game in 2D - potentially because of a small team and not enough resources to create a 3D or at least 2.5D game, but it's a major factor that really rubs me the wrong way.

The last problem is simple - content. You can finish a run in about 3 - 4 hours. Your last task is to build a big statue that costs a few advanced resources (which you should honestly have at the end of the run) and then it basically transforms into endless mode. The problem is that every run feels roughly the same. The map doesn't change, the biomes don't change - you start the same way every time and there is no variety. That's vastly different in other games in the genre - again, I use frostpunk as example. Frostpunk has edicts, so you can alter the ideology of your town. You can be a highly christian authoritarian that basically creates the nazi-vatican that forces children to work in coal mines or you can become the benevolent mayor of your little ice city. Also, there is a variety of maps in the game, so every playthrough is different. This is completely missing in the wandering village. It's just the same run over and over again.

Overall, I think the game is a bit lacking and the only reason why I'm recommending this is because it's still early access. I have high hopes for the game and if the devs pull the right strings, they could easiely make a great game ouf of this.

Overall:
I think the game is good for the people that already enjoy city builders, for those that don't I would say probably either wait for more content or pass on it, as it stands I enjoyed my first run but by about hour 3 I was realizing the monotony that comes with just adding farms and waiting to add more people to my colony, In my opinion I think more crops with a dedicated cold crop would be better to break up the monotony of just spamming beets/wheat/berries, as for tech I would like to see some kind of teraforming tech to turn certain parts to dirt and certain parts to farmland as a late game tech.

TL;DR 6.5/10 for me, though i dont love samey city builders so it may change for you, certainly try it if its on sale

Posted: May 11
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
As this is an Early Access review, the first thing I need to make clear is that the Wandering Village I played was fully functional. The worst I can say about its performance is that I could tell when it was auto-saving due to a brief stutter... on 4x speed. It even ran as well on the Steam Deck, despite a handheld not being the best choice for a city builder.

That's not to say the controller support was lacking. It all worked great and was as intuitive as a genre that was so clearly set up for point-click-hover mouse control could possibly be.

There was also a complete game's worth of content, with enough variation in the technology trees and environment challenges to keep things all-engrossing until the game said it was over. That isn't to say you weren't perfectly allowed to keep playing the mobile mesa you'd built for five times as long, just that there wasn't enough new to discover or react to for all of that extra time to remain rewarding.

Everything else about the Wandering Village experience is exactly as advertised, though I never did feel the need to zoom down to my villagers' eye line. The casual, nature-focused art style was supported by a New Age-y, lost-to-time soundtrack that I would have called repetitive if it didn't fit the mood so well. Together, they can almost convince you that the world's not so harsh after all. If you can avoid the temptation to let your guard down, you might survive, even thrive, in a land covered in poisonous plants set against just that.

Posted: October 2, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I definitely recommend it, but there are some tentative parts I'll explain.

The Wandering Village is a pretty unique management game. You indirectly control your villagers by essentially pointing out the things you want done and then giving that task a priority. Villagers also work at structures that they build, which takes away from your fluid labor force (general workers). While you're checking on them, you're also riding a freakin' giant walking animal because your only other choice is a life of poison and death on the ground. So you also need to keep Onbu--the creature you ride--alive. You do this by feeding, healing, and curing. But you can also guide Onbu when you gain it's trust, which is especially important when it comes to the biomes you will come across and what you feel prepared for. You could also choose to forego the trust and simply take from the beast and deal with what comes. In short, you have to juggle a lot of important matters, sometimes a few all at once.

Starting out, the tutorial does a good job of explaining what needs to be done, but I feel it could emphasize the trust mechanic with Onbu better. Specifically explaining the benefits of valuing trust vs. ignoring it. There is a lot to learn, so it's possible I missed a few details as well, but the nice thing about the game is how it rewards patience and being observant. You may eventually answer your own question about something just by continuing to play. I find it challenging to manage, but extremely satisfying and relaxing when things just work out. But they don't always work out and you can easily cause a lot of problems for yourself if you're not careful. I managed to avoid dying a couple of times, but even now at 16 hours, I'm in a tight spot again. The challenge doesn't let up, but I actually appreciate that.

My biggest problems are mostly related to it being in Early Access. I want more content, more dynamic systems (why even have worker huts, really?), and I'd like a bit more story. I'm also finding that stone is a difficult resource to keep stocked, particularly in the late game. There are some random encounters you can experience along the way and I found out that they seem to repeat more often than I'd like. I'd definitely appreciate more variety there. And lastly, while I don't hate the price, it is pretty high for what you get. But, to be fair, if everything on their Early Access roadmap is implemented, it's easily worth that price.

Overall, I have had a fantastic time being awake until 2 am on multiple sessions because there's always more to do and more to improve. It really sucked me in for a good while. I highly recommend it if you want a more unique take on managing a small civilization.

Also, I'd die for my Onbu.

Posted: September 16, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
If video games are themselves a tech tree, "Banished" unlocks a lot of different other games. Itself "what if Sim City but production chains," you can up the game aspects and come up with Timberborn, lower them and get Age of Man, add in more narrative and get Frostpunk, up the individuality and you get Rimword, up the production chain detail and get One More Island, up the detail and realism and get Farthest Frontier and so on. Yeah, this isn't literal, don't @ me about chronology.

The Wander Village is what if Banished, but a strategic layer. Strategic layers are fun ideas that usually don't work too well, because inevitably it means jamming one game onto another game, and one of the pair will suffer. Even when it works, it doesn't work.

The Wandering Village is the exception because the strategic layer is intuitive. It's a big animal, it gets hungry, tired, and sick. It takes care of itself, but does better with some attention, and needs more the later in the game and the harder the environment. It takes the place of what might be the military aspect of a different game, and like the best implementations of those feels wrapped tightly in, creating a wide spectrum of choices and ways to develop.

I suspect that the tech tree and food will be tinkered with, and the UI has some frustrations. There is no ability to determine the sex of the rock dinosaur, which, come on devs, you're leaving a solid Discworld gag lying right there. I'm undecided on whether the event pacing is right, but that will make a difference for the replayability. It feels priced correctly in terms of what you get now, so it's recommendable in early access, and more about whether anything gets screwed up in the finalization of the game rather than what more gets added.

So, while it depends on what you're looking for out of a city builder, this is a recommend if you like them.

Posted: September 15, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
BLUF: Beautiful Game that needs balancing, but stands enough on its own two feet to be an introduction to city builders.

This game has a lot of heart. I know how dumb that sounds in the modern gaming market, but you get that feeling at every step of this game, from the art style to the music and sound effects, it all plays together well and you can tell a lot of focus went into it.

Currently, however, I cant in good faith recommend it for one reason. Balancing. This games balancing is all over the place, the biggest culprit of which is food production. In games similar to this, food production is always that little bug buzzing in your ear and is to be expected. However, those other games have the luxury of map space, while this does not. Compounding the issue, is that no matter how big you make your farm on your limited area or how much you staff it, the farmers will refuse to cultivate more than 10 plots of the farm. This leads to famine, every time. Yes, you could build more farms, but the problem will still persist. My working theory is that you need 1 farm per 10 people (possibly 8), and need 5 of them to run the farm. So for every 10 people, you only get 5 actual workers, which then sends a ripple effect to the other production and housing systems. Which sucks, because the bio system they have for best crop types per biome, is a refreshing idea that cant be fully utilized.

Hopefully its just a bug and not something hard coded to be like that for the illusion of always behind.


Edit: Had to turn off comments. Because wow. Who knew giving a dissenting opinion based on your experience would rustle this many jimmies? People legitimately felt attacked by this review.

What's best about it? It's nice to have survival city builder which offers something more than simply building and managing your city. You have to pay attention to the map and keep alive the creature that carries your village. It's a fun take on city builder. Also, Onbu is really cute.

Posted: December 24, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
So lets start off with discussing what i see to be reoccurring criticism and my experience with it.

Difficulty:
Yes when playing on the normal difficulty, it definitely felt easy, as someone who has played games like this quite a bit

Simulation:
This is far from the simulations provided in Dwarf Fortress and Rim World and you certainly lack the same level of development and control that these provide in that aspect.

Now with those in mind your probably asking yourself "ok so why are you recommending it" and thats because despite those two things its still really fun and really niche. Your not just managing your villagers and village you also have to keep in mind that the giant rock dragon ur on is important to ur survival. Maintaining trust by feeding him and healing him so you can help direct him around the world, and avoid storms. Also the fact your on the back of a giant dinosaur means you have to put way more thought into managing space and resources, since their not quite infinite. While resources can be gain by scouts going out into the world to gain resources from off dino sights, its never going to be as much as you gain from the back of puff the magic dragon. Its a super cute, and interesting idea that is embodied brilliantly. The game is still early access, and i only see it getting better, as of now its definitely a great game that i recommend, with a higher difficulty if you need that. definitely a solid 20 hours of a few runs and even more if you want to seek those achievments and such. Im excited to see where this game goes next!

Great game, would definitely recommend.

Posted: September 18, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This is a wonderfully atmospheric and accessible city-builder where you juggle the needs of your growing village with the usual - managing food, water, housing, health etc - as well as the needs of your enormous animal host, Onbu.

The game sells this symbiosis well, with Onbu moving you onwards from biome to biome; bringing you access to new resources and temperatures, which determine which crops you can grow, the scarcity of water, and the toxicity-levels from (the presumably apocalyptic amounts of) pollution that has reduced the world to the smattering of ruins and nomad tribes left for you to encounter throughout the game.

If you like the atmosphere in , then its heavy influence on this game's design will light a fire in you.

It is well fleshed-out for an Early-Access title, with integrated facility to provide feedback and bug-reports in-game. Its early-access launch content was enough to keep me entertained for a solid week or so, and I can see that growing exponentially as the game increases in complexity with the addition of new biomes, events, stories, and goals. I'm excited to see the project grow, and to check-back after launch to see what's been added!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
First of all: not worth $25 in its current state, unless you're really starving for city building/survival content.

It's a chill city builder with a nice twist - riding on the back of a giant "animal" in an apocalyptic world which is constantly changing biomes. There isn't super micro managing of your citizens like rimworld or banished. That being said, it's still more hands on than "plop building down and wait for more resources". The changing biomes allow for swapping priorities/planning. It comes complete with a tech tree however its nothing to write home about. You can send out scouting parties much like FrostPunk however, the missions are more repetitive and less lore building. Zero late game as its still early Early Access.

TL;DR Promising, relaxed city builder that still requires planning, however due to its lack of current depth is only worth during decent sale.

Posted: September 14, 2022
Product received for free

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
SDHQ STEAM DECK PERFORMANCE REVIEW:


Follow our curator page for more Steam Deck reviews



The Game Itself:

I want to start by saying that this game is awesome. I have personally been following it for months and it has lived up to my hopes. The game's graphics are colorful and vibrant and the gameplay feels satisfying so far. You build a city on the back of a giant, taking care of not only your people, but the beast as well. This is a city-builder, it doesn't really break many boundaries in that regard, but the addition of developing a trusting relationship the beast you live on is an exciting new element. Now, you have to take care of and develop trust with the monster, or he will rustle his back and destroy...everything...Overall though, I think the game has a lot going for it and I am excited to see where this heads through the Early Access lifepspan.



I was warned by the developers that the game wasn't made with the Steam Deck in mind, though they will be adding in optimization and support over time. I am pleased to say I am not worried as the game runs pretty well on the Deck! For the most part, the game hits 60 FPS and sticks to a 4+ hour battery life. There are really only 3 snags I think come up with the game.

The biggest is controller layout. The game was very obviously made for keyboard and mouse play, which makes sense given the type of game it is. Thanks to Steam Input's versatility though, we created a community controller layout named "SDHQ Steam Deck V1". This control scheme maps some necessary inputs around, like using a radial menu with the left trackpad and mapping game speed to the Dpad. You still need to use your mouse cursor, which is mapped to the right analog stick and right trigger to emulate left click as well as the right trackpad for more precise movements.

The other issue is a bit of a framerate drop when the game is loading your village back in after being far away. The game drops to around 30-40 FPS for around 5 seconds, but will then bounce right back up, so it isn't a huge issue. The text is also a bit small, but for a game like this, I would say it is okay, though I would love to see a text-scaling option in the future.

Overall, I was really impressed and super pleased to see how well everything worked out of the box. The Wandering Village also has cloud saves, which are fantastic if you also play on a desktop, and a native Linux build! I expect to be playing this a lot more and look forward to seeing the optimizations and more to make the Steam Deck experience even better.

Posted: September 15, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Overall this is a great game in a similar vein to Frostpunk and Timberborn. Currently there's a decent amount of content and I "finished" the starting difficulty after about 5-6 hours with a final population of just over 100 villagers. I don't have any major gripes with the game and am excited to see what new features are added as the game progresses through early access.

The core game-play loop of keeping your colony content, healthy and fed while also maintaining your relationship with your rock-doggo "Onbu" is solid. It feels satisfying when Onbu begins to trust your commands and you can better plan out your colony based on what biomes or events you will run into.

The UI is clean and straightforward, but I do wish there was an "advanced" option that gave more insight into historical data for production and consumption of resources. Currently you can view your overall food use/production in the past 24 hours, as well as how many of each resource are currently "reserved", but that's about it. The fact that there's no dedicated UI element for water production/consumption is a large oversight in my opinion. Similarly, I think it would be beneficial for there to be more information regarding how long it takes or the specific mechanics of curing poisoned villagers. The game states that villagers will automatically seek aid from doctors, but I found that even with two fully staffed medical stations on opposite ends of my colony, a handful of villagers would just keep working until they died, walking right past idle doctors.

The art style fits the game brilliantly, with the 3D and 2D assets blending together in a cohesive way. The art style is flexible enough to make the game feel both bright and charming at times, while at the same time allowing for the environment to feel threatening and deadly when needed.

The music isn't anything to write home about, but it fits the theme of the game, and helps raise the feeling of anxiety as you pass through dangerous territory. The soundtrack might not be as anxiety inducing as something like Frostpunks, but it matches the game quite well and doesn't feel too repetitive.

Overall, it's a game that feels well rounded and "complete". It has a clear direction, and I have certainly enjoyed the available content. I'm excited to see what changes and additions the devs will bring, and will return for a new play-through each update.

This game is a nice little game if you just want to chill out and have quite an enjoyable ride on a big stupid beast. Because it is really, really stupid. Amicable, but boy is it stupid. But let's start at the beginning:
The game basically drops you with a little background story onto Onbu. Further story has not been implemented yet. So you ride this big doofus and try to make your living while satisfying its frankly quite humble needs.
With a catchy nice soundtrack and decent UI the game is entertaining while new research achievements keep you interested in exploring new options. While this is going on, although you have been the nicest you could ever have been to it, Onbu basically chooses to not obey you in the worst possible situations, running directly through every poison cloud and tornado he can find. It's like it's trying to get rid of you, but you hold on, you keep petting it and hope for the best.
The game is not too hard on easy, but you have to prepare for harder times. With mediocre decisions, you can lose and poisoned plants can overwhelm you if you are ill prepared or not reacting quick enough. After all, it was not too hard to progress on easy mode and explore the game in its entirety.

Being in early Access, the game has it's flaws. While some production lines seem very unnessessary (Tree Nursery and Forester, you really don't need that much wood), other resources seem extremely hard to get by (for me it was stone, harvesting spikes and deep mining both hurt Onbu which at some point I really stopped caring about since the imbecile dinosaur doesn't listen anyway). The Onbu Constipator seems useless and just a bad tradeoff in comparison to the Energy Booster. The food pump really does not seem to give you any advantage since it's really not that hard to stack food and mushrooms while just flinging the food into it's kisser improves its mood. These are probably easy-to-fix issues.

After 10 hours on easy mode I came to the point where I discovered all useful research, built everything I wanted, built the endgame milestone and the game had no further objective other to maybe research everything else. So i did that, 5 more hours went by and i am done having seen everything in the game. While having enjoyed the time, that's a bit too little. But it's early access and there's a roadmap, promising some story, better interaction with Onbu and I am really looking forward to it!

After all, I loved my asinine Onbu (even if it didn't love me) and look forward to play it again when it's a bit more polished, since the gameplay was good and fun!

PS: I love my Onbu, no Onbus were harmed in the making of this review. It's a really retarded lizard, though.

Posted: September 18, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Really neat idea for a management game! Having to take care of Onbu as well as your villagers puts an interesting twist into gameplay.

Pros:
I really enjoyed the toxic plants effect, since it can get out of control very quickly and requires you to make quick, sweeping decisions to control the spread of the infection. Things can get very harrowing very quickly depending on how unlucky you are - I had a toxic plants effect then an earthquake right afterward in the early game which was definitely a fun challenge to recover from. I also never ran into any bugs or performance issues, and the art style is absolutely beautiful and unique.

Cons:
My biggest gripe is that the game could use some balancing. I played on the hardest difficulty and never really had too many issues. The hardest part of the game is getting established within the first 1 - 2 hours. Once you build a couple decontaminators + blie extractor, and get Onbu to like you enough to always listen to your commands, then the game gets pretty easy. Berry collectors/farms are ridiculously productive and I never felt like I was desperate enough to harvest blood or do anything to make Onbu lose trust in my decisions. To challenge myself, I just completely stopped using the hornblower because being able to fully control Onbu's actions is just too OP right now. There's also some sound issues - I noticed that the background music will sometimes just end abruptly rather than smoothly transitioning when you move into a different biome.

Conclusion:
Overall a really unique, well put-together game with a ton of potential. Since the game is early access I'm definitely willing to forgive some of the balance issues, as I'm sure they'll get ironed out.

Posted: September 14, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
TL:DR: I do enjoy the game, but would recommend it on sale for cheaper than current price, as there isn't enough content to justify $25.


REALLY wish Steam had a Neutral rating for reviews, as this is a perfect example of good and bad all in one. I'd recommend it at a cheaper price due to the lack of content right now.

It took me 10 hours to do after learning everything to play efficiently, but I reached the "endgame"
Day 290. Endgame? Nope, we must keep walking to survive! 
A Screenshot of The Wandering Village


The Good:
Decent art style - Reminds me of Studio Ghibli. It's a very relaxing look to an otherwise dark game (you are trying to survive the deadly poison plants).

Good Atmosphere - The game presents itself in a manner fit of the art style. It's very nice and works well.

Progression - You can unlock tech at your own pace, but face being left behind if something goes wrong. Some tech requires knowledge obtainable from Shrines with scavenger parties.


The Bad:
Shallow Game-play - It's a very linear game, directing or letting the Onbu walk down two set paths: North and South. You also have a few multi-choice selections for what I'd call 'special events'.

No real goal posts at the moment - Once you unlock everything in the tech tree, you just keep on trucking. There's not really an end to the game per-se, more of when you want it to end.

No real in depth simulation - Everything is extremely cut and dry, with no real dynamic systems in place to alter game-play to a point where it would snap me out of just monitoring my village and Onbu.

There is also no good way for me to see what tasks are being done and what is completed. I wish I had a chart for that stuff without needing to click on every individual. It makes seeing what needs to be done or checking progress much more tedious.

Poison plants can break stone roads, which is all fine and dandy as it stops you from walling off parts of the map from poison plants, but it also forces me to use my resources to fix it every time it happens, and it gets old fast.

You will find it hard to gauge when the Onbu will listen to every command you give it until it starts doing the happy dance and wagging it's tail when you travel. Otherwise it's a guessing game until that point and a gauge to see it would be great.



I'm sure with time it'll turn into a great game, but at this point it's not a game for $25. If it was priced around $10 it'd be a steal.


Edit: Opened up comments as I've now played pretty far into the game and now feel confident in answering questions.I've also started fleshing out the review.


(The review will stay negative until I feel that I can confidently have it as a positive. Just because it's negative, doesn't mean I don't enjoy the game.)

Posted: July 23
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
TL;DR: S'alright. Design issues and lack of content. Will recommend if it improves. I really want it to.



The art is very appealing and the setting is AMAZING with so many unique possibilities. Unfortunately though I can't recommend it. Fair enough I got almost 8 hours out of it but with colony sims I really expect something more. And it wasn't necessarily a memorable 8 hours.

I blew through more or less the whole tech tree and I never really broke a sweat. I played on the normal difficulty and I could switch to a harder difficulty, sure, but I feel like I already saw everything there is to see and it became very repetitive.

Gripes:
-Scavenging is annoying micro management more than interesting decision making
-No reason not to play on max speed
-A lot of the buildings you just toggle on when you need them and toggle off immediately after if you want to play optimally. Or just leave them manned and idle because you can't be bothered anymore.
-Biomes are rather short lived and repetitive
-Biomes don't actually change the way you play. You just switch some crops around if you walk into a desert, and it's sad to see the core premise of a wandering village be solved by three or four mouse clicks once an hour.
-Exclusively the ocean biome has unique tech for it that is only usable in the ocean biome. No other biome is like that. It's weird.
-No events really caused any worry or concern
-Most difficult part of the game was finding a spot to place my big end game decoration
-Nothing shocking or surprising happened in the play through. You know... some dwarf fortress style "FUN"
-No choices to make a run unique. I guess I can choose to be cruel to the animal or not but regardless I will still need to heal it, cure it and pet it and then harvest it's blood for food variety and it's bile for fighting the poison.

Again, I love the art and setting, there is so much potential. Just needs to work out some design issues and add a lot more content. I am looking forward to changing my review.

Posted: April 1
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
The game is fun, but there's some pretty frustrating aspects to it. At the moment, my review is negative, but I intend to change it when more improvements are made.

1. As other reviewers have said, the lack of an overarching goal beyond "don't die" isn't doing it for me.
2. Villages die *WAY TOO EASILY*. No food for a few in-game hours? Boom, your population is cut in half. These people have the energy reserves of mayflies. In fact, as far as I can tell (not scientific), being poisoned takes longer to kill them than not eating.
3. I don't like that I can't zoom out to see more of the village without going into the "See the Onbu" view. This tripped me up dozens of times when I was trying to apply priorities to harvesting over a wide area.
4. I *hated* having to micro manage harvesting rocks and trees. This is something that should be happening automatically. Either make harvesters at the workpost auto-harvest, or make builders that need stone go get stone, or make stonecutters who are out of stone go get stone. The villagers aren't stupid, they aren't going to sit on their thumbs and say "Gee, i really need stone, but that rock that i'm looking at hasn't been marked as harvest-able by the village leader, so i guess instead of building the granary that we need to not starve to death, i'll just chill".
5. I very much did not enjoy having to manually set priorities after setting something to be harvested. Make it a single click-and-drag.
6. Double clicking on something (e.g. poison plants, rocks, trees, so on) should auto select all of the things of that type that are visible on the screen.
7. There is no UI indicator on how much the Onbu trusts the village, major information gap, and the player may not even realize the Onbu isn't following commands like which direction to walk in. Took me 4 times before i even realized.
8. My Onbu decided to sleep in the middle of a toxic storm within 5 minutes of starting the game. Really? That's not OK. The Onbu shouldn't be suicidal. It's one thing for it to refuse to run through something dangerous, it's an entirely different thing to have it literally lay down and take a nap while it's being actively harmed. At worse it should slow down to a crawl, but never sleep.
9. I randomly had my Onbu go from 100 health to 20 health without any kind of UI indication, or explaination. I could not figure out if it was caused by environment damage, or something that I was doing, or what. The game needs to make the health of the Onbu significantly more in-your-face. Any damage at all should cause a noise and UI ping, and lots of damage in a short period of time should force the player to pay attention.
10. My Onbu walked through a thunderstorm, and half of my buildings were destroyed. Unacceptable. Something that took me 20+ minutes of real-world time to put together demolished in under 20 seconds with no warning. I literally shut the game down when this happened because I was forced to go find every building that was destroyed and click "rebuild". Buildings need to be able to survive no less than 3 damaging events before being demolished. Add a repair and/or maintainence mechanic to give the player flexibility on "fix" verses "rebuild". But just demolishing half my buildings, and then requiring several minutes of busy clicking to ask for them to be rebuilt is rage-quit level of bad design.
11. I unlocked huts, an upgrade to tents. I clicked two tents to be demolished to make room for a hut. It took 10 minutes for my villagers to actually demolish the tents, they were apparently off doing who knows what. Demolishing buildings is very short time cost, so it should implicitly be prioritized above other tasks.
12. Allow the player to place buildings over other buildings, with a confirmation box asking if they're sure. I should not have to *first* destroy the existing buildings, wait for the villagers to get around to it, then remember to check back to see if i can place the new building.
13. I absolutely do not like the "Change out your crops when the Onbu moves to a new biome" mechanic. If you're going to keep this mechanic, then allow me to set a schedule that tells the villagers what crop to plant in which biome. The player should *NOT* be needing to micromanage this.
14. Kitchen produces 3 polenta for 3 corn. Am I not understanding something about the food mechanic? as far as I can tell, this provides the exact same amount of "food" per crop, but by adding 1-3 villager's worth of labor to it. Change it to be like the other crops early, 3->5.
15. I don't like that the Herbalist is it's own stand-alone building, when it's literally just a farm with a different name. The healing herbs should be just a different crop to pick from in the list.
16. Same with the mushrooms. The mycologist should be merged into the farm building.
17. Add dirt crops. One to start the game with, and then another set of researched crops that can be unlocked.
18. I hate the cactus farming mechanic. It's a very labor intensive solution that can be easily worked around by building a crapton of air-wells to tide the village over.
19. Why can't I tap into the Onbu to get water? We can get blood to make blackpudding, but not water?
20. Not being able to rotate buildings is very annoying.

I love the fresh take of a city/survival builder and the need to find and create your own resources through exploration and different world regions on the back of a large friend. Besides the current shortness of the game, my only real complaint so far is the ai of the villagers and onbu, not much of a story, and the lack of a more versatile research tree; but as the studio has already made it clear they will be working on these, i will be content to wait!
((I love you Onbu. Your happiness means everything to me))

Posted: September 16, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game is definitely not finished yet, but it's definitely good. Right now it feels they want to set up "hard choices" of helping or hurting the Onbu (giant), Helping or hurting Nomads along the way, and chosing paths (both literal and tech); BUT those choices are sorta of both forced and not important.

For instance, Onbu "Trust" is the only stat you DON'T see, and it's also the only thing that seems fickle. I can break the creature trust by hurting it all day, so long as I just Feed and Pet it at the last second before making a request it seems to obey. Meanwhile if I have long ago done nothing but love and never broke it's trust.. it seems to never let me choose which way to turn at crossroads.

Same problem with wandering nomads and decisions for poisoned nomads, etc. Since there is no reputation system, acting like giving medicine or water to them means anything is pointless. They either give me nothing, more people, or I "roleplay" that I feel bad that some people might die. I'm never rewarded for helping people out, and never shown consequences for letting everyone die around me.
Now, that being said; mechanically giving them my resources to get more people and things so that my town gets bigger and stronger still works; so THAT part still works. So that game still works in early access. Like I said, the game is set up so long as the developers know it's not finished yet.

The feel of the game is great. The Game Cycles is about dealing with the change of biomes. As your Onbu walks around you need to constantly shift what you grow, what you harvest, and what your scavenge so that you are ahead of the problems. The difficulty is that the hazards ahead get worse and worse the farther you walk, but so do some of the potential bonuses and tech. So you must grow fast enough to take advantage of those things in time to "win".

The win is usually when you have out "teched" the hazards enough to not worry too much about them. The only problem I had with the game in this is that it was self aware of this problem and so it created a buffer to stop this. Late tech required "knowledge points" to complete it. The only want to get this is from random scavenge points on the map. This means RNG can make you wait to do tech. Mix this up with the fact that some resources are only found from scavenge points and you need those for some buildings to build those late tech buildings... and you're stuck playing the game longer than you need to be to "win" the game.

TLDR; The game has enough potential for me in just the feel it brings to play recommend it, but it has built in mechanical enforced length. It's only the late, late game; but it still sucks to just wait around for RNG for new things in a game. Buy if you're okay for 10-20 good hours of game while waiting for updates or to support the game. I can definitely see myself playing it a different way in my second/third play through which is a big win for any city builder.

Posted: October 9, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
What a wonderful little game, a wholesome new spin on city builders! Though a fairly short game as the game technically "ends" at day 100 but you can continue to play for what i assume is forever. But despite being relatively short, i have no doubt it will be beefed out throughout development and i cannot wait for what the devs have in store! I have played this on all difficulties and I feel like the difficulties need defining and tuning more. Beginner and intermediate feel the same and the hardest difficulty is only hard until you have 30+ villagers and the main essential buildings researched, the late game seems the same on all modes.

Pros:
. Wonderful immersive music that change in each biome.
. Onbu is adorable and its fun looking after his needs and keeping him safe.
. Good AI
. Very stable game, never encountered any bugs or crashes.
. Outstanding use of 3D and 2D assets resulting in an adorable art style.

Cons:
. Early access always has its risks.
. Relatively short game.
. Fairly easy difficulties.
. Some crops wont be used as much as others as some need very specific biomes that I never seemed to be in that often, so villagers always complain about their diet.
. Sometimes the villagers wont build or harvest something until you make it a priority even if there is a low workload.

Suggestions:
(I understand that some of these might even be in development already)

. Greenhouses so you can grow crops in all biomes.
. Barns/coops and livestock.
. Make difficulties more distinct.
. Villagers age and have kids.
. Schools for kids giving educated villagers boosts.
. The ability to do more with mushrooms (eg. mushroom soup for your villagers)
. Be able to make more foods with a combination of crops (eg. Berry pie: wheat + berrys, tomato & mushroom soup etc)
. More crops (eg. potatoes, onions etc)
. Meet other Onbu and maybe make Onbu caravans were you use balloons for villagers to get from one Onbu to another.
. Bandit raids on your Onbu + a barracks/garrison building for soldiers to defend Onbu.
. More biomes and more varied random encounters.
. The ability to select a villager and order it to do a specific task.
. Graveyards to honour dead villagers.
. Make gaining Onbu's trust harder and make the consequences of upsetting him greater.

That's all i can think of for now but I'm sure ill think or more things :)

A special thank you to everyone involved with this game! <3

PS: I need an Onbu plushie!

Posted: September 19, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
***The Good***
Concept: Limited-scale city builder played on three layers. 1.) the village, 2.) the onbu, 3.) Interactions with the wider world (onbu's path / biomes / events / scavenging locations)

Art Style: The little 2d animated sprites are adorable, especially because you can zoom down into the village level. Gives it all kind of a whimsical paper-doll look amid the 3d rendering of Onbu itself. The art style was what caught my interest first.

Ongoing Development: Early access games get a bad rap sometimes, I think. This game has a great dev team, and a solid roadmap. I believe that when it's finished, it will be fully worth its price tag.

***The Meh***
Story: Currently nonexistent. There's a little lorebook that explains game mechanics, but no real depth at this stage in development. (More story is planned, however)

Gameplay: Honestly? It's a little thin. Solid for what it is, but once you've figured out a decent priority system, it only takes 1-2 hours to really get rolling. Many colony sims have an early-mid-lategame staging for development, but right now The Wandering Village kind of goes from early to done. There's no real 'endgame.' I hit a point where I had no interest in further research because using the buildings would hurt trust with Onbu, and I was able to survive just fine without them. THAT SAID -- the devs are very communicative, with a clear roadmap.

***Pricing Fairness***
At this stage of development, I probably would have priced this at $20 max, not $25, but bellyaching over $5 on what is clearly a labor of love with a great team behind it seems silly. It's a bit steep but nowhere near robbery. Kind of nice to have a little game like this to boot up now and then.

Posted: July 24
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I guess my problem is I'm not sure what this game is trying to be. As a city builder/management sim it's really shallow (everything basically boils down to "what crop am I growing for the next 10 minutes"). There's not really a major story-telling aspect aside from the initial "world is toxic" setting. The idea of a city building a symbiotic relationship with this titan (onbu) is a super neat idea, but...

At the same time it's also very shallow. Get a horn, feed it once or twice, and it will basically do most anything you tell it to. And there's no punishment (that i found) for doing the "anti-onbu" things aside from it basically ignoring your orders. Which ultimately doesn't really matter, because the city management is shallow enough that minimal planning is needed to prep for the next biome you're entering, and you would likely have had to make those preparations anyway. The only time I actually directed my onbu was when I wanted to figure out what was in a biome I hadn't been in yet. 98% of the time I just let it walk.

If you like simple and soothing city builder games, this game prolly isn't a bad pickup. If you were hoping this had a bit more strategy involved or the relationship with the titan was more impactful, at this point in time (7/24/23) I can't really say you'll have fun with this game. You'll likely be like me and get a handful of hours of trying things out and then be done.

Posted: November 22, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
The Wandering Village

has a really nice style for a Strategy-Survival Game and a nice concept with its theme in which Players right away start on the Back of a Giant Creature that, like the Title of the Game already gives away, wanders around.
And with the Change of the Creatures Position there comes also changes to the Environment the Villagers will find themselfs in and the Players has to help them to survive by building and harvesting various different Things.
Also the Creature that carries the Villagers arround require the Players attention from time to time.

The Tutorial is well made and easaly leads Players into this Game and how it works.
With different Houses, Technology, Research and assignable Jobs for Villagers, there is a high variety on how to prepare or fight against challenges that the Changes of the climate, cold, hot, swampy, etc, will throw against the Player.

The best Part of this Game is its nice and, even if its survival, still relaxing and enjoyable theme. If you want to just lean back for a while you can play on normal Speed, or if it isnt fast enough there are sliders to speed up the tempo to force events to happen more early. Even an implemented difficulty Setting helps to get a more preferred Gameworld.
And for sure the best Part are the interactions with the giant Creature. At the Beginning just a low amount, but over the course of a Game the relationship between the Villagers and the Creature lead to more options like letting it know when it can safely rest or to feed it or healing it etc.

For this Game i will not count negatives at the moment, because it is still in an Early Access state.

So far tho i can say, that i am already impressed by it and i am looking forward to future updates in the hope that they implement even more Biomes and Buildings and Gameplay-Options.

I recommend this Game to People who like to enjoy chillig Strategy-Survival Games and who also love simple Graphic, but still artistic style.

---------------------------------
8,7 / 10 graphics (Nice choice to go that 2D Drawing Style in a 3D World, it really gives it a nice artistic touch)
8,5 / 10 Gameplay (Easy to get into the Game)
6,4 / 10 Story (The Main-Story is good so far, but i would like to see a little more sidequests and unique Side-Character Stories to tell a bite more about the World they life in)
7,4 / 10 City-Management and variety of Buildings (City Management is easy, the Building variety maybe a little bit low, but that is likely to Early Access state and i hope they increase the amount of possible Buildings)
4,2 / 10 Soundtrack (There are a few Tracks, but for the Playtime it takes for one Playthrough i would like to hear a higher variety of Tracks to not getting the same over and over)

Posted: September 14, 2022
Product received for free

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Quick review: Buy it, awesome and pretty welcoming gameplay mechanics combined with an interesting concept for the "movement around the map", a great difficulty curve and a quite nice visual artstyle. It lacks a little bit of "objectives" if you want to "complete" the game.

Extended review: The wandering village is a pretty straight forward "City Builder"/"Colony management" game that takes some concepts from the genre that usually are "static" and by putting you in the back of one "definetively small beast" turns them into something more dynamic while adding some extra mechanics to the "management core" of the game. You can expect an absolutely beautiful visual stlye and art direction as well as nice sound design.

The learning curve is pretty welcoming and you can expect some extra depth to it that you might think at first, I kind of dislike the idea of having to survive "for as long as you can" instead of having an exact objective, but that's just a personal taste there's nothing wrong with it. In my case I plan on playing until I unlock everything in hopes that there's some kind of ending after that.

The game has a lot of content for an "early access" and a lot of polish to be honest, if they are just planning on expanding the game and adding more features with this level of polish I'll be quite happy with it.

The price might seem high for a "non complete" game, but at the moment I think it is woth it.

Posted: January 26
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I have just a little under an hour played with this game and overall I have enjoyed it. It is an unique city/base builder that is done in a cute art style.

The major uniqueness to the game play is that instead of seasons coming and going, your creature (Onbu) walks through different regions that have different biomes, thus subjecting your villagers to different weather. Along the way a blight will occasionally infect your trees, bushes, villagers and so on. This blight if it hits you early on can spread quicker that you can contain it if you aren't prepared, as I clearly was not during my first game. I still may be able to pull through but it isn't looking good.

Another unique part is that you can somewhat control the Onbu by having it potentially changing it's direction on the world map. You can zoom out and see various paths, sometimes ahead you might see the possibility for new villagers or possible dangers. Even though you can try to influence the Onbu, from what I gather it is not a given, just a possibility.

All in all the game performed great on an aging i5-7400 @3Ghz run 16GB Ram, 1060GTX and Samsung SSD. I experience no crashes or bugs during my playtime. That's always a plus even more so with a EA game that released not too long ago. For the price I do recommend it for fans of the City Building genre.

It is Steam Deck verified, I haven't tried it yet on the SD, but I will do so and report back on how it runs on said platform. That being said, I am not a fan of running RTS type games on the deck and prefer good old mouse and keyboard. That said it is nice to see it is a SD Verified game.

Posted: July 21
Overall feeling: recommend. Great storytelling, really cozy and fun for the first 4-ish hours, but gets monotonous and lacks replayability.

---

I really enjoyed the first 4-5 hours of this game! The main gameplay loop of designing, printing, and packaging gets addictive quickly, and getting to experience customer stories through this small-business-owner format was lovely and kept me wanting to play more and more. The storytelling aspect is great - the customers are a diverse bunch of creatures, Really Cute, and with lovely stories that add to the charm of the game. The art style is GORGEOUS (although Really Bright), and the sticker customization is genuinely so fun. It's collage based, so there's no pressure to be a "good artist", it's just fun.

However, without the aesthetics or the storytelling, the core gameplay loop was just... kind of bland. It does a great job at being a relaxing past time, but has zero challenge or anything that inspires long-term progression, really. There's no "numbers go up woo" chase that's typically present in job simulator games: your income / number of customers / overall work experience is basically the same in end-game as in the beginning, so there's no external motivation to make more stickers. There is barely any challenge other than sometimes running low on money and having to postpone printing a sheet of stickers until tomorrow (which is really not how operating a small business is irl, but I get that the game is trying to go for cozy over realistic). There's nothing to strategize about, almost nothing to improve or optimize, and the only goal keeping me playing past hour 5 was getting all the achievements (which is unfortunately really tedious). So, once the stories end and you get bored of simply making cute pixel collages for the fun of it, there is not much motivating you to play more.

Honestly, considering the simplicity of the core gameplay loop, the lack of challenge and business progression, and the fact that storytelling was the main driver to keep me playing, this is probably a better interactive visual novel rather than a true small business simulator.

Despite this, I liked Sticky Business. I still recommend this game, but with a few "buts". This game is AWESOME if you need to spend a zero-stress cozy evening making collage stickers and roleplaying as an online art store owner. The storytelling is cute, and getting to know your customers is lovely. You can easily sink several hours getting lost in designing new stickers. However, when the stories end, for a lot of people the game will probably get boring quickly, and there's kind of no reason to replay unless you're really into designing aspect.

---

Posted: July 23
Product received for free

Sticky Business is an utterly adorable, relaxing, and addictive game about operating a sticker shop. Everything about it is astonishingly wholesome and although its gameplay eventually becomes monotonous, the positives far outweigh the negatives. Despite its theme occupying somewhat of a niche corner, there is a lot of fun to be had, and I hope to see a sequel, or DLC in the near future.

Pros
Wholesome aesthetic
Addictive & easy gameplay
Every small task is made fun & with adorable animations
A range of brief, generally uplifting stories for each customer.
Encourages creativity, but does not shun those who lack it
Cons
Monotonous achievements involving intense grinding to buy all upgrades/stickers
The simple premise loses its spark after a few hours, providing no longevity

If you would like to see more reviews written by me, please follow my curator page and help support my work Cookie Reviews.

Sticky Business encompasses such a simplified concept, yet I have not seen anything even remotely similar done so masterfully. Despite its slightly suspicious sounding name, the game is the definition of everything CUTE. It encourages inclusivity, wholesomeness and of course, a love of stickers.

There is no main story, but there are mini stories told through short paragraphs on returning customers. Gameplay is all about managing your very own sticker shop. Buy stickers from an enormous, ever-growing collection. Design your own sticker by combining designs from a monumental collection to create something truly unique. Print your stickers, customise your online shop and of course, pack and post the sticker orders! Every task you do takes up time. Once the day is over, you will be forced to sleep and start the next day. I never felt any time pressure and never experienced a late order, however if this concept sounds worrying to you, there is also an option to make the day speed “limitless.”



Sticky Business’s interface is exceptionally user-friendly and extremely easy to navigate. Not to mention that every click feels like a hit of dopamine with a cuteness overload of colours and animations. This is difficult to explain, but even printing stickers made me feel so accomplished, the matching ding sound only added to this. Making these mundane tasks fun and addictive is a success on its own. Pack the orders how you see fit. Upgrade your packing paper and filling to confetti colours, polka dots or your favourite colour. Add in a freebie sticker or sweet to make that customers day. Pack the stickers and send it off with a click. Earn money and hearts from successful orders to buy more upgrades. Add more slots to your online shop, buy different sticker paper to print stickers on, new designs and so much more.



Customers will order specific sticker designs based on what is available in your online shop. Some clients will be connected to one of the branching stories and their order will come with a small bubble of text to read. The text typically relates to their personal situation and why they are ordering the stickers. It often will also reference a request for more stickers from a different theme, such as dinosaurs, space, animals or so forth. Creating stickers that encompass these themes will allow that character’s story to progress, and they will come back the next day or so, purchasing those new stickers, and with the next section of their story to read. All conversations are kept within easy reach and can be re-read at any time.



As aforementioned, one of my favourite elements about the game is its promotion of creativity, to make unique, artsy designs, yet it is also OK if you do not… and the game will not punish you. Want to chuck three types of stickers together and call it a day? You can! Want to create the most perfect bouquet of flowers, with a matching starry background where every colour perfectly compliments each other and the angle of each sticker is flawlessly identical? You can! I would not call myself a creative person, but I adore this game. After seeing some of the examples of stickers from other players, I realised the games true potential. Works of art can be produced here, but if that is not your style, that is fine too. The stories progress based on the *types* of stickers used, not how cleverly you place them together. Of course, thoughtfulness and effort is encouraged, given the pure arrangement of stickers to choose from, but it is nice that progression is not restricted to this.


The noticeable downside to this game’s simple premise, is this. The gameplay does become rather stale when repeated, which is to be expected with a game of this nature. My main gripe is the grindy achievements that force this. If you do not care for achievements, the four or so hours of gameplay will likely satisfy you, but for completionists, the achievements can turn this fun game into a bit of a slog. Even for those not interested in achievements, after the main stories are completed, you have most likely upgraded everything to perfection, and without new character stories coming in, there is little to keep you interested. Given the very reasonable price of $AU14.50, I believe this to be a fair trade off, well-worth the enjoyment I had. But for those looking for more of a long-term game, it is important to be aware of.


Visuals are bright, blocky, and reminded me of the Myspace era. The overabundance of vibrant colour is an attack on the eyes, but in the best way possible. Stickers are obnoxiously cute and ooze the cozy games aesthetic.



The backing audio is nothing unique, but helps create a relaxing environment. Despite this sounding trivial, those dopamine-giving dings and clicks I described earlier also play a vital role in the game and help make every task an absolute joy to complete.


4 hours (I 100% completed all stories, but not the completionists achievements).

No

Not really.

Sticky Business is a reminder that even the most simple-sounding premise can provide pure entertainment – if done correctly. It is a testament for the many simulation-based games that have not been able to master such a niche theme. This is not a game that will appeal to the masses, but if anything you have read in my review even somewhat intrigues you, you are likely to enjoy this game and I encourage you to give it a try.

Posted: September 29
Sticky Business Review: Crafting Cozy Creativity

You know, the idea of running a small business may sound like a recipe for stress, but imagine the joy of designing products and sending them off to excited customers. That's the delightful essence of Sticky Business, a charming simulation game that lets you step into the shoes of a small business owner, in this case, running your own sticker shop with all the creative freedom in the world.

Crafted by the German indie studio Spellgarden Games, Sticky Business is a cozy and adorable simulator where you venture into the world of online entrepreneurship. Your mission: create unique designs, handle orders, package products, and send them off to eagerly awaiting customers. The gameplay isn't overly complex, but it's surprisingly engaging and kept me entertained in unexpected ways.

Once you dive in, you'll find yourself settling into a comfortable routine. Each day brings a set number of hours, and every task consumes a chunk of your precious time. After the tutorial and creating your first sticker (a cat in a coffee cup, in my case), you'll slip into a pleasing rhythm of order fulfillment, posting, and squeezing in some time at the end of the day for new designs or restocking. You can even toss in freebies like extra stickers or sweets, though I couldn't quite tell if this boosted order numbers.

As you progress in Sticky Business, fulfilling orders and collecting hearts unlocks more design assets. These hearts also double as currency for buying additional colors to jazz up your designs. The thrill of acquiring upgrades, especially early on when you must choose your design components carefully, opens doors to new creative possibilities.

Sticky Business does offer some light business and management sim elements, but its core charm lies in creativity rather than gameplay complexity. It's the perfect game for unwinding. However, if you're after a deep business simulation, it might leave you wanting more.

But don't let that fool you; there's a story here. Customer orders are sprinkled with messages that offer glimpses into their lives. From a grieving family to someone seeking new friendships, these short but emotional insights enrich the game.

Sometimes, customers will request special stickers to progress their stories, sparking inspiration for fresh creations you might not have considered otherwise. I found myself diving into the store to purchase new sticker upgrades more than once, responding to these unique demands. The requests aren't overly detailed, usually centered around a vague theme rather than strict specifications, but they nudge you to step out of your comfort zone and create something new.

One area Sticky Business could improve is customization beyond stickers. While you can control elements like the paper and filling for order boxes, having more say over your workspace and online store front would be a welcome addition. In such a creative game, it feels like a missed opportunity not to have more control. Sure, you can change your shop's color, but you can't set your own prices or layout, which can sometimes mean you're selling a sticker for just a few coins.

Visually, the in-game graphics are adorable. The work surface is a pastel paradise adorned with plants and coffee cups. The stickers themselves sport a cute and cartoony style that's reminiscent of clip art, but they're charming enough to convince me to buy a few.

The one drawback for me was the music. While cheerful, it became a tad repetitive, eventually prompting me to switch to my own tunes.

In the grand scheme of things, Sticky Business might not be a sprawling game with countless tasks. It's repetitive, offering just a handful of activities. But you know what? It's a joyful and fun experience, tailor-made for anyone who enjoys cozy, relaxing games. From its cute graphics and cheerful music to the freedom to create without fear of judgment, Sticky Business is the perfect way to unwind without a care in the world.

Posted: July 27
"A simple, comfy and wholesome game with cute small stories about the customers and their lives."
Sticky Business allows for a fair amount of creativity in the creation of stickers and then selling it. I enjoyed it greatly, and before I knew it, I was 2 hours into the game despite the game being incredibly simple; make the sticker, print the sticker, and sell the sticker.


Plot 5/5
Sticky Business does not have a plot or story behind yourself, and why you started a sticker business, but as you sell and make new products, you get to hear about the lives of a few regular customers. Some of these regulars know each other, and you can hear the perspectives of each customer on their lives. All of these stories are wholesome and engaging. Hearing about the customers made me happy, and some customers even make suggestions of what they'd like to see in the store. I would drop everything I was doing to make their sticker desires come true even though they were predetermined messages.
I loved seeing the stories between the customers, and seeing their happy reactions to the stickers that I made. While there was not much plot, or anything that could really be considered plot, the mini stories and interactions with customers that I did experience, I fully enjoyed it.

The controls of this game are relatively simple, which makes it easy to pick up, however there is nothing further to it, without any challenges, quests or progression, which could make a player lose interest and get bored.

I did also find that there lacked explanations in some aspects in the tutorial of gameplay, for example: How do you get hearts? What does candy do? What happens if you add extra stickers to an order? When is the due date of an order? What are all of the icons in the day summary screen?

These were all questions I had while playing the game, and I did just end up having to guess or figure it out myself by testing it. The lack of explanation left for many things to be desired, but I acknowledge the possibility that I may have just missed the tutorial or explanation for said things.

While the game did have many options and possibilities to customise your stickers and packaging, which I enjoyed greatly, I think some further additions would also be good. The ability to create your own text for stickers rather than just the set ones, and further website customisability for your store are things I would love to see added in the future.

The art is adorable, plenty of splashes of colour in every screen, making it aesthetically pleasing. I enjoyed the art for both the UI and the stickers.

Sticky Business has relatively simple background music, and much to my surprise I did not find myself getting sick of the music even after 7 hours into one sitting. The sound design on notifications, clicks, selecting items and etc. were also very fun and satisfying to listen to when performing actions, which I liked. It did not stand out as incredible, but the audio in Sticky Business was good.

I do believe that Sticky Business is not the most replayable game, as the main engagement for me was the mini stories of the regulars, and after completing the stories, there aren't any further communications from them. This makes the gameplay rather repetitive. I found that once I finished all the stories, and had all the upgrades, I got bored very quickly.

I do believe that it may be good once in a while to open up to make some cute stickers and package some orders, but it is not something I would play frequently and enjoy for lengthy periods of time after finishing it.

I quite enjoyed Sticky Business, it was visually pleasing and aesthetic, accompanied with cute and satisfying sound design. The small stories of customers were engaging and wholesome. There was a fair amount of freedom in the creativity aspect of creating stickers, but of course there could also be more, such as being able to draw your own features or adding your own text. I did, however find that the game lacked any progression, which makes the gameplay rather bland after a period time, as well as replayability after completing all of the mini stories of customers, and some explanations of certain features in the tutorial. However, I enjoyed Sticky Business and consider it to be a wholesome and relaxing game to pick up.

Posted: July 18
I DON'T HATE THIS GAME, I JUST CANT RECOMMEND IT IN THE STATE ITS IN RIGHT NOW.


I have been looking forward to this game for a while so I was very pleased when it first came out. Beautiful graphics and lovely music, despite the music looping it doesn't get repetitive, unfortunately, i cant say the same about the game as a whole. Great concept for a game, make your own sticker business, it has great LGBTQ+ representation but i feel like its lacking a lot in the little things that would really polish this game. I have nothing wrong with the stories they're wholesome and cute, it's mostly with the layout of the game and some parts that feel really clunky.

When you have created your first sticker you need to print it off, printing costs depending on the type of sticker you're making, E.G Paper, holo, card etc.. When arranging your sticker on the paper you can either do it manually or click and have the game auto fit it. I have found that the game isn't very good at this?? there as been times where its not let me complete a page despite there being enough room at the bottom for another row, that causes me to have to come in and manually do it which isn't a problem just a nit pick. The actual problems I have though is that you cant organise your stickers, or your printer sheets. I would have loved for there to be a small folder system where you can categorise your stickers in the packing menu and or the printing menu. I am tired of scrolling looking for stickers when I have upwards of 50 designs. I know some people might disagree with me and say "it's more clicking" but i would rather it that way, it stresses me out not being able to organise my stickers, if I had my own files I could have exclusive freebie stickers, pride stickers, animal stickers and so on. As of now its a mess and I get drained having to look for everything. Even if you didn't want to add a file system being able to click on the requested stickers via the customers order to have them be put in automatically would be a great help. I love love love the packing peanuts and packing paper, the sweets are also a great addition however I feel like i am always constantly forgetting the sweets exist. The buttons to swap tabs are at the top of the screen near your stickers so i find myself ignoring it most of the time to prioritise the stickers. Maybe if it was swapped to the bottom it would be easier to see but that might just be a me thing.
It would also be a great edition to include custom thank you cards! they could be unlocked mid game rather than right at the start, i think it would include more personality to the game and makes your orders unique and personalised.
When printing new stickers there should be a little pop up which tells you what stickers are low in stock. I don't have the best short term memory so i end up forgetting what stickers i need to print and waste money printing wrong ones. I would really benefit from a "Low in stock" menu, even when packing your stickers having them glow red when they are low in stock would defo help me remember more, and instead of removing them entirely from the stock when they do run out, grey them out. I get tired looking for a sticker because its just disappeared when its ran out.


When creating stickers you should be able to have certain elements have boarders and some that do not. I feel like most of my stickers look stupid with white boarders when only a small bit needs them. Also being able to select the type of paper you'd like to use BEFORE finalising the sticker would be great. I always find myself forgetting about the other types.
Also small small smalllll thing... LET US DRAW!!! I WANT TO DRAW MY OWN STICKERS!!!!! it doesn't have to be a mandatory feature to progress but as an artist i would love to have the ability to create completely custom stickers to sell to my clients.

Here are a few other small issues that don't really need a paragraph but are worth mentioning
Maybe add more music? the music now is fine and relaxing but it would be nice to have different sound tracks or being able to unlock different music, you could do that via upgrades and equip it by clicking a casset player maybe? or a record player, for a record player the vinyls could have unique decals on for different tracks.

When packing your orders the button PACK is very similar to the word BACK i find myself accidentally clicking this instead of the home button which makes me prematurely send my order leading it to be incomplete. Possibly changing it to a check mark would help a lot more.


very small thing that might just be a me problem but i struggle to understand how to gain hearts, it feels very random despite me always adding 75%+ to an order ( loads of freebies) i find myself making 0 hearts a day and i am unable to gain more stickers due to this. I also understand the coins are profit based rather than money as a whole but it would be helpful to see how that money is calculated i.e
Printing = -30
sales = 200
profit = 170
Total money = 170
just so it makes sense and you're able to see where your money is going, a little similar to how stardew shows you what sold for what when using the overnight sale bin.
When unlocking clients @Curry was a mystery on how to get, maybe when you haven't met the customer it should tell you what you need to complete in order to unlock them E.g @curry is unlocked after finishing @Miss honeys story line. It's just the small things that would make this game so much better..

for possible replay-ability the devs could host sticker contests which would encourage people to replay the game after completetion.

I took my time with this game but it can easily be completed in 3hrs or less if you speed run it. I think if it gets frequent updates / holiday updates it will be a thriving game but as of now it is very bare bones.


Like i said i don't hate this game, I've played 5 hours and i will defo intend to play more if these small things are worked on. If you enjoy a peaceful relaxing game then id say go for it, but at the same time don't expect any organisation with your stickers, it will get very tedious after a few hours.

Devs if you read this I would love to chat to you about other ideas for this game. don't hesitate to reach out to me on steam <3

Posted: July 20
NOTE:
The below review was my initial negative review for this game prior to updates. I have since played the update put in by the devs and recommend this game, as the issues indicated below have been addressed. Game is simple, wholesome, and can be extensive, depending on your creativity and energy for detail/personalisation. Still missing a few features but collectively a good indie game.

At 60ish minutes played, I reviewed this game as positive. I am changing my review to negative as, at 6 hours, I am entirely sick of this game. 100%ing it is needlessly time-consuming as upgrading everything takes forever. My eyes burn and I can't adjust the brightness. I am so sick of the exact same song on repeat. I can barely customise my shop and I am now getting 2-3 customers a day, if I'm lucky, which has massively slowed down the process.

This game is cute, simple, wholesome fun. Initially, I enjoyed it. However, the longevity of it just does not exist. This may not be an issue, except the devs put in achievements which require you to play much longer than completing the stories will realistically take, and I am bored. The game needs additional features, ranging from accessibility to customisation. It needs to bump up the cash/hearts you gather as you work, as it is a slog to unlock everything. There should be a loadout option so I don't need to select the same colour combo for my packaging every single day. As well, there is NO sorting option on the stickers- if you create enough (and why wouldn't you, with an excess of options) you will be scrolling back and forth hunting for them every order. There's no indication on the printing page of the stock you have, which turns printing stickers into a memory game (spoiler: not fun). The time restriction each day feels restrictive, too, and could stand to be longer.

All in all, I do technically recommend this game. It's sweet and simple, it does what it's trying to do. However, as an actual , with achievements which require you to play for an extended period (beyond any story motivators) it is exhausting me and I will not pick it up again once I've completed it. Which is a shame.

With some updates- which the community are begging for, and the devs surely cannot ignore- I would change my review to positive.

Posted: November 15
Cute and pleasant but a little lacking in some respects. The core gameplay loop feels less like it's rewarding your progress with more sticker components and more like it's artificially gating them to limit your output?

The packing section has some cute options but does not accurately reflect how a small seller would ship stickers. You're not going to ship three stickers in a big box with packing peanuts.

The writing is middling to weak; every storyline is predictable and leans into self-indulgence. The streamer complaining about getting flamed for switching to playing Cozy Games had me rolling my eyes. Every conflict is resolved by buying your stickers, somehow.

Everything is on trend for something billing itself as a "Wholesome Game" so I guess you're getting exactly what you expect. It's fine, and I've had some fun making stickers, but it's made no lasting impression. At time of writing I've played two sessions of it. I expect to get 1-2 more out of it before I put this away and forget about it entirely. If Steam let you answer "Do you recommend this game?" with a big shrug emoji this review would be marked that way, instead of Positive.
