7. Just a dream here, but being able to pull a boat with a trailer and take it to a boat launch would make this
game so freaking sweet
8. Maybe some foldout chairs for bank fishing that you could customise would be cool as well.

Overall im more than satisfied with my purchase and i don't have a lot of money to waste on games, but i feel this game has earned its place as my favorite game of the year so far.

If you like fishing, come join our community and make this game great for years to come. Great job devs and i hope to see a lot from ya'll in the near future.

Posted: September 1, 2022
Firsts things first: I am a big fan of theHunter: Classic and theHunter: Call of the Wild. When I saw a fishing game set in franchise, I was ecstatic. However, this game is an arcade fisher, which is okay. Call of the Wild is very arcade compared to other hunting games. Its at the very least user friendly and has easy drop-in, drop-out multiplayer with friends. I have honestly been enjoying myself in this game, but I am playing it for what it is.

If you are looking for the next Fishing Planet or Russian Fishing Simulator, keep looking. If you are a fan of the franchise that Expansive Worlds has created and want to invest early in the future of this game, then get the game. We all know Expansive Worlds takes care of their games in the long run... look at both theHunter games. Both were extremely bare at the start, but look at them now. Sure, this game was probably another quarter or 2 away from being releaseable, but they are also not a AAA company. I'm glad that the game itself wasn't a full-priced game ($60) and I'm also glad they decided to put it in a franchise bundle with theHunter:COTW so The Angler was discounted. They didn't have to do that and is honestly why I ended up picking it up instead of waiting for a sale.

The PC fishing community has not been kind to this release, which is justified. There are so many graphical issues and bugs that should have been polished before being released. There is also the issue of not having enough species in the game. That's also an issue considering how many species could easily fit in this game already.

This game has a ton of issues, but because I'm still having fun in the game, I can't justify review bombing it like everyone else likes to. The Devs know what they have to do, and I'll support them the entire way.

Posted: July 2
theAngler: Call of The Wild - An Exercise in Good Fun

Looking through the comments and reviews you may see a large amount of people complaining about the graphics, the UI, the lack of AI animals wandering the map, and the lack of what seems to be ambition from the developers, but if you look just a little past those issues which were dated to between months 1-11 of the initial release and have been improved by the time 2 years later they finished the console port (yes, they did a console port, what I wager is the main reason updates might have been slow; they were working on that little, small, minor undertaking of reformatting the game to run on a Xbox and PlayStation) you find a game that does exactly what is promised on the box:

You can fish in every little puddle and cup of water on the two massive open world maps, regardless of the level of success you may encounter, and never be forced into being social with randos while doing it.

You get to explore an open world filled with collectibles that have little blurbs of fun stories that tell interesting narratives when you cobble them together in order once you find them all, coins from all different eras, and even souvenirs that serve no purpose other than to be bought and admired once you max out your in game items (Or worn, in the case of the Bigfoot outfit. Yes, they give you a Bigfoot shirt with rippling muscles and copious amounts of fur. What more could you ask from a game studio?)

There are trails to walk for eons as you wander between campsites, items to pick up as you explore to unlock outposts and vantage towers, and plenty of charm to be found in a very helpful and kind player base that in my experience is quick to share a laugh and even quicker to offer aid and advice.

The fish are just straight up everywhere, as long as you use the right baits/hook sizes/lures for what you’re trying to catch. Just because you CAN use the 4/0 frog doesn't mean you’ll catch something with it

The Multiplayer Experience, Sponsored by Red Bull's Stunt Team:

When people move from a game that has had well over 8 years of work and support to a new project by the same company, it can many times lead to disappointment as the team working on "YOUR FAVORITE GAME™" aren't the ones in the company tasked with bringing this new project to life, and that's a whole different can of worms to dive into, but at the end of the day you get a great fishing game to play while in a VC with your buddies, as you all try not to fall off the boat because you turned off the safety measures and did a corkscrew jump off a pile of rocks. Oh yes, the multi-player.

When you think about multi-player games, you often think of shooters, Mil-sims, and Minecraft. And no one blames you, but this game has a very interesting take on the format. You and a handful of random players are dumped unceremoniously into the reserve, with no forced interaction. The games in game chat has a character limiter, but it has enough to chat without VC, and if you absolutely require VC I found discord had no impact on my performance while playing. The in game emotes are both well animated and fun: you can do jumping jacks until the heat death of the universe, wave hello, point out that rock ahead of the boat, or cower in fear from Bigfoot (Yes, he is in the game, no I will not tell you where. Get the game and find him yourself)

I have some advice for the like, 2 people who have read this far (I see you and I'm proud of you) and it has to do with kit building for your setups. The reel says what size line it accepts up to. Never exceed that number, and go for the Fluorocarbon line (low vis + strong v.s. abrasion, which you’ll encounter on the bigger fish like Gold and diamond pike or the lake trout/salmon of Norway). The rod also says the upper limits on the test strength of the line you can use with it. Once you build a few rod kits you'll be able to do it with almost zero effort on your part. And baits. Use stuff size 6 to be an equal opportunity angler and use things size 5-3 for more focus on the larger fish in the pond, especially the pike and salmon. And pay attention to what the fish's journal entry says they like, it can make the difference between catching a fish on every cast and getting nothing for an hour (my advice is use Frog 6, it's taken by Pike, Smallmouth, and Largemouth, and those three are in just about every body of water on the American reserve)

And DO THE CHALLENGES IF YOU WANT FAST(ER) LEVELING. There are many that allow you to do Any fish, of Any size, of Any Weight and get rewards in the form of massive EXP boosts for the weekly quests. Yes, the harder the challenge the better the reward, but at the end of the day you don't need to stress yourself out over virtual fish. You have plenty of time for the weekly challenges if you play the game with friends and lose track of time from the hi-jinks they can pull. My personal favorite challenge was the "96 lbs of any fish" and the "Catch 45 of any species" as they allowed me to fish for what I wanted and enjoyed to catch, which are the Largemouth and Smallmouth bass in record setting quantities and mindbogglingly massive population densities of the fish in a singular section of lily pads on a land locked lake.

Now, I'd like to end off with a quick story about another player, who for anonymity sake I shall refer to as "John." Me and John met up by sheer luck because I stated in the in-game chat "bass are loving the Phrog 6 today" (Bait type Top-water frog, hook size 6, simplified to Frog 6). John replied "You're close to a Legendary spawn location, want to give it a try?" And thus we went like two rednecks to the nearest lake and began trying to catch a 25+ pound Largemouth named Goldstein on rods rated for 6 pounds and line that would barely hold up origami cranes, forget a fish of such mind boggling proportions as the Legendary Largemouth. Over the next half hour we shared a boat, fished the water, and shot the sh*t in the in game chat about game functions and interesting design choices we noticed in our combined 10 levels of experience in the game. We eventually got into discord with each other and began to help each other with quests and finding new spots to fish. We fought 11 pound pike on gear rated for not 11 pound pike, caught collectively about 180 fish between the two of us in a 4 hour period of gaming, and even started to talk about life and our personal experiences. We both got to level 26 before the night grew old and the sun came up and we had to bid adieu to each other. This game, while yes feels empty without any animals wandering around, and yes has small graphics shortcomings, and of course has a somewhat clunky UI, at the core is a functional and very fun fishing with the boys simulator, and I am thankful I get to play it with a player base that understands that about the game, and does everything in their power to ensure everyone they meet and interact with leave with a smile and hopeful a scrapbook full of their biggest catches.

So to the very small amount of you who made it to this part of the review, I have just one thing left to say: Buy the Game now, wait for sale, or try it via a buddy gifting you a key, but for all that is worth anything on this planet:
Join the official discord for theAngler:CoTW, make some buddies, or bring your own along for the ride, and experience the amazing world of Fishing with the Bro’s.

Yours,
MrQwertyxsad
humble Fisherman
and Bass Enthusiast

Posted: September 4
This is quickly becoming one of my favorite games of all-time. Ignore the majority of the older negative reviews, ever since the latest major update the offline experience has been mostly smooth and enjoyable. If you are like myself and grew up fishing, this game will likely be perfect for you. The general topography is brilliant and effectively replicates some the most compelling fishing experiences that you will encounter in North America. The controls and menu system are nearly flawless and what the menus lack in aesthetics, is made up for in functionality. It also has a charm to it that the other fishing games out on the market are lacking and it truly reminds me of trips that I have taken in the past, whereas the other games feel very sterile and arcade-like in comparison. Although some other fishing games have more options (ice fishing, fly fishing, etc.) and maps, they still don't bring me back as frequently due to the overall experience.

It has a lot of potential to be the ultimate fishing experience depending on what DLC and free content updates are released in the future. For this to happen, the game needs a community of people that give constructive feedback and not hyperbolic criticism. With some luck, the disgruntled players will move on with their lives and find another game to care about. On another note... thanks to this game alone, I plan on taking up fishing again next year and replacing my fishing rod which snapped after trying to get a Pike into my boat a few years ago.

Suggested Changes:

- Make the tackle box menus look like an actual tackle box and allow the player organize it as they see fit
- Add additional fishing gear (fishing binoculars, fillet knives, fly fishing rods, ice fishing rods, fishing pliers, sonar, etc.)
- Additional animations, including removing the hook from the fish, scooping them into the boat with a net or hand, etc.
- Trolling while using a boat and rod holders
- Ice Fishing
- Season-based map variants
- Additional shops throughout the map
- The ability to cook your fish over a fire after catching it and eat it
- Allow the player to enter almost every building
- Allow the player to save up for and decorate their own fishing cabin and display their best catches alive in a tank or dead on the wall
- Additional multiplayer features (social, functional and co-op goals)
- Additional reasons to explore the entire map (unique unlockable gear, skins, etc. after collecting certain items around the map such as fossils)
- More NPCs to interact with
- Games within the game to play while in a cabin with other players (chess or poker, for example) to help capture what it is really like to take a fishing trip with family or friends

It is worth mentioning that at the time of this review there have been significant server issues that will hopefully be fixed soon. I plan on updating my review over the coming months as the game evolves.

Posted: August 21
This game started out in a place where it had a good backbone but lacked in many ways. But with the recent updates this game has started to shape up into something that could really be amazing if they keep up the quality updates. If you go into this game with the mindset that this is a call of the wild game similar to the hunter call of the wild then i think you will really enjoy it. It is a very exploration heavy fishing game with massive open world maps where you can fish anywhere you want. This was the main draw for me from the beginning and is still my favorite part of the game. The game finds a good balance between realism and fun and is the reason i enjoy it so much. If you are here to chase after the diamond rank fish similar to the hunter call of the wild you will not be disappointed as diamond fish are very tough to get. Even harder than diamond animals in the hunter. The areas where this game lacks currently is the animations of the fish & the way water transfers from waterfalls to slower moving water. Both lack polish but overall don't detract from the gameplay too much.
There also used to be a massive problem where you could catch anything on any lure but in the past 6 months or so they really tweaked that and its much better now.

Now lets talk about the most recent update. The Evolution Update.

The new leveling system implemented with the recent Evolution Update is a very good change as it gives more purpose and value to leveling up than before. The new water system is also a good step in the right direction tho there is still room for improvement. Another major feature of this update was 8 new fish species to Golden Ridge Reserve which was imo the best part of the update. All the new fish are very interesting and have really breathed new life into this map. The new tutorial missions are also a very good addition to the game as they teach you everything you need to know in much more depth than before. Theres also a new token system where you get diamond, gold, & legendary tokens for catching those fish ranks. Those tokens can then be used to purchase the best gear in the game and exclusive cosmetic items as well. This is a change i feel has helped a lot in giving more purpose to those fish as they are no longer just a big fish but also a way to get more gear from the shop. Another thing that will be happening sometime somewhat soon after this review gets posted is the console release of the game. This will bring cross platform to the game which will be game changing! It will be a breath of fresh air to get to play with anyone regardless of platform as there is not a fishing game out that does this yet. Ill likely update this review at a later date after the console release. But i hope that in the meantime this has helped you decide if you want to buy or not! Its a great game if you can overlook the small things i mentioned!

Posted: September 9, 2022
EDIT: After 1.02 patch the water looks much better.

So, after some 92 hours in this game I've decided to say some stuff. I'm not a fisherman and never really cared for it. I was looking for something new to waste my time on and bought this and the hunter bundle for 25% off. Tried this one first and... wait for lame dad joke... Got hooked. Still haven't played the hunter yet. I immediately noticed that it was more arcade than sim but I didn't let that stop me. I thought the map was similar enough to one of my favorite places on this planet and that was good enough for me. Some say it looks bad. I disagree. Some say they couldn't catch a fish and gave up asap to get their money back. Well, I must've been catching their fish because I'm slightly shy of 1,400 fish caught. I've even gone on several streaks of catching 2, 3 maybe even 4 fish in a single minute. Maybe I just don't know what a good fishing game is since I haven't played one outside of RDR2 or Far Cry since the SNES days. I like the game and yes it needs work just like any new game in the past decade or so. I'm not completely finished with this game yet. I have a few exploration things to find like dino bones and petrified trees and a few longevity achievements. Everything else is done. It's hard for me to actually say how good it is but I feel I have gotten my money's worth and I had fun playing it most of the time. I will say that the water doesn't look great up close (it almost looks like a clear film with wrinkles is on the surface that doesn't move) but from maybe 10 or 15 feet away and further it looks really good. The fish models look good enough to me but their animations are lacking especially when they turn for a lure and look like they're confused at times about how to get to it. If you cast far out, the first fish in range will lock on and will not let any other fish go after the bait unless you speed reel and outrun the fish then another fish will lock on and chase it. I find it frustrating when it's either full cast or a 30 foot toss with not much control in between for precise distance casting so when going for a particular fish it can require some thinking ahead and figuring out the best way to get the fish you want. I play with a controller so I don't know if this is an issue with mouse or not. Precise cast controls would be my most requested update along with an optional center screen dot to know exactly where you're aiming even though I've adapted and usually get close or spot on with my accuracy. Camping/sleeping with the ability to pass time would be a necessary element. The character creator is probably the most bland I've seen since PS1 but because it's only first person I guess it doesn't even matter. 3rd person option would be better in nearly every way outside of actually fishing. Driving a jeep or boat in 3rd person would be a major upgrade when going up hills and in the tight blind turns in heavily forested area's. The signs along the roads need to go. They serve no purpose and even the best driver's will crash into them because they're 6 inches off the roads. They don't exist in Yellowstone and they shouldn't exist in this game, and that also goes for the unused upside down boats, docks and some other useless things that look like filler that are laying around. I would like to see some functional geysers, fumaroles and bubbling mud pools in the hot springs area and some scattered about the entire map because that's Yellowstone! Most bodies of water there you can't even use a boat but they are needed in this game so I can let that slide. I could get picky about lots of other things like no animals and that annoying lady that won't shut up every time I see her but I'll end it here for now. I would assume expansive worlds will fix and add stuff over time like I've heard about the Hunter game and I applaud them for what they have created because of my personal connection with Yellowstone National Park and my love for hiking and exploring there. Like I said, I'm not a fisherman. But, I believe that I will be taking it up very soon and I will credit this game and my old long gone hero for stirring my spirit to become one. If you read all this BS and care to give the game a good try(past the tutorial) and wanna catch some fish and chill in some beautiful scenery then I say buy the game and play it.

Cannot recommend in current state.

This game should have been DLC for COTW: Hunter. They tried to turn a fishing game into an open world explorer except there is nothing to do in this open world. So they force you to play Park Ranger and look for invasive species or other issues in the park, granted that isn't a bad idea but there is nothing else to do but blindly drive around to each location: complete task: move on. The environment is ugly to look at and otherwise unrewarding to explore. There's a whole lot to do but none of it is enjoyable.

Tutorial: Isn't terrible, it explains how each mechanic works. But the casting system and fish hooking system is atrocious. With casting there's no skill, just need high mouse sensitivity or you're not going over 15m. To hook a fish all you do is cast and any fish will go straight to the hook like it's a magnet. Which isn't bad, since you don't want people sitting and waiting to attract a fish for 30+ minutes like in real life. Just don't animate the fish moving statically from 50m away making a beeline straight to the hook, it looks lazy.

Graphics: It's a Hunter game, looks like every other one but somehow character models are worse and the clothes are terrible.

When people buy a fishing game, they want to fish. When fishing in the fishing game is both unrewarding and unenjoyable then why call it a fishing game?

Updated to reference new map DLC: Officially more expensive than a map in Hunter: Call of the Wild with less features in it. Not the move in a game with only an average playerbase of 150

The depth and breadth of the Park offer so many challenges for a fishing family separated by time and space. My Dad is is 90-ish I am late 60's my daughter younger. We live too far apart to see each other much more than a couple times a year if we are lucky.

But now, after 52 years, 3 generations of my family are exploring and fishing together once again.

Other fishing games have parts of the fishing thing that are done better. But the thing is, they do not have this exploration element that gives you such a complete opertunity for the kid to say, hey see that lake way out west where we gotta walk half an hour to get to, or the old man to say, I found aspot where you catch 3 pounders every cast... come on I'm driving.

I have played The Hunter since I first saw it for several years. We are not hunters, we are sailors and fishermen, but also explorers. I am a marksman in The Hunter, but have like 8 trophies after thousands of hours. I just am not a hunter, but I am well and truly a fisherman that spent 50 years exploring the deep florida wilderness fishing by canoe, and now am no longer able to be physically safe in a canoe.

I don't know what to say, how to explain it. Call of the Wild: The Angler has given my family a precious gift. The scenery is lovely, and we can put 4 in a boat... and drive for hours together.

Anyone who loves fishing and has a fishing buddy who now lives a thousand miles away needs this game.

Posted: September 2, 2022
LONG RANT

Just get Ultimate Fishing Simulator, check back in a year to see if they've fixed this. I just don't know who this game is for (presumably the 5 people who have left positive reviews?). It's a fishing game where 90% of the time you're not fishing. This is a Pawnstars meme, "I'd like to fish" "Best I can do is driving for 3 hours with the jankiest vehicle controls this decade".

The graphics are... fine. People are complaining about them but it's fine for a niche market like fishing games. The exception to this (oddly) is the water. Terrible blur and you can actually SEE the texture tiles because if you turn 45 degrees to them, there are seams. The character models are absolutely awful too. Graphics are not what is holding this game back though.

Audio is a much bigger issue than the graphics. This is the worst audio design I've ever seen in a game. All of the not-nature sounds need to be removed. The vehicles are the worst. Put your head in a cardboard box then run a vacuum cleaner on the top of the box. That's what being in a vehicle sounds like. I hate to use "cringe" as an adjective, but every spoken word is so... cringe it deserves a pass. Voice acting sounds like semi-competent actors doing their best with the pile of crap dialogue they were given, so still not great.

Gameplay is another huge issue. This is a FISHING GAME. This isn't CotW: The Hunter, we don't need miles and miles of roads and mountains to explore. We need lakes and rivers. There's one store on the whole map. The quest giver moves around the map at various times of day, so you get to try to track him down every few hours if you do a quest. You're trying to do too much! Just make it a good FISHING GAME! Collectibles!? Is this 2006? Everybody alive hates those. At best it's something you never complete, at worst it's something you begrudgingly find a guide online to collect them all for your precious achievements.

Bugs. There's many. Presumably they'll be fixed after this title leaves it's unofficial "Early Access" phase. You know, when it's a real game.

The fixes I'd like to see:
-Get rid of every bit of manual exploration. Unlock the whole map right from the beginning, triple the number of fast-travel points. People can still go climb a mountain if they want a pretty view, but people that want to FISH IN THE FISHING GAME can just get to that.
-So many more fish/locations. It took a truly impressive amount of testicular fortitude to call this "genre-defining" with 12 fish species and one map in your game. Ultimate Fishing Simulator 2 is in Early Access and has 5 or 6 maps and dozens of species. You do get that the fishing is why people buy this game right?
-Rework or even do away with dialogue. Make it text if you can't be bothered redoing the audio. The last thing I want in this whole world is some old guy blabbering on in my ear every 5 steps I take. It's not necessary.
-You have to physically go to the only shop on the map to get new gear. This should be a menu option. Yay you made some money, now spend 30 minutes fast traveling back to the shop and then driving (with the game muted) back to your fishing spot. Screeeeeew that noise.
-Get rid of the jeep. Add fast travel points as mentioned. This is the least-pleasant driving experience I've ever played. Vehicles handled more reliably and accurately in the original Twisted Metal clear back in the 90s. I cannot believe that a single person drove that jeep and said, "Yeah, nailed it". Also, if you're going add signs/posts every few feet along the sides of the roads, you have two real options: 1) make them destructible or 2) be able to drive through them. Every time the awful controls had me drift half an inch to the right and my vehicle was brought to a full stop from 60mph on a little sign, my rage grew.
-Underwater cam. I mean... that's a gimme.
-Fix your controls. Why is everything a HOLD E? Want to get in the car? Hold E. Want to talk to the shopkeep? Hold E. WHY!? Just tap the freakin button and do the freakin thing!! Why have you gone out of your way to make things unnecessarily difficult? Why is the ENTER key a default keybind? Have you played a computer game in your life? Where are your hands? Are they near the ENTER key? THEN WHY IS THAT ONE OF THE MOST-USED KEYS!?

This game is so bad it made me angry. Not at the lost money, I have hundreds of terrible games on my Steam list. Mad at the claims they've made. "Genre-defining". Posted: January 16
I bought this game after the initial tease and release knowing full well what I would get in for. I was on the Discord during the first few weeks of Youtubers getting early access and I made my points clear on it there and sadly I will raise most of the points I had there - here.

As someone who played a lot of call of the wild and thehunter: classic I know how beautiful the worlds Expansive Worlds can make there games. I also know that the games they develop are more 'Arcady' than what is expected from most people may expect, but as someone who has fished since I was a child it hurts so much when I play this game and know that is can be improved upon. Unfortunately, that it isnt just the issues with the fishing aspect but the entire game. So I will break this down into Realism issues, gameplay issues and general issues I have with the game.

Fishing Issues:
-It is a shame that a game which focuses so much on animal welfare doesn't actually care for the realism people would use for tackle. There is nothing stopping me from using 25kg (55lb) braid to catch a fish which may be under 1kg (2.2lb). The game solution to this is to give you a score the lighter the tackle and bigger the fish - the higher score you get. Which is how I managed to get a score of 14899 on a "Gold ranked" rainbow trout which took 12 minutes to bring in. This was early on in the game and after getting diamonds, this still is my most fun I had. The issue is there is no incentive for people to use light or realistic tackle on fish because as long as the fish is above a certain weight, you could get a diamond. Which is the complete opposite to The Hunter: Call of the Wild where if you blast a small animal with a big round you will potentially not get diamond rank. I have no idea why this doesn't follow the same methodology because Call of the Wild requires a bit of skill and to not brute force your way through the game.

-Penalties for fishing around objects. This is a simple one, why is it okay for me to cast into some lilies or next to a post and catch a fish like it was nothing? Either make the line snap more easily or add a "Weed/vegetation" mechanic where your hook gets caught in it.

-Penalties for losing gear. Why is it okay for me to lose hooks when I cut the line or get a fish which is too big for my line like it isn't an issue? I know it might be annoying but that's why you buy a packet of hooks and not one hook from a shop.

-Fish spawning, it is really weird that the game basically tells you where diamond ranked fish are. For people who do not have the game, it is basically a quest for each fish. It tells you to take a picture of 'x' location. Once you done that, hundreds of gold rank fish will spawn and eventually a diamond will appear. Once you caught it, they all disappear. I can argue that one diamond in a mission is nice to get you 'HOOKED' (haha get it?) into the game. However the hunting games do not do this and it is so rewarding when you get one and not for it handed to you on a plate. I havent caught a diamond in the wild but I really hope I do, however before I do that. I will do all the missions and get a free diamond, just so the experience of getting a wild one means nothing to me. :)

+Some people say it takes ages to catch a fish, I am sorry that they dont understand how fishing works, but it isnt an issue to catch a fish, and it is quite nice that it can take a few minutes to catch one. Feels more realistc.

Gameplay issues:
- Driving sucks, thankfully you dont do much of that.

- Boats suck, I am not even american but I know that you probably don't use speedboats to catch fish. I believe boats generally get radar or something to find fish in deep water.

- The world is beautiful, I love it. However - The developers have a game which has animals in it. Borrow some of those models to give a bit of life to the game, that would be cool, it isnt hard you are professionals of your job ctrl+c then ctrl+v.

General / My Issues issues:
-Character customisation sucks, I know I dont see my character much, but when I do I will be taking a picture of a cool fish.

-Speaking of fish I love how each fish has the same patterns, no differences at all just big fish, small fish.

-The Hunter: Call of the Wild has a hunting lodge, this is where you can show off your trophies. Expansive Worlds know you'd think that would be cool to have an aquarium of sorts. They'd probably think it would be cool too, but having it in the base game would mean they couldn't sell you it as a DLC. (I remember when they said they wouldnt sell micro transactions in The Hunter Call of the wild).

Posted: December 24, 2022
To be honest, I have no clue about fishing.
I bought the game because the environment looked pretty in the screenshots and because I like exploring and taking screenshots in games.

For that, it's amazing.

There's a wide variety of environments on the map(s), a lot of lakes, ponds, forests, flower fields, tiny houses, secrets to find and discover and I'm a sucker for those.
That's what sold the game to me.

A negative aspect is that there's almost no wildlife, besides the fish, some birds that are glued to the watchtowers, some butterflies, that's it.
There are animal sounds in the background, but you never see any of these animals. This makes the world feel artificial and sometimes like a pretty but dead nuclear wasteland.

One can drive around in a car that is kind of clumsy, gets stuck at every tiny obstacle and struggles uphill with only an average speed of 20 km/h. Or, one can drive in a boat, which is okay, I guess, but still feels like riding a bus on water.

I'd like to see quads to drive around, like in theHunter Call of the Wild, or horses to ride, which would make much more sense in this environment.

Since I mentioned that I have no idea about fishing, all I can say is that it feels tedious and boring to me. I can't imagine how people can do that in real life, for hours, but everyone has their preferences, I guess?
Nevertheless, for the quests and challenges to progress it's okay.

Graphically, I think it's the same engine as theHunter call of the Wild, which is nice, but feels a bit dated in 2022. Fire, trees, and some of the ground textures look hideous and pixelated in 4K.
Overall they've made the best of it and the game still manages to provide a lot of gorgeous screenshot material.

I still wish there were a few more graphic options, like a higher drawing distance, a proper photo mode, or at least a way to hide the HUD icons.

If there is an active quest selected the task is written in GIANT BOOMER FONT all over the screen, which is also kinda annoying.

I'd love to see an update for the game that adds options to: Disable Hud, Cancel Missions, First and Third person camera change for the vehicles, proper name detection instead of ?????, Backpack upgrades, even more things to discover, Horses to ride, a lot more visible wildlife on the map. AND: More maps!

If you've got time, maybe some more character customization options.

Posted: July 13
(Game update came out on Aug. 16 2023 adding and overhauling stuff. Will update the review after I put some time in it.)


Call of the Wild: The Angler is a game I want to enjoy, I try to enjoy, but I am no fisherman. I want to recommend this game, but it doesn't feel finished, let alone polished. Let me explain

Expansive Worlds other products, The Hunter: Call of the Wild or The Hunter let you pretend to be "a hunter" instead of "a fisher". The thing is, those games do a fun simulation while understanding they are a game. They give tools to help us locate animals, they explain the scoring for when you bag an animal. And even if you don't know what your doing at all, the game tries to align you into playing right. The Angler doesn't really have that. Game is fun to walk around, enjoy nature and explore the map... BUT that isn't fishing. The actual "fishing" is a convoluted mess of rods, techniques, lines, bait, and location.

You can buy assorted rods, I am sure they have different values but it is all moonspeak to me and the game doesn't explain it well. You buy reels, some reels don't attach to some rods, so measure twice before buying. All the hooks look the same, but apparantly they are different sizes, no explaination on what hooks do what.... Lines have colors and material builds, I think the only think that matters is the diameter of the line though...

Scoring is convoluted, you get recommendations in your guidebook on what fish are and what kind of water they like. Again, I am no fisherman, and trying to follow the book just has me scratching my head looking at the map.

I am sure my own ignorance is a high wall for my not enjoying myself, and I feel that is the problem. The Hunter and COTW did a great job of slowly directing the player into understanding "the game" and how to improve on you scoring. I also understand this is a product still "in-development" and check back on it every update hoping it will be the update that i suddenly "click" and start having fun.

DO NOT LISTEN TO THE NEGATIVE REVIEWS HERE.

I am a LONG time theHunter player. Been playing the franchise since Classic was on a website (this will be relevant in a sec).

Did this game have a rough launch? Absolutely.
Did the developers fix those issues? Absolutely.

This is one of the best fishing games I have played. It's a great mix between realism and relaxing fun. They have a discord channel specifically for content suggestions and another one for bug reports. They WANT to make this game how everybody wants it. So participate!! But be realistic guys. Don't get upset when they don't add your ridiculous out-of-this-world request that would have to change the entire game's mechanics. And if that is the only way you think this game will be good enough for you, then just delete it and wait for another open world fishing game to come out that meets your standards... good luck lol

If you're on the fence about this game, just get it. Get through the beginning stuff and then when you get to where you have to visit all the places, go to each place and fish there for a bit. Do what the game wants you to do! Explore and fish! It's an OPEN WORLD FISHING GAME! And NO you will not catch a fish every cast. You will not catch a fish at every spot you try. THAT'S THE POINT!

If you love fishing IRL, get this game and take the time to learn it. You won't regret it.

Posted: September 1, 2022
This has gotten a lot of bad reviews and I don't really think they are justified.

First of all for everyone interested in buying: This is a fishing GAME not a fishing simulation. The mechanics are quite simplified and this fills the gap between fishing in games like rdr2/far cry and real fishing simulations.

I played it with a group of 4 players of which two people are experienced anglers in real life, one has just gotten his license and one has never held a fishing rod in his hands. All of us have fun with the game, even tho the more experienced guys feel like the fishing part is a little shallow.

You can get a decent amount of fun out of this game in my opinion.

Pros:
+ Large open world with different places to visit and fish from
+ Vehicles right from the start (unlike the hunter)
+ relaxing fishing gameplay and different fishing methods
+ Graphics are pretty decent with minor inconviniences
+ Not a full price game: 25€ / 30$ (Side note: While there are free alternatives in the fishing simulation genre, they tend to be either very grindy tho admittedly some people like that feel of progression, or you have to pay for stuff within the game with real money)
+ The ambient sounds are good as to be expected from EW

Cons:
- Gameplay is quite shallow for experienced players
- Graphics could use some fixing
- Multiplayer is buggy af. It took as quite some time to get 4 players into the same server
- Some animations are lacking or just plain missing.

Things that should be improved in my opinion:
* Fix Multiplayer
* Fix Bugs
* Add more animations
* Add difficulty settings (removing HUD, options to adjust realism)
* Add some critters to make map more alive (they could literally reuse assets from "the hunter" to add ducks and hares :D)

EW is known for adding stuff after the game is released over the following years. Things I would be looking forward to are:
* "Hunting Lodge" / Aquarium / Photobook
* Add more quests
* New maps
* New fishing methods (fly fishing, feeder fishing, throwing bait into the water to increase bite rate and stuff)

Posted: November 5
Product received for free

Introduction
"Give a man a fish, and you feed him for a day. Teach a man to fish, and you feed him for a lifetime." A familiar bit of wisdom and it is the gospel truth as far as I'm concerned. Feeding is a base need, so how about more complex desires? Unlike hunting, the noble sport of fishing involves almost no violence or risks for those which partake in it. Especially so if you apply the "catch & release" rationale as well.

Precisely this method is maintained by Call of the Wild: The Angler in its approach to simulating sport fishing while emphasising a clear message in regards to environmental sustainability. It's the third project for developer and publisher Expansive Worlds. Their previous titles were focused entirely on hunting, so I am glad they branched towards fishing in the meantime.

The base game focuses on a single location in the United States of America. For creative reasons alone, I presume that the developers only inspired themselves from the real life Yellowstone National Park and renamed the new site as Golden Ridge Reserve. Everything else points at a near identical origin to Yellowstone: from the 19th Century inception via presidential decree, to more precise elements such as topography and a map that's bordering three US States (Wyoming, Idaho and Montana).

Golden Ridge has been crafted with attention to detail in mind. It reminds me of Firewatch (located in the Yellowstone Timberland Reserve) since it also features plenty of watchtowers is similar circumstances. The Angler does have a story, in spite of its open ended structure. Clayton Johnson is the Golden Ridge Reserve Warden. A park ranger, if you will. You're his new deputy, a blank slate, silent protagonist that's fully customizable. Clayton will affectionately refer to you as "Buckaroo".



Without any time constraints getting in the way, you've been tasked with assisting the Warden in his daily survey activities. This by itself involves exploring the reserve and pinpointing various anomalies you'll undoubtedly find on your path towards the next ideal fishing spot. Side missions contain invasive species and various collectibles, spicing things up when you wish to take a break from angling. The Golden Ridge's shop owner, Sophia Taylor will act as a veritable guide apart from her standard activities regarding the purchase and management of your gear.

The Angler is being powered by an updated version of the Apex Avalanche, a propietary engine developed by Expansive Worlds and used efficiently in their past games as well. Apart from a couple of crashes to desktop which I'll write off as par for the course, given my aging system, no stability issues to report. Frame rate is stable and running the game almost maxed out (I'm always disabling motion blur and depth of field) was a cakewalk even for a 2016 midrange PC.

There's plenty to see in Call of the Wild: The Angler. Simply taking in the sights, finding the perfect angles for a cool screenshot (pressing "P" disables the HUD) became a side activity for me. The day & night cycle becomes important from more than just a gameplay perspective. Seasonal events, such as the recently ended Halloween theme, further enhances the locations with new decorations.

The voice acting is passable, while the background noises are emphasizing on the serene aspect of your fishing trips. Add a soundtrack to that and you're on your way to Skyrim, my friend. You know why you're in the Golden Ridge Reserve though. Top notch angling on top of relaxing environments. No dire wolves or frost trolls in sight.



As a simulation performing a balancing act between realism and arcade elements, I wasn't entirely surprised that there isn't an underwater "chase camera" while battling fish trying to escape my hooks. The aforementioned barebones fishing mechanics in Skyrim Special Edition won't cut it, Red Dead Redemption 2 was a the middle ground arcade option and it also didn't feature the option to see fish struggling underwater. Perhaps this will be added in the Angler at some point, but its absence is not a deal breaker for me.

Whether you practice your fishing skills with floating baits (a waiting game) or take the proactive luring methods which involve constant movement, the bigger the catch, the more it will fight to escape your warm embrace. Knowing when to tighten or loosen the tension of your fishing line will be crucial to success. Reinvesting your credits (in-game currency, no microtransactions at all) into better gear is paramount. Rods, fishing lines and lures should be your priority.

Clothing items or new vehicle skins can wait until you've got superior fishing gear netting you silver and gold ranking fish. Speaking of which, some of the best fish species ranking-wise, are crepuscular. So your best chances of catching noteworthy specimens, should be around sunset and sunrise. Patience is the key here, but I think you already expected that from a fishing title. Change tactics and fishing spots constantly for maximum efficiency.

Now, this can be a walking sim if you want to "hoof it around", but why now try the offroad vehicular option, a Jeep Wrangler lookalike or sailing via speedboats? The latter option is quite useful for fishing in the middle of the lakes and who knows, perhaps you may even meet some legendary critters while you at it. Catch & release only. An aquarium would be a nice idea for a future DLC. Certainly better than mounting a fish trophy on a wall and more in tune with the conservationist message conveyed in the Angler.



It's not the biggest open world for a title focusing on natural exploration, but it's densely packed with details off the beaten path. The full zen experience in a neat package that also involves fishing. Truly, if hunting wouldn't be your cup of tea from a moral standpoint, at least you can indulge into sport fishing with a clear conscience that the creatures you are angling in this entry of Call of the Wild, won't end up on a grill. We're in this for the sportsmanship, not mere sustenance after all.

+ Relaxing gameplay.
+ Beautiful simulation.
+ Steam Achievements.

- No Steam Trading Cards.
- No underwater camera.

Posted: February 23
Update - July 22, 2023 - Still very underwhelming, after another two hours of play, it just feels like work, not overly fun or challenging, and kind of a drag. Issues I had before are still present, and overall, still unimpressed. Will probably try again in a few months.


This game should be renamed "Call of the Wild: The Wanderer" or "The Walker" Cause it's all you will do. And not for the better.

Absolute lack of fun. You start the game with a 3 ft rod, and a reel that can apparently only hold essentially 2lbs test line. Want to jump right in and go fishing? Nope. Almost every fish I have hooked has been far too large for my starting setup, fight the fish for literally 10 minutes and gain zero line and don't even tire it out a little until it snaps off... and this is at the location they start you at, immediately after the tutorial. Okay, guess i'll go buy some new gear? Nope. Cause you have no money, cause you can't catch fish... alright, so how do I make money and get XP as a new player? Well, there are two ways that I have found:

1. You can fish for micro fish, which essentially are very small large mouth bass or the more common perch. The perch which are about 40 grams in size will net you a whopping 1 xp. They're not even worth the cost of the bait you will use to catch them..
OR
2. You can go the second route, which is to completely ignore fishing and to turn the game into a looooong and dreadful walking simulator. Run around and discover the areas for xp, and look for flowers and diseased trees.... That's right, in this FISHING game, the best way for a new player to level up and make money is TO RUN AROUND COLLECTING FLOWERS...

Make sense out of that. Picture this: You've bought a fishing game. "Gee I sure can't wait to fish!" you say, as it downloads. Run the game, play the tutorial, "Oh, this is alright" you think. Finish the basic tutorial, keep fishing. Hook something. "OH BOY! It's fighting!" Fight it for 10 minutes, playing the drag, trying to pump it, fight it's direction, reel like a SOB, aaaanddddd... wait... is it still 28 meters from shore? Ok... keep going, fish pulls, fish stops pulling, nothing moves, repeat, and eventually SNAP! Lost the fish, lost 20 minutes of your life, lost your bait, that you have to pay to replace, and you got zero XP or money.... "Gee.." you think, "What should I do to make money so I can purchase the standard items I need to actually fish?" Well, as you run around looking for anything to ease the misery of trying to catch trout using essentially a stick with a piece of hair tied to it you discover a glowing thing.. you approach and it's a flower, you collect it, "HERE IS SOME XP AND MONEY!" The game says. And now you're playing "COTW: The Wanderer". As you continue walking around and not fishing though you begin to see all the off putting things. Floating rocks, sounds of animals that don't exist. UI issues, terrain that looks so unnatural in it's form and shape that I could have made it better myself in UE5... you finally say "Well, that's enough of this..." and you're past the return window, so here rots another game that was released way too early, one that you've now paid for and tried, and have such a sour taste from that you may never try it again...

I've had more fun at the dentist getting a tooth pulled, at least that was exciting enough to make my heart beat...

This is trash. Absolutely no fun. Why must games make new players suffer and struggle and grind to be able to just afford the standard wal-mart gear and be able to play the game decently well and actually have fun.

Now, does the game look good? Yes. Mos things look great, except a few floating rocks, and questionably sculpted terrain. However, remember, this is a FISHING game, not a walking sim. Quit making me be miserable for 6 hours before I can enjoy the game... does it play well? I mean, from the VERY limited fishing I did that wasn't just casting and waiting, yeah it's alright, but the fact remains, when you start this game new, you're going to have a terrible time, you're probably not going to do much fishing (at least not successfully), and eventually you'll get two and a half hours in and realise you've had enough and quit, probably forever or at least for a long time since you've past the return window...

Some more things I don't get, why do some lakes give you a "Fishing area discovery" and then tell you what fish are in that water, but most don't. We're talking like, 20% that do. Do the rest of the waters not have any fish in them? Are they just filler for the map? Like, the idea behind an open world fishing game has always been a hope of mine, to be able to go anywhere on a map and cast into anything and see what happens, but this honestly is terrible.

So TLDR:
If you want a walking sim, and to run around literally looking for flowers, this game is for you. If you want to enjoy a fishing game, sit on a dock and catch a few fish, this game is not for you.

WHAT I WOULD LIKE TO SEE:

1. Don't pay to replace bait. Just buy it once and it's there. Constantly replenishing and buying bait is a time and money waster.
2. Better and more actually realistic starting gear. There's no reason why I can't land a 3 pound fish with my starting gear. I'm an angler, i'm trying to fish, i'm not a caveman or a some completely unknowing new fisherman. This game is obviously meant to be more for people who have REAL life fishing experience, so why make them suffer at the start of the game? Give me an actual rod and reel with some line that can actually hold a fish.. not some makeshift smelt fishing setup...
3. More fast travel. I get it, "open world" means exploring. But there's just too much space to cover here, it's a buzz killer, or compress the open space. Yeah running around is part of the fun, but at a rate of 10:1 compared to actually fishing, it's just no good.
4. More consistent water body info. If I walk up to some ponds and they have info tabs than all bodies of water should, even multiple for different parts. No fish in this puddle? Tell me that too.
5. Improve the casting. It's weird, feels strange and is way too hard to control or use any finesse.
6. More smaller fish (if you aren't gonna let me catch the big ones until I make a bunch of money...) Really, if you want to force me to catch tiny fish to get money and buy new gear, at least make them easier to find and more plentiful. I get that fishing ins't a guarantee, and an open world game is meant to be realistic, but the fact that it's so dependant on small fish at the start and the fact that you can't reliably catch fish to your "level" is frustrating.
7. Severely limit the "fetch" quests. It's a fishing game, stop making me run around collecting flowers..
8. Improve the water. Yeah fluid dynamics are hard. Water in video games is hard. But this game should focus mainly on water cause that's where fishing happens. Reeling in a spinner makes the water look like an alligator is about to come out. The fish jumping also looks really strange.

Honestly, there is potential, it's just not there yet. And buying it at this point (specially at full price) will sour you so bad, you won't even want to try it later when it may be better.
Just wait a year or two until it's decent, or maybe get it at a severe discount (I got it at 67% off, still feels like a waste of money right now...)

If you read this whole thing, I truly appreciate you.

Thank you.

Posted: October 23
this game is a good fishing game when the fish are biting........ the first good stretch of 20-25 hours was great i like it alot but somewhere along the way the fish started to bite less and now when i boot up the game and attempt to fish i get zero bites to the point where i just get upset after about 20 mins of having nothing take my baits. i use the correct tackle and even the wrong tackle. i switch up the target fish and cycle through the tackle but nothing i do results in having fish on. even after finding spread sheets on what is used for what and doing the circle jerk there nothing is working. i can drop a line right on a fish i'm trying to catch with the right tackle and nothing happens. it used to not be this way.
another issue is that the quest fish you're supposed to go catch for the BS reward system don't exist. after 10 hours of trying to catch a single fish not even the tier of fish but just that one specific species they just refuse to give it to me.
on to other problems.... the movement is trash, when you're running straight and hit A or D your character jerks to a stop and instantly strafes left or right. turning feels like a slow motion molasses sham. driving is serviceable but far from good. boat driving is ok but you lack the ability to go slow and make less noise in a game where "making noise" allegedly scares the fish away. which i don't think i've seen anywhere in the game but everyone on the official discord says is real.

bottom line is it needs work on the core game. balancing between the tackle needs work. they need to provide actual data in game for what the tackle does. hook sizes have zero info on what weight groups they work for. as well as there is no weight to species data to show what tier the fish are that can be caught. it's all guess work within a network of RNG values.

Posted: September 6, 2022
You know what....I crap on a LOT of games in reviews, but this one doesn't deserve half the crap it's getting.

I spent the last few days playing Fishing Planet and The Angler side by side at the same time, and honestly, The Angler is the one I find more enjoyable.

The actual fishing feels pretty much the same with the main difference being Fishing Planet seems to focus on the strike and The Angler focuses more on the fight.

I also have to give The Angler a win in that the gear system is 1000x better as it's not developed in any way to push you towards buying DLC packs. I have all the rods I need in The Angler, I don't need to buy a rod case. I don't need to get spammed to buy a Boat pack or the newest fishing expedition every single time I go anywhere like in Fishing Planet.

Also, speaking of boats and being spammed to buy things, The Angler has multiplayer and more than just one person can ride in a bass boat. CRAAAAZY. I was about to buy a boat pack on Fishing Planet to haul friends around since I figured "Eh, I spend a couple bucks and then the game is free so it evens out" - then I see only one person fits in a boat on Fishing Planet. Well done The Angler, you've put yourself waaaay out ahead for me personally because I love playing games with friends and The Angler seems 100% more geared towards this.

Also, the waterways on just the ONE location you can go in The Angler seem larger than ALL of fishing planet put together. Much sad.

So yeah, would I buy this game again? I think so, I have a feeling the issues with this game are going to be reformed the same way Hunter: CoTW was, so I'm interested to see what the devs do in the future, and $25 for a new game is pretty much nothing these days.

The new version is a very bad update, there is no longer the old version of the painting experience, I am very disappointed with the current version, and hope that the developers can immediately improve the game experience, the following are the problems I found：
1. In the public room, you can't start the game happily, because there are always people repeatedly entering and leaving the room, which makes it impossible to start the game, I think the game should cancel pushing room information when everyone is ready to start the game.
2. In the new version, if you choose the wrong lexicon or other settings, you can't go back to the waiting lobby in the game, which makes everyone annoyed.
3. In the game, when your brush draws to a location with UI, the brush can't draw properly. This is a bug in the new version, which will cause the full-screen landscape drawing to no longer draw better.
4. When someone quits during the game, the Tab's people list and the chat bar will be disabled to some extent.
5. In a normal 15s~300s painting game, the brush update is the most unreasonable, which is a very serious problem, because in a short painting time you don't have much time to adjust the value, this update is not even as good as the old version's 3 point value, which will make people feel stupid, I hope the developer can restore the old version's 3 fixed brush values in the next update again, or set it as an option that can Let the player choose the option.
6. In the painting game, the "point" and "short line" drawn by the brush is not very good, can be further optimized.
7. Flash animation will be played at the end of the game, which is more interesting than the old version, but you can't skip it, so it will seem a bit troublesome.
8. The tools used for drawing should not be limited to the mouse, in this update, if the tablet is connected after entering the game, the tablet will not work properly, which is not good for the game experience.

I hope this game can become better because it allows people to meet many friends and lose many friends.

Posted: November 16, 2022
As someone who grew up playing LittleBigPlanet, I'll try to be unbiased. After all, this is NOT a LittleBigPlanet game. However, this game is solid in its own ways.

Pros:
-amazing graphics and performance (I haven't had any issues with stuttering like some people are saying and I have a mid-grade at best PC)
-Soundtrack is perfection, possibly the best of the franchise
-not terribly difficult but could be challenging at times
-coop/multiplayer is fun and works smoothly
-controls are fine. I use an Xbox controller and I have had no issues at all

Cons:
-only 1 con and I know I said I wouldn't compare too heavily to LBP but the ability to be creative took a massive step backwards. No moon, no custom levels, and no pod. Also no stickers or decorations. So if you wanted to make hair with decorations like you did back in LBP2 or spam stickers everywhere you can't do that lol.

All in all, solid game all around. If you played LBP you'd enjoy this game. I definitely felt nostalgia playing this. PlayStation, Sumo Digital, and whoever else: pls hear all of us out. Remaster LBP 1+2 (or make LBP4), make it cross platform with PS5 and PC, and allow us the fun customization that we all know and love. There is so much potential to revive this franchise it is literally oozing from the screen. Pls give the fans what they want.

Overall: 8/10

Posted: December 14, 2022
Let me preface this review by saying, I love LittleBigPlanet. I love LittleBigPlanet more than you could ever know. LittleBigPlanet 2 is my contender for the single best game ever made. I can say with full confidence that nothing that I have played, am playing, or will play in the future, can ever surpass the unbridled joy that I received from playing that game as a lad. And, coming into this game, I lowered my expectations accordingly. I knew it wouldn't, couldn't, be the same. But, if this game could just manage to recapture even a fraction of that joy, then it would be a winner.
This game did not do that.
This game made me actively upset.
Firstly, I struggle to imagine the reasoning behind making this game a tight, "Super Mario 3D Land"-like platformer when one of the main appeals of LittleBigPlanet is its loose, physics-based puzzle platformer gameplay. In LittleBigPlanet, Sackboy behaves much like any other physics object in the game. He can be flung around, he has inertia, he can be pushed and pulled, he can fall over other objects, etc. Speedrunners of the game have found many ways to exploit the physical properties of Sackboy to pull off some wild movement tech, and the skill ceiling is surprisingly high, despite its simple appearances. What I'm trying to say is, controlling Sackboy in LittleBigPlanet is FUN. Not only that, but it requires skill. You can improve at it. The hard level community in LittleBigPlanet makes a lovely showcase of pushing Sackboy to his absolute limits (for an example, look up "adsffff" on YouTube dot com).
Controlling Sackboy in Sackboy: A Big Adventure is not fun. Controlling Sackboy in Sackboy: A Big Adventure is EXHAUSTING. Remember all that stuff I said earlier, about Sackboy himself having physics? That has been completely discarded in this game. Sackboy moves at one (abysmally slow) speed, that you can marginally increase by rolling. Your speed might increase when rolling down one of the few slopes in this game. Sometimes. But don't find yourself having TOO much fun, old chum, because that speed boost you get is often woefully short-lived, brought to its untimely demise by a Bounce Pad lying in wait at the bottom, which will... launch you? No, no, that would be somewhat exciting. The Bounce Pad will gently push you into the air, like a mother pushing her baby on a swing. Many slopes in this game don't have the decency to even give you that release, instead, they make you watch as Sackboy unceremoniously sliiiiides down to the bottom. Oh, and since this game is a platformer, I suppose it's obligated to have a jump, too. I don't think I've ever seen a platformer with a more painfully basic jump. In stark contrast to LittleBigPlanet's jump, which let you fine tune its height down to the most minute level, Sackboy's jump in this game has one height that is achieved by holding Cross, and one slightly lower height that is achieved by tapping Cross. How ambitious! Also, do you recall how in LittleBigPlanet, Sackboy's jump retained his momentum? Well, Sumo Digital must have thought that was just far too extreme for us to handle, so the jump in this game brings you to a screeching halt, no matter how fast you're going. No slope jumps or bunny hopping to be seen here. It's as if the very act of moving himself is a Herculean task for Sackboy. Sackboy does not "run" in this game. Sackboy trudges. He struggles to push himself through the soulless wastelands of this game.
I do not use the word "soulless" lightly here. LittleBigPlanet 3 may not have been Allah's gift to gaming, but at the very least it felt like a game made by people who had an inkling of passion and respect for Media Molecule's masterpiece. This game feels as if Sony had asked Sumo Digital, "make a 3D platformer for our PS5 launch, please," and the poor employees all begrudgingly got to work, dusting off Sackboy with a look of desolation on their faces. I'd like to pose a question. Do you think, if Sackboy was replaced by a different character in this game, that people would even notice? The worlds themselves are so generic that I struggle to find anything in them that would make me think this game has any relation to LittleBigPlanet. Grass world, jungle world, water world, sci-fi world, Vex world. Wow. Don't strain yourselves coming up with these original level themes, guys. The grass world even had SNOW in it! And, what's that brown, fuzzy creature traversing through these riveting locales?
To be honest, I can't tell you what that... THING we control in Sackboy: A Big Adventure is. But it is not Sackboy. It does not move like Sackboy, it does not look like Sackboy, it does not even attempt to sound like Sackboy. It is a wretched fiend, devoid of heart, wearing the tattered pelt of our old friend, and insisting that it is him. Every time I hear that creature let out a boyish "hup!" as it heaves itself into a pitiful jump, my skin crawls. I am in no way using hyperbole when I say that it makes me sick to my stomach. It doesn't matter how many familiar costumes it fastens to itself. It is not Sackboy. It will never be Sackboy.
If you, at any point, loved the LittleBigPlanet franchise, and are thinking of purchasing this game, I have one piece of advice for you. Don't. Stay far, far away. Keep your pleasant memories just as they are, as memories. This game is an insult to Sackboy, an insult to LittleBigPlanet, and an insult to Media Molecule. Furthermore, it is an assault on human creativity, and I am sorry to have played it.
Oh, and the other reviews may have clued you into this, but yes, Epic Games is here. You know, in the Steam game I bought? There's nothing I can say about that that hasn't already been said.
Thankfully, the future of LittleBigPlanet is not as desolate as this game would make you believe. Keep an eye on Project Lighthouse and Restitched. That's all I have to say.

Posted: October 27, 2022
If we put aside all the discussions about the new PC features and yet another former Playstation exclusive getting a PC release, and instead get to the point: Sackboy: A Big Adventure is a single player/co-op story-driven platformer. Let's take a brief look at the main aspects of the game.

Neuter:

• Structurally, the game is as simple as it gets: there are 5 worlds, each of which contains roughly 10-15 levels. Core gameplay loop consists of running through various obstacle courses, returning to the hub world where you can change your appearance if you wish and then enter the next level (as a general rule, the levels are connected linearly, with a rare exception when the player gets to choose between 2-3 levels). And that's all there is to it.

• For those who want to master the game and perfect their skills, there's plenty of endgame content after the main story and also a time trials mode called Knitted Knight Trials.

• Seeing how the game is clearly family-oriented (kid-friendly rating, kind and cute humor, etc), the general difficulty should be manageable for the vast majority of the players. Besides, in case you run into difficulties, there's an option to activate an infinite lives mode in the settings, which guarantees that you avoid potential frustration that could've been caused if you lost all of your lives and had to start the level from the beginning again (or choose another level from the hub world if there is one). However, it needs to be said that such an assumption applies only to the main campaign. Knitted Knight Trials and endgame content require advanced mastery.



+ There are tons of mechanics and possibilities that allow you to interact with your co-op partners, decent bosses (or as decent as they can be in a platformer), and the combinations of the aforementioned stuff on many levels, with the gradually increasing level of difficulty. Honestly, it doesn't make a lot of sense to list everything the game has to offer, I just want to state the fact that thanks to this gameplay variety, I can hardly imagine anyone growing bored, unless they disliked the game in the first place.

+ There is a straightforward character customization system in the game. The in-game currency that you collect during gameplay allows you to purchase complete sets/suits, or separate parts of those sets/suits, emojis, Sackboy's colors and fabrics in the local store. This system allows the main character's avatar to stay dripped out throughout the entire game. Fortunately, there are no microtransactions in the game. Therefore, the more you play - the more stuff you'll be able to purchase in the in-game store. The pricing is quite fair - a single playthrough will get you enough currency to purchase a few full sets from each world even if you don't get the highest scores.

+ Absolutely stellar soundtrack. Each level has its own theme song. Sometimes it's something that was made specifically for the game, other times it's a worldwide hit such as "Take On Me", and each track synergizes perfectly with everything that is happening on your screen.



- Each level in the game contains special orbs. These orbs are not just achievement-related collectibles and they're not there solely to boost your score and give you bragging rights either. They are, in fact, the keys that unlock the new levels and are essential for story progress. Simply put: let's say you need 10 orbs to unlock the next world, but you've only managed to collect 9 after having beaten the previous one. In this case you'll have to return to one of previous levels and collect the orbs you've missed to get the required number. Since the developers apparently realized how frustrating this mechanic could've potentially ended up being, in my opinion, they set a rather low bar for the amount of orbs required to unlock the next levels, seeing how we never had to replay a single level for that purpose. We did, however, replay a few levels because we enjoyed them that much! With that said, we need to keep in mind that the skill of the players varies dramatically and I can imagine a world where some players would have to GRIND in a platformer for kids. And if that happens - it becomes detrimental to their experience and, as such, becomes a serious downside.

Posted: February 16
This game is fantastic. Sackboy helped my wife and I through one of the hardest times in our lives. Our son was born premature at 26 weeks weighing 1lb 7 ounces. It was a long four months driving back and forth to work and the hospital. During this time, I suggested we play something to take our mind off of our circumstances if only for an hour or so. She reluctantly agreed and I picked out sackboy. At the time, I had a PS5 which I sold later to cover some medical bills. We loved the entire experience. The music levels are brilliant and I couldn't help but smile everytime we jumped into craft world. It can be a tougher game, but its really worth it. My wife played and she had no real gaming experience so i don't mind recommending it to gamers of any level! The graphics are gorgeous, the music is sublime, and it's endlessly fun. I'm playing it now on my steamdeck while my son is asleep at night. I bought it on sale, but I would have paid full price both times for it considering my nostalgia with it. First of all, keep 'em coming Sony.

I've never played LBP, but based on the trailers and bit of gameplay I've seen, LBP was a lot darker and edgy, which is not exactly my thing, however Sackboy it's more wholesome and in my opinion, It's the definition of an E rated game, which is not bad at all. Not only can you play it with your little sibling or children but you'll have lots of fun. And while not required to advance, it can become challenging to try and 100% the whole thing.

The game looks amazing graphically speaking and the whole world and characters have this style that look like handmade, beautiful. It still needs a bit of optimization though, and for some reason having a PS5 controller wired to the PC for it's features tanked my fps. Otherwise controls are pretty good and intuitive, it definitely seems like a Sackboy themed Super Mario World, and since Nintendo won't release those on PC I think it's the closest you can get.

As with other Playstation titles, the challenges or trials in this case, were the most tedious part of the game, but definitely worth trying to complete. Other than that there was only one level near the ending that really gave me a bad time, but with practice the gold rank is doable.

In conclusion, pretty decent platformer, good graphics and style, in need of a bit of optimization, co-op must play, get it on sale.

Posted: November 2, 2022
i7 8700k, 32 GB RTX3080ti
------------------------------
Update 2022/09/11 - Shader Stuttering seems to be fixed - Time to enjoy this beautiful game
With today's update, the shader problems seem to be fixed. I deleted my savegames to restart the game and so far all is smooth in 60 FPS with maxed settings and ray tracing in 2K resolution.

The camera stuttering with mismatching FPS game/monitor hertz settings is still there. Work-around is still working: simply set FPS and monitor refresh rate to the same number your system is able to provide at a stable rate. My CPU is too old to get a stable 120hz without lowering DLSS to performance, but I get stable 60 FPS with DLSS quality mode.

The game looks fantastic on PC and thanks to the smooth performance now, it's as enjoyable as the PS5 version. WIth the vast range of graphic settings and the fixed stuttering, it should run well on mid range PCs. I change my recommendation.

---------------------------------------
Original review of 2022/09/02
Sackboy is a very beautiful PC port, the ray tracing additions let it stand out compared to the PS5 version, but so does the shader stuttering... which shatters the whole experience.

From the start on, you will be facing stuttering with this title, especially strong when you come into a new cutscene or a new level with lotsa new elements. Everytime some new element (enemy, item, effects) shows up for the first time, you will face micro stutter, no matter how powerful your system might be.

Replaying a level only solves the problem temporarily, as soon as you update your graphic card driver, the stutter will start all over again. This could easily be solved if the game would take a few minutes and compile all shaders on the first game start (and whenever you update drivers).

As DF pointed out there's an additional problem: camera stutter on flexible FPS. Work-around: set the FPS limiter and refresh-rate of your monitor to the same number your system is able to deliver at a stable rate, e.g. 60FPS/60Hz, 120FPS/120Hz etc.

While I appreciate the graphical update, negligences like this in a big budget title aren't acceptable. On the other hand, former PS ports were very solid or quickly fixed.

Meanwhile I recommend Uncharted instead, as God of War an awesome PS port. Uncharted builds the shaders in the background and shows the percentage. So you can either wait for it to complete or if it doesn't affect the performance of your current level let it do its stuff while enjoying a silky smooth game.

I hope Sackboy sees a similar solution in the near future.
