Posted: November 3, 2022
Review by Gaming Masterpieces - The greatest games of all time on Steam.

Is this game a masterpiece? YES, absolutely. 3D platformers don't get much better than this. This game is (after Gods of War, Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves and Ratchet & Clank) another PlayStation-exclusive hit ported to the PC. You can now also experience the adventures of the likeable hero from sackcloth on Steam. The game has been on the PlayStation market for almost 2 years. Who is Sackboy, anyway? Some may never have heard the name. Well, Sackboy is the knitted hero from the Little Big Planet games. For the launch of Sony's PlayStation 5, he finally got his first standalone adventure of his own. Unlike the Little Big Planet games, however, where players could create their own games and share them with the community, Sackboy: A Big Adventure is a pure 3D platformer with a focus on action and with a fun multiplayer mode. However, a level editor is no longer included.

A platform game lives and dies with its controls. The design goal of it was therefore a control system that is really simple and accessible, but also has a certain depth. Therefore, Sackboy's repertoire of movements has been greatly expanded compared to the previous games. He can jump, of course, he can run, and grabbing and pulling things is a really important part of the game. But then a bunch of other moves have been added. For example, a rolling movement for dodging, a graphically totally cute hover mode, the possibility of a smash jump.... Sackboy now also has movement options that can be found in other 3D games. In addition, there is his fist punch, which can now be triggered simply by pressing the X button, and with which smaller opponents can already be eliminated with one hit. In combination with these movement possibilities, quite complex sequences are now possible, which are simply necessary for a challenging and exciting platformer. A loss of life resets you at the last (of the numerous) save points within a level, but if you lose all lives, it's back to the world map.

What is the story actually about? Well, the story is not a masterpiece, but leans very much on the usual hero story of computer games. Especially in platformers, I've seen it more than once... Bad guy shows up, kidnaps all my friends, only I can still save my friends (and the whole world). It wasn't just in the fantastic Sonic Generations that it was like that. But why invent something new when the old stories work well? In this case, it's the insidious Vex who suddenly flies in and sucks up all the villagers with his hoover, only Sackboy can escape quickly with a small rocket. Vex is now forcing our friends to build a very strange and evil device that will turn the whole world into a parched, barren eyesore full of nightmares. Of course, we have to stop that!

Our adventure to stop the nasty Vex takes us through completely different worlds. From snowy mountains, a tropical jungle, an underwater world or even a detour into outer space, everything is there. The view is isometric - we see our hero from behind or from the side, whereby, interestingly, the angle of view is fixed. In contrast to most comparable 3D platformers, we cannot move the view with the right stick - instead, we always see Sackboy from a little further away from a predefined viewing angle. It is therefore no longer so easy for inexperienced players to lose track. However, our hero can be seen a little smaller on the screen due to the slightly more distant camera, which makes precision jumps more difficult to perform. In general, however, you get used to this way of displaying the game very quickly and control Sackboy like a pro through the increasingly complex sections of the game. In addition, it is practically impossible to get sick because of the 3D graphics. Each section is filled to the brim with collectibles and hidden challenges outside the direct path to the end of the level. Even on the overview maps there are many hidden areas to find.

The game does not include a level editor. However, you can still exercise your creativity in creating new things - by customising your character to your liking. In the shop of Zom Zom we can exchange the collectibles (bells) we collect during the game for new outfits (and hats, emotes or faces). You can also change the colour of your hero and save your creations of outfit, hat, face, emotes and colour. The selection of items already unlocked for Sackboy from the beginning is large. Very extensive. Some additional skins can also be discovered and unlocked directly in the game itself. Finally, you can download two additional free DLCs on Steam with which you can transform Sackboy into Nathan Drake or Chloe Frazer from Uncharted.

A special feature is the online multiplayer mode. You can take on Sackboy's adventures with up to four players. This is basically a cooperative multiplayer mode, but you can also annoy each other. Picking up the other player and throwing them around may be useful in many situations, but can also be quite tedious if it happens for no apparent reason. All levels can be played together, and in addition to the main missions, there are some multiplayer-only levels where cooperative action is necessary to get to the end.

Aren't consoles actually the species-appropriate habitat for classic 3D platformers? Super Mario 64 (for the Nintendo 64) is still considered the first really good game of its kind, and for a long time there were hardly any comparable good things on the PC. But those days are probably over now. With megahits like A Hat in Time, Psychonauts 2 and the recently released Kao the Kangaroo, there are also first-class genre representatives for the PC. Kao the Kangoroo in particular reminded me of the good old days with the Nintendo 64. Many of the classics originally released on consoles have also made it to the PC, and here (since they were released much later than the original) they are technically by far the best versions. Just a small selection of the stuff worth recommending: Crash Bandicoot n Sane Trilogy with the first three games of the originally PlayStation exclusive story of Naughty Dog's lovable bandicoot, the Spyro Reignited Trilogy with the first three parts of the adventures of the young dragon Spyro, or the not so childish adventures of Sponge Boob in SpongeBob SquarePants: Battle for Bikini Bottom - Rehydrated. Finally, in July, Hell Pie, a new game by a slightly unsavoury little devil, came onto the market, which doesn't have to hide from the long-established brands either.

The graphics of Sackboy don't look that exciting at first glance. Maybe that's because I didn't find the predecessor Little Big Planet particularly good-looking either - but that was my personal taste. At second glance, however, I have to say that Sackboy: A Big Adventure is also an absolutely top game in terms of graphics. The levels are extremely varied, there are countless animations, enemy types and always new surprises to find. The graphics are colourful, high-resolution and technically the developer has made full use of the capabilities of modern PCs (or graphics cards). You can play the game in a razor-sharp 4K (3840 × 2160) resolution on your new TV, you can play it on your ultrawide gaming monitor with 3440x1440 (21:9), you play with 60 FPS if you have the appropriate hardware, newer Nvidia graphics cards offer Super Sampling (DLSS) and a correspondingly high screen refresh rate far beyond 60 Hz is also no problem. Gamepad works of course fine, you can even use the special features of the official wireless PlayStation 5 controller... if you connect it to your PC via cable.


Sackboy is good, really good. One of the best 3D platformers currently available on the PC.

Posted: January 5
So what's it about?
It's Sack Boy!!! And you can play it on PC how cool is that :-). It's best described as a 3D platforming game similar like Mario Odyssey. You are the unlikely hero to save the world from the Baddies. This world is so full of textures, materials and little details that you just want to step inside your PC and touch it.

The good
The graphics, the sounds effects and the music is some of the best you can find at the moment on PC. It looks so good and plays so well. I used a controller and I had a great experience (TBH I cannot see how you would be able to play it without controller but it’s there if you like 😊).

There is so much customisation - emotes, costumes and then you can mix it all up. There are so many cool details to discover; a lot of love went into the game. You can even dress up like a silly chromium LED banana with New Years glasses: what more do you want?

I love the challenge the trial levels offers and some of the later levels .

There is local coop and it works remarkably well but... (see below)

... some levels require two players to complete - you can finish the first one by one player but it's awkward. The latter levels are much more demanding and you really need another player. With online multiplayer being what it is - it would have been great to have an AI to assist you or just not to make the coop levels a requirement for completion.

It has the Epic Games overlay. Why? I bought the game on Steam not on Epic :-(. An optional sign-up/in to Sony PlayStation is asked - as a reward you will get an additional costume. At first I thought signing in to PSN would allow cross play but that is not the case. Likely because the game signs in to three different networks the first 10 seconds at the title screen is experience stuttering. It doesn't affect the main game at all but it remains annoying.

There is no online cross play - I looked for Steam (Epic?) players several times but unfortunately no one was there. If you would like to complete the many multiplayer achievements then this will be a challenge unless you can find someone to partner up locally.

Unfortunately, there is no HDR support - while the game looks great it would look even better with HDR. The closest is perhaps using Win11 AutoHDR function.

I had two hard crashes (blue screen) while the game being paused. I’m not sure what happened there. Other than that, I didn't experience any issues, bugs or glitches.

It would be great if the game had a level editor like Mario Maker and that you could share levels with the online community.

There is a huge difficulty spike between the end of world 4 and world 5 . If you plan to ace all of these levels, be prepared to restart a lot until you get it exactly right. Sometimes it is just skill and other times pure luck - there are some levels where the margin of error is like 0.1 second or less. You make a mistake just before the end? You will have to restart. This is less of an issue if you just want to complete the story and I suppose there is some reward when you finally get it right.

I always wanted to play Sack Boy but I never had the opportunity to get a PlayStation. I absolutely loved the game and I can highly recommend it if you like cute (3D) platforming games. The game is not challenging at first but offers instead a chill experience with great music, visual and so much customisation to Sack Boy. This changes for the last third of the game where it becomes challenging to impossible – but most players will not see this part I assume while looking at the achievement. It is a work of art - and probably the best 3D platform experience on par with Mario Odyssey. It offers easy local COOP. What I didn’t like are the many networks the game needs to sign in and the lack of cross play.

Posted: December 22, 2022
It is really hard to talk about this game, LBP is a classic ip that lends itself well to the style of Mario 3d world platformers but the issue with this game is it has real issues, there are many design choices that make the game fall short of great plus there are some bugs and glitches that straight up ruin the enjoyment.
The biggest issue with the game in my opinion is the level designs for the game, there are so many levels that end up being extremely frustrating because of either buggy elements of the game or simple design choices.
One of these choices are the camera, this game uses fixed cameras which really creates issues, many parts of levels and even entirety of some levels are reduced to player bashing their head against the wall because the camera is giving the player a skewed view of the world which leads to poor jumps or movements.
There are some fun levels that are set to some familiar pop and rock (1 rock song as far as I remember) tunes that you get to play through, but most other levels are running the OST and unfortunately the game's OST has more misses than hits which is a shame when you think of how good the OST for LBP games was.
Sound design has some glitches but they can go over normally with a level restart.
The story is basically Mario storyline, you have the not bowser kidnap your friends and you set out to save them and stop the big bad.
The visual presentation of the game is beyond gorgeous, Sumo has really made the presentation feel close to lbp 1 and 2's feel.
All in all for the first outing in this genre it is not horrible but it is a flawed game, and while it doesn't seem MM has any interest in picking up LBP ip again I can hope Sumo continues working with this ip and we get many more lbp related titles.
3/5

Posted: September 24, 2020
The purpose of the Complete Edition is to allow for RCT3 to be sold on Steam again under a new name and publisher after Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 Platinum was taken down by Atari a few years ago. This version is not a "remaster".

This means that if you have previously purchased RCT3 Platinum before it was removed from the Steam Store, you DO NOT need to buy this version of the game. The only major differences between Platinum and the Complete Edition are that references to Atari are removed and the game supports 1920x1080 resolution by default, other than that it is the exact same game as before.

However, if you are like me and did not get the chance to buy RCT3 Platinum on Steam previously, then this re-release is for you!

This game was one of the many games of my childhood and I am glad I can play it again after losing the original disks.

Posted: September 24, 2020
This is technically the same game as Platinum!, except for the fact that it has support for HD resolutions and no Atari branding anywhere. If you don't have RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 Platinum!, then I would get this.

I see a lot of people complaining that it is essentially a copy of what we had before and it seems like a cash grab. However, Frontier now has the rights to the game again, which opens the possibility for updates in the future to enhance the game and fix bugs, upgrade it to modern tech (64-bit, multicore support).

Now, it has yet to be seen if that will happen, so if you already own the Platinum edition that was for sale previously, I would hold on and see if any updates to come to life.

Posted: December 22, 2021
The Roller Coaster Tycoon franchise has been a bit like a roller coaster itself. RCT1 was the chain lift, bringing everyone up to the top of the world, while RCT2 was more like that first plunging drop, the one you go down screaming the whole way with excitement. Both were great games, both are games that are hard to top.

RCT3 can't quite beat them. RCT3, to use the coaster analogy above, is like the loop right after the big drop. It's exciting, it's a bit scary, it makes you want to try it again, and you remember that part of the roller coaster for years afterward. But without the chain lift and without the first drop, you have no momentum to make a loop like that. RCT3 is built upon the great ideas of the first games, but in the conversion to 3D, some small amounts of the charm have been lost.

Don't let the few hours I've played fool you: I bought this on Steam for the expansion packs, because my ancient retail CD was just the base game, and I played thousands of hours of RCT3 before losing the disc.

So, what is the good, the bad, and the ugly of RCT3?

The Good:
-As the game is older, the price is great.
-It doesn't matter if your computer only has integrated graphics, it'll run RCT3 quite well.
-Riding the Rides is a good novelty.
-This comes with the Soaked and Wild expansion packs, which allow you to build pools and animal enclosures respectively, along with packing in a bunch of new rides.
-Has a great sandbox mode where money is not a problem, letting you build crazy cool parks.
-Has great scenarios that can be a challenge.
-100% kid friendly.
-Has a scenario builder so you can create your own challenges. Great for when you want Sandbox with Money Management, for example, or when you want to give yourself a real challenge.

The Bad:
-Riding the Rides is a novelty, and that novelty wears off quite quickly.
-While it'll run on everything, there's a reason for that, and that reason is the graphics are dated. For people like me, who don't care about graphics so long as the game is fun, this won't be a problem, but if you're someone who needs photo-realistic textures and ray-tracing to enjoy their game, this is not for you.
-Expect to look a lot of things up because this comes from an era where tutorials were optional and didn't always include everything you should know. Luckily, the game is old, so a ton of information is out there.
-While the game will tell you that your guests are hungry/thirsty/looking for a toilet, it won't tell you exactly where the problem is. This can lead to frustration if you've spent hours making the Junk Food Market in the middle of your park, but guests that won't quit riding Awesome Coaster 1 are getting hungry in the far corner of the park and complaining about it.

The Ugly:
-Terrain editing is a bit unintuitive. This sounds like a minor thing until you realize that a sandbox park is just a flat surface to build on. If you're wanting to theme an area, or even just cheese the support height limits for a roller coaster, expect frustration.
-Some of the scenarios will make you scream in frustration.
-Peeps (the people riding your roller coasters and flat rides) are stupid sometimes. This stupidity also extends to your park employees. If you notice dozens of rides breaking down, animal enclosures not being fixed, pools getting filthy, paths covered in puke and litter, or any other signs that your employees aren't doing what they need to do, have a look in the Staff Management window for glitched out janitors and mechanics. Pick them up and drop them on a path.
-Some micromanagement will be required. If you hate this, it's going to ruin your day. Rides will break down, Peeps barf all over your park, litter stacks up, and the bigger your park is, the more you're going to have to use the Patrol Area tool to assign your mechanics and janitors to areas of the park. Animals will, given proper food and space, breed more animals. Keep an eye on this or you'll soon find an enclosure that was perfect for the couple of lions you had is now packed too full with lions that aren't happy.

If you're used to how tycoon games typically work (Lots of micromanagement, building things here and there, and spending a few hours now and then trying to figure out why what you did won't work), RCT3 is a good choice for you. If you want a great roller coaster building game that you can run on just about anything, RCT3 is a decent choice. If you've wanted to build an awesome theme park, you'll probably enjoy RCT3. If you played RCT3 a few years ago and can't find your old discs anymore, this will give you a good nostalgia hit and leave you smiling for a few hours. If, however, you're looking for the glory days of RCT2, you'll have to get that game instead.

Also, if you need to scrub the rotten taste out of your mouth after playing any of the later RCT titles (anything released after RCT3), this works great.

Oh, and a word to the wise: if you get motion sick easily, don't ride the rides in this game. Some of the coasters you might build could very well recreate the Peep experience at home, and the janitors in game make cleaning up vomit look way easier than it actually is. Also, while this game doesn't support VR, I'd also recommend against trying to make it work with VR. The camera controls by themselves might make you motion sick, and riding any of the coasters is a one way ticket to worshipping the porcelain throne.

RCT 3 is one of the best time wasting strategy game out there and with the Complete Edition,which has Soaked and Wild expansions,you can easily waste hours and hours managing some of the best amusement parks that we all wish we had near our cities.

Graphically,it's pretty decent,at least now,back when it released it was pretty dope,having reflective water and some of the light effects were a blast to checkout and manage,especially the fireworks which you can create and edit however you want.

Audio wise it's ok,there is nothing amazing about it,tho the soundtrack is quite chill and relaxing,depending on which of the in-game songs you choose and you can also import your own songs or music and have it play in-game which is pretty nice.

Now the gameplay,that's where it really shines. The game lets you freely create and design most of the coasters,transport rides but also pools,wildlife zoo's and pretty much create a waterpark filled with sketchy and insane rides.

You can edit fee's,taxes,manage employees that clean or repair rides,shops can sell their default items or you can mix them up in some custom shops that are brilliant to easily get money and never go bankrupt.

Most rides also feature custom blueprints you can either download online and then just put them into your park or just save yours and upload those,really boosting creative rides and experiences,which also,you can enjoy because the game lets you use a cinematic camera that will follow the ride and you can pretty much experience what horrific or absolutely insane ride you created.

There isn't really any story,you can just enjoy the campaign that each of the expansions and the main game has or just play a custom sandbox where you really can go wild with your imagination.

Sadly,the game has quite a few bugs,some are just visual bugs,others sometimes can crash the game,so do save a bit regularly cause you never know what might break the game,I had a scenario where I tested a launch ride with over 400 km/h and when the ride flew out in space the game just froze and crashed.

Overall tho,Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 is still one of the best park management games out there and now that it's on Steam,it's definitely worth a try,a solid strategy game that might never get too old.

If you liked the review and want to find even more content,reviews or just support me,you can do it on my Patreon :

Dude. Nostalgia waves for hours! I remember being so very excited for a Windows XP and this game. Posted: July 11, 2021
This is simply a re-hash of RollerCoaster Tycoon 3: Platinum that was rereleased for PC on Steam.

Remember when RCT3 was removed by Atari?

Anyway, this version definitely plays better than the original release. Bugs are far less common, the game runs smoother and has a more stable framerate, and is generally better optimized.

There are a couple of cons: terrain editing can still be aggravating, so be meticulous when you do it--the game will screw up paths at the slightest movement during terrain manipulation, and it can be an nightmare to fix.

Also, it may just be me, but the Janitors seem to be less effective? Had to hire a lot more, and actually make use of patrol areas.

BIGGEST PRO: This version supports custom content exactly as the old versions did, so if you have custom scenery, CTRs/CFRs, and the like, they will be perfectly playable here. Just make sure you reinstall them right!

Honestly though, I'm biased towards this game. I've gotten well over thousands of hours into the disc retail release of this game, and it's in my top 15 favorite games of all time. So you'll get glowing praise from me.

I recommend this game to anyone with a creative mind. Sure, Planet Coaster exists, but this game is a LOT less demanding and has a MASSIVE modding scene. Definitely the most worthy compromise you can get.

Product received for free

My name is Leah, I have had 3 copies of this game in total and I have never regretted it.

This review will highlight the cons and pros of RCT3 (Roller Coaster Tycoon 3), if you do not like reading long reviews I recommend passing on my review. That being said I will give my honest personal opinion and history with this game, my first copy was in 2012, the original physical copy which I at the time played on my Dell laptop. The graphics for a game made in 2011 were astounding, more so the gameplay and money managing aspects of this game really nailed it. Not only does this game teach young kids money management but it also teaches it in a manageable bite-sized portions, you screw with the loans and you go bankrupt, you get greedy with that new coaster and you go bankrupt. To mention the varieties of coasters is just breath-taking, from the Air-Powered Coasters to the Wooden Coasters and everything in between you have every type you'll need.

The coaster customisation is amazing to say the bare minimum. You have the options to color your tracks in 3 ways. (Top Icon is the rails, Left is the sides and Right is the supports.) Alongside being able to make the actual coaster multicolor you can do the same for your cars. It's all there from music to lift chain speed. By default the music will be excessively loud but it's quite easy to configure in comparison to other games.

Anyway here are the pros of the game;
- Great Customisation
- Astounding Variety of coasters, food and drink.
- Decent graphics
- Teaches money management
- Doesn't cost as much as a triple A game of the same quality
- Includes all the DLC packs.
- Sandbox mode + Campaign mode
- Can see the coaster in FP
- Very goofy at times (making 350,000KPH coasters, No finish Coasters, 10-20G coasters)

cons of RCT3: Complete Edition;
- Outdated soundtracks
- Glitchy when expanding to x4 the average park
- Campaign takes time to progress
- Campaign is too easy
- The last good iteration of RCT

Hope this was helpful!
- Leah Vermeylen

Posted: September 29, 2020
RollerCoaster Tycoon® 3: Complete Edition

In summary, this was a kind of game that you would have in your childhood, which is a good one. Rollercoaster Tycoon 3 was the first edition of the Rollercoaster Tycoon series that featured an actual 3D gameplay, rather than 2D like Rollercoaster Tycoon 1 and 2, which have been quite successful in the past, which still is in newer reboots for modern systems and Mobile, which I would highly recommend on the go. We don't talk about RCT World, ew

- The Graphics are dated indeed, however, it still holds the memories.
- You can ride all your Rides and Rollercoasters for the first time!
- A very rememberable soundtrack, many variety.
- Multiple themes to Typical Parks to Spooky ones.
- Expansion packs that were legit and not a cash grab, To Zoo's and Waterparks included.
- Firework Mixer
- The 'James Hunt' cheat to spawn a Jeep to drive and run over people.
- Death Wooden and Speed Coasters to demolish guest for fun.
- The Park Inspector that you would torture or put in a animal enclosure.
- Last but not least, the last successful and rememberable game of the Rollercoaster Tycoon Franchise.

Now with the Complete Edition compared to the Platinum Edition, there was a licensing disagreement which caused this to be re-released. Now, I expected this as a remaster, it's not, it's a re-release with 1080p support, which I certainly am happy to use this on my 1080p laptop. Posted: September 12, 2021
Originally released nearly two decades ago, RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 is perhaps still one of the best theme park building games of all time, going toe to toe with titles like Planet Coaster (which - fun fact - was made by the same developer) with its sheer amount of content (including pools and animal exhibits) and rich park simulation mechanics. More so than its predecessors, RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 puts a heavier emphasis on creative, sandbox-style gameplay with improved terrain-editing tools; features like custom firework displays, billboards, and importable music; a revamped scenario system that punishes you less for coloring outside the lines; and of course, the ability to view your park from all angles in 3D space. Although the 3D graphics aren't quite as impressive by today's technical standards, the art direction is still pleasing to the eye and it's easy to spend hours making your park look as beautiful as possible. This aspect of the game can be extended even further by installing some of the wealth of custom scenery objects available online, giving you even greater freedom to design the theme park of your dreams. There are still a few issues with this port though, like the lack of support for resolutions higher than 1920x1080, and the fact that the image browser for custom billboards still refers to a system directory that was removed all the way back in Windows Vista, but it's easy to solve these problems if you're willing to do a little bit of tinkering around.

9.5/10 - A must if you like games where you design things and like theme parks at all in the slightest.

Posted: September 25, 2020
Up front, if you already own Platinum Edition from a couple years ago before it was taken off of the store due to Atari being Atari, this doesn't have a whole lot of improvements in comparison to make it worth it to upgrade for most people. While I don't mind too much, I do think a couple more quality-of-life improvements wouldn't have hurt to justify getting a more recent version.

That being said, if you never had a chance to own it or had a disc but lost it, this is still one of the best theme park games out there! RCT3 with all of it's included expansions has a ton of content on it's own. It's a little bit dated on the graphics as this is still a game that came out 16 years ago, but turning the settings to max and setting the draw distance and LOD sliders to max can still make beautiful looking parks (especially at night!) and the rest is charming in its own way.

Compared to Frontier's other popular roller coaster game franchise, Planet Coaster has a more free-form approach while RCT3 uses a grid-based system for just about everything like the older games in the franchise. I personally like working with grids more as it's less of a hassle to line things up to look good so this is a positive for me, but someone who prefers absolute freedom in placement would better like Planet Coaster instead.

For what it's worth, I'm still having fun with this game all these years later. And I'm sure anyone even mildly interested in making a theme park to either trill or torture guests will find a lot of enjoyment out of this to this day!

Posted: June 26, 2017
I've been wanting to review Machinarium anyway, but amazingly it was just updated a matter of days ago. This little treasure from Amanita Design has been brought fully into the present with modern resolution support, controller options, and a pretty hilarious bug that makes it run super fast if you try to G-Sync it. Despite that last bit this update has wiped out any criticism I could have leveled at the game for feeling dated or being clunky, leaving only the clunky charms of its trash robot inhabitants to recommend to you without reservation.

Machinarium is the tale of a little robot in a junkyard. He isn't WALL-Eing the place up, he was dumped out here and it's up to you to find out why. A quick jaunt across the wastes finds him in a towering mechanical city of similarly junky, quirky robots all needing your help. Somewhere in the great beeping metropolis is a secret that only you can uncover, and a plot that only you can unravel to save its clanking inhabitants.

Doing this is sure to be one of the most adorable gaming experiences of your life. Your little robo-buddy toddles along on two baton-like legs, snakes his little grabbers out to nab things, drops items into his flip-top maw, and takes in the world with the most precious, gormless stare you can imagine. Just having him on the screen will put a smile on your face, and when he starts tooling around in carts and tumbling off of ladders you really can't help but sensibly chuckle. The other denizens of the city are no less charming, with uptight patrol bots stomping around, mechanical street bands tooting on old pieces of pipe, and clockwork bugs humming happily through the alleys.

It's a living game world in a way that so many other titles can't seem to capture, and it's ironic that it's accomplished entirely with robots. Much like Primordia every robot has their own distinct character but here, it is expressed entirely without words. As with all Amanita games the only language you'll here is perky gibberish, leaving characters to communicate through wild gesticulation and the occasional thought bubble. It's the little details in the art and animation that make it work so well, all the way down to your robot's eyes narrowing when enacting small revenge on a tormentor, or the way he adjusts his metal plates when left idle long enough. And more than anything this helps the story, which has some emotional twists that are heightened by the players emoting their little metal hearts out for.

As excellent as the look and feel is, we can't forget the puzzling. Machinarium, much like other Amanita games, only allows limited ranges of movement on most screens. While this opens up more later in the game it can feel limiting, but the trade-off is that it becomes easier to find what you need to interact with and how to interact with it. Almost as a concession to this point, your robot can stretch or shrink his height to reach out-of-the-way items or blend in with taller or shorter robots, a gimmick used to full effect throughout the entire game. You won't be finding a ton of items, either, so combined with the limited movement and interaction points this should be a pretty simple game for anyone to get through.

Your journey in this mechanical wonderland shouldn't take more than two hours, but those are two hours just loaded with humor and charm. The sketchy art style itself is a joy to behold, with rich details in every surface and object. A subdued soundtrack accompanies the look in a way that gives more texture to the troubled city, offsetting some of the silliness with a reminder that not all is well in the mysterious metropolis. And with the recent updates, any concerns about compatibility or accessibility have been entirely wiped away. With so many fully-realized elements, Machinarium is a clear classic of the point-and-click genre, one that makes an excellent entry point for newcomers or a charming diversion for veterans alike.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at or on my !

Posted: December 3, 2013
This, has to be the most compelling story I've ever played through in a game. One of the best, most charmingly clever, point & click titles I've ever played, a masterpiece of a game. The rustic hand drawn graphics are genuinely exquisite and really help disguise the click areas of this game. Features a really touching twisted fate mecha-folkstory, of a young robot living in a steam-punk dystopian wasteland, trying to save an enslaved princess robot. The only dialog between the characters are small animated scenes inside thought bubbles, which I think is a cool way to help tell a story without literal or verbal ques. The music is beautiful, very original and thought provoking, it really helped set the tone. You'll come across the occasional puzzle here and there and they're are some tough ones, but none are too frustrating. Unlike many titles in this genre, Machinarium consistently had me at an "aHa!" moment, great game 10/10

Posted: July 21, 2020
A charming game that places an indefatigable and likable android protagonist in an overall melancholy and wistful setting of crumbling edifices, broken machines, and seedy robots. (Naturally, as developer of Primordia, I find this a very congenial setup.) The game has no dialogue or text, and it aspires less to high philosophy than to episodic cartoon travails, but this works quite well and doesn't overstay its welcome. Beautiful artwork and excellent music round out the charm.

The puzzles are more in the vein of a Flash game than a traditional point-and-click (frequently they are focused on a single room, and typically they involve minigame logic challenges rather than inventory-based problem solving), but they are fair and in some instances quite clever. I found the integrated hint system, which I used a couple of times, less than fully helpful.

All said, this is a favorite of critics and players alike for good reason -- it is a game with character and integrity, available for a song.

Posted: October 22, 2020
Machinarium has delivered one of the most memorable game experiences that will stay with you for years to come. This is a game that would be in my all time favourite indie game list if I had one and here’s why:

Using this type of artwork for a video game was a really good idea. The game’s not new anymore, yet it looks like it could have been made in 2020. It’s artistic in a way that makes it ageless. Every scene looks like a painting - if nothing else, it’s just beautiful to look at. Furthermore, bringing in the theme of a machine city, gives it a very Gigerish feel, if you happen to be familiar with the mastermind behind the Alien movie designs. But where Giger mixed horror with eroticism, Machinarium comes off cute and weird – like steampunk. Machinarium is like steampunk mixed with Giger’s artwork.

Machinarium is first and foremost a puzzle game. The puzzles are strong and tied to logic. I did feel frustrated at times when I was unable to see the solutions, but I always ended up admitting to myself that I had overlooked something of importance and it was not the game designer’s bad choices. The puzzles also help with enhancing the experience in how they’ve been executed. They’re conducted in a makeshift fashion that you would expect from a world that looks like a huge junkyard and solving them feels fun.

Sounds in Machinarium do not carry any articulated messages so any meaningful information is delivered through visual and auditory imagery. They did stumble here a bit with the most obvious case being the usage of the word „Oil”, which did stand out as a failure where it was occurred. I wish they had stayed true to the main principle without any exception. It’s usually tricky to pull off, but if used correctly then the effect is very strong and really helps with putting one’s fantasy to work.

Besides puzzles, game obstacles also came in the form of and here Machinarium pays homage to many classic games including arcade games. Boy did I have fun with the mini games of Machinarium! The only letdown was the one you had to play if you wanted hints to help you with the puzzles. I wish they had made it more dynamic and interesting. Currently it just feels like chores you have to endure if you wish to see some hints.

To , I wish to bring out the most important: the game feels and looks iconic. Overall it was a very well executed, emotionally satisfying and challenging experience which will get my highest recommendations.

Machinarium was the first video game I've ever played, so I like to look at it as the start of my adventure behind the computer screen.

I think I was around 13 at the time. We didn't have a console or gameboy at home and the only previous contact I had had with games happened when I went to my friend's place to play FIFA on his PS2. I remember there was only one computer in my place and it was my dad's work laptop. We barely ever touched it.

One day my father came home with a usb pen which he took from a colleague by mistake. It had this game inside (probably an illegal copy). After having finished it, my dad gave me and my younger sisters permission to use his laptop to play Machinarium. He even encouraged us to play it, sort of like when he tried to convince us to read good books. This on itself tells a lot about the game, considering how conservative my father used to be when it came to video games.

Anyway, from then on we started gathering in front of the computer screen every day to play the game one hour each time. It was everyone's favourite part of the day. Everyone looked forward to the time just before dinner when my father used to get home. He'd open the laptop, launch the game and we'd all get absorbed by these , the and the . Eventually my mom joined in and soon this became something we'd do as a family every day (we're five). Can you imagine five people in front of a laptop playing a point-and-click game? Ye, it's as weird as it sounds.

The interesting part is my parents don't even like video games or technology in general. They are bookworms more than anything else and for instance they are heavily against my usage of the PC for entertainment. But somehow... somehow this game captivated them. Somehow they were able (more like eager) to spend an hour of their busy lives to take part in this adventure. And the fact that I was able to immerse myself in this together with my parents and sisters, makes me look back at this time of my life with fondness and gratitude. Fondness towards the fact that this game united my family and brought us closer together. And gratitude towards my father for having introduced me to video games in the best way possible... through a game with an , , a (one of the best soundtracks I've heard) and . This game will always have a special place in my heart and I couldn't recommend it more.

PS: I eventually bought this game on Humble Bundle to support the devs but I haven't played it since.
PS2: It's funny that the trigger that started my video game adventure 6 years ago was pulled by my parents, who were so against this kind of stuff to start with. Little did they know...

Posted: November 9, 2018
Amanita Design's best known game is probably their worst one, since it's a more conventional point-and-click adventure than the weirder Samorosts. And it comes with everything annoying you might expect from an adventure: moon logic, long unskippable animations, and arbitrary restrictions.

The latter are actually relatively rare—it mostly makes sense why you can or can't do anything. However, there is a twist: your robot can only interact with items within his reach and he has three modes (tall, normal, short)... which means that that thingie might have been unclickable simply because you forgot to switch modes. Which you will, because in any non-normal mode the robot's speed slows down to a crawl.

Why does everyone like so much then? Because what it lacks in usability, it more than compensates for in heart. This is a very lovely game with a charming story and incredible sound design.

I think beats at almost everything it tries to achieve. But if you've played it already, don't pass this one either. Amanita Design's care and attention to detail shines in this as well.

Posted: August 4, 2015
I, a robot?

Adventure is only a point-and-click away as Irreverend Opinions reviews Machinarium!

---

The Blurb

A puzzle adventure in a stylised world of robots and amazing music. A robot that has been abandoned by his city in pieces must pull himself together and return to not only confront some rather bad robots, but save his robot girlfriend in the process.

The Good

The first thing I noticed about Machinarium, as a first impression, is the music. The soundtrack by Czech composer really stands out in the task of impressing a strange new world without alienating the player from what they are engaged in.

Graphically, the art style for Machinarium is quite striking, with hand-drawn animation hauntingly evocative of works by surrealist Jan Švankmajer, and seeming to be another achievement for Dvorský that fans of Amatina Design will be encouraged to see. With their pencil-and-paper 'living comic' art style, the organic appearance of the background and characters helps to round out the artificial world with a warm and almost human sense, which helps the player to get involved with the characters quite readily.

For an adventure game without dialogue at all, the plot is quite memorable and involving, with the characters having both impact and personality. By removing dialogue from the game, the designers also allow the game to be accessible to players who do not speak English, using thought bubbles and pictures, authentic instruments and short beeps or buzzes to illustrate what characters are thinking or asking.

Puzzles throughout the game are both thought-provoking and challenging, sometimes requiring the player to think outside the box to complete tasks without pushing for weird feats of skewed logic present in some games of the genre. Should the game prove to be too much of a bother, an in-built 'hint' system allows players to get some suggestions to how they can complete the task.


For some players, the puzzles will be a bit challenging, though thankfully a short minigame can help to unlock the puzzles if you are more of a mind to do a reflexive shooter than a point-and-click puzzle solve.

Some players have reported having issues with transferring the game from fullscreen to windowed mode, though this seems to be more of a UI confusion than a bug issue.


None to speak of.


Turn out the lights and enjoy the immersive, imaginative world.


Well deserving of the awards it has recieved, Machinarium is a beautiful game with something special for art and music lovers, as well as fans of the point-and-click puzzle genre. 10/10.

Posted: December 29, 2020
Machinarium is a must play for fans of puzzle/adventure/point-and-click games

Reasons to play:
Beautiful artstyle
Clever puzzles
Inspired world
Heartwarming story and characters
Innovative hint system
Negatives:
Very short
Not optimal controls and mechanics
Difficult? (this might be a negative)





At this point in time, Machinarium should be revered as a modern classic in the adventure game genre. It stands the test of time as an indie wonder which not only sparked an interest for the minimalist story-telling but brought back puzzle adventure games from the brink of Lucas Arts deathbed. As of writing this review I have replayed the game after not touching it for about 10 years, this time using an iPad. It is not truly an iPad review, neither can I accurately talk about the PC port more than the fact that they are very similar and I can happily recommend both.

I did refer to Lucas Arts, but truly Machinarium does not fully operate in the same space. Instead of dialogue driven adventures, Machinarium is more heavily reliant on puzzles. The inventory and item spamming on any interactive object or character is still there, but so are a good bunch of logic puzzles that take center-stage. This keeps a nice balance of the creative item interactions and the more logic driven brain teasers, without being too farfetched nor high IQ for the everyday player. Interactions with other characters are communicated with what I could describe as "supply and demand" thought bubbles that tells you how to progress or how to help out your fellow robot friend, while solutions are often narrowed down to a small amount of options. Even though you several times after finally finding a solution, smack your head because you should have found that solution earlier than you did. It is fun, satisfying and clever. Sometimes too clever for you, which brings me to a nice point. The hints.

Growing up with the likes of Lucas Arts games, in the time of no walkthroughs available, I think I developed thick skin to the most grueling and downright idiotic puzzles. Therefore I would never be the one to complain when a puzzle gets me really stuck, as I've seen many players do nowadays. Nevertheless the very player friendly hint system at play in Machinarium should be cherished. It consists of a hint button which gives 1 obscure hint (and 1 only) in the screen you're visiting, and a walkthrough book which are unlocked for the specific screen by playing a small minigame. The game thus challenges your patience by a minigame for you to be able to advance, which I think is a cute solution to the hint debacle which plagues present players. Did it have to exist? No. Am I happy it does? Certainly.

What about the game in general? The art is delivered in a warm palette, steampunk charm and rusty robotics. It is a city for the machines, where oil drinking, jazz bands, arcades and robot deities and coppers are prevalent. It is a city of ill-doers and bullies, old and young, lonely and lovely, cats and bugs. Spite it's cold robot heart, it is packed with character and adventure feel. Your protagonist can make himself bigger and smaller like an accordion which is easily accessible and if you idle for too long you will receive a flashback to happier times with your robot love. The sound design is delightful, while the story is just about right. The game could have been expanded upon and been given a more resonating ending, but as it stands, Machinarium is a great effort.

Some nitpicks though. If you want to interact with an object you have to move your character first to the spot to reach, which means traversing the world sometime isn't as smooth. Movement can also not be cancelled, so you might be making a wrong step and do a bunch of back and forth in this game, as movement animations can't be sped up either. But all in all these are minor complaints about time saving, which you won't need as the game is at max 4 hours long anyways.

A must play for adventure/puzzle game enthusiasts, a fringe game for those not familiar and a calming game for those that enjoy art and thought exercises. If not for the PC longplays, buy it for the tablet and just enjoy a soothing evening in the sofa.

Posted: December 28, 2015
Machinarium is a point-and-click adventure game in the old fashion of "click inventory items against everything on screen until it works". You play the role of a tiny little robot dude whose first task is to rebuild his body, having been unceremoniously dumped into a junkyard.

The story is told without any words, instead using the charming artstyle and clever worldbuilding to convey what's happening. It's a risky venture, especially in story-driven games like these, but Machinarium pulls it off very well; Little Robot Dude's attempts to sneak back into the city are easy to follow and very cute.

Some of the puzzles can be somewhat obtuse, as is the norm for adventure games, which may put off some players, but there is a hint system built into every puzzle which lets Dude give his own insight on the solution. For times when this doesn't suffice, a short walkthrough can be unlocked with some skill at a minigame, which will give the player a storybook guide on what to do next. The wordless presentation makes Machniarum a game that can be enjoyed by all-comers of any language, age, or skill with words.

Finally, the Robot Street Band's performance will stay with you forever.

Posted: January 5, 2020
An oldie but goodie - for the ~5 hours for my playthrough, I enjoyed my time spent in Machinarium. Recommended for some casual time-killing. I played it as a break from more intense games.

Gameplay
Machinarium is a straightforward point and click game. I liked how the main character can extend and shrink, which adds an element to the puzzle. For example, if there's an item you can't reach at the normal height, sometimes you have to realize you have to extend the main character to reach the item.

The puzzles I'd say are of middling difficulty, being an occasional point and click game player. The developers have put a nice touch of illustrated walkthroughs, right in-game! (I just looked up screenshots of them on the Steam community, one of the guides has all of the screenshots for convenient access.)

Now, even with occasional looking at the developer walkthrough when stuck, it still took me ~5 hours to complete the game, so I'd say go for it unless you're trying for some perfectionist run. All the achievements are mandatory if you complete the game, i.e. none are missable achievements, so it's not a big deal to avoid all guides.

As this game is made by Amanita Design, it has their signature art style, which is a treat to the eyes. Even after so many years, the graphics still hold up as unique and paints a fascinating world. The music, in typical Amanita Design games quality, is whimsical and has a flavor of its own. So I know that with these two aspects, I'm in good hands when it comes to an Amanita game.

The main story isn't that interesting, and I'd go as far to say it's pretty generic. But I enjoyed exploring the world of Machinarium and some of the NPCs have more interesting background, though it's left pretty ambiguous in the game. So I'd say I enjoyed the art and music direction, just enjoying the environment, and the story was more in the background.

Overall, Machinarium is a game that still holds up graphically and is a high quality and pleasant experience, 10 years after release. There have been so many instances of it being on sale, so if you got it for cheap, it's worthwhile to play it when you're killing time or just as a break from other types of games.

Posted: November 16, 2020
This is a great pack with a unique assortment of games. All of them work over the web, which is a big plus.

- Quiplash 3: It's good ol' quiplash. Can't go wrong with this one. The prompts are good, and there are custom packs if you get bored of the defaults. The last lash is always the same- every player gives 3 answers to a prompt. I'm not a huge fan of this, but meh. It's quiplash.

- The Devils and the Details: This is my favorite, simply because of the chaos it creates. Players yelling at each other to finish collaborative tasks, scolding the selfish players, and freaking out when there is an emergency. It can get a little old, but the wide variety of "scenarios" keeps it fresh enough.

- Champ’d Up: Head-to-head drawing game. Pretty fun even if you suck at drawing. Playing multiple games in a row allows for comedic callbacks, since the game lets you "tag in" drawings from previous games. It gets pretty silly.

- Talking Points: This is a close second favorite. Players have to bulls**t their way through a wacky presentation. It's fun to make up something as fast as possible on the spot. Lots of improv is involved. I wish there were more images to choose from- when images repeat it gets a little less funny. The custom mode is pretty fun if you have creative players. The scoring system kinda sucks.

- Blather 'Round: This is the one I have played the least, but it's interesting. It's not as funny as the other games, but it's still very entertaining to try to deduce what the word is. It's like charades with words. Seems to have good replayability.

Overall, awesome pack that is well worth the asking price. Plays great over Discord or IRL :)

Posted: October 18, 2020
As always, Jackbox brings hours of laughter to my group of friends.

Favorite game: Champ'd Up.
The drawing tools are expanded from those of previous entries, such as Drawful, allowing for more creativity and freedom in drawing. The fun really kicks in when you draw the challenger, using only your opponent's drawing as a reference point. I definitely recommend using the extended timer so you don't feel as rushed to get your drawing right.

Least favorite: The Devils and the Details.
This game just doesn't flow well for my group of friends, but I still recommend trying it for yourself. It doesn't have the same format as most other Jackbox Party Pack games (Prompt, respond, vote), and is much more continuous and at times hectic. While there is a bit of competition, it's mostly a cooperative game. While this could definitely be a big drawing point for some people, it wasn't very fun for us.

The brain game: Blather Round.
This game is essentially word charades. You choose one of three things (person, place, etc.) and have to vaguely describe it by filling in the blanks of a sentence using a list of terms the game provides. As the round continues, you can form more clues in the same manner while other players try to figure out what you're describing. Lots of fun, and if you're like us you'll end up playing it multiple times in a row and forgetting to try out the other games.

The chill game: Talking Points.
A much less competitive game, but that's not a bad thing. You take turns giving presentations on material you've never seen before, and while you're briefing each slide, another player is creating the next slide. Forces you to think on your feet, and even for a group of people who all hate giving presentations, we had a lot of fun.

Ol' Reliable: Quiplash 3.
If you liked the previous Quiplash entries, you'll like this one. The only real changes are the ability to choose your avatar, and the new final round: Thrip Lash. In Thrip Lash, you give a three-step response to the prompt, with each step being revealed one at a time. We found that some of the prompts in Thrip Lash were weak, but overall it's a solid addition. You also have the ability to create your own prompts in the menu.

Posted: January 26, 2021
Easily the best Jackbox in years. Quiplash 3 continues the high quality of that game, even if little has changed aside from the final round. Champ'd Up is possibly a contender along side Drawful for best drawing game. Blather Round came completely out of left field and is one of the most popular Jackbox games among my friend circle now.

Now for the less glowing critique. I personally really like Talking Points, but it seems to be massively unpopular among those who I have played with, and I understand why. It requires a performative personality and a sense of improvisation that isn't for the shyer folks in your group, and may end up with some people feeling left out. Also, the scoring criteria isn't super clear and seems to be heavily weighted towards those who go later.

I have not had much experience with the Devil and the Details yet and while it seems fun, it is almost impossible to play virtually as it is too hard to coordinate in a video chat when all voices end up drowning each other out. In person, I can see it being a fun collaborative affair, but COVID has unfortunately put the kibosh on that.

Champ'd Up and Blather Round alone make this the best Jackbox since #3 and the one probably most in the spirit of the original games in terms of accessibility and straight of fun. Time will tell if the two games I mentioned as weaker will be more viable once in person gatherings are a thing once more, but regarless the pack gets a strong recommendation.

The Jackbox Party Pack 7 comes with some good games, it is not my favorite though.

Quiplash 3
Always a classic. Always fun. In Quiplash you come up with the best punchline. There are no noteworthy changes except the art style.

Devils in the Details
One of the few co-op Jackbox games, but with a twist: there is still a first place. For me, doing chores virtually is even worse than in real life. On the plus side is that you do not have waiting times.

Champ’d Up
This game can be really, really funny. You draw multiple characters and give them names to win in certain categories. Later, you use the same characters to win other categories, which can lead to hilarious combinations.

Talking Points
This Party Pack does not only have a game where you do chores, it also has a game where you do PowerPoint presentations like you are back in 7th grade. Do not get me wrong, it can be hysterically funny. Just make sure that everybody in your group feels comfortable giving a speech. Otherwise, it can get awkward.

Blather ‘Round
I got this Party Pack only for this. It is like a trivia game, where one person chooses computer-generated hints. It can be a magical moment, when you already gave up because the hints you could give were not so good, but then somebody guesses correctly at the last second.

Keep in mind that you play with one smartphone / tablet or web browser per person. If you want to play with your friends online, you can use Steam Remote Play or Discord. It is still fun.

YouTube™ Video: The Jackbox Party Pack 7 Review | One of the Best Packs Yet! 
Views: 14,176
The Jackbox Party Pack 7 is one of the best Party Packs that has come out recently with 5 different new and unique games that are great for parties and streams.

The Jackbox Party Pack 7 is one of the best Party Packs that has come out recently with 5 different new and unique games that are great for parties and streams.

Since this is 5 games in one I will review each one individually.


If you have played any previous Jackbox games you probably know what Quiplash is. In it every player gets prompts with fill in the blanks that you try to create the funniest answers you can. And then everyone votes on which answer they thought was more clever or funny and then the person with the most points at the end of the game wins.

This version of Quiplash has some unique rounds to spice things up along with obviously an abundance of new prompts. Also you can make your own questions in the game if you want and whats really cool is you can actually play other players custom made questions in a featured content tab so that is awesome. And the artsyle is this really cool looking claymation vibe and so overall this is probably going to be a lot of players favorite game in the pack.


In this every single person is on a team of devils trying to do everyday human chores to fit in. So the gameplay consists of there being a huge list of chores on everyone's phones and when you do them there are small and simple minigames you must complete to get points for the family.

This game overall has a very interesting and unique premise but my problem with it is all the chores you are doing kind of feel like actual chores. I think if the minigames had been a little more fun almost like little Warioware games this could have been incredibly fun but every single task you do consists of you doing the most mundane things ever like looking through a phone book for a specific phone number to type in so it kind of makes the game fall flat a little in my opinion.


This is stupid fun and honestly one of my favorite drawing based Jackbox games ever. In it each player draws and names a champion to fight others and then gets to create another champion to fight another players champion. Then the rounds start and each person votes on who they think would win in a fight and in the later rounds you can tag in your other fighters which is awesome.

And one really cool feature about this game is if you continue playing with the same players across multiple games when it comes time to tag in some of your other fighters you can actually use your fighters from previous games which is super cool. Also the music in this game is way better than it has any right to be.


This is one of the games that you kind of need to have the right group of people to play because it’s less of a competition and more just a fun little experience. In it each player will give speeches kind of like Ted Talks to the other players and when its your turn to give the ted talk another person acts as your assistant by choosing what the words you have to read are and what pictures accompany your power point.

Everyone can like or dislike your speech at any time and that is what determines how many points you get but overall you should just be playing this game to give hilarious speeches to your friends or family and it is pretty fun when you get a group of people to really commit to this game.


This is kind of like a game of charades almost. In it each player chooses a word from a list of 3 and it could be a person, a place, or a thing and when it’s their turn they try to form sentences with a very limited amount of words to give the other players hints.

The entire time the other players are trying to guess the word and sometimes the person who is giving the hints can even include the previous guesses in their hints. So say someone said the hulk but the real word was a different super hero the person giving hints could make a sentence saying “it’s very similar to the hulk”.

And if someone guesses the correct word then they along with the person giving the hints gets points and if they used any other words from other player's guesses they get points as well.

And so overall this one is really fun because I haven’t really played a charades like game in a Jackbox Party Pack and so it is a very fun and unique experience.


And so overall I absolutely loved this party pack. I loved 4 out of the 5 games and the one I didn’t like I didn’t hate I just wasn't a super fan of. If you are a fan of previous Jackbox Party Packs you will definitely enjoy this one!

Posted: December 13, 2020
Product received for free

Full review (including score):
YouTube™ Video: The Jackbox Party Pack 7 (ACTUAL Game Review) [PC] 
Views: 50,905
Usually, with each new Party Pack, you get maybe three good games and two bad ones, so let's see if the latest keeps up that trend in my Jackbox Party Pack 7 review!

Summarized review below!

Another year, another Jackbox Party Pack. My friends and I are huge fans of this series and return to it numerous times throughout the year. Usually, with each new Party Pack, you get maybe three good games and two bad ones, so I was interested in seeing if the latest would keep up that trend.

Quiplash 3 was a good bit of fun. It’s by no means the strongest game in the pack, but it takes the already solid Quiplash formula and delivers the best version yet. You basically answer a series of prompts with what you think is the funniest and best-fitting answer and those answers go up against others in a series of rounds until you get to the multi-answer finale and all the points are tallied up. It’s pretty simple really, but the Jackbox team has done a great job with all the creative prompts, the visuals and music, and just the overall presentation.

This is something you’ll see extend to the other games in the pack as well, they’ve really upped the visual side of things this time around. Regardless, Quiplash 3 is a solid first game for the pack and one my friends and I will be returning to.

The Devils and the Details is easily one of, if not the most, chaotic games I have ever played in any of the Jackbox games. It plays very differently from the rest of the pack, being a co-op survival game of sorts where you each play as a member of a family trying to complete certain tasks before the end of each day. However, each family member has a personal score and it can be increased by completing selfish tasks that harm the rest of the family. This creates this cool dynamic where you’re both trying to help out the rest of the group while also trying to stay above the rest.

The actual tasks are divided into individual and group tasks – with the latter being where the chaos comes into play. They oftentimes require you to instruct another player, but when you have seven or so people playing at once, it quickly becomes a mess of players shouting instructions at others and trying to get everything done by the time limit. It can get very loud, but that’s the point of the game and I quite enjoyed the change of pace compared to the other games’ comedy-centric focus. It may not get the laughs, but it will definitely get the communication going in a chaotic fun sort of way.

Champ’d Up ended up being my favorite game of the pack. Every pack has a drawing game, and Champ’d Up not only expands on the drawing tools offered in the previous packs through colors choices and an undo button, but pits drawings against each other in a very cool way. You’re basically tasked with drawing something against another drawing without knowing the category that the two are competing in – only the original drawer knows the category. This can create some very cool matchups and the worse your drawing skill, the funnier it becomes.

This was one of the two games in the pack where my group literally couldn’t breath because we were laughing so hard at some of the drawings, and the way the game facilitates these matchups just makes it all that much better. Jackbox always seems to knock it out of the park with the drawing games and Champ’d Up is no exception.

Talking Points is the game that had the most laughs from my group. And not just regular laughs, but the kind where you find yourself wheezing. It’s a presentation-style game where you have one player presenting on a topic they know nothing about and another player feeding the first player new text and picture slides for their slideshow. As the presenter does not know what slide is coming up next, there is a ton of adlibbing involved, but that’s what really makes the game shine. You gotta somehow link together all of these unrelated images and lines and it can lead to some pretty funny moments.

For example, I pitched my presenter an image of a squirrel, then sausages, and then house keys, and he managed to weave it together into this werewolf narrative that had the rest of the group dying. It’s definitely the simplest game in the pack in terms of its design, but it’s got some top-tier execution and provides a solid foundation for a simple, yet fun party game – the type you can just bust out with any group and get to playing.

Blather 'Round is without a doubt the weakest game in the pack. It’s not outright bad, but it definitely doesn’t click like the rest of the games do. It’s basically a trivia game played using word charades. You get a word and have to convey it through a limited set of other words and player guesses as they come in. What my group found was that a lot of the prompts are simply too hard, even the ones marked as “easy”. For example, I would get something like Bikini Bottom, which you would think would be at least somewhat easy to pitch, but the clues are so abstract that half of my group was guessing oceans and lakes and such and the other half was guessing coastal cities.

Of course, just like the other games in the pack, this is all going to depend on the group you play with. Blather 'Round is just the type of game that is better played among those that like trivia games (and this is coming from someone that does).

The Jackbox Party Pack 7 is yet another solid addition to the series, definitely one of the better ones. It’s got some really good highlights – most notably Champ’d Up and Talking Points – but some other fun additions as well – Quiplash 3 and The Devils and the Details. The only one that didn’t quite stick was Blather ‘Round, but even then, it’s not outright bad like the usual bad game included in past Party Packs. If anything, this might be the most well-rounded pack yet.

Follow my for more reviews + videos!

Posted: August 13, 2021
By far, in my opinion, this is the best Jackbox Party Pack I have ever purchased, and played, thus far.
Through Sub-category, reviewing each segment, as the entirety of the game.

1.)Quiplash 3:
The third one in the series, this is a game of wits/clever commentary within about a minute to answer gap, per round. You are given a category, to fill in what you feel would be or not be the best answer for that category, and you generally compete against other people, each person in your party having their own category, besides the one(s) you compete with.
👍This game is really fun, and they even have separate episodes in the options to choose from, for folks who may be getting married, for children and/or a sports team. Overall, this game has a lot of re-play value, and is especially great for friends or family you are close with. Bear in mind too, that you can include an outside audience, if you so chose to do so. :)

2.) The Devils and the Details:
You start as a 'devil' family, over-going daily chores as a family, sometimes having to involve other parts of the family to complete tasks. However, be aware, also, there is one task that is in red, and causes trouble for the rest of the family, and if the person so chooses to pick that task, the other family members have a chance to stop the devious motive.
👍This game is especially fun with family and/or close friends. However, I do feel it could be repetitive, were it to be played too much.

3.):
Get ready to show off your creative and/or possibly not creative but hilarious skills of drawing. Each round, you are given a subject of which what your drawing would be deemed the "champion of [random category]" The first part of each round, a person is given this prompt, and then, the second part of the round, the player is given the other player's champion, and has to create a worthy opponent for this champion, pay mind, the second round person involved is not aware of what the first person round's drawing is the champion of, and have to base it off of the drawing.
👍This game is great, especially with the drawing mechanics, and choices between different pen styles, and different colors. The avatars chosen at the beginning of the game are fun. My family has found it to be quite hilarious, even creating "champions" that make a comeback in following games, and we have a lot of fun, creating new champions. However, this game may not be for everyone, especially if they lack the desire to draw. But even, if you feel you do not possess the ability to draw, it can still be a fun game, for everyone.

4.):
This game is a true pop culture game where you are given a category [people, places, things, etc] and it may or may not involve time eras that your party have knowledge there of. However, that does not lose it's charm. You have to make your party guess what it is that you are trying to tell them (the subject you had chose at the beginning of the round) and when they guess, you, the person in charge of the subject chosen, may also use what the other players clues to guess the subject to what it is you are trying to reveal. Whoever guesses the subject, also earns points. Anyone involved in the cluing toward the subject, if the main player chose your guesses in the category round, also get points.
👍No matter of different time eras and possibly not knowing what the subject may be, this game has a lot of fun and cause people to be in cahoots about it. The ultimate goal is to guess the subject. Whether you like to be clever, and/or immature about things, this game is full of fun.

5.):
Imagine trying to sell a product, or making a powerpoint about something. This is exactly what the game is. You are trying to convince your audience that your item, is the best. However, it doesn't necessarily have to be this way. You are given a powerpoint, and an assistant (*ahem* another player in your party) to help you with the powerpoint. You create the context, and your assistant gets to choose a powerpoint slide that is given by the game, that they would feel would fit most (or possibly not fit most) to your speech. You can draw on the photo, creating more hysterically lasting memories. Each player gets to make a comment at the end of the powerpoint, and vote on which one they felt was best, at the end.
👍I do not feel this game may be for everyone, however, it can grow quite hilarious, depending on the party you play with. Clever-minded to immaturity, this game is overall fun.

No disclaimer about the fact that I'm European this time around. This Jackbox Party Pack has a Filter for US-Centric content, to make it accessible to the broader audience around the world. Definitely a welcomed addition. You might still note that all of those games were played with the aforementioned option turned on.

Do I recommend the Jackbox Party Pack 7?
- YES, GET IT AT ALL COSTS!!

Individual game review:

Quiplash 3:
- A classic of the Jackbox Games.
- The best of all.
- Simple and fun.
- Infinitely replayable.
Schmitty's back for some more Quiplashing. The concept of Quiplash just never gets old. It's easy to understand in 2 sentences, it's hilarious and moreover, its third round FINALLY was improved with THREE answers to input in a prompt. This leaves space for even more creativity and laugh moments. The "make your own" mode is still there even. I think they've really hit the spot here. My personal note is 10/10.

The Devils and the Details:
- Developed from what was an April Fools' joke.
- Cooperation game with a tiny bit of deception.
- Interesting concept of interactive tasks on phone.
The cooperative game that will really get the interest of Jackbox players. It is fun in its own way (perhaps different from the rest of the series). There is a complexity to it. It marries cooperation and individualism very well. It has many challenges and the theme is just well made. It is however barely playable on a browser or so I'm told, so try to play it on your smartphone. A mic might sometimes be required. It must also be better if played with all players in the same room. Personal note is .


- The best drawing game ever made by Jackbox.
- Hilarious battle of drawings.
- Leaves space for creativity.
- AMAZING SOUNDTRACK!
Everything is in the lines above. The concept well detailed and easy to understand. Despite being a drawing game, it proved absolutely hilarious and accessible. So many twists. It has an infinite replayability. The universe is absolutely awesome. Nothing else to say, that's in my top 3 of my favourite games from Jackbox. Most of my friends approve as well. Personal note is .


- Will definitely please the fans of Patently Stupid.
- Can be tricky to understand at first, stressful if first timers are talking first.
- Can be quite funny once people grab the concept.
- Room for creativity pretty much everywhere.
Met with a bit of mixed opinions at first in my own sessions. Despite that, if people understand it and are able to improvise, it can prove to be very funny. The speaker and the assistants' thinking and cooperation is what will make their presentation hilarious. It is best played with a mic. It has to be a lot better if done in front of a big screen with all players in the same room, like Patently Stupid. I have to try that out one day. Personal note is .


- Very tricky, even with the US-Centric filter on.
- Satisfying when you find the answer.
- Requires players making others guess to think a lot to succeed
The less funny game of the pack, but not a bad one. It basically calls for some basic trivia and guesswork. That said, the concept is easy, it's using it that isn't as the host of the guess. Could definitely benefit from some additions in terms of possibilities when creating a sentence. My personal note is .


The best Jackbox Party Pack EVER CREATED. To this day, as 2020, I can only recommend that you get this pack above any other. It is the funniest, most accessible and replayable pack Jackbox has ever made. Very good Job, developers, this one will probably be the most played and requested one until - one can wish - The Party Pack 8!

I debated buying it because I own basically every other pack... but this is seriously a MUST! Every single game in here is a winner, unlike other packs. Every game adds something totally new and unique.

Champ'd up is probably my favorite game in the pack, and favorite drawing game of ANY jackbox pack. They've improved on the drawing system so much for a cleaner experience, and the idea of tailoring your champion onto someone elses is so genius and leads to serious laughs.
