This pack is the best pack out there. Get this one! I will be playing this pack much more than others.

The most recent entry at the time of writing, and also by far the best pack. 4 out of the 5 games in The Jackbox Party Pack 7 are exceptional party games that knock every other instalment in this series out of the water. Champ'd Up is an endlessly entertaining game about creating characters and putting them head to head to compete in strange and specific tournaments, and is the best game in this pack. Quiplash 3 is the most recent Quiplash, and is probably the most famous Jackbox game, a simple but very effective game about answering prompts and voting for the funniest answers. Talking points is a great improv game where you present a power point presentation while your partner makes it at the same time, using quick thinking very important. The Devils and the Details is a very chaotic coop game where you complete as many warioware-esque microgames as possible to blend in with human society. Blather Around is the weakest entry, essentially just verbal charades, but you can ignore it's difference in quality due to how great the other 4 games are in this pack. I would strongly recommend this pack above each other one in the series, it's easily the best in the series, both for someone brand new to Jackbox, or someone who owns and has played every previous on before. 9/10

Posted: April 23, 2021
Jackbox Party Packs come in all shapes and sizes, and include a number of different games within them. So I'll break down this review based on types of games in this pack:

CO-OPERATIVE PLAY!
This pack includes some AWESOME cooperative play games. Devils and the Details is a crazy fun game where you work together to complete random challenges. It involves a lot of yelling so make sure your microphone is working for this one!
But the real star of the show is Blather Round, a creative take on the classic Password. You basically try to describe your prompt using awkward language (e.g. you might us "sad liquid event" to get people to guess Titanic). I've played this game with family, friends, and even random strangers online, and it is always a blast. Worth the price of admission 👍🏼

FUNNY
Quiplash is a lot of fun, a great game to play with friends. Basically you're just trying to give the funniest or most amusing responses to prompts.

DRAWING
Champ'd Up is a high energy game where you draw and name characters, and vote for the best ones. I still like Drawful a bit better, but the music and the whole vibe of this game makes it stand out.

TRIVIA
This party pack is not the best game option if you just want to play a straight trivia challenge. For trivia heads I'd recommend looking into Party Pack 5 or 6 instead.

The style of this game is awesome and its so fun to look at. You get to improvise a presentation, if you get embarrassed easily this may not be the game for you, but with the right people it's genuinely so much fun. And I LOVE the way you vote in the game.

QuipLash 3
A fan favorite among Jackbox fans, I don't like quiplash as much but I can understand entirely why people love it. I love the clay animation in this game, it looks awesome and the music is fun.

Devils and the details
Best played irl, otherwise it'll be even more stressful than it already is. It can get pretty chaotic with everyone yelling at each other but people I've played it with still enjoy it. Working together to complete chores is a silly yet fun idea. The art is cute but it's a pretty hard game. I still like it!

Blather Round
Least played game in the box. It's a pop culture guessing game which is a fun idea but not played as much as some of the others in this pack. May fall flat compared to some of the others but this can be pretty entertaining.

Posted: April 28, 2022
++ Quiplash 3 (The best version of quiplash, Jackbox's flagship title)

~ Talking Points (giving presentations on user generated topics is fun but tiring)
~ Champ'd Up (decent drawing game for those good at art, but gets old if you all suck at drawing)
~ Blather Round (Jackbox's attempt at Akinator is okay, but oftentimes players can't guess the answer as the clues are too vague)

- The Devils in the Details (not much other than watching the screen and tapping your phone)

Whilst all the other games are worth a try but pretty mediocre, this pack is worth it alone for Quiplash 3. It solves the issue of its predecessor sometimes having a very lackluster final round and I can't stop coming back to it, it's just too good.

Posted: October 15, 2020
Word Spud.
Lie Swatter.
Civic Dodole.
Zeeple Dome.
Joke Boat.

They've been waiting for a year for their new member.
They will have to keep waiting.
There are no bad games here.

Champ'd Up is a real treat for people who love to draw, and even people that only draw black and white stick figures can join in and stand a chance. So much unintentional humour - and a lot of fun to be had by trying for some humour if you can guess your opponent's prompt and make a deconstruction of it. You get to keep your drawings for the next game if you play with the same players, too! Compared to Tee K.O., it feels like a better flow because you draw two things at a time and every drawing is used at least once, possibly more because there's four drawings and six rounds per person (and again, they can be used in the next game.) Also includes the best part of Bracketeering with none of its bad.

Blather 'Round is like Taboo with less control, and hilarity when someone guesses Oedipus off of "They are tragic; They feel the mommy." Or a rush to type Atlantis after the hint is "it's a not tall liquid civilization."

Devils and the Details is designed to make people talk over each-other and get frantic. I need more time with this one to say much about it.

Talking Points is a chill game where people probably don't care about the points. It can be cute and/or wholesome. It has a "free mode," but I don't see why you'd want it unless you use it to make custom restrictions.

Quiplash is Quiplash.

Posted: February 15, 2018
I've been following Gang Beasts since around 2013 when it was just a twinkle in the eye of a couple of friends on IndieDB, even before the pre-alpha.

Since then this game has seen many transitions, even stepping backwards many times in the gameplay department but never lost it's touch. That is, until they decided to develop a PS4 version as well and then replace the PC version with it. Since then, the game has gone MAJORLY down hill. It's lost almost all of it's charm, by that I mean the way it USED to play. You could do a lot of stupid and silly things, I don't think Gang Beasts was ever meant to be a fighter but more so a silly brawler. By tightening up the controls and trying to make the game better they've made it worse in many ways. They also introduced a stamina system a while back that contributed to me not wanting to play it simply because there was no TOGGLE for it. Sometimes I just wanted to climb the stages for fun without some stamina limitation in my way. They also removed a lot of the "bugs" which weren't really bugs but more so just stupid things that made the game a little more fun.

They've tried to make the fighting more streamlined but they've honestly made it worse, the character controls are still clunky but the character tries to respond quicker to your inputs which leads to a lot of frustration, they also changed the grab scheme too, now you can't even reach up high to grab, you can only reach waist height, climbing while faster now feels worse thanks to some of the mentioned issues. You also cannot grab someone and jump now, they'll automatically let go and I have no idea why they did this, it's stupid and just removes yet another bit of charm the game had. The game has always looked decent but with the PS4 patch they tried to make it look nicer and instead of doing that they killed performance completely. Gang Beasts was always kind of heavy on the system for no reason but the PS4 patch shot it through the roof. The menu is also still very clunky, the only positive out of all of this is the updated costume customizer, that's it and even then, the jelly dudes look worse than they did before some how.

The game's biggest problem is the gameplay/controls, since trying to "fix" them they've completely broken what was fun about this game. They tried to make it more skill based but it didn't work at all, often times now my hits don't connect at all and I'm seemingly always being one punch KO'd by AI instantly, you can't sprint and then jump anymore like you could before, kicking barely works, the dive kick is fairly useless considering how low you jump, the head butt now leads to more self KO's than anything so it's also mostly useless and grabbing is just awful, your character will grab everything but the thing/person you're trying to grab, it was a little tricky pre-PS4 patch but now it's just absolutely God awful. Devs also talked about moving the game into a more general direction back before it was picked up by a publisher, they talked about doing a lot of the things that Human Fall Flat has done, races/obstacle courses and big open spaces, but they seem to have completely dropped this aspect of the game.

So yeah, almost everything that made Gang beasts feel like Gang Beasts is now gone. I hardly enjoyed the last few hours I've put into Gang Beasts since the PS4 update. It just doesn't feel good or feel like the game I originally paid for. I HATE giving negative reviews, I can usually find a good reason to give a positive review but ultimately, Gang Beasts has let me down hard specially for being such a hugely loyal fan for so many years. I expected a lot more.

Posted: December 12, 2017
This game was absolutely amazing when I first played it over a year ago. I really feel like the blend of glitchy physics and simplistic gameplay on levels breakable in ways that shouldn't have been possible absolutely captured lightning in a bottle.

Since then, however, I feel every update has been loosening the lid and letting a little bit of that magic slip out to the point where the remaining charm exists solely in the mild amusement from watching increasingly Raving Rabbids / Minions-esque characters slap each other a little bit.

It makes me feel as though Boneloaf had a very specific vision for this game - one that is unfortunately wildly superceded by the earlier releases. Trying to reign in the out of control physics and removing things like Waves and Race mode - tweaking the climbing system and dumbing down the options available to you for game customisation (off the top of my head, infinite grip) has truly killed the fun I had in this game.

This, in combination with wildly simplifying the levels has turned this game into nothing but a reminder of the great fun it used to be. Back in the day, it wasn't uncommon to uppercut someone onto an airvent attached to the ceiling before knocking it down in an attempt to climb up there with them, or dropkick someone across the room into a well-timed sausage-hole. Now, it's unlikely that anything will happen other than two characters wildly flailing until one falls over followed by the survivor dumping the fallen off an edge.

TL;DR: What was once up in the pinnacle of couch competitive games has unfortunately slipped into disappointment.

Would no longer recommend, but it was fun while it lasted.

Posted: August 17, 2016
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Since last year, me and my room mates have enjoyed drinking and playing this game together. The last update however, made the game significantly less fun. It was so bad, that we actually put the game down after only fifteen minutes. This is the shortest that we have ever played the game. All in all, the latest update is a very large step backward.

The first of my three biggest complains, is that that knockouts are totally broken. You can't knock people out anymore. If you hear the *crack* sound when you knock someone out, they're back up within a second. This takes all the fun out of watching helplessly as someone clumsily tries to throw you over a railing. It's almost impossible to even throw someone out now in the wrestling ring arena now. The only way we were able to get someone out, was when the game glitched, and the person trying to pick up someone knocked out flew into the air.

The second, is that the climbing mechanics are practically nonexistant. A large portion of the game's appeal to me and my room mates, was trying to grab onto someone climbing a wall, and pulling them off. The new climbing is awful. We used to be able to scale the wall in the train arena to avoid being hit by the train, but you can't even get that high anymore. Even worse, if you try to continue to climb after running out of "climbing stamina", you slide back down the wall. On a similar note, it appears that the grip strength has been reduced as well. This has also been very frustrating.

The third issue, is that the lives no longer appear on screen anymore. It turns out that if you hit the back button, you can see them, but that's extremely inconvenient.

As much as it pains me, I can't recommend this game until the developers have either fixed these issues, or rolled back to the previous version. This really is a great game, and the developers have been on top of updating it and adding new levels. I would still reccomend this game, but I hope that this negative vote is enough to get the attention of the developers.

Gang Beasts is one the best local multiplayer experiences available, no question. I have played this countless hours leading up to this Early Access release and I am thorougly excited about the new features and goofiness that awaits.

There is something incredibly appealing about watching plasticine-looking somewhat drunk people punch each other in the face and throw each other into dangerous situations.

If you're having some friends over for a gathering, grab some controllers and play this gem. I have not heard this much screaming since the original Smash Brothers.

We will continue to make this our end of week game in our studio, good job Boneloaf. All the best. Looking forward to every moment that Gang Beasts has to offer.

The Steam copy has lots of new features and tweaks that make it far superior to the old 0.0.1 - 0.0.3 version that were previously available.

It feels like the devs made a cool tech demo but have no idea what to do with it.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Posted: February 17, 2022
This game saved my life.

I am 37.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Posted: February 25, 2019
I bought this game years ago while it was still in early access; the game trailer made it look silly and fun so I thought it would be a good game for me and my son. Let me tell you - I have never laughed so hard playing a game before, nor had I heard my son laugh so much at a game. We would play for hours upon hours. There was the odd game crash because it was in early access, but any other bugs usually just made you laugh more, like your character slowly stretching apart and flying into the air, or getting launched at mach 3 across the map and slamming into the wall. If you had asked me then if you should get this game I would've said yes in a heartbeat, even for $40.00, I'd say buy the game.

They eventually fixed the game crashes and loads of other bugs which was appreciated. However fast forward to now and after multiple new updates the game has improved cosmetically, but the gameplay has gotten much worse. I don't play it anymore and honestly when I come back after a couple months to see if the latest patch has improved things it just makes me sad, because it never does play like it used to and it just reminds me how good this game used to be.

These are the 4 main reasons why I feel it's not the fun game it used to be:

1) Punches simply don't land well anymore.

There was always a bit of luck involved when it comes to who would knock out who, but now you can hit left/right punch over and over and over and have nothing happen, even when you throw some head butts in too.

2) Even if you do finally get a knock out, they're back up within less than a couple seconds.

You have to get successive knockouts in order for the other player to actually stay down for a lengthier amount of time. This might be okay if punching didn't work so poorly now.

3) You used to be able to break out of grapples more reliably.

If someone grabs you, you used to be able to spam jump and after a few jumps you'd break out and leap slightly away from the other player. Now you can spam it all you want but you're usually just going to still be stuck to the other player for as long as they keep holding grab. I suppose this ups the "silly" factor since it makes kamikazee type plays more common given that you usually can't get away from someone grabbing you and jumping off the edge, but that gets old quickly when you actually want to try to play to win and not draw.

4) You used to be able to climb pretty much all surfaces very easily. You could grab a wall and spam jump to get all the way to the top.

This would make for hilarious games where you'd be chasing each other to all edges of the map and trying to grab someone's leg to pull them off the wall. I understand they likely changed this to avoid griefing in online matches, but man if they only could've at least kept it allowed in local play.

There are other minor issues but those 4 things I feel are the main reason why this game is not what it used to be. The problem is that if you've never played Gang Beasts before, you could buy the game and still have fun for a bit because it is so wacky, so I can see why this still sometimes gets positive reviews from new players or Youtubers that only play for a couple hours with friends. But if you were to ask those same people after say 10, 20 hours of gameplay, I suspect they would be getting bored with it already. It's really disappointing for someone who's played since the beginning and knows that before there used to be an actual competitive game underneath the wackiness, one that actually played pretty well.

At this point I would guess that the developers have made their money and are focusing on making a new game by now. But if you devs are reading, I would change this review to be positive in a microsecond if you fixed punching, grapple breaks, and just added some game customization options. Let me decide how long knock outs last in my match, how many punches it takes to K.O., how much stamina players get, etc.

I put a lot of hours into this game, here's hoping it goes back to the game it used to be at its peak.

Posted: November 7, 2016
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I first found this game through a YouTube Let's Play, and it looked really fun.

Well, it is really fun. There's just something so entertaining about being able to pick up your friends after you've punched them unconscious, throwing them around like little ragdolls, and best of all, BREAKING STUFF! You'd be surprised at the stuff you can headbutt into pieces, among them: elevator cables, glass, doors, railings, and much more!

The graphics style is adorable, and it reminds me of those little claymation shows and movies I enjoyed as a child.

Moreover, the control scheme (at least for controllers) is simplistic, and even one of my non-gamer friends got the hang of it immediately!

Replay value? You betcha. Some of the best multiplayer games, in my opinion, are the ones that offer you a simple premise, a few different scenes / characters for when you want to switch it up, and leave you to your own devices. Even if you don't have anyone to play with, one of their builds offered a cool mode where AI-controlled enemies came in waves. Available single- or multi-player!

Speaking of, this game is being worked on all the time. They come out with new builds chock full a' updates more often than I take notice. From bigger things--like more customisable characters and changed menus--to smaller things--like the lighting or details on models on the various maps--it's great getting to see this game progress as time goes on. And honestly, I think it can only get better from here.

Yes, it is "Early Access", but this plays better than the majority of Early Access Games I've experienced. Is it worth $20 yet? Maybe, it really depends on how much you think you'd get out of it (it's definitely its funniest with other people, so if you're more of a lone-wolf kinda gamer, maybe this isn't for you, at the price, just yet...maybe look for it to be on sale on Humble Bundle like I did).

I've experienced just a few glitches, but they're certainly not game-breaking; in fact, they enhance the game! I mean, how can you not laugh when your character breaks every single carriage on the ferris wheel and then is slingshotted into the water? It has an adorable charm to it, and even if it costs me a winning streak, it is a pleasant occasion that I just can't get annoyed at. It's like if your kid pulled a flower from your garden to give you as a present. You still have plenty of other flowers (and plenty of other matches), and it brings a smile to your face. And isn't that what games are here to do? (Most of them, anyway.)

Even though I don't have a whole lot of friends, I've managed to put a solid eight hours into this game already, and by no means am I going to stop there. I wholeheartedly recommend it, and if you're still on the fence, take a gander at some YouTube videos like I did, because they portray very well what the game is like to actually play.

Good with friends, but lately input delay and glitches have gotten much much worse. It seems every time they update it they break it more than don't do anything about it and leave it

*EDIT SINCE SEPTEMBER UPDATES* The glitches for the most part have left the game, random crashes, audio not working, audio not turning off, audio BLARING for no reason, etc. and the multiplayer has gotten much better. Instead of playing a map 3 times it goes first to four on different maps which is nice, elevator spawns have been fixed to all spawning on bottom for nice balance, and the input lag feels like it has been halved. On the other hand some mechanics still need tweaking - some people who I can punch for 20 seconds will not go down but I will go down in one hit, and I will go down for 10 seconds even when tapping a (if that's even still a feature) yet other people will go down for a little bit. But that's really my only complaint, if it's me I have no idea what it could be. Gameplay is much better and smoother, the UI is better and smoother, the audio options actually work, there's much less phasing through stuff and dying randomly, and the new maps are pretty cool too.

This game would benefit HUGELY from adding VR support.

I want to start this review by saying THIS GAME DESPERATELY NEEDS VR SUPPORT.

This game is so detailed and so perfect for VR and motion controllers. I seriously hope the developers add VR support soon as the VR space is lacking a cooking game as detailed and enjoyable as this game. This game could be the flagship cooking game for virtual reality.

----------------------------------------

Initially when you first load into the game it comes across as a little overwhelming but I encourage you to give it a chance and at least play for a couple of hours before you make your judgement.

I advise you place your spices and chopping boards under the TV monitor opposite the oven. This way you can quickly glance up at the TV screen to see how much of each spice you need to season your ingredients with. It may seem like a lot at first but once you get into the flow of things and start memorising the recipe you'll be fine.


- Lots of recipes
- Physics are acceptable for this game
- Graphics are great
- Difficulty Progress is great
- Plenty of funny moments


- Controls are a little janky: Takes a little while to get used to the controls and they are a little difficult to use sometimes. Another reason why VR would be bloody perfect for this game. Natural interaction with your hands would make this game even more fun.

- Weird sluggish mouse? Even with the latest mouse smoothing changes the mouse still feels not as responsive as I would like. It also feels like VSYNC is forced on despite being turned off.


This game really is very fun. Played 8 hours already and I've only owned it 2 days. If you're a fan of cooking or simulator it's definitely worth checking out.

Posted: July 8, 2022
There was a solid 2 days of my life where I was obsessed with making soup in this game. Just soup, because it was easiest to manage in large batches. I had the process for like 5 soup recipes completely memorized. I'm almost 100% sure any achievements I have unlocked are strictly for soup dishes.

It was a pleasant thing, to be so consumed by soup, and I recommend it.

Posted: June 21, 2019
I really like the idea of this game. I like this game... but... man there are a lot of issues here. I will, likely, keep playing the game and really hope they improve things and maybe even take some of my suggestions below, but in this state, I cannot recommend this game to anyone else, and I'm pretty shocked it has a "Mostly Positive" rating right now. This isn't early access anymore...

Let's break it all down:

Pouring

Pouring things into other things is cumbersome. Finally have gotten used to pouring soup from a pot into a bowl and getting close to 300ml, but would MUCH rather use a ladle, even if it was 50ml at a time; it's more realistic and much easier to control (unless I have to aim and tilt; just give me a "pour into thing" option). Also, there's no aiming help when pouring from a pot or other similar items (like there is for purchased liquids), and on a flat screen, the lack of depth perception really hurts this (more on that in cutting later).

With the pots, however, at least you can see the liquid level, so it's not too hard to tell where the start of the pouring is. The bottles and cartons, however, are totally different. Because it's so difficult to stop the pour at the right moment, you want to have low volume things pouring slowly, and to do that you have to very slowly move the mouse until it starts to pour. If you could see the level, then it would be easier to tell when it was going to start.

What I'd REALLY much rather have is the interface like the sink for all pouring situations (and the ladle idea above). Push button to start pouring, push it again to stop, done. There's enough other challenge that the current mechanic is just annoying.



Flipping food is a nightmare. Once you have the item on/in your utensil, you have to hold down shift, carefully maneuver the utensil forward, left/right, and down (but not too far or your pan will disappear into the stove and throw everything else in it, on the floor), then hold down the right-mouse button (still holding shift), and carefully move your mouse sideways to turn the item over. If you let your mouse go forward or backward at all it might crash into the pan and (again) cause it to disappear and throw it's contents on the floor. Then, assuming you did all that correct, you either release or drop it, and have to be careful where your utensil ends up because it might run into something and... cause your pan to disappear into the stove (worst case) or fling something to the other side of the kitchen.

Leaving the spatula and tongs as they are would be okay (well the tongs anyway) if, at least, you couldn't accidentally push them into the pan or other objects and cause them to go flying, or really move at all.



Cutting seems simple enough... put think on cutting board, grab knife, focus cutting board, align the line where you want to cut, and cut. Easy. The issue is, however, you can't really look around once you have your line where you want it, so getting perfect cuts is incredibly difficult for something that even a new cook could do more easily. In real you build up muscle memory and can improve on this, but here, it never gets any better. Sure, you can add a perk to slow down time, and you can add a perk to keep the food from moving, but that's only minimally helpful. Maybe a perk that eventually lets you cut things into even parts (you pick how many) automatically? Not sure... I don't want to take away all the feeling of getting in there with your hands, but the current implementation is just irritating.



Again, more awkward controls. If you want to just put stuff on a plate, easy, hold plate, click each thing, boom. If you want to arrange things, however, putting them in a particular place requires using the cumbersome shift mechanic, which I'm sure I will get faster at, but it will always be an un-enjoyable mechanic.

Maybe better would be something like, hold down the right-mouse button, and then use WASD to position, QE to rotate, and just snap the Z to be above whatever is there (i.e. if you move a potato (with WASD) over another potato on a cutting board, the moving potato would just pop to right above the placed potato, and when you move off to only be over the cutting board, then it snaps down to just above the cutting board.



Similar to moving stuff, the mouse is a major detractor in this game. First thing that helped a lot was to turn off the mouse easing or whatever that setting was. The second is to turn the sensitivity almost all the way down (even on my gaming mouse that I can adjust on the fly, at its lowest setting still needed the game turned down). Other interfaces, however, still move way too fast or strange. The little mini-screen that appears when you deliver the food, for example, is crazy hard to control, which can really irritate you if you have just seconds left to deliver a dish.

If you're going to base nearly EVERYTHING on mouse movement, then that mouse control needs to be dead-to-rights perfect; this game's mouse implementation is rough, at best. Tune the sensitivity better, and even it out across all interfaces, it shouldn't suddenly be faster in one area than another, unless you're going to allow for separate controls for each movement type's sensitivity.



Would MUCH prefer this felt like a menu I maintained for the restaurant, rather than just a series of unlocks. If a real restaurant found that a recipe was not meshing well (from a productivity perspective) they could drop it from the menu, but I can't do that.

Also, I was hoping to be able to create a new recipe and add it to the menu, rather than just picking from a catalog. That would help it feel more realistic too.



While there are "sticky notes" all over, and a tutorial, nothing really teaches you the mechanics. For example, it took a long time to figure out that 300g of potatoes, which require 6g of salt, should have 3g of salt put on each potato you cut them or you will forever get "too much salt" or "not enough salt" critiques.

What does it mean when there's a red border around an item, after the green bar fills up, but before the red bar starts? I assume it means it is at risk for burning, but nothing in the game ever talks about it (unless I've missed it).



If boiled potatoes should have 20g of salt, then adding that salt after the potatoes are in the water should be fine, but if you get the salt on the potato instead of the water then you get marked down. In real, you could just as easily add the salt after the potatoes...

How many people, in real life, have opened an oven door into their plate and ended up shattering said plate all over the floor? I'm willing to bet significantly fewer people than the number of plates I've broken, in this game, at the oven.

Speaking of broken plates... where's the broom and pan? Pick up one shard, throw away one shard, pick up another shard, throw away another shard, repeat about 8 times... ugh...

An oven at 93% looks like it's crazy unhygienic. It took a while of rubbing 'wear' marks with a sponge to realize what that was. Rather than a progression of wear that shows visibly like that, why not have a progression that increases the chance of it breaking (can be reduced with regular maintenance), but doesn't necessarily show on the outside. Just know that the last time you had it maintained or fixed was x days ago or whatever.

You can't fit a pan in front of a pot on the stove. This annoys me to no end because I like to keep my soups on the back burners, and use the front burners for active cooking. Instead, I can only use either two burners for soups, and two burners for pans, leaving two back-burners unused.

Again... I really like the game, but it seriously frustrates me, and because of that, I cannot recommend it.

Posted: June 13, 2019
Product received for free

Pros
✓︎ Extremely thorough food and equipment assortment.
✓︎ Sixty-seven real life recipes to learn and cook.
✓︎ Perk and skill system is a nice touch to the game.
✓︎ Most items are physical objects that can be moved, rotated, thrown and interact with the environment.
✓︎ Gameplay is not limited to a campaign, but provides a sandbox mode, too.
✓︎ Great care for every aspect of the kitchen work, including cleaning and assigning individual ingredients their own cooking times.
✓︎ Each work day is divided in three phases for optimal efficiency.
✓︎ Potentially limitless hours of fun.

Cons
✕︎ Minor collision issues.
✕︎ Requirements higher than what is listed as minimum to run it smoothly with lowest settings possible.
✕︎ Minor problems with controls not being as comfotable as they could.

Cooking Simulator is a groundbreaking simulator including a campaign and a sandbox mode. Such a complete pantry and kitchen with ovens and inflammable, explosive materials... don't try this at home!

Dialogues are limited to tutorial and guidelines.
There is no actual plot to the game.


– You are here forever!
This gamemode is where the player faces the challenges.

During the campaign each day is divided into three phases, starting with the preparation. It's supposed to be dedicated to replacing and preparing ingredients. Some things, like dishes and veggies, can be accessed immediately from the pantry and there is no need to worry about them. More advanced equipment and items such as spices or liquids must be bought from the boxes that act as stores, with their own selection menu. As this process might be quite time consuming, it is advisable to take care of it during this period.

At the beginning everyday there are around 5 orders to complete throughout the day. The recipes are quite faithful to the reality ingredients wise, but obviously cooking times have been reduced for the game.
There are various cooking stations, such as the basic stove, ovens, food blender and fryers together with just the right amount of tool types. Cooking stations are limited to those already placed in the kitchen, but additional tools can be bought at any time from the box. The stations have their durability and after some usage they need to be repaired. This consumes some time and money, but thankfully they don't break often and some perks can help to minimize the encumbrance.
Each food order is displayed on the screens at the center kitchen island and provides the recipe, as well as the time left to complete it. Some operations required for the preparations of the dishes are to cut, cover with spices, boil, fry bake or simply assemble the ingredients. As the game progresses new recipes are unlocked. Every serving is judged based on the ingredients coherency and cooking technique following those on the recipe, if a dish is not plated correctly, it won't be accepted.

After the serving phase, comes the cleaning one. It can be used to empty the pans and pots, rearrange the spices, clean up the kitchen with a sponge and a floor mop, throw away the garbage. It can also serve as an extension of the preparation phase.
Each day concludes with an experience, fame and money summary. Experience levels are used to gain useful skills and one a few levels, some perks as well. When the restaurant is finally ready to advance to the next fame stage, a culinary critic judges a serving of food. If the test is successful it increases substiantially the fame level and allows to advance to a further level, giving the player a small trophy as well. The highter the fame level, the more difficult the gameplay gets, incrementing order quantity during a working day.


- The kitchen is on fire!

In opposition to the campaign mode, in which recipes and ingredients unlock gradually, here the player is provided with every single item available in the game, as well as infinite money. Seeing all those ingredients is truly inspiring and allows a real cooking creative freedom. The dishes in here can't be judged unless the player selects a recipe to follow and serve.

As there is no pressure at all, this mode allows an advanced game exploration, with more hazardous activities.
Encouraged by a dart target-shield, the player can engage in some knife throwing. A sticky note on the oven suggests the most brilliant idea in the game - “I won't ever put a flame extinguisher in the oven!” is what it says, but the fryer works just as fine! If the boxes accidentally end up on the open stove fire, they will burn and cause a magnificent reaction with the gas canisters placed all over the kitchen, setting the floor ablaze– which will cause the fire supression system to activate. It wouldn't be a true simulator, without the windows, screens and AC units breaking as well – just what is needed for the level of frustration certain recipes can provide.


The graphics are gorgeous and very detailed, as even on the minumum setting all the food looks realistic outside and inside. Just by looking at it the player can tell what kind of cooking it's been through. The environment is very pleasing and lifelike, too.
Tere is inbuilt a very handy screenshot system, which pauses the game and allows the player to take the screenshot from the best angle and distance possible.

There are several music soundtracks to select from, as well as no music at all. All of them work well as a background noise. Additionally kitchen sounds are very well made and suggest what is happening in the pans, integrating the immersion.

First things first – before buying, be sure your machine is somewhat better than mine, which already satisfies the basic requirements. This game is heavy, as I played on the lowest possible settings and still had some performance issues, including long loading screens and occasional stuttering.

Sometimes collisions do not work as they're supposed to, as it is possible to break some plates when taking them from a specific shelf, if not using some immagination to how to do it safely, ignoring the actual animation. It happened that when I was passing near the fridge, the content of my pan randomly spilled around, too.
The perk for keeping items still when cutting, did not work for me.

Some mechanics are overly complicated and time consuming, such as setting up a timer requiring way too many steps. Fetching spilled items one by one is very frustrating, as it consists in selecting the item and then waiting as they end up in the pan, misclicking would cause the pan to be put on the surface and is overall very obnoxious and mentally tiring. Pots can be emptied in the trash and not in the sink – not intuitive at all! Also rotation mechanics are very upsetting, as the items not always spill as they're supposed to, sometimes falling around or sticking to the surface.



Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-7500U CPU 2.70GHz 2.90 Ghz
8 GB RAM
NVIDIA GeForce 950M

It offers a challenging campaign and an infinitely entertaining sandbox that sets no real time limit or game completion. This simulator can really be used for some cooking brainstorming and experiments, without spending additional money, which in my opinion is an excellent point. The price is very good for what the player gets.

Alright, hear me out on this. The game is really fun and I like it. It's nice and covers the "cooking simulator" theme really well. You own a virtual kitchen, complete requests and everything's fine as long as you do not run into any bugs. Sadly, there is A LOT of bugs.

I do not want to sound rude but I am really dissapointed by the fact that instead of focusing on improving the optimization and smooth gameplay the devs would rather focus on releasing new DLCs that are more likely to contain the same annoying bugs and glitches from the base game.
If you do not mind your items glitching into the textures and disappearing, fridge/oven's door getting stuck, really wonky physics (although I guess this is to be expected from "simulator" titles), some bugged recipies that need 100% pixel perfect cooking time or amount of ingredients, unstable fps and stuttering, etc. then I guess you are free to enjoy the game to your heart's content.

Nevertheless it is still a fun game, just needs a bit of improving rather than new content which is not that necessary or so I believe. In the end but I wish the aforementioned bugs and issues were addressed better.

Posted: September 28, 2019
BUYER BEWARE - Recommended game, but I have a lot to criticize.
_______________________________________________________________________

There is a reason why VR would drastically improve this game's user experience, and my review will attempt to explain to you why.

There aren't many cooking simulators out there; this is probably one of the best you could get. Despite my recommendation, however, I have to say that the game doesn't feel great.

There are a couple of issues with Cooking Simulator's core system:

1. Janky movement: The player simply moves too much and too quickly through their WASD movements and crouch controls. This will often lead to ingredients falling off of the player's plate/pot/container very easily, often requiring you to pick them up from the surface the item dropped on. While there are no penalty points for food sanitation, this can be annoying at its best, and immersion-breaking at its worst.

1.5 Violent physics: Combined with the awkward movement system, some items have the tendency to break. Sometimes you might be standing in front of a fridge with a plate. Opening the fridge when you're too close could potentially push the plate off-screen, causing it to collide with a nearby wall and spilling all of its contents.

2. Awkward positioning system: This is both a blessing and a curse. The game has a system in which you can place certain items on top of others--such as a bunch of onions onto the cutting board, or a bun on a plate. Normally, this wouldn't be an issue, but the game only allows the player to place these items on the center of the container's surface. This means that if I want five pieces of steak on my cutting board, they would be stacked on top of each other by default until I meticulously push them out of the way or moving them with an additional cooking utensil. This can be very annoying late-game, as it makes meal prepping a lot more time-consuming (unless you use one cutting board for one dish's single ingredient, which will take up a lot of space in the end).

[EDIT: I have been told that there is a workaround for the centering issue. For those who wish to collect multiple items without stacking, you can move your mouse or body before the item falls onto your container so that it would land in a different position. While this tip is incredibly helpful, the player should be careful due to the fact that there is a lack of a proper weight/friction system in the game--there is a strong possibility that your distributed items would slide off your container if you move too hastily.]

3. Lack of proper portion control: The game has a decent collection system, where you can put multiple objects into your container. Say that you diced your onions into tiny 5 gram bits. You can, by default, scroll your mouse wheel to highlight all of the onion bits and transfer them together onto your plate. This can be very useful for large dishes such as pumpkin soup, as you need a lot of pumpkin to make a single pot. Unfortunately, the game doesn't give you the option to fine-tune the amount, so if you want to cook a pot of penne and split them into two portions, you usually will end up with one portion significantly larger than the other.

Also, when you combine this issue with the awkward positioning system, you will often have ingredients falling off your container, since they often stack on top of each other and fall off.

4. Limited mouse controls: This is one of the biggest issues that plagues the game's cooking experience. The devs wanted to make a cooking game where the player has all the control; however, they decided to design this game for the Keyboard and Mouse. This means that when you're using the spatula to flip something, or if you're using a knife to cut something, you're going to be using the mouse to perform the task. It's definitely doable, and it can be pretty easy once you're experienced, but it just feels incredibly awkward when you look at your spatula spin along the Z axis slowly just to drop your fillet so that it falls on the other side onto your pan.

[EDIT: I realize that using a knife is actually the bigger issue for me and I totally forgot to mention that, so here are two paragraphs describing the cutting experience.]

Using a kitchen knife is pretty much identical to being crippled. Since you can't really move your mouse up and down to cut like an actual knife, you actually use the left mouse button and the knife will move down to cut whatever that's underneath. Since you can't really rotate your mouse to cut in different angles, the game wants you to rotate the knife via WASD for you to get the angle you want. All this feels... incredibly slow and awkward. In many ways, it really feels like you're cooking with only one arm.

What sucks the most is that you can't really move the ingredients around the board with your knife to cut things into sizes you want. Say that I need to cut a piece of salmon into 25g chunks. I can easily cut fish through a grid style format, but I cannot cut the fish sideways unless the chunks of meat fall over sideways. This means that I usually have to cut my salmon into fish fries to get the appropriate size for my chunks.

When you take a look at all these issues, you can see that many of these problems stem from the controls themselves--WASD movement are too dynamic, which cause collision issues; the positioning system isn't efficient, because you use the mouse to both hold the container and collect items, which is why everything is forced to be collected at the center of the container; the mouse controls are awkward because the player is supposed to simulate 3D movement on a 2D plane.

I understand that the devs want to get into VR when they're sure that there's enough demand for it, but I see it more as a way to improve the design of the game. Unlike many other game genres, a game revolved around actual cooking is one that takes finesse, and this game doesn't really have that yet.

Posted: June 7, 2019
I've never written a review on Steam in my life. But I'm writing one now, for this game. That's how much I've truly enjoyed it and continue to do so.

Truly a strong entry into the culinary simulation niche side of gaming but not without some minor weaknesses. Potential is rich in the game and the content is sweet and savory and… Oh, sorry – I was a getting bit carried away. In all seriousness, this game has room to grow and will easily stand the test of time as one of the most memorable cooking sims of all time.

Strengths:
- Selection of dishes to create is quite large at the start and are all achievable in another game titled “The Real World”, haven’t played that one yet.
- All prep work, cooking and plating all feel realistic in terms of time and effort, nothing is cheesy or out of place and every aspect requires involvement.
- The look and feel of the kitchen, ingredients and tools are vibrant, modernized and up-to-snuff in terms of the current era in gaming graphics.
- Spending extra time and effort in a creation makes a massive impact on whether you get a decent payout, i.e. wildly chopping a lemon into odd and unequal pieces and not garnishing the dish properly will notch you a star rating or two and put you at risk for failing to impress a food critic which sets you back exponentially.
- Customizing your kitchen and setting it up to your style is limitless. You’re not tied to only having 2 pots, you can have 6 if you want. Want more frying pans? You can buy 10. Want to buy 50 gallons of sour cream? Done. You can easily arrange items for ease of access and redundancy and truly rock the kitchen.
- The Sandbox mode is truly a well-designed playground in which you can initiate food orders at a PC and follow along the steps in order to create the dish at your own pace. Practice juggling multiple orders and finding your groove in a safe environment so long as you don’t set the whole place on fire ;)
All in all, it’s truly a fun game with massive potential and has a lot going for it currently. There are a few things that stick out to me like a sore thumb currently.


- Collision issues. I.e. cut pieces of potato fall through the wire of a deep fryer basket at a large rate. Attempting to cut pieces on a cutting board will wedge the piece beneath the board and the countertop. Moving with a blender moderately full of produce can send some items across the kitchen, etc.
- Frame rate gradually dropping as the days go by (19 currently). Some tasks cause massive plummets, i.e. pouring contents from a pot to a bowel, using/seasoning with the “Thyme” herb, when an order comes in and appears on screen.
- The “career mode” literally feels like a survival/endurance mode. I understand there’s a preparation time and a cleaning segment of each day, but I still barely have enough time to arrange, fully stock up and organize my kitchen. Also, the only feeling of proprietorship of the restaurant you have is changing the cosmetics of the kitchen, i.e. walls, floors and ceiling and purchasing recipes once you have enough fame and points.
- Pouring contents from a pot to a bowl/deep plate is cringeworthy without a ladle. Why not use one you ask? Well, there isn’t one… That’s why…
- Another thing about liquids, perhaps implement the ability to use the scroll wheel of the mouse to adjust the amount of liquid you’d like to end up in destination? For example, I pick up my bottle of “Olive Oil”, I use the scroll wheel and roll it upwards to increase the milliliters I’d like to have end up in my pan, and then pour. Same could be arrange for a pot to a bowl. An idea folks.
- Co-Op mode. Cause nothing says culinary genius than having a friend to blame for why the pasta was overcooked!
I can see lots of work is already been accomplished in just the matter of days and even just hours with patches and the efforts in connecting with the community. If they keep this up and truly support the two-way communication they desire with their player base, this title will make other sims pale in comparison as the development begins to thrive with the support of both developers and the relationship with the consumers working in tandem.

Posted: January 28, 2020
Iron Chef: PC

Cooking Simulator is a, well it’s a cooking simulator. In the career mode, you take on the role of head chef in a restaurant that’s not doing particularly well. It’s your job to return the restaurant to its former glory, by serving high quality dishes and earning yourself fame. Reaching certain fame milestones will bring a food critic to your restaurant, giving you the chance to increase the restaurant’s star quality.

I enjoy cooking in real life, and I’ve always enjoyed cooking games (though I can’t think of any 3D cooking games I’ve played) so I was pretty excited to give this a try. While I’ve found my time with it so far to be pretty enjoyable, it can be a pretty frustrating game to play.

Positives:
For the most part, the visuals are pretty decent. It’s nothing mind-blowing but it looks nice enough.

Cooking in the game is enjoyable, and the systems in place to cook the food are good. There’s a noticeable change in color for food that’s being fried, chopped items look like they’re supposed to no matter how you chop them.

Completing recipes earns you experience points, and leveling up lets you unlock new skills and purchase perks. Skills range from giving you the ability to hold food still while you’re chopping it, to seeing the temperature/’doneness’ of a food item in a closed oven. Perks come in three tiers and usually offer a 10%/30%/50% improvement of something such as tip amount per dish or lower ingredient costs.
















Cooking Simulator can be a pretty frustrating experience thanks to clunky controls, no recipe management and other issues, but despite its issues it bafflingly manages to be an enjoyable experience. If you enjoy cooking or are just interested in the cooking game genre, I’d say that this is worth grabbing on sale.

If you found this review helpful, please consider following my curator page:

Posted: December 25, 2020
I want to recommend this game. I really do.
Food experimentation is something I usually just think about, and creating wacky, and sometimes just satisfying food dish is one of my dream simulation games in theory... but Cooking Simulator becomes a lifeless slong after barely 3 hours in without DLCs.

Creating dishes is not enjoyable when you take in the fact you have to face against time limitations, hostile physics, and picky evaluation system. If I wanted a messy time-management game, I'd go play Cook Serve Delicious instead.
What I dislike even more about this game is how it limits your creativity by forcing you to create recipes, and unfortunately, experimenting to see how well an original dish went doesn't work (unless you're playing the Cakes & Cookies DLC, which is, personally, how I think this game should have been from the get-go). You're stuck doing literal chores with an awful UI, following the same boring recipes. And that's not even the tip of the iceberg -
Game breaking bugs, Unresponsive support team that ceased development for DLCs that have been released months ago. It's as if the game is dead, and yet, they're now focusing on the VR version, which is most likely going to be equally horrid.

It's clear that whoever made this game had a vision, but they couldn't evolve beyond their nearsightedness and delivered this mostly broken mess for a quick cash-grab.

It's overall a disappointing experience, and one that is not worth paying above 9.99$.

Posted: December 13, 2022
Sadly, it just gets painfully boring near the 10th hour.



Watching Let’s Game it Out play this on Youtube, I thought I would love the sandbox experience, and I did! When playing, I tried all manners of different approaches.

I did things chaotically, not caring if there were broken shards of glass in the meal I was serving, frying up my cooking utensils, serving food which I had dropped on the floor three times and blowing up my kitchen devices.
I played professionally, trying to serve up orders as fast as possible with the best quality, getting the restaurant from one star to four stars.
And I also played it the fast food way, using ingredients that I had prepared four days ago, making a gallon of soup and microwaving it for each serving, going for speed over quality and trying to maintain score.
I even streamed my shenanigans to my friends for one night. I did all of that in less than 10 hours, and then I found myself bored and unenthused.


This is a fun game but only for a short time. Cooking is enjoyable, and memorizing recipes is a good challenge, but that’s just it. You’re locked in a kitchen with no interactions with the outside world. All you do is get orders on a monitor, cook them and then serve them into a box and get a score.

There are no NPCs for you to interact with. The closest thing you get is some 2D portrait pop-ups at the top of the screen after each meal and event to blurt out a line you’ve heard a hundred times before.
You don’t even get to see your customers! As mentioned before, whenever you want to serve an order, you place the plate into a box in the wall, its door closes and the game is immediately paused to give you your score on that meal. There are no interactions to be had with anything besides food items.


It would have been nice if you could hire kitchen staff to help you, get to see your customers and have them physically react to your food, even barge into your kitchen to complain. Basically to interact with like a live NPC who isn’t a 2D portrait telling you “good job” for the 20th time in the past hour.
All you do is sit in a static kitchen, doing whatever you were doing the day before and until the end of time with nothing else to do and no one else to interact with. I know I sound like a broken record at this point but that’s because there is almost nothing more to talk about. That’s just it. Whatever you’re seeing in an image or video is exactly what you’re gonna get here. There is no real variety or special events to spice things up. It’s always the same.

To be fair, there are some events like a food critic visiting whose meal score affects the restaurant’s score, but there’s really nothing special or different about it. The only “different” thing is that a 2D portrait pops up on top of the screen to tell you that he’s “important”. He doesn’t ask for any special recipes and isn’t hard to impress either. Serve him crap, like a ⅖ star dish and he’ll still love it give your restaurant a star.

There are other features that try to spice things up and create variety, like skills/perks you can purchase, selecting meals of the day etc. but none of them truly add anything. They just make things easier, like having unbreakable plates, lowering customer expectations, getting more money, a magic wand that cleans the whole kitchen in one click and anything else that feels like cheating and makes it even more boring. Other features like the Meal of the Day affect the game so little that they might as well not be there.

Maybe co-op could have made this more fun and add more value, but sadly, the developers have stated firmly that they will never add it.



Bored of the base game, I tried the and found it to be even worse. Not only is it the same, but now you don’t even have the 2D pop-ups, automatic orders and scores to work with. No, it’s not even a restaurant anymore. You just ring a bell whenever you want to take an order (max five orders at any time) and you deliver them to the aforementioned box with no interactions, time limit or anything. It is so bare-bones and lonely that you actually miss the 2D guys. It feels like you’re playing an imaginary tea-party with yourself.





I can’t really recommend this. It looks fun and it can be, but there are just so many hours that you can play with yourself (pun intended), doing the same thing over and over until you get bored out of your mind. It took nearly 10 hours for me, it might take longer or even less time for you. Either way I expected more from a sandbox.
Maybe if you have VR, you can enjoy it for a little bit longer, but ultimately the lonely, static room I described is all you’re gonna get.

If 10 hours is enough for you, then sure, get it, but if you’re hoping for something to entertain you for a longer period, this isn’t it.

Posted: December 21, 2021
This game has a lot of potential. Unfortunately, it also has a lot of problems, the amount of which make it impossible for me to recommend this to anybody, unless it's a 90% off sale or something. I'm going to make a long rambling list/story/description of all the hassles I have had with this game, the devs (because the experience with the community does actually impact the play experience) and the discord server, which, unfortunately, is a massive part of being able to report bugs (which this game has a lot of. some game breaking.)

Caveat that I play sandbox a lot, because the main stories are just too glitchy, with progress constantly having to be restarted to due game breaking bugs. I also do not have the latest dlc because I refuse to support these devs anymore.

Also, the reason my play time is what it is is because of all the effort I went to to get the game playable, which exceeded the allowable refund time - and it is decently entertaining when it works.

Important information re specs: My rig is an i5 - 9600k, GTX 2060 super with 8gb VRAM, 16gb ram. Desktop. So I more than meet the system requirements. I do honestly believe that if you are trying to play this game with a system that is under the minimum, then yeah, you're gonna have bugs. My point of contention here comes with the recommended requirements. Namely...what are they? Because they certainly aren't the ones listed on the steam store page. When I first bought this game, I would get constant BSOD Machine Check Exceptions about 20 to 30 minutes into gameplay no matter what mode I was in. That I can kind of let slide, because it turned out to be user error on my part, sort of. (It was a unity thing and I had to up my CPU vcore to fix it.) But it's a great example that this game is not optimized well at all. I get low fps on any settings, despite exceeding the hardware requirements. it always feels very laggy and it makes my fans sound like a jet engine. (the only solution i have found to this was from the discord where a user suggested turning vsync OFF in game, setting the in game frame limit to 5 frames above the target you want, and then using your gpu settings outside the game to turn on vsync that way.) Incidentally, I have heard a dev say in their discord server that "for some reason, our game doesn't seem to work very well on high end machines", That is unacceptable! It's probably because it's not optimized well at all.

This brings me to the discord server which is a very important part of the game experience because it is the only way to report bugs. The devs really do not pay attention to the steam forums. However, even on the discord server, bugs get ignored constantly. I have reported bugs several times following their template and supplying the output log as requested only to never get a response, despite them saying in may 2021 in their announcement channel that they will be responding to reports with a checkmark to indicate they noticed it. I understand they have work hours and I am not expecting them to be in the server during their time off - but I reported the honey pouring glitch SEVERAL TIMES while the custom menu patch that broke it WAS STILL IN BETA and they still published the update without even fixing that bug...which then went on to be unfixed for MONTHS afterwards. They only seem to publish several rounds of bug fixes when a new dlc drops and after three or four updates, bugs will go unfixed until the next dlc releases. There are game breaking bugs, like things becoming uninteractable, that have been in the game since launch that are still not fixed. The discord you are directed to for customer support is useless because nobody gets back to you and the mods there are very rude and unhelpful.

The controls are also very janky, and I think a large part of the reason it has so many bugs and why these bugs are so unreplicatable is the very physics system that is the core appeal of gameplay. Sometimes the physics engine will just...freeze. And the only way to fix it is to restart the save/game/sometimes your entire computer. The physics engine is probably responsible for a lot of the lag. Objects will just disappear into space or fly off of plates randomly. I desperately wish this game had mod support simply so that people could fix bugs the developers clearly have no interest in fixing.

This game is basically streamer bait for "haha look at the wacky physics." It's impossible to have entertaining gameplay for long term in career mode because of these game breaking bugs, and the devs are not going to fix it any time soon, if ever. It really feels like an early access title still, even though it's had multiple dlcs already. As for the DLC, i have all but shelter, and even the dlc feels like...missing potential almost? Like, why can't we make our own fillings in cakes and cookies? Some dlc bugs are still in the game despite being reported multiple times - like the fact that with a large pizza, you cannot fill the entire pizza with sauce/toppings, which affects your final score. I must have reported the fact that not all the decorating tools spawn in in cakes and cookies sandbox at least three times, with no response.

There IS some fun to be had if you just fool around in sandbox periodically and don't do anything serious - it's basically the only way to play the game in its current state. But overall I can't recommend anybody actually spend money on what is clearly an unfinished game that will never be polished, which is tragic, because there is potential here.

Posted: July 30, 2021
If you've ever watched this game being played on Youtube, you've probably found yourself laughing hysterically at the insane antics on screen. Simple cooking jobs gone horrible wrong, food landing on the floor, pots and pans flying through the room etc. In one memorable episode, a Youtuber attemped to pick up a plate from the counter, but instead ripped off a cabinet door, sending it flying up vertically, hitting and breaking the overhead recipe tv-screen. This, I will openly admit, was one of the most insanely comical moments I've ever witnessed in Youtube gaming.

So if you're looking for a slapstick game of culinary mishaps, this one can be fully recommended. However... if you actually want to play a cooking simulator, you may very well get severely disappointed with this title.

The game suffers from three major problems, add these ingredients together in one recipe and you get a complete disaster.
1) The game relies heavily on pixel-perfect clicking. If you don't get it 100% right, things will go wrong... badly wrong
2) Cooking Simulator suffers from the same kind of weird mouse delay as Car Mechanic Simulator. The cursor somehow seems attached by a rubber band, so you move the mouse, and the cursor starts moving, but you have to wait a bit for the cursor to actually get where you want it to go. It's really hard to explain, but it's a strange sort of fly-by-wire system using a special "translation-method" for mouse movement, rather than the standard built-in mouse control.
3) in this game physics are extremely complex: you don't just place something on a plate, you control the angle as well as the 3-dimensional position from which you let go of the item. Get it wrong and the potato (or whatever you're handling) will roll off the plate, or simply land on the floor, because your 3d angle tricked you.

The result of these 3 elements is, that the main focus of this game is, not to actually cook, but instead to try to overcome the physics obstacle course of very, very carefully manoevering your (lagging) mouse cursor to the exact positions required by the game. Now imagine this being a constant requirement for every single action you perform, and you have a game, that literally leaves you utterly exhausted from the constant extreme concentration required. Of course, all of this must be done under intense time pressure and you'll find the game constantly telling you to hurry up, and warning you that the customers are about to lose patience and leave.

It should be added that yes, my PC DOES meet minimum requirements and yes, I DID try adjusting the mouse settings in every way... it just doesn't really help much.

I really, really want to play a cooking simulator, unfortunately this game is not such a thing. Maybe if your hand/eye coordination is super sharp and you have an extreme high-end computer, you will be able to enjoy it, but be warned: just making sure that your PC meets the minimum requirements is not going to be enough.

Posted: June 29, 2020
This is a very hard game to review. I couldn't decide whether or not to recommend it because the glitches are so bad and the play mechanics in some parts are impossible or require "tricks" that shouldn't be necessary. The only thing is, the game is truly addicting. However, I wish I had never bought it as it has only brought doom to my life. I no longer want to be a chef.

Things that will annoy you:

1. Cutting things. You have to cut stuff to a certain weight but this can take a long time especially on small items. For example, you would think cutting Brussels Spouts in half would be super easy. Technically it is. However, you have to do it with only one on the cutting board at once because even when your knife is nowhere near the other sprout, it will somehow magically cut it. There will be times where it will not cut what you want and the item just moves. Just let me cut the potato or pumpkin in half for goodness sakes, game!

2. Your pantry sometimes does not update with the new ingredients you need. My apples and potatoes disappeared from the pantry and I'm not sure what else should be there that isn't because I restart the game and it is different. Buying 5 Asparagus at a time or Brussels Sprouts (those evil evil Sprouts) one by one can slow things down even if you buy things before the day starts.

3. Items will say Heating Mistakes when you didn't make any. Now I know, you're probably thinking, well you suck at the game and deserve it. Alas, I promise, I can flip Salmon like a boss but it is hit or miss whether or not it likes my heating even if I did the exact same things and had the exact same coloring on it.

4. Once you get into the more difficult or updated recipes, some will be ridiculous. Maybe I'm a perfectionist, ok I confess I am a perfectionist, but I practice recipes in the Sandbox? mode to make sure I can make them quick. I do prep work in the mornings. My soups are always ready to just heat and serve. Some recipes though, the steps are ridiculous and the game mechanics are so bad that you can only get a perfect score on accident.

Tips:

If you made the bad decision to get this game:

1. Get the 150 Ladle. Stop everything and just get it immediately. Otherwise enjoy wasted soup.
2. You can make your soups at any time and then just heat in a pot (I use the small one) and serve them. Even the more difficult soups. Get the soups, especially the initial ones, and update them because it gives you time when someone orders one so you can work on a different recipe. Don't turn in the soup right away if you need time to do two other dishes (or so on) so that another order doesn't come in right away.
3. You need lots of lemons. Cut those bastards beforehand. In fact, just put some plates with parsley (or oregano twig etc) and the lemons and be ready to top with something else.
4. When you boil something like potatoes, you need to use the colander to strain the liquid or it will give you a message on not enough salt/too much salt.
5. When it asks you to drizzle something, get the colander and just cover the item in it without even bothering to measure. Some items can only absorb so much oil so you'll waste liquid but as least your items are covered like they are supposed to be.
6. Don't get the bruschetta recipe. Try to avoid recipes that say to make a mixture of spices and liquid which you then use to drizzle on stuff. If it is just say salmon topped with 5 ml of lemon juice then that is one thing, but the drizzling mechanic for mixtures is just near impossible.
7. Buy the meat ahead of time and season it. Just have some seasoning fun. They don't spoil so you can leave out fish and meat which you seasoned laying around and then just cook to order.
8. Don't try to reach too far for plates and bottles. Also don't stand too fast if holding these items and crouched. Things will break. I've somehow mastered the art of not breaking stuff so just be patient and you too shall never break plates or bottles again. I never wasted the points on the unbreakable plates and bottles because you'll want the others.
8. The perks that slow time when chopping and for being able to see the temp through the oven are very good. Also the holding still one.
9. Don't punch your computer. You will be having the perfect day, critic and people loved your food and then BAM glitch or you mess up. Your game freezes or lags. You get one of the impossible recipes and your perfect day is down the hole.
10. Google some of the recipes because there might be work arounds you just are not seeing. (Like the drizzling in a colander thing)

Please stop releasing new stuff and fix things!

Posted: June 30, 2019
Coming from someone that has been doing challenge runs and speed runs. Playing this was a nice change of pace.
If you have some kitchen experience, remember what it was like to actually prep food before opening time. For instance, I slice my veggies, and have about 5 of each meat already seasoned and ready to go. Do not throw out soup after making 1 bowl, store it somewhere until the next order, throw it on the stove for a few minutes and then serve.
My only warning, DO NOT unlock 7 or more recipes at once and expect to be able to prep them before opening, you will find yourself overwhelmed. Another delightful thing about the game is, you can say screw it, and stop cooking start breaking pretty much everything... I blew up the kitchen and started throwing T.V. screens everywhere.

Now with that part done some things I have issues with. For one, I constantly set things down onto things I'm trying to pick up the 'sweet spot' for these items feels fickle, with that in mind, if I am using the large circular tray/plate and set it down onto something it bugs out and everything on the tray will go flying, little funny at first incredibly irritating in the middle of rush. I also noticed that you cannot put a large pot on the back burner and a pan on the front burner properly, the pan will sit tilted thus leading to heating issues with the dish. I have also had an issue with items disappearing or clipping through the counter tops. Two of my sauce pans were on center stovetop, something bugged out and they both freaked out broke a t.v. screen made a huge mess everywhere, and the pans just disappeared, and now I cannot use those center burners even after repairs. That is it for the minor bugs, overall i really love the game!

My suggestion for possible content or sequel.
If it is not possible to do in this game (i have heard from your dev that you may be doing larger kitchens and stuff in the future)
But if not possible with this game, I would like to see a multiplayer feature. Again if not possible with this title, maybe consider doing 'Diner Simulator', providing maybe 3 roles. Chef, Sous Chef and waiter/prep, Giving you a decent little team to create or destroy something beautiful.
