Posted: February 16, 2021
TLDR: The concept was satisfying, however both Career and Sandbox mode missed the sweet spot of being "fun while challenging". Sandbox mode is unsatisfyingly unchallenging whilst Career mode is too chaotic.

Sandbox mode is for you to experiment and get wacky in the game, or maybe let's cook from your imagination! You spent a lot of times trying to create an instagramable food. No matter what you do, it always look like a pile of sh*t. Destroying and burning the whole kitchen will be what you see the most on Youtube, because the players don't know what to do in sandbox.

The Career Mode is fun in early stage. Once you managed to get 3 stars restaurant, the experiences become a chaos as you are the only chef that singlehandedly need to memorize abundant of recipes that ranges from seafood into steak, with entirely different ingredients for the whole day. This can happen because you don't decide the recipes, your supervisor do instead. This is Cooking Simulator, not Kitchen Nightmare TV Show. You are the chef after all, you should be able to control the recipes, not them! Even Spongebob can't cook other than Krabby Patty!

Posted: July 5, 2021
Former Chef here

The little I've played makes it hard to recommend unfortunately. A lot of things that should be fairly straightforward to perform are made unnecessarily difficult - for example assembling a burger. When attempting to place a slice of onion or tomato, the game defaults to placing them down vertically instead of flat, forcing you to spend a frustrating amount of time manually aligning and rotating each individual piece to place them down. Likewise if for example you wanted to pre season trout or salmon during prep to save yourself time later, you'd naturally think (or at least I would...) to place them all on a tray, except that the game will stack them up in the middle of the tray instead of laying them out. For a game that focuses quite a lot on getting things done quickly / in time, the game itself gets in the way too much and makes for a frustrating experience. I get that this is equal parts a physics sandbox, but I think there's areas where the physics adds to the experience, and other areas where it detracts.

I'd also say, having ran shifts in a commercial kitchen solo, most of the dishes require too many steps for one person to tackle alone - there's a reason most kitchens of this size would have multiple stations and I don't feel like the game compensates enough with the timers for this. I'd love to see multiplayer implemented - not only would it share out the tasks in a way that makes more sense, but the derpiness of the physics also lends itself much better to playing with others and bantering about the dumb crap that's going on.

To cap off these main negative points are smaller frustrations such as the oven being buggy and taking damage simply from opening and closing the door.

One big thing however I will say that the game does well is the FEELING of being the middle of service - being halfway through one order when another comes in, and having to adjust the plan in your head on the fly to make a start on the next while finishing the current. Took me back to some of the (few) memorable moments of hitting the flow state and flawlessly throwing order after order through the pass. Feels good.

Posted: January 7, 2020
This is a very underrated gem for what it is, a cooking game.

I remember watching videos and streamers rip up the whole kitchen or try so hard to play it safe in this game without something bugging, spilling, or breaking on them, and I have to say, they were all playing it wrong. THE GAME PLACES YOUR FOOD FOR YOU.

I’m on day 10 and I have not broken a single dish or had the food glitch out on me. Why? Because I played it how the tips and tutorial suggested it. It’s an insane level of difference once you realize that you can place your food out of anything, pots, pans, bowls, whatever, and onto your plate if you stay still while doing it. You don’t have to use the spatula, tongs, or anything to place food other than this way. Just grab it, and if it’s too hot, it’s likely already done, so put it on a plate via clicking it with a plate in hand. Flipping is the only chore so far and you get used to it.

The game is a lot more fun long term wise, when you’re not un-intentionally playing it like a 4head.

Edit: You can automatically transfer liquid with the ladles too.

Posted: July 1, 2020
I like this game a lot, the concept is nice, replay value is good, and there's a lot of things you can do. But honestly, I don't recommend the game due to fact that it's hard to play it without encountering any issues/bugs/glitches.

TL;DR: Play it if you don't mind encountering some bugs and issues in your gameplay.

My actual expectation of a playable game IMO is if the game isn't causing uncomfortable issues to your gameplay. I bought the game with the thought of wanting to relax after a long day of work. But I end up trying to troubleshoot my save more than actually playing it. Which is already what I do in my day job. ; w;

Anyway, expectations aside, I just wanted to point out a couple of things this game can improve (aside from fixing the bugs):

1. Tutorials - Currently, tutorials are very linear. A lot of parts have to be done exactly step-by-step, the consequences of not doing so can cause the tutorial NPC to bug you till you repeat the step in exactly the way it was instructed or getting stuck on the tutorial till you restart it.

Players who's either already familiar or wants to get crafty about the tutorial doesn't get enough freedom to do so. In example: you exactly have to pour the Chicken Stock from the carton or pot and game doesn't allow you to use the ladle. This means that instead of carefully measuring your ingredients, you'll be forced to eyeball them.

2. No matter how good your PC is, it feels like the game isn't built to do bulk cooking. Try making a bulk of something and see your game start to lag due to the amount of rendered items. Would be nice if the impact can be lessen.

Eitherway, if you choose to buy this game, I would definitely recommend getting Cakes and Cookies DLC, the gameplay mechanic from the DLC is more relaxed and has more freedom to be creative.

Posted: May 25, 2020
The real fun is in messing around with propane tanks and fire, or at least sticking to sandbox modes. At the moment, when you do try to get serious through objective-based modes, many frustrating bugs and physics issues get in the way every now and then, which usually results in wasted time and failures. You end up having to fight one of these issues at least once per game day once you're doing the more complex recipes:

1. The basic act of cutting things may just stop working on you. Scallions sometimes end up becoming the hardest substance on Earth and resist the very first cut.
2. Saving and loading is very dangerous if you were mid-cooking. Soups suddenly have NaN% ingredients, bowls explode and dump all of its contents everywhere, lives get ruined.
3. Solid food phase through their container if you move too quickly. The coolest part is when you place the completed meal on the serving counter, and the act of doing so makes all the food fly away, making you serve a completely empty dish.
4. Many recipe steps can be completely ignored because the game clearly doesn't support some food interactions. Garlic sauce doesn't need garlic. You can have horseradish sprinkled on trout pre-bake, and not post-bake; you never need to chop ingredients that will never be in the final plate.
5. Drizzling sucks and is surprisingly non-intuitive. If the game tells you to drizzle a mix of soy sauce, oil, and vinegar onto something, it's easier to just flood the food with the three different liquids one after another. Or else you have to perform the herculean task of distributing 10mL of a liquid to a dozen different things.

When playing Career Mode, the most efficient move is to not do anything fun. Prepare 3L of basic soups at the day's start, serve within 10 seconds of the order being given, and end up doing 20 orders a day because the customers instantly come after each dish. This means completely avoiding recipes with names "french fries". By god, avoid french fries at all costs.

While these bugs might be temporary and will be fixed in the future, they have not been fixed since their release, so I have no hope for that. If you're a streamer looking for a Goat Simulator experience in a kitchen, this is for you. Otherwise, not really.

Posted: June 6, 2019
Cooking Simulator is a one of a kind game. See, I love cooking in real life. Cooking is such a rewarding experience. Pouring your soul into a dish, serving it to people, and seeing the dish put a smile on their face is just an exhilarating feeling that only cooking can give you. And that is why I am so glad Cooking Simulator exists, because I know that in real life, I will never get the opportunity to see just how BAD I can make a dish. Cooking Simulator is beautiful because you can TRULY do whatever you please without real life consequences. If doing what you please is cooking a flawless and presentable 5 star meal, go ahead. If doing what you please is overcooking a steak with a blowtorch and then marinating it in soap and a disgusting, thick blend of burnt pumpkin-eggplant sludge, go ahead. You have freedom to do as you please.

Overall, Cooking Simulator is a hilarious time waster with fantastic graphics, wacky physics, and lots of content. It is buggy from time to time, but there is no bug that is unbearable. Purchase this game now while it is still on sale. You won't regret it.

Posted: January 14, 2021
I have mixed feelings on this game. I have had my eye on it for a long time, and initially tried it on Nintendo Switch because it was on sale for $1.99. The controls on the Switch are garbage so I decided to get it on PC since it had piqued my interest.

I spent 14 hours in a matter of a 4 days playing this game. It definitely takes time to get used to the mechanics and game play. When first starting, the tutorial really doesn't feel like enough to get you started. I would recommend spending sometime playing around in Sandbox mode and practicing before attempting any of the career modes.

I was having a blast playing this game and getting pretty good. That is until drizzling became a thing. The drizzling mechanic is basically non existent. You put some sauce in a bowl and then pour all the sauce at once on to your food and it "drizzles" it. If you are lucky it doesn't go all at once. But you can't control the flow. It is easier to drizzle straight from the bottle than how the game instructs you to. What ends up happening is you have to do it over and over again to get the food more evenly covered. It is a waste of time and energy and makes the game incredibly tedious.

The higher level recipes almost all include this mechanic and since it is so variable it is hard to get 5 stars on taste. This pretty much ruined the game for me and I am probably going to stop playing. Fix the drizzle and I would be back for more in an instant.

Posted: June 23, 2019
While i don't have many hours on my steam game I played for a year in testing. Honestly for a full release it still feels Early Access, the game has no depth as a cooking sim and it has no depth as a management sim. Here is my full review and why I can not recommend it.

Good-
*Graphics are beautiful
*Concept is fun
*A fair range or ingredients
*A skill tree and unlocks

Bad
*This Game truly is not optimized and performance makes it Laggy and stutter.

*Tutorial is frustrating and leaves you not feeling confident.

*Controls NEED help as they are confusing.

* Career path had no back story
* No temps or real recipes- The microwave has to low settings yet the stove does not, the recipes are not some thing most people would order like salmon and 2 Full boiled potatoes not cut.

*Cutting/chopping/plating is all horribly executed, you can not make a plate look pretty I'm career mode.

*You can not customize your own menu

*Finances make no sense bc you buy the ingredients and plates while you cook.

BIGGEST ISSUE OF ALL the game feels stale and needs a crew of ai cooks. Doing it all by yourself gets boring

* No MULTIPLAYER! The game is perfect for friends yet fails to deliver.

In the words of Chef Gordon this is still RAWWW! If you do try this make sure you get it on sale it is not worth $20 in its current state. The devs seem responsive and may fix this issues, I will change my review at a later date as it progresses.

Posted: July 9, 2019
I would not recommend this game. I really wanted to like it, but it has three major shortcomings which make it unpleasant:

Bad optimization
Framerates vary wildly depending on what you are doing and where you are looking regardless of graphics settings. When the framerate drops, input lag jumps. This is frustrating when making precise moves and looking around a busy kitchen.


Some tasks (like chopping and pouring) require unusual precision from the player, while other tasks (like plating) are helped along massively by the game. Worse yet, some tasks combine realistic ease with stupid difficulty. For example, the game will help you by positioning food perfectly on your spatula! But then you have to precisely position and angle the spatula as the food slides off in a goofy way. Cooking Simulator should either be realistically simple or hilariously hard. When it's both, the player is just confused and annoyed.


Spices often fall through the food, so you have to examine the surface to see if one sprinkle of pepper phased its way onto the chopping board. If there are multiple objects on a plate (like chopped potatoes), they tend to flip out and fly away. Don't be surprised if the game accepts a perfect dish on the serving counter and then delivers an empty plate to the customer, leaving you with amazing food objects just floating around.

Posted: November 7, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
THAT GAME...

...Will give you feels that you may not have had anywhere else !

You might say : "Oh but it's like Besiege."
MAYBE, EXCEPT THAT YOU GET SATISFACTION FROM YOUR OWN DESTRUCTION.

You might also say : "Oh but it's like Simpleplanes !"
MAYBE, BUT AT LEAST THE DEV BEHIND THIS GAME ACTUALLY IMPLEMENTED MULTIPLAYER.

You might even say : "Oh but it's lik BeamNGDrive !"
MAYBE, BUT WITH LEGOs, THEREFORE BETTER.

To be more serious now, Brick Rigs had a lot of potential when I got it, and it's still as fresh now.

The 1 man dev team that created Brick Rigs is always active, and we get a mindblowing update every month !
To give you an idea, in the span of 1 year, we got :
-Multiplayer
-Aerodynamics
-Helicopter improvements
-GUNS, both handheld and vehicle mounted
-PVP gamemode
-Space map
-Large Desert Map
-Variety of materials to make your bricks from
-A good bunch of new, essential bricks

And I may have not noticed all of the updates, the game looked decent when I had it, yet it was only 7 months old !

So, if you have the spirit of a creative child, the rage of a WW2 pilot or the audacity of a stunt driver, then go ahead and buy it ! This game is worth 15$ right now and this price will get more and more meaning as the updates come up.

Posted: May 2, 2018
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Brick Rigs is a game about building and messing around with LEGO vehicles. They can’t use the name for legal reasons, but we all know the truth.

So cutting to the chase, would I recommend it? Yes. But there are a few things worth noting. Let’s get into it.

Pros:
- Core gameplay is fun and well executed
- Destroying LEGO creations never gets old, and you can use a rocket launcher to boot.
- Steam workshop integration to share and download creations
- Surprisingly good graphics and world physics
- Intuitive menus and easy to learn controls
- Really big maps to mess around on
- Can slow down and speed up time as you please

Cons:
- Lacking in content and polish, given that it’s Early Access
- Not great for multiplayer, although the option to play with friends does exist.
- Trains tend to derail pretty often which can get annoying.
- Building on the point above, the lack of a checkpoint or save state system hinders your ability to explore with your creations. You will almost always crash before you get far.
- Character models feel like cheap placeholders, and there’s no way to customize them or your gear, beyond selecting a job like Police Officer or Firefighter.
- There’s a zombie killing mode, which is cool, but it’s barebones right now. It could be really great in the future though. I’m thinking like LEGO Call of Duty Zombies, but that might be setting the bar too high.
- This last one is my opinion and could be seen as a Pro, but you can place bricks inside of other bricks. This allows for more unique designs as well as more compact designs, but goes against the spirit of LEGOs/brick building games. Bricks are designed to connect to other bricks. That’s the whole point. If I can make something in a game, I should be able to take real bricks and make it in real life. It also leads to glitchy, overlapping textures in some cases, which is annoying to look at.

So overall, I’d give it a 7.9/10.

What it does, it does well, for the most part. The foundation has been laid for a great game. That said, there’s definitely room for improvement. It comes down to how dedicated the developer is in the future, but that’s really the nature of Early Access, isn’t it? If you love LEGOs and want to support/encourage the dev, it’s a pretty safe purchase. I certainly don’t regret it.

Posted: February 23, 2018
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
First thing I'm gonna say is: I love this game. It's fun to mess around in, it's fun to build, and it's helped me make a lot of great friends. But I can't recommend this game. I love it, I can't stress that enough. But I doubt you will. The developer won't give us a changelog. He won't listen to the community, and, oh the community. What a pile of rubbish it is! They have this insane idea that, when someone like me and a group of friends suggests something AS MINUTE AS A CHANGELOG, they go bat****. They say "he isn't your slave", "He can do what he wants", and **** like that. I am sorry, but I just cannot stand it. We give a suggestion, and they dogpile on us. The moderators slander us, the community accuses us of spamming dislikes on anything on the front page (despite the fact that it happened to us as well, and that moderators can check that ****, but instead they sit on their lazy ***es and endorse the toxicity to anyone who disagrees). As I said, I love this game. Or should I say, loved. The develpoer cared about the developements and the community, oh the comunity, was just us. Me, some friends, some who were to be friends and conform to the toxicity, and some who were to be friends and eventually get shunned for speaking out. It's a hivemind. This is from someone who was inside or a while. So my conclusion? Don't bother. Get a Lego game, try out Scrap Mechanic or Rigs of Rods, but whatever you do, no NOT get sucked into this community's endless pit of toxicity.

Update: I have taken an almost year long hiatus from this game to clear my mind, and I've come back to it to play with close friends and no one else. What I've gathered from my time back in the game, with no disrespect, is that the developer constantly makes decisions that are, what I would call, regressive. There are, of course, good parts of updates, but his updates seem to be mainly focused on new gimmicky bricks and maybe a graphical update every now and then, and less on actual optimization and bugfixes. There definitely has been an attempt at both, but I feel it is still being overshadowed by, frankly, unnecessary and frequently bug-ridden content. As for the community, I wouldn't know. I have been banned from the discord (It was so long ago, I don't know if it was justified or not, but for the review I will assume it was), and I don't spend enough time on the Steam Workshop so I can stay away from the drama and mob-mentality that I felt plagued the community before my hiatus. Unfortunately, I still cannot recommend the game. The developer is definitely working harder on the game and I feel the quality is improving, but over the years of owning and playing the game, I fear one simple brick or gamemode (like guns) has, and will again, plague the community with immature kids who want nothing better than to shoot everything they see. I don't want to hate on the people who chose to spend money on this game, but I personally wouldn't suggest you pick it up, unless you intend on making your own vehicles and having fun with a close group of friends.

I am a 63 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Posted: July 26, 2021
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I've been a massive fan of this game for years and I hoped the 1.0 update would remove the things that really bugged me. Those were:
-The game is called Brick RIGS implying you're supposed to make vehicles, yet WHEELS don't work! If you drive faster than 50 kmh, you're playing Russian roulette as they randomly bounce and throw you off the cliff...
-The engines should distribute power among driving wheels, instead power is multiplied by each driving wheel. Want to go faster? Just add more wheels!
-Gears don't work. Instead of lower gears having more torque and less speed and higher ones having less torque and more speed, here, the higher the gear, the higher the power and speed! Want to go like a rocket? Just switch to manual mode and switch to 6th gear immediatelly, touch the accelerator and you are ballistic!
-Aero is hit and miss... There is no drag, you continually gain speed while falling. There is no sense in how it works either!

All of these would be ESSENTIAL to a game focused on making vehicles, right? Years later, 1.0 arrives and it fixes... None of those... I'm sorry, dev. It's time we part ways.

EDIT 20/09/2023: Seems that wheels finally don't launch your vehicle randomly. Nice. The other gripes I had are still there though.

Posted: August 21, 2021
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I have loved playing Brick Rigs for many years, it is like playing with legos except you can actually drive them, fly them, and smash them with no consequences! This game has brought me MANY hours of tireless fun with activities such as street racing, building, and living in a lego world. The controls are simple and easy to get used to, the physics are hilarious, and the multiplayer is fantastic, creating a comical yet comfortable game that is an absolute joy to play.
At this point in the review you must be wondering why I gave this game a thumbs down when there is so much to love about it. My reasoning, is that Brick Rigs 1.0 update ruined the game. I am sure that many other reviews have said the same things, but everybody wanted the 1.0 update to have useful fixes such as better tire traction, better severs, new bricks, more maps, and other useful features. However, these expected changes were not to be, and instead we got a worse game than we started with. Servers are laggier than ever, the new UI is awful, the previously simple and intuitive game I loved has been ruined. Everyone I know who used to play Brick Rigs has stopped playing because of the update. The new 1.0 update has made one of my favorite games into an example of how a perfect, enjoyable, charming, and simple, game can be turned into something not even worth playing, let alone paying for. I am sad to see what Brick Rigs has become.

Posted: April 11, 2020
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
It's like a cross between LEGO digital designer and an open world LEGO game, is the simplest I can put it. Everyone has either played a LEGO game or had a go at Digital Designer, but here you get to play with what you've built. It's a fun thing to mess around with and see how far you can push the limit of both your own designs and creativity and how far you can push the physics engine! It's got an active community and the workshop is filled with great designs and builders (plug for my own workshop here). You can either play online or single player, but the latter is more for building a designing something as you can't get that much fun out of going things by yourself.

However, despite the good, there is some bad and I mean quite a lot of bad actually. The multiplayer is unstable when here's more than 1,000 bricks out, even after it was updated once. This has been improved with a full release, but multiplayer is still a bit buggy. Many servers are filled with kids mad with admin powers and I suggest generally avoiding joining random servers and instead making one with friends instead. There are some minor bugs and glitches, but none that I've found 'break the game'. While I did praise the community, many of them are screaming kids who don't know how to construct a proper sentence or argument from what I've seen (again, I tend to stay away from the discussions page to avoid being dragged into one). However, the biggest problem many have is the lack of constant updates. The games is built by one man and one man only who is working hard to make this game as good as he can with his limited free time, which I must applaud as there's no way I could ever make a game like this.

Overall, do I say this is worth it after all that criticism? Yes, I do. It's a fun game to design and create in and I've spent many hours as you can tell making tanks, planes, cars, buildings and set pieces. It's a very versatile game which you can spend hours in making anything from a humble hatchback to a massive aircraft carrier. It embodies the LEGO freedom we all wanted as a kid but couldn't get because we didn't have the right bricks. Let your imagination run free and stay away from this discussion page!

Posted: March 30, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Brick Rigs
It's every little kid's dream to be able to drive their LEGO or Megabloks creation. Well, now you can!

This game is way to nice to look at than it should be, the Unreal engine gives it a lot of depth and the lighting effects are fantastic.
Much liking having a bucket of LEGOs, you have an unlimited access to blocks of almost any variety to build what ever you want, as long as you have the patience.
When I finally sat down and started in the builder instead of drivinbg one of the many Workshop cars, I found it relativly easy to use. All the nessesary control and colour changes are there as well as an easy menu. It may be a bit tedious, but it's easy, so you can easliy get used to it.

I started doing builds and uploading them to the workshop. I now have had several vehicles top the Workshop boards, proving that even I can build great things!


Now, there are a few issues.
For one, the physics are kinda odd. Things don't like to stop or turn. Or go in a perfect straight line for that matter, either.
You will lag out later on if you start using large vehicles, so watch your brick count or stay in single player!


Bottom line?
RECCOMENDED
LOVE IT

Posted: September 10, 2021
Purchased this game on the launch day, i have been playing daily since then.

What i like:
> Nice buses to drive and quite many and various brands

> Multiplayer mode

> Freedom to choose where and what time u wish to drive

> NPCs actually overtake if you are parked on the side of the road (Bus stop or any road)

> Route planning actually has some challenge as there is an need to plan the route based on demands and peak times. you will also need to schedule the right buses for those routes.

Eg. for the city "Oakwood" ideally you will want small electric buses instead of gigantic buses as this will help move your profit higher. (50k vs 150k). Also there is types of route.

Problems i faced:
> Weather (Really kinda upset by the weather, it always just rains or not)

> NPC dialogues. Once you played couple of hours like, u will realize that the NPCs keeps saying the same all sentences and it gets kinda annoying after awhile

> Multiplayer mode can't chat meaning if you are playing with strangers, you guys kinda just start honking at each other. Morse code huh lol

> Still pretty buggy.
- AI's walking off the bridge in oakwood and landing on the road below the bridge
- Player & NPC missing umbrellas when alighting from bus
- Wheelchair NPC's Umbrella kind of glitched and broken
- NPC's arms sticking out of bus sometimes when they do "actions"
- Random little bump into a sedan at 15km/h causes the car to fly away ( just lolx )

> AI bus drivers just stop moving at bus stops to wait till their "Supposed" time to leave (when their counter reaches 0" This causes u to be late as u cannot let passenger get off or on and even if you manage to, you get smacked by a penalty for "bad parking".

> AI traffic blocking the road when they should proceed to turn right at stop signs or when they have the right of way

Improvements i suggest:

> Fix the above i have mentioned in "problems i faced"

> Implement heavier traffic during peak hours and more variety of cars

> Allow bus stops to have more than 1 bus at the same time (By parking behind them and lined up if the bus stop is long enough)

> As others have said, we could have emergency vehicles to make the environment more realistic

> Add a whether forecast with temperatures and whether it would rain

> Make rain not a "everyday" thing and "variable rain density" (currently it will just rain everyday as i see)

> Hoping to see fully crowded buses during peak hours

> Really wish they add a multiplayer chat (that be really helpful)

> NPCs don't do frequent brake checks on your bus. (I've encountered this multiple times)

Verdict:

I personally don't think it is the right time to buy this game now as they have not fixed alot of stuff and neither is it a big deal breaker from Bus Simulator 2018. Perhaps when they have fixed the issues mentioned, it will be worth buying.

Qn : Am i satisfied or pleased?
Ans: Meh. I'm honestly not but neither is it bad. its just hmmm

Peace out

Posted: September 7, 2021
I am a HUGE fan of the 2018 bus simulator, to me that was PEAK Bus Simulation. The controls were easy to handle the bus felt great to drive and the game was set out nicely!

I waited for hours for the release of this game, to be greeted with a half finished badly controlled game.
- There are issues with the clothes clipping, cars driving through people, cars driving into your character and pushing them down the road and your character clipping into cars which upsets the character's model camera.
-The camera angle is funky the character movement feels off too, Being able to run sideways while trying to run forward doesn't seem to normal.
-Now for the bus controls, the bus turning circle is way too extreme, the bus is so sensitive and i couldn't adjust the seats for the life of me! The driving mechanic feels so messy and the HUD for the controls is unorganised and at times nonexistent.
-There are cars on the road which don't follow road rules, they will drive out in-front of your bus and at times drive right through people walking on the street.
-NPC's will stand on the side of the road and with no warning will sprint onto the road in-front of your bus which will cause you to collide with them.


If a system isn't broken it shouldn't need to be fixed, if this game had the controls of bus simulator 2018 it would've been a lot more enjoyable, i'm not even going to try and give it a chance as i don't want to play this game for more then 2 hours as i will be refunding it.

NEW POST as of JUNE 2023

This game has improved significantly, especially with the recent map expansion, as I said in some of of my earlier comments my two young sons enjoyed this game EVEN with all its previous flaws, however it got to the point that even they lost interest until......this year, we've ALL come back to the game, it's becoming quite enjoyable, the devs are paying attention to the players and I thank Tamara (DEV) for the feedback given to my earlier review. You can read Tamara's post in terms of the most pressing issues addressed, and a LOT of them HAVE addressed, that being said however, their are still SOME glitches, such as passengers clipping thru roofs when standing up, the wheels on the bus don't go round and round, meh! I'm not going to nit pick too much as these things don't kill the game or spoil enjoyment too much, there has been great improvement, for me one of the most profound high points of the game is the shear customization features (why is there a red wavy line under customization? damn this British keyboard!)
Anyhoo....bonus on the improvements, and as long as those creases stay ironed out, things are finally looking up for Bus Sim 21 nxt stop....ergo.....I recommend, I really do!



OLD REVIEW FROM 2022 BELOW (to be removed in due course)

I can't recommend this to anyone at the moment because there are WAY TOO MANY issues that I, and other players are experiencing. NPC (Non Player Characters) issues are exhaustive and they appear to have a death wish which is ALL TOO contagious!

- Drivers frequently crashing buses into stationary objects and scenery for no apparent reason.
- Pedestrians Jay walking on highways and byways OR taking a stroll along the medians that divide them.
- NPC drivers have glitchy, jittery arm movements on the steering wheel, as if they're having some kind of seizure.
- Larger buses and double "deckers" constantly get stuck on corners, as the curves in the road are way too unrealistically sharp and tight.
- NPC Driven buses DO NOT stick to established bus routes, constantly and randomly changing direction and missing out bus stops all together.
- NPC buses stop at bus stops but don't let passengers off.
- Passengers heads and bodies clip thru vehicle bodies and roofs
- When it rains passengers are holding unfurled umbrellas INSIDE buses, which clip thru the walls of buses,
Similarly, when it rains, some pedestrians are holding their arms out as if holding an umbrella, but they're empty handed.
- NPC Buses stop at bus stops for FAR TOO LONG causing long lines of buses to gather up behind them.
- NPC Buses tend to stop for too long at junctions when there is no traffic, this also applies to other NPC traffic.
- NPC traffic appear to be unsure of whom has right of way at junctions and on/off ramps.
- Pedestrians are constantly stepping out in front of buses and traffic and paying no attention to the roads at all, this especially causes problems when driving yourself as colliding with a pedestrian incurs a costly penalty.
- NPC drivers don't appear to obey traffic lights, or pedestrian crossing lights.
- Pedestrians don't appear to observe or obey the "walk / don't walk" lights at cross walks.
- Crosswalks are often located in the most dire locations, such as right in front of a bus stop or even in some cases, right OVER a bus stop, yes you heard correctly, an actual crossing THRU a bus stop, GREAT civic management!
- Buses spawn out of thin air, in a stationary position even in the middle of highways.
- People drop thru bridges onto the streets below, or do a "Mary Poppins" and suddenly take off and fly thru the air. (this looks especially freaky when they're holding umbrellas) DEVS will you please fix this won't you? spit spot!
- On the town map, the detail is messy, confusing and unclear, with bus route colors too similar to other routes, making it impossible to clearly highlight a single route.
- When you customize your buses inside the paint shed, the lighting is poor and the shading is bad depending on the model of bus you're customizing, and decals are sometimes glitchy or broken.
- The route planner / designer is appallingly bad, way too basic and unworkable. You get a choice of "loop OR ping pong"
- There is NO way to change the weather, when it rains (and it rains VERY often) the visibility is atrocious.
- Bus stops are all "road side" meaning they stop ON the road as opposed to pulling into a "bay lane" this causes an incredible blockage of traffic.
- Buses will wait an insurmountable length of time letting cars and trucks past them instead of pulling out when there is right of way, and they have an annoying habit of slowing down and stopping for no reason.
- The lanes and markings on the roads and junctions are inconsistent and unclear and at times completely devoid of markings, lines, lanes or signage, leaving you unsure of where you're supposed to be.
- There are often invisible obstacles on the roads or streets leading to unavoidable collisions.
- Bus stops are often too close together, and the world maps too small to operate large fleets. Journeys are way too short by distance, but too long time wise as buses stay too long at each stop.
- At present the so called "bus station" is nothing more than a glorified bus stop with only 2 stops. (I don't bother using it as buses tend to "back up" and / or get stuck on curve when entering or leaving the bus station (especially double deckers)
- The game frequently freezes (not crashes thankfully, at least not for me elseways) and sticks, the game becomes stuttery and "janky" especially when entering a high "spawn in" area of the map (despite my having a high 'spec' computer)
- Pedestrians appear to walk as if in VERY slow motion, and what's with some of the people walking in quick but tiny "pin steps"? it takes them forever and an age to cross the 'dang' road! it's sooo annoying.

This list could go on forever, but I won't! For MOST of these "issues" fixes via regular updates SHOULD take care of the problem, but at this rate I don't think the DEVS (Developers) will EVER solve all the problems, it's disappointing and it makes the game damn well 'unplayable' and spoils the fun.
Is this what game designers do now? Create and sell a 'BROKEN' game to people for no small amount of dosh and then spend forever fixing it on the fly? For GOD's sake DEVS, GET your act together!
THIS JUST WON'T DO!
The last update they sent out has actually made things WORSE, now ALL my NPC buses are chock full of people STUCK in closed doors and arms, legs and heads sticking out of the bus.

Game is pretty good, but this game had lots of issues with bugs. Bugs luckily were fixed at "Next Stop" update.

-> Game is good for players which likes buses but I still think even after huge update game still missing some things. I wouldn't say it's down grade from 18 ANYMORE by "Next Stop" -Update, but still the game needs lots of optimizations. Game has lots of potential but game needs still content and few features.

Posted: October 21, 2021
EDIT - updated review with Next Stop DLC

I'm glad to say a lot of the issues I had with the game have been addressed and I like the new extension. The buses appearing from thin air is still there and double deckers still get stuck in certain place. I am glad the they have got this into a playable state now but feel this is where the game should have been at release. Still I do enjoy the game now and hopefully more new areas will be added in the future.

So sad to have to leave a negative review but overall Bus Sim 21 is a major let down.
First the good points, the buses look great and are enjoyable to drive. Day to night cycle and weather is a nice addition.

However there are glaring bugs that ruin the experience for me. Firstly AI buses magically appear out of thin air on the map. You can see one is near you on the mini map then there's a flash and it appears stationary. It's so pathetic and this is 2021, I have a decent PC, why has the game been designed like this? It totally ruins the immersion for me.
The destination boards can't be edited like they could in BS 18, why has this been removed? Even the destination is wrong as it shows the next to last stop on the route.
The transit terminal is a waste of space, it's a huge building yet you can only use 2 bays. It's meant to be a central hub for god's sakes yet it's merely a glorified bus stop.

The map itself is too small and badly designed. You could literally drive from one end to the other in about 3 minutes. Im hoping there's going to be a substantial expansion at some point.

AI traffic waits at junctions too long and let's pedestrians cross all the time causing traffic to back up and make you late. AI buses block bus stops and stay too long meaning you can't drop off or pick up passengers causing you to be late and end up being out of hours.

Traffic lights turn green almost straight away, cars ignore red lights, there's no road markings at junctions so this causes confusion and tail backs.

Pedestrians still fall through bridges and this is nearly 2 months after release.

The liveries and decals are rubbish. The wraps look like they were made by a 3 year old and are awful and garish. Where's the custom liveries like in BS 18? Again this has been removed.

Buses getting stuck when negotiating corners. This happens frequently especially with the double deckers and causes traffic to back up.

So there you have it, a game I was so looking forward to and it's a major let down. I can't recommend it in this state and I wonder why they even released it like this.

I may revisit my review if the major issues I've highlighted are ever fixed but I doubt they will be.

So for now I'm steering clear of this game and suggest you do too

Posted: May 18, 2022
Last updated: 27/10/2023

Props to the developers for continuing to update the game, the pace of updates has been slow sometimes but currently, despite the remaining - and some longstanding - glitches - it is an enjoyable game, especially with the school bus DLC and free map extension with more rural style areas, plus the Tram DLC and spin-off game to look forward to (making the Season Pass quite good value.)

Recent updates (since Next Stop):

- AI traffic has improved. They will now sound their horn back at you sometimes, and are more confident in overtaking you.
- The timetable has improved. You no longer have 3 mins between stops that are next to each other, and it is now more challenging to be on time - you can though, add time back in if you need it, but you will make less money.
- Some bendy buses back ends' seem to move when stationary and kneeling - that was also the case before the update.
- Some buses still have functional glitches, such as the diesel Grande West having broken windscreen wiper animations.
- The devs have listened and have tripled the number of usable stands at the Transit Terminal from 2 to 6, reducing congestion and making it look more like a proper bus station.
- The bus limit has been raised from 100 to 180, though note more buses = reduced FPS, especially when they all spawn nearby, so take care with this on low end PCs.

This means there is only ONE issue left from my original review: reused sounds. Most of the buses do not sound like they would in real life - they fixed it with the eCitaro, why not any other buses? The Enviros' especially are desperate for new sounds.

Current bugs:
- Most issues with AI has been fixed but some erratic behaviour remains - mainly with pedestrians running into buses or getting stuck in some locations
- School buses, as well as routes that peak at night, continue to run and stand at bus stops outside the times they should
- Some rain textures have been fixed but the wiping animation on some buses is not smooth, and is non-existent on others (the rain texture on the glass is just toggled instead)
- The increase in AI buses causes performance to drop significantly (previously around 60FPS, now 30-40. A large number of buses on screen at once causes stuttering on weaker hardware when graphics are high.)

Updated conclusion:
The graphical style, though slightly unrealistic is good enough to have you believe you are driving in a real My game is set to very high and performance is good in most areas with the exception of areas with a high AI bus density and busy ENVIROments. (sorry).
The fact you can just jump on a bus, check tickets and take over is really nice, and it is really pleasant to see your buses roaming around with passengers on.
The "story" is nice, although gets slightly repetitive near the end, I now enjoy just adapting my own routes and driving around.
And the buses themselves - there is a nice variety. The electric buses as well as the double-decker Enviro 500 are enjoyable to drive despite the reused Setra sounds on many buses. And the models are really detailed, the team responsible for those are amazing.

I think naming it Bus "Simulator" is probably backfiring slightly as those in the extreme simulation community (rightfully, to an extent) detest this game. If you see it as a Bus Game, with a balance between management and simulation, you will enjoy it far more.


Buy this if:
- It is not full price/you find it elsewhere at a discount
- You like route and timetable planning
- You enjoy company management
- You like customising buses
- Enjoy driving and are not overly concerned with accuracy of physics (they are not terrible, just more arcade like)
- You enjoy completing mini challenges and career progression (though a sandbox mode is available if not)

Avoid it if:
- You can't live with any bugs.
- You want a simulator with an emphasis on pure realism (especially sounds and physics) - check out The Bus, but loose economy or career features, and no AI buses, or OMSI, but get outdated graphics, expensive DLC, and numerous bugs if you can even get that ancient piece of software to run.
- You do not like cats, Winter of Passion, or Spring of Affection. Summer of Love coming soon to Disney-.

Final rating: 8/10

CPU: Ryzen 7 4800H
RAM: 2x8GB @3200MHz
Storage: Samsung SSD

Posted: November 27, 2021
First, in general, this game is a really nice game to play.
Yet only in singleplayer, as the multi has too much bugs to be enjoyable. But bugs are a thing that we already know from Astragon and they'll get fixed some time in the future - we all know that.

General:
- I played in the closed Beta and the game has improved massively since then, just saying :)

Positives:
+ huge Map with much details - old Map (from BS2018) is playable too
+ new busses, some more recent, electro and cng but also the good old Citaros :) (and the Alexander Denis')
+ Open World Experience, theres no menu where you have to start from once you load into the game, you can start missions and routes while standing at a bus stop yourself and attend ur busses or smth
+ driving physics seem to be quite accurate, wheel support is good (controller aint I suppose)
+ Improved lightning and dynamic weather (compared to BS18 this is a huge upgrade, you had to start with ur desired weather and it stayed like that for the whole route)
+ "Reallife" Time - 1min ingame = 1min irl, you can skip time (so you dont have to wait half an hour for the next bus^^)
+ different land schemes and just the nice graphics from UE4 (or 5? xD) upgrade the game


Negatives:
- first the negatives are always the ones that get pointed out better than the positives, some of these listed below are just minor improvements that could be made but there are some major issues (in my opinion) too:

- AI: As was the case before, the AI is just bad. Of course it is difficult to get a AI working realistically, especially in complexe Traffic Scenarios, but in some situations, they just seemed to be ahead of themselves. They run over the street without any crosswalk or sign of recognizing the bus. The pathfinding under bridges is horrible - as has been the case in the beta in mid July (!!). And thats just the pedestrians, the AI Cars also seem to be pretty shy when it comes to priority on crossings: Ex.: You want to turn left onto a prioritized route with the cars on that travalling straight on - if you use ur left indicator they will just stop and not move anymore until you turn them off or turn - if you dont approach with indicator lights on they'll just ignore you and drive into you.

- "Main Station": Massive Downgrade from the 18s, there seemed to be a problem with the AI Busses picking the right of the 6 visual lanes pre-beta which led to them only opening 2 lanes. A Main Station with 2 Lanes? Like come on, even BS18 had 6.
- Graphics on rain (tho FPS are really stable, just the visuals suck especially on the main window) UPDATE: they patched so that the rain drops are actually visible on the main window until you turn on the wiper.
- Bus Stops: The Bus Stop signs are really close to the street - if you want to deliver ur passengers as closely to the sidewalk on Stops as possible, you have to avoid the signs which leads to not being able to close in realistically. Also the park position is kinda random, cant tell when it is perfect (for the game) and when just good etc... AI Busses stopping on Bus Stops are just 2 metres in the street when they spawn (passengers have to cross 2 metres to the sidewalk idk)
- Bus Spawning in general sucks: On the max visible range (setting) the AI Busses will spawn with lightning and in visual range, so there isnt a clean transition and they always spawn not moving (even in the middle of nowhere)

(these are the main issues I have while playing, they arent game breaking, but just thinks that make the experience much less enjoyable at least for me)


Fazit:
I like the game. Its great to chill, simulate bus driving but once you jump into multiplayer or try taking it a bit too realistic it gets annoying. Some ♥♥♥♥ just doesnt work the intended way, and the devs seem to get slower. Pre-launch and the first few weeks, the communication between Community and Devs was great but the discord is getting more quiet recently. So the game is great as long as you can see all the positives of being able to drive a functional bus etc. and just ignore bugs or make fun of it! I do recommend buying it still, just dont expect a perfect game - it is none.

Posted: May 7
This is not a simulator, it's a sandbox game with buses.

But even if you take the name forging away and take it for what it is, what the game is is still trash. I'm talking bugs, tons of bugs, so many bugs that I'm convinced the game has no testing team. I've only played this for around 6 hours and I've already encountered a lot of weird stuff. Wouldn't be so bad if you wouldn't be much affected by it, but because the way the game deducts you XP points and money for everything, most of the bugs end up punishing you. There's the smaller bugs like the game taking XP from you for driving against a one-way road or telling you you missed a stop, or you didn't let a passenger off even though you were standing at a stop with the doors open at the time. I've even had some people standing in the bus bay forcing me to a "bad stopping position" because I didn't run them over. These things are annoying and slowing down your progress. But the way worse bugs are like invisible objects and invisible pedestrians. Considering that running over a pedestrian instantly cost you 20 grand, if you get this early in the game like I did, it significantly pushes your progress back.

It's almost like the game doesn't want to be played, so it keeps putting you off until you surrender. But I'm going to play my money's worth out of it regardless, I ain't no quitter.

Posted: December 29, 2021
EDIT #4 May 19th 2023:

So it has been a long time since I updated this. I was waiting for a major update to release.

I am now changing my recommendation to Yes.

All bugs that I have previously mentioned have been fixed.
They released a huge FREE update. I have to hand it to them for making the update free. It comes with a big map extension that would be DLC in other games.
It took them some time but they finally did it.

You can also play an extra mode that allows you to play the story and you can have everything unlocked. Or play Sandbox or Career and earn money to purchase more buses.

They also will release some cool DLC, like School Buses and driving a Tram.

So yeah buy this :)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

EDIT No3. July 11th 2022:

I am close to changing my review to a positive one, but some issues still remain.

The good:

They have added new voice lines for the passengers.
The AI buses spawn in sooner as to not spawn on top of you.
Pedestrians no longer fall through bridges.

The bad:

It still takes stuck AI traffic 2 minutes to de-spawn. That's quite a delay to your schedule.
A new bug appeared with the 2nd last patch where passengers got stuck in the doorway of a full bus. The last patch aimed to fix that, but what it does is, when the bus is full and passengers want to get on, some other passengers then get off. But this takes time and creates a delay.

Once the passenger issue is fixed fully I will then change my review to positive.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:

With almost 100 hours in the game I still cannot recommend it.

It was released with too many bugs and issues. Some bugs have been fixed but some bugs I am not sure that will be fixed due to the nature of them.

Coming from Bus Simulator 18 I had big hopes for this version as the devs were boasting about improved features. It has a great new map but it let down by the issues.

AI: We were promised improved AI but it seems to be just as bad. The AI will sit there waiting to turn when it has plenty of time but just sits there. But the AI has no problem turning into you when you have the right of way.

AI Passengers: Many of the passengers phrases have been recycled from Bus Sim 18. That's just being pure lazy.

Weather: It has dynamic weather which is great but you are unable to choose what weather you want to drive in. You can only fast forward time.

Map: New map, lovely map with many feature, from city center to the sea view. But in some parts of the map some buses become stuck when coming to a steep hill. Forcing you to reset the bus and drive very fast to ensure you do not get stuck. The new map has a bus depot but it not utilized fully. Why build a great feature that you can only use a quarter of it?

Bugs: The current bugs that I see are buses spawning on the map out of thin air and people falling through bridges onto the road below it.

Keys were sent out to playtesters but many bugs stayed on release, why? Is this the norm now, we buy broken games and just wait for bug fixes?

I enjoy the game but it frustrates me. If you own Bus Sim 18 then stick with that for the time being. As I said I enjoy the game but it's not fun when you get angry at it.

Posted: August 1, 2022
Review of the game (no bias) EN + RU text

EN:
I recommend this game to anyone that likes simulators and ready to wait for updates. I will present a list of pros and cons. I don't really understand why this game gets Mixed reviews
Pros:
+ A ton of content. (I think for about 40+ hours). I am playing this game for 6 hours already in one of two locations that you can choose. With all the missions taken I've opened about 30% of the map (bought bus stops and unlocked the parts of the map). Storyline is interesting and doesn't lack mission variety.
+ Graphics. In comparison to 18th part of the game it has better graphics, better antialiasing and look in general.
+ Missions. Instead of the system "buy and own more, get more levels to unlock more things to buy" you get a progression based on tasks and unlocks that make sense. (Example: missions before unlocking the island with tourist attractions you need to put ads (banners) on your buses to promote that island. Game characters say that is for your business' sake, but this action actually unlocks new story character with extra missions on the island based on your decision to promote it)
+ Customization. Game provides a good variety of buses. About tuning: you can change buses' color, decals, custom ones (you can put figures and stuff on the bus to make a pattern) and interior coloring


-
- Bugs (minor ones). As another game of Astragon you should expect bugs. However, Astragon is also a company that doesn't leave the game after the release and they fix all the major bugs frequently. Half of the bugs that I had were fixed within a week and some of them even hours after discovering them. The bug that is annoying now is that auto-disable of blinkers really sucks. They can be automatically disable too fast and you can get a fine because of them (here you can turn on red light if you are going not straight, but turning off blinkers gives you a fine, because game thinks that you've driven straight)

RU:
Рекомендую игру для покупки, если вы один из тех, кто любит симуляторы и готовы ждать обновы. Плюсы и минусы сейчас объясню. Не совсем понимаю отзывов этой игры.

+ В игре море контента (по моим подсчетам на часов так 40+). Играю шестой час в карьеру в одной из двух локаций. С учетом прогрессии я открыл и обустроил примерно 30% карты. Прокачка интересна и разнообразна.
+ Графика. По сравнению с 18-ой частью - графика получше. Лучше сглаживание и картинка в целом.
+ Миссии. Вместо системы "покупай, затем открывай новое, чтобы купить" у вас будет система квестов и наград, которые имеют смысл и взаимосвязаны. (Пример: перед разблокировкой острова с туристическими аттракционами у вас будет миссия заехать в покрасочную и нацепить рекламу этого острова и его достопримечательностей, что кроме прибыли за рекламу разблокирует вам и остров, так как на вас выйдет персонаж с этого острова, который продолжит линейку квестов)
+ Кастомизация. Выбор автобусов хороший. Из настроек: цвет, раскраски (декали), реклама, раскраска салона и свои фигуры (сами расставляем)
+ Хорошая русификация, однако войс на английском, субтитры норм качества


-
- Баги. (несущественные). Играя в игру от Астрагонов вы должны ожидать от нее багов. Но и по той же причине, что игра от них вы и можете ожидать то, что баги фиксят, а игру не бросают. Большинство багов, что я встречал, были пофикшены уже через неделю или даже считанные часы после их обнаружения. Из тех багов, что сейчас есть - поворотники, а именно система их автоматического выключения и он меня бесит. Они часто выключаются слишком рано. По ПДД этой игры можно поворачивать на красный при условии, что вы именно поворачиваете, а не едете прямо, но из-за того, что баг выключает поворотник, то игра наказывает вас штрафом, думая, что вы ехали на красный, хоть вы и соблюдаете ПДД

PS.
EN: I like this game. I was hesitant at first because of the Mixed reviews. However, when I've bought it I enjoyed my experience.
RU: Мне нравится эта игра. Я сначала не собирался ее покупать из-за смешанных отзывов. Однако, когда я ее все же купил, то мне понравилось

Posted: March 11
This is a really good game. It's fun, it's relaxing, and it's enjoyable, which is pretty much what you want from a game. OK, is it challenging? No, not really. There are degrees of difficultly you could set for yourself, but if you just like driving buses, it's up there. And, for what it's worth, I think the European map is more enjoyable than the American one, but you can decide that. They each have their merits. The passengers are equally annoying, whichever map you choose!

YouTubers will tell you, "but this is no 'OMSI'", and they're right. This is no OMSI. And that's not a bad thing. If you want a 32-bit never-to-be-meaningfully-updated-crash-here-and-there-usually-here-AND-there-with-quirks-when-not-crashing bus simulator, stutters thrown in for good measure, and not to mention Dulux-white painted cars (drats be them 32 bits), and have some cash on the hip, get OMSI! If you want a relaxing game to play, instead of a course in bus-engineering, get Bus Simulator 21.

I do have a couple of complaints with this game, though. Foremost is its handling of TrackIR, of which its handling of is rubbish. If you've ever used TrackIR, you'd understand. Unlike other games (e.g. ETS2, ATS, FS22) which handle it really well (FS22 FTW on that (FS being Farming Simulator, not Flight Simulator!)), BS21 (BS being Bus Simulator, not the other thing) handles it really badly. There's no obvious way (if any) to reset or pause it. I've crashed many a bus while trying to get TrackIR where it needs to be, wiggling my headphones around like a crazy person. Game's fault, not TrackIR's fault (because TrackIR is brilliant).

My second complaint is about braking. I've fiddled with the settings, but for love nor money can I get a bus to stop by pressing the brake pedal like a normal person would (full disclosure, I'm using the Logitech G923, where the brake pedal is dodgy at best, but works fine in other games (the pedals are accompanied by a rather fine steering wheel, no complaints in that department)). You have to kind of pump them like you're a drummer in a rock band. It's a quirk, you get used to it, but somewhat annoying. It rather detracts from the natural experience of accidentally hitting lampposts or other objects of interest.

As an aside, if you play games (where TrackIR is supported) and you move your "head" using the mouse or keyboard, you need to get TrackIR. Without this sounding like a sponsored Ad, once you've used it, you'll never not want to not not use it. If my washing machine broke tomorrow and my TrackIR broke tomorrow, I'd get another TrackIR. I still have a sink, after all.

Diversion aside. Good game.

That's my considered opinion. Take it or leave it!

Posted: June 27
I know every version of this game from other years, and I'm sorry to see it descend towards total simplicity and kitsch. Setting the realistic mode still misses the realism and the game is completely arcade. Let's start with the negatives that will keep me from recommending the game...

MAPS:
- wide and repetitive streets,
- predetermined stops,
- different stops for tram and bus,
- repeatability of the map construction scheme that these are districts from A to Z,
- no random events, e.g. an accident or road repair,
- by force, without any changes in the road layout, tram rails were inserted, in addition, without the required supply traction,
- signaling adapted to the bus despite the lack of detectors or the ITS system, it just changes "for me",
- always the same obstacles, e.g. holes on the road or speed bumps, but no usual unevenness on the roads, which are not obstacles for the bus to "feel the road" a bit,
- lack of diversification of the map with rich/poor places, lack of creating a city (one decent city) and neighborhoods, not districts located from each other by the distance of a bridge, tunnel or suburban road,
- the WORST thing about the maps is the island, I haven't seen such a tragic performance of roads, objects, paths, vegetation (also in asphalt) for a long time.

UI:
- buying buses, switching between them or modifying them to be identical to the previous ones... it's nasty, unintuitive, confusing,
- too many hints, too many.

AI:
- too much favor of cars towards the bus, especially at intersections, it is a real extortion by the bus if it happened,
- waving waiting people at the bus stop? Even on request, this is not done in the direction of the bus
- the WORST thing about AI is asking you to stop mid-ride to release a passenger... it's actually illegal to do that outside of a stop.

THE REMAINING:
- poor driving physics,
- and no influence of the weather on driving,
- candy game graphics,
- selling tickets or passengers like to hang up,
- strange parameters of some buses (the smaller one has more seats...),
- no variety of passengers, only healthy and adult people or only on wheelchair, no passengers running to the bus, no drunk passengers,, no prams with a baby,
- no boards with timetables at stops (upper levels),
- no option to modify buses with additional things, such as LED boards, ticket machines, better seats, wi-fi, air conditioning, etc.
- no possibility to use the line setting as a loop so that people constantly exchange and not as a "last stop" and suddenly they get off and there are no new ones,
- a lot of good things from previous parts have been taken away in favor of bizarre ideas, either the creators drive cars or they are not even interested in buses, no passion.

I am very disappointed.

Posted: May 13
Pros:
- Simple to learn
- Multiplayer
- Decent graphics
- A good amount of buses to choose from
- Manage your own bus lines and fleet
- Devs give a decent amount of updates every year

Cons:
- There are some very annoying bugs occasionally
- Some very cringe worthy one liners are being said by NPC's
- All buses sound and feel the same
- No Steam Workshop integration, Mods.io is there but is less attractive

Conclusion:

If you're looking for a true simulator, this is not it. OMSI2 or The Bus is maybe more what you're looking for. But if you're looking for a more relaxing and simple gaming experience, this is the game for you. Although there are some very annoying bugs, I think the amount of content that's available outweighs those bugs. The developers also keep expanding on the game and are providing good free content. The DLC's are decent, I would however recommend you only buy the bus packs and not the interior packs. There are mods available for good interiors through the integrated Mods.io platform. It's a shame they didn't use Steam Workshop though as a lot of people playing this game don't want to make mods for the Mods.io platform.

You can also play this game with friends and it is really enjoyable. You don't constantly have to sit behind a steering wheel, you can also just go out of your cabine and walk through the bus like an actual person. You can also throw some ticket inspections so passengers don't get to travel without paying.

And the roadmap last of all for this game is great. They are releasing a huge update very soon, expanding the map. They will also add very cool DLC in the future like School Buses and Trams.

Posted: September 17, 2021
Product received for free

Bus Simulator 21
A fun and addictive bus simulator, in an impressive environment, with a lot of replay value. There are some noticeable glitches and anomalies but they don’t mar the overall experience.

Bus Simulator 21 is the third PC installment of the franchise developed by Stillalive studios and published by Astragon entertainment.

This version of the simulator builds on Bus Simulator 18 with thirty licensed buses to drive adding Volvo, Alexander Dennis, Scania, BYD, Grande West, and Blue Bird to the list.

You can now drive a double decker bus and e-buses on the two extensive maps located in the US or Europe in either single player or co-operative multiplayer, along with managing your fleet and organizing timetables.

Gameplay Video
YouTube™ Video: Bus Sim 21 PC Gameplay 
Views: 137





There are four different difficulty levels with various features you can choose such as speeding fines, speed bumps and speed limiters; pot holes; disability ramp access; automatic kneeling and ticket collection, along with various assists to steering, breaking and acceleration. There are a number of ways you can tailor the game to match your wishes.

The environments were incredibly detailed and lively. I didn’t really appreciate how intricate they were until I started running around for the collectibles, which were fun and challenging to hunt. The maps are very large but somehow, they have managed to add so much variety to the different locales, each having their own personalities and character. I was forever stopping to admire the view and appreciate the different sounds. The character movements were a little odd at times, some moving slow like they had soiled themselves, and taking an eternity to walk over crossings! There are some comical moments with graphical glitches and bizarre physics, usually involving accidents. These only happened very occasionally however.

The traffic AI was reasonably good I thought. Automobiles drove around as expected in the main, although there were occasions when cars would take an absolute age to make turns.

Driving the different kinds of buses was fun. I preferred playing in third person view with the bus showing as I drove, although with larger buses it was difficult to see whether your indicators were flashing or not, which resulted in some accidents. I had to turn off the NPC voices as they were amusing at first but then got annoying, especially when trying to concentrate on planning routes. It is quite easy to build up time and if you go over three minutes ahead you need to stop and wait a while or else it is considered “out of hours”.

There is a basic tutorial which provides a quick rundown of how to operate the bus but the management side of things is hardly explained at all. The campaign mode does act as a type of tutorial but often it left me asking questions on the Discord channel to fill in the gaps. The tutorials need a bit of work, and if you are a newcomer to the series, it can leave you frustrated trying to manage your fleet, organize routes and time tables. Once I got the grasp of things though I started to enjoy the game more and it became very enjoyable.



You can customize your character with the usual attire and looks, and even wear a proper uniform.

The sandbox mode lets you operate in any area with any bus. Everything is unlocked for you to play with. You can customize your bus with various decals and ride buses which would normally take you hours to unlock.

The multiplayer mode means you can set up with three other friends or players online, and work co-operatively to run your business. Set up some routes and have your friends drive the bus or ride the bus with them acting as conductor. I had no issues with connection or finding a game to join. It was quite fun but I’d imagine it would rely on people being sensible as crashing the bus would cost the owner money in repairs.

Some of the collectibles were extremely hard to find but I had a lot of fun doing so. Collectibles resemble a luminous green bus. There are twenty to find on each map along with a couple of SAM statues and even a haunted house.

The main game is campaign or mission based where you follow a story of sorts which teaches you how to run your business. You will need to learn how to set up routes to meet certain criteria set out for you. For example, you may need to connect three districts in a balanced route, or upgrade a district to level two. Each bus stop has a level and by using that stop you gain experience points. Earn enough experience points and you can upgrade the stop. Upgrade all stops in that district to raise the district level. Each stop either weighs in favor of passengers departing or entering at that stop, denoted by a blue or purple color. To balance the route, you would need to have an equal number of blue and purple stops.

There is some strategy involved in the game. It’s not all about driving buses. The route planning can be quite technical with day and night cycles, peak times, and planning efficient routes. Some of the missions can be quite time consuming and there are thirty or more on each map.

Positive marks are rewarded for good driving, like using your indicators correctly, and reaching stops on time, and negative marks are given for accidents, improper use of indicators and speeding, for example. Each stops earns you XP until you reach a new level which earns you a pay day. Money can be used to buy new buses, and to help with business costs.
Gradually you will have a few buses running different routes you set up, all collecting money for you to buy more expensive buses i.e., electric or CNG.

The bus can be operated in first or third-person view. The seat can be adjusted and regular controls are mapped to your gamepad and the rest selected by using a wheel. There are various distractions for you to deal with like issuing tickets, waking up sleeping passengers, warning commuters who are listening to loud music, asking them to unblock entrances and asking for their tickets. All these options can be adjusted or turned off however.

The driving can be as realistic as you wish and weight and inertia plays a part. Once you get used to it, the driving feels satisfying.



I was incredibly impressed by how much detail and variety went into the environments. Just little things like inflatables in the swimming pool or packets of crisps in the news stand all made it feel so real. It was a pleasure to explore.

The buses looked nice and the interiors looked realistic.

There are some noticeable repetitions especially in character’s faces which could be improved.

I loved the bus sounds. They sounded very realistic and soothing.

I was particularly impressed with environmental sounds like cranes and boats near the docks and birds singing in the parks. It made the area come alive.

there is a lot of stuff that needs fixing, tweaking and straight up changing that will probably never be done.
