Posted: September 13
Two years on from its release and many updates later, this game is still riddled with bugs and problems which make it an incredibly frustrating experience overall. Some of the updates have actually made things worse instead of better, which is such a shame because this could and should have been a great game.

The positives: the collection of buses is diverse and a huge step up from Bus Sim 18. There are the brilliantly speedy electric buses which are a pleasure to drive and, at long last, a double decker is included (but only one). The base game's total of 31 buses has gradually increased to nearly 50 with various DLC packs, an enormous improvement. Customisation of buses is also better with many more wraps and decals to select, although I would have liked a livery designer. The biggest improvement of all lies in the open-world nature of the game instead of returning to the menus after each drive, along with a 24-hour cycle. This is a superb innovation and makes the game far more immersive.

However, if the developers stepped up their game in some areas, they let things slide badly in others. In trying to cram a host of new features into the game, they forgot the most important element: the driving. Bus Sim 21 is simply nowhere near as good as Bus Sim 18 in a number of ways when it comes to driving the buses. The main problems are the terrible AI of both cars and pedestrians, unrealistic steering, the lack of comprehensive wheel support and a weak new map. Disabled passengers don't make it clear when they wish to alight, meaning you fail to put the ramp down and get penalised for 'skipping a stop'. Lost valuables are often impossible to retrieve due to the awful 'use this seat' function which also makes ticket checks a right pain.

The AI is appalling and has been since day one. Traffic crashes into your bus on a regular basis whilst attempting dangerous overtakes and naturally you are the one fined each time this happens. I've also lost count of the number of cars that have pulled out in front of me at junctions. The pedestrians are an abomination, from the fact some look like they are walking through treacle to the hilariously bad 'totter' animation of the old ladies. Much worse, however, is their behaviour on crossings: they think nothing of stepping out and running into the side of your bus. It happens time and time again and is maddening. More than once the developers have claimed this issue has been fixed but arguably it has got worse.

Passenger dialogue is another major disappointment. Using largely the same voice actors is bad enough, but to include all the already incredibly tired one-liners from Bus Sim 18 is unforgivable. If you've played that game, you'll know the most annoying lines: 'Marbles', 'Gruyere' and the Beethoven 'joke' - and they're all here and repeated just as often. The sound balancing of the dialogue is poor, too: the old woman from Bus Sim 18 with possibly the most irritating voice I've ever heard is much louder than the others whilst some of the new ones are too quiet. I could only stomach a couple of hours of hearing the same old guff together with new annoying lines before this was turned off.

The new map, Angel Shores, is disappointing with its sanitised, Fantasyland interpretation of San Francisco and a collection of tiny, dull, unrealistic streets. It feels small overall and even smaller than its European counterpart, Seaside Valley, also included with the game and much the better of the two. There's nothing wrong with a fictional city setting per se, but how much better would it have been if they had opted for one larger map that actually felt like a real city? Unfortunately, Seaside Valley comes with its old campaign so it is like replaying Bus Sim 18 but with worse AI and many more frustrations.

Another problem since the Next Stop update is a lack of time to actually enjoy driving the routes. They drastically cut the time allowed between stops meaning that unless you drive like a bat out of hell and turn off almost all the random events, you're not going to stay on time on some routes. There have been three updates since Next Stop came out and this has not been addressed.

The last major frustration is with the clunky interface. I've had trouble rebinding keys, setting up routes and changing general settings due to the menus refusing to co-operate at various times. It's a shambles.

If you're interested in a bus driving game then Bus Sim 18 is the one you want. This game is unrefined and far more frustrating to play, which is a massive shame. I'd love to change this review to recommended and will do so should some genuine game-changing updates materialise. The potential for a fantastic bus driving game is there, but now two years since it was released, it doesn't seem likely, does it?

Posted: September 20, 2021
Bus Simulator 2021, a review

I played Bus Sim 18 and loved it, so when I heard that 21 was coming out I was immensely excited and counted down the days to release. Unfortunately, launch didn't appear to go too well, and I was put off buying the game at its hefty £29.99 price tag due to the innumerable negative reviews. However, after a few days of debating myself, I decided to bite the bullet and part with my hard earned cash. What a good choice that was.

The new map, Angel Shores, is quite massive, and I'm generally a fan. The detail is exquisite, the place feels alive, and though I haven't unlocked the entire map yet, I particularly like the suburban sprawl of Greenwood and the gorgeous stretch of road in Cayote Bush. It is quite diverse overall, and the American setting is a nice change from the usual German environment we see in so many simulators. That said, it's not without its faults. There are certain buggy areas (most notably one where pedestrians just fall of a bridge and onto the road in Greenwood), and performance takes a hit in certain regions. I also found the really chunky road markings a bit off-putting at first, though these may be the real Californian markings, so it's probably just personal preference. The colours also feel maybe a bit too vibrant which reduces immersion somewhat. Furthermore, despite not being colour blind and never had any colour vision issues, I find it next to impossible to distinguish traffic light colours, having to rely on the position of the light. These are minor issues though, overall, it's a very nice map to drive in, and really good job Still Alive, it's one of the best I've ever seen in any simulator, they just need to iron it out a bit.

As for the buses, well there's so much variety. The models are all round fantastic, and many of the buses carried over from 18 have been spruced up noticeably (The Urbanway is a work of art!), albeit with the odd exception of the Citaro K. The buses all have their own unique feel to them, they drive differently, and sounds are generally good, though there is a sizeable portion of the same old default sounds from 18 on a few buses, but this is understandable given the year that this was developed in! And the electric buses! They sound really incredible to my unaccustomed ears and that acceleration is quite the game-changer. Possibly my favourite thing about the new buses is that we finally have some decently comfortable interiors, or if not we can change them to that way! Oh, which brings me to the customisation. It's quite a bit better than 18, though I'm not a fan of how hard it is to write text on your bus side, and I long for the return of the toggle to remove wraps from bus windows, I hate it when they cover them. The buses are great, but new sounds for buses that don't have unique ones would be really welcome when the devs can next record them.


- The old map has been touched up a little bit, I enjoyed driving round it in the new buses, and I'll probably replay the story after I finish Angel Shore's
- On the old map you get access to the airport DLC area even if you didn't own it in 18!
- Sadly though, performance is substantially worse than in Bus Sim 18. In 18, I had the graphics set to "High" all round and got a solid, perpetual 75 fps. Now, I have them on Medium-Low and still get 75, but there are frame drops to the low 50s in many parts of the map, American or European.
- I at first found the new steering system really horrible, but you do get used to it after a few hours, it's just different to 18.
- The ai is generally improved, I am a big fan of how it actually now overtakes you when you're at a stop, and on the pedestrian side of things, they actually show some signs of intelligence and wait for you to pass before crossing the road, or hurry up a bit if you're approaching. I'd always try and let them cross of course, but in 18 I found they had no tolerance for high speeds and emergency braking was often necessary, upsetting the passengers.

To conclude, yes I recommend Bus Simulator 21. Is it flawed, yes. Is it worth £29.99, for me yes, but it is a lot of money and I'm sure others may disagree. But if you're sitting on the fence as I was, I'd say go for it, this is a very fun game. The first two hours are not very fun if you're used to 18, and as I hit that 2 hour threshold I had a sleepless night thinking about whether to refund it, but I decided to keep it, and after about 3 hours (I think someone else remarked on this) the game truly does come into its own. Thank you for reading!

Posted: September 7, 2021
So far, so... buggy. This game feels like an early release. Controls are lousy, and the turning radius of some of the buses makes it hard to drive... even though these same models were fine in Bus Sim 18. The AI pedestrians seem very jumpy, to the point where it's kinda entertaining. While the graphics are good, I don't understand why the roads are so wide - the tighter roads of Bus Sim 18 are a nice challenge.

Now let's talk performance... oh my... I was experiencing WILD FPS FLUCTUATIONS. It went from 80FPS to 47 within seconds, with no apparent reason why. I am able to play other games with quite frankly better graphics, with more stable, higher FPS. Even if I lower the resolution, I do still get some occasional stutters. Just bad performance all around, which was initially an issue with Bus Sim 18 as well, so hopefully this will get fixed.

In general there's a lack of polish. The rain animations on the windshield look pixelated and static (water doesn't run down the window as expected), and the cash register interactions are weird; some passengers just don't collect their change. Perhaps they just want to support the new bus system... II don't know. The interface seems unnatural and clunky, and makes Bus Sim 18 seem much more streamlined.

In general, Astragon really should've given this game more time in the oven. I did feel the same way about Bus Sim 18 as well, although it wasn't quite as bad. It's disappointing, because there's so much potential in this game, and it is relatively fun even with the issues. However, I recommend just waiting for the patches to come, or at least, for a sale. This isn't worth $35+ for the time being.

The game has quite a few issues and just isn't worth its money:
- The performance is horrible, even with modern hardware on low settings
- The game is full of bugs and glitches, especially in pathfinding and animation
- The physics are very bad and extremely unrealistic
- Missing translations/localization in a few different situations
- A very annoying tutorial on a laggy map which doesn't seem to be skippable

For a SIMULATOR with such a high price tag I expected more, way more, at the very least from the physics behaviour. But whenever hitting the sidewalk a bit, the bus bounces into the air, clamps to 45 degree max rotation and hits the ground like a falling stone and acts like nothing ever happened. The bus also has instant acceleration and braking in all directions and a very unrealistic behaviour in general.

The performance problems are also worth mentioning. Turning the graphic settings to medium gives about 50-60 FPS with occasional drops to 20-30 on a mobile RTX 3070 (130W) GPU and a well cooled Ryzen 7 5800H CPU. (FullHD resolution, 100% scale, Vsync disabled, NVMe SSD)

The only positive thing is the included multiplayer mode, which sadly has its limitations as well. (Lags, limited to 4 players only, turning your save file permanently into an online session)

The devs might have wanted to use the "Early Access" feature of Steam, the game launched with quite a few game breaking bugs, I had to manually set the launch options to force DirectX 11, I then had to delete all the default controller key bindings just to register my steering wheel and its button mappings.

Then we have the gameplay, I have seen some strange things in my play through, for example it was night time and the game asked me to complete a mission where I drive a route with some advertising, I thought I will drive the bus to the depot (a bus not assigned to any route yet) and then skip time to the early hours of the morning, I saw on the mini-map another bus right where my bus was (but it wasn't showing in the game) I follow its blip on the map where it then randomly spawns and goes crazy (it was a bendy bus) this then hit me like a ball under the world where I then respawned in another random bus, that was "returning to depot" I got a bit confused what went wrong there.

Then we have the fact that when I started playing I played in the reccomended difficulty, I didn't like the way the controls were set out so I decided to modify them a bit, but this made it impossible for me to drive, my bus just wouldn't move at all. I ended up re-loading the game, it asked me to drive route 2, so I went to the bus, stopped at 1 stop and it completed that quest. Easiest quest ever... I have decided that maybe I should start a whole new save, and this second playthrough went without a hitch and where I put all the time.

Is it worth buying right now (near its original launch of September 7th 2021) Probably not unless you are a die hard fan, but give it a few months the devs will have hopefully polished the game up and it will be worth it.

Overall with the bugs and other problems aside, I think it is a fun and great game and I can see it has quite a bit of potential. But I still say that the devs might want to try issuing Early Access next time as a lot of these bugs can be found just by playing for the first few minutes. Sending out promo copies to YouTubers doesn't do anything to help fix the issues, they just want the views on exclusive content.

Most people playing Early Access titles expect there to be bugs and teething troubles, but when you release a game full price, with day 1 DLC with these sort of bugs, expect bad reviews.

Posted: September 8, 2021
Product received for free

First up, this game is fun! I've honestly enjoyed the hours played so far.

That out of the way, this very much feels like an Early Access title. Performance is poor on a 3060Ti at 1080p, which should be virtually impossible. Turning down shadow detail helps.
The English translation needs a lot of work; many words are mis-used, or sounds-close-but-not-actually-right. Plenty of misspellings too.
Bugs and glitches are rampant; from collisions with nothing at all, to AI pathing leading to pointless traffic jams and riders not being able to get on or off the bus, to the Route listing getting confused and doubling up stops or losing track of which stop the bus is on (displaying 4, while the active is 2, but updating to 5 when 3 is reached). Quests not giving progress correctly as requirements are met.
The tutorial alternates between pedantic follow-every-step-exactly-or-else-start-over, and being assigned a goal that has never been touched on, leaving you to fumble around until you figure out what it means and where/how to get it done. Then ends, apparently without touching on most of the more complex elements (or maybe I just haven't triggered the next step of the tutorial yet, I have no idea!).
My favorite is how you can't click on anything in the cockpit if you're using head tracking, without turning your head to point the reticle-dot exactly at the button or switch you want to activate. The mouse pointer is still there the whole time, but it's literally pointless.

This one definitely needs at least another month or two in the cooker with severe QA and bugfixing. Again, IT IS FUN AS-IS, but it'd be a lot more fun without the constant aggravation of the large and glaring rough edges.

Posted: September 12, 2021
After a bit over an hour of playing the game, I must say that it's not bad. But it doesn't mean it's perfect. I really liked Bus SIm 18 and was excited for this one, but skeptical after seeing the reviews.

The game kinda plays the same with a few changes and new features. The American-themed map is nice. It's good to have something different for once instead of always driving on an European-themed map. The selection of buses is very good.

Driving feels ok, FFB works acceptably well. Buses don't feel heavy, they feel a little bit too light in my opinion.
The AI traffic is not the best but it also ain't bad. There have been improvements over Bus Sim 18, like cars passing you when you're stopped at a bus stop. But they also tend to pass you when you're at an intersection with your blinker on, which isn't all that good. They also sometimes (not always) stop in the middle of the street for no reason on some streets.

Passenger AI works, but a few times I've noticed that when many passengers try to board at the same time, they get stuck at the door so you have to close the door, pull forward and open the door again to fix this.

I was unable to finish the tutorial at first, since nothing happened at the bus depot after doing everything. I was able to finish it the second time.

I haven't really encountered any game breaking bugs yet, a few quirks here and there. I guess the last few patches have fixed a lot of the problems many users have reported so it is nice to see the development team listen to players.

I may update this review if I find anything people should know before buying.

Posted: September 7, 2021
Love this game already. Yes you've probably read the other reviews and have seen a lot of teething issues, but considering this is only day 1, I'm pretty sure this will all get fixed very soon. You don't tend to see these types of issues on games with a much larger development team, mainly because these last minute issues get fixed on a massive day 1 patch. And speaking of a day 1 patch, the team have already worked super hard in getting a hot fix out today for steering wheels, so I have high hopes for them.

A lot of people are saying they're experiencing really poor frame rates with game. I'm not sure about that. If you consider constantly hitting 100 FPS on an RTX 3060 Ti to be "poor" then sure, but I don't, so I can't say I've got that issue. Now, is it poorly optimised? Absolutely. My system runs hot, and I mean, really hot. I turn down the graphics settings to Low to see if it alleviates the high temps, but no, the GPU still runs at the same really high temperature. Definitely some optimisation issues there, and I'm sure they will get fixed over time.

Would I recommend the game? Absolutely. It is a super fun game. It is the perfect game to play if you just simply want to wind down for the night or just mindlessly relax to for a while. If you enjoyed Bus Sim 18, you're going to absolutely love this one. Some people say that the UI is a little "too cramped" compared to the previous game, I don't think that's the case at all. I think that just comes down to the fact that people don't like change.

In conclusion, it has a few issues which I'm sure will get ironed out in the coming weeks. But other than that, it seems like a fun game and I can see myself playing this game for a while. I will update this review once the issues outlined above have been fixed :)

I am no bus driver. But I have played a lot of Bus Simulator 18, so that makes me more than qualified to write this review, right?

Graphics - improved over 18. The city is nice, but definitely not triple A game nice. Its a sim game, expect sim graphics. But its a vast improvement over the previous game, and the new map is fantastic.

Gameplay - most of the game is fixing little issues that were in the previous game. And it helps. Most of the time, you manage your bus routes, and then drive routes. Its fun to manage, and its great to get out and drive.

Some highlights:

Took man in wheelchair about 5 stops too many because I forgot put the ramp down at his selected spot.

NO ONE HAS TALKED TO ME ABOUT WINTER OF PASSION YET

The game isnt cheap. So unless you love buses, you could wait for a sale.

My bus is a giant pride flag wrap

I created a 2 stop route that goes around a single block. It doesnt make much money, but what a ride.

Conclusion - I like it. You might too. Or you might hate it. It really depends on your love of sim games and buses. If you dont like either of those, look elsewhere. If you like buses and sims, get it.

Enjoy!

As someone who loved Hardspace: Shipbreaker, I already know I'm going to love this game. Judge my words by how long I've continued to play after writing my review.

I immediately recognize there's a lot of quality of life features here to make the experience pleasant.

Chucking things into the truck has an extremely long range, have yet to find the limit. And you only need to be looking in the general direction.

There's no survival mechanics to worry about, so you're free to just endlessly deconstruct to your heart's content.

You can fully strip the ships down to absolutely nothing. Very satisfying.

You can upgrade your tools, making each teardown slightly faster and easier than the last.

You use a crane for removing very heavy parts, and have explosives to blast shortcuts through something, such as electrified doors/walls which may otherwise be difficult to get through.

There's quite a lot of ships to tear down! The first few aren't full ships, but by the end you have a gigantic tanker/cargo ship! Can't wait to get to that!

So yeah! If you liked Hardspace: Shipbreaker, you'll definitely like this game! In fact I'd already dare to say this is probably a better game. It runs better at least, and it isn't distracted with trying to have a story.

Please don't add a story, devs!

If it's even remotely possible, add mod support! Mods always take a game to the next level and greatly increase its value! Player made ships to tear down would be AMAZING!

Posted: August 16
The thing you must keep in mind when evaluating this game is what you're looking for going in and how this game compares to other titles in publisher PlayWay's library and to the first game in this series.

Ship Graveyard Simulator 2 is a salvage game, where you are dropped into a shipyard, given a set of tools, and must scrap parts of or entire naval vessels however you please, be it systematically or chaotically. Compared to the first game, this title is vastly improved by allowing modular destruction of ships. For that alone it is praiseworthy, but it shares many of the similar qualities with regards to how the game plays and what some might criticize it for: repetition, tedium, lack of variety in environments.

Ships are assembled like legos instead of other destruction titles that tout voxels or other granular destruction elements. In fact this game shares a lot with the Gold Standard in this genre, Hardspace: Shipbreaker. Not a bad title to take inspiration from. The loop involves destroying parts of the ship, gathering up the pieces, and chucking them into your truck (with infinite capacity, thankfully), and eventually carting off to be sorted (in a very simple minigame) and either sold or used to upgrade your tools. This is peak Dad Game that may turn off players looking for a bit more stimulation in their gameplay.

Ships gradually increase in size and complexity but I noticed that there was a lot of repetition in design, particularly noticeable at the end of the first tier of ships, where large objects are placed in similar situations and use similar tactics to free up. A path for a crane must be cleared to haul these large objects out, which is a nice touch, but I wonder how necessary this is or whether levels would be more expediently completed with the strategy below.

After you've cleared a path and gotten everything of value out of the ships, a familiar pattern sets in where you try to use the game's logic to isolate the destructible walls & floors from the ship superstructure so that everything falls apart by itself. Several minutes spent gathering and chucking into your truck results, which can get tedious. It is still a nice feeling to not only slowly tear apart the ships and see your work in real time, but to be able to use the crane to haul off the ship superstructure, like cleaning your plate of food.

The tools themselves are improved. Upgrades change the game from taking some effort to peel off walls and slice through junctures into Rip n' Tear in terms of efficacy and speed. I was better able to get into the flow of it once I could one-shot studs with my hammer and use the saw with minimal cutting speed. Crucially, a grappling-hook style rope was added from the demo that aids in traversal. While it doesn't always work great, the fact that it's there was welcome.

All in all, for the price I paid for it and compared to its predecessor, this title is a huge step forward and is one of the better titles in PlayWay's catalog in terms of polish and stability. It does have bugs but mainly to do with the physics causing objects to float in the air or elements not destroying when they should. There was a temporary loss of using my tools that I was able to figure out how to fix on my own.

As long as you know what you are buying and don't mind these type of games, I definitely recommend it. It's no Hardspace: Shipbreaker, but even Hardspace, for all its polish, had significant issues and a controversial development cycle with similar constrained variety, and not many of these type of niche games are being made.

Posted: August 19
Wow, somehow they manage to make it actually worse than the first game. The first Ship Graveyard Simulator was not an ideal game, but it was fun to scrap stuff from ship carcasses. Here? Not so much. Sure, you can actually destroy hulls now, the graphics is a bit prettier and you get ability to jump around. That is all that good here. In the first game, when you hit things you supposed to hit - they were deforming, when you cut things you were allowed to cut - you see animation of cutting and then the cut itself. And if you cut it in a wrong place you will get leftovers you will have to cut again if you want more materials. In this game? You hit point and it simply change color to black. You cut something - you see animation of tool working and then, guess what, part lose color. Not cuts, no deformation, just change of color. And there is literally no connection between the tool and the materials. You see animation of tool in the air and the part you were destroying lose color. Then, when you decolor all the connection you "bonk" the part with your hammer (actual in-game name of the action) and it becomes disconnected. You are free to press the button and pack whatever that was into small box in your hands and to throw it to your track. And as long as you point in the right direction - it does not matter how far away your truck is. It does make cleaning the place much faster, but with how small immersion is there already it just make the feeling of the game even worse.
But while immersion is the main thing in the simulators, there are more downgrades from the first game. Another big thing that was watered down is progression. Previously there were experience you get from using tools, fulfilling contracts and making money. When you leveled up you get skill points you were able to use in simple and straightforward skill tree, separate for each tool. And available ships were unlocked based on your level - there was a goal to work towards. Now? No experience, no unlocks. As long as you have enough money you can order any ship. But there are even more. In the first game there was a progression for facilities. And when you get a new level you unlock more options and the facility get a visual upgrade. Not anymore, everything is at the max level already as far as I can tell. You can still upgrade tools and now there are one or two more levels of them, though. Oh, and in the first game there were a progress bar for ship demolition. It was satisfying to hit 100% knowing that you actually did everything. And you get a nice change of background color from red to green in the ship booking system when you get at least 90% of the ship disassembled. Not anymore. And, unless it will unlock at some arbitrary point in the future, the hiring workers system is gone too. As well as making advanced materials on your own. Now all you need to upgrade your tools you can only get from the ship. Only tools upgrades can be crafted. And it looks like you don't even need to upgrade tools to destroy advanced points, you can do it with anything. meaning that another progression system was scrapped.
And on top of that I get 2 crushes to desktop in less than one hour here. In the first game I did not get a single one in several hours.
Someone in upvoted revies for this game compared it to Hardspace: shipbreaker. The only similarity is that you can completely disassemble something called "ship". Every other part of this game is objectively less developed. There is no story, no characters, no material deformation, no goal, no challenge. The only thing in the SGS2 that required at least some thinking is how to get "heavy equipement" out before you can destroy its supports.
I would advice to stay away from this title unless some significant game mechanics will be added.

Posted: August 25
The game has good concepts. The reason for my review is the overall lack of progress. I have moved up now to the difficult ships and what I have noticed is
1- There is no real new concepts of challenges (the winch is nothing really). Ships are simply previous elements put together in different arrangements.
2 - The use of each tool becomes harder (more effort, hits, time). The issue is you end up with the same resource and same cost while the ships are bigger. Hence you have to upgrade your tools to work on larger ships but there is no benefit (financially or timing) in doing this. The previous game at least the materials value was proportional to the effort involved
3- Outside the ship, there is noting to do except upgrade and the recycling and the way it is done does not add to the game.
The movement around and use of tools is good and as a time killer game I works well, but as the ships get larger and harder, it just become monotonous and frustrating as the benefit is not there.

Review written October 2023, with version 1.0.5 of the game. I would have reviewed it earlier but the game went through some bad stages when it had such annoying bugs it wasn't worth playing. As far as I can tell right now, any remaining bugs are minor.

Enjoyable game for people who like making sense of things, clearing up messes, or compulsively tidying things away. I'm not qualified to talk about OCD, but an obsessively neat person might enjoy it.

A training stage plus 12 ships, or portions of ships, to clear out, disassemble, collect the pieces and take them for recycling. With the profits from whatever you've just done you can buy upgrades on six different tools which help you work faster or better. You can stop working on any ship at any time, take whatever money you've made so far, and move on to the next. Or you can clear up every part of the ship leaving just an empty muddy space ready for the next one. Completely clearing a ship is very satisfying, but you get no bonus for it.

The free 'Prologue' version is the full game with all facilities, but features just the training stage and one large ship.

Pros: Good graphics, very rarely crashes or hangs, features autosave. Rope feature is fun.

Cons: Apparently, with 50 thousand in the bank and nothing to spend it on, I'm still working out of a draughty one-room shack with no toilet. I like a game which rewards me for doing well.

Posted: August 29
Let's jump right into the main question here - would I recommend this game to you? That depends on two factors - how much do you enjoy simple repetitive tasks, and how much jank are you willing to accept?

If you want complexity, this is absolutely not the game for you. This is a game for people that want to shut off their brain and hold down a mouse button until their hand cramps. This is a game for people that like to watch objects fall through space. This is a game for people that want to think exactly one time in any given hour. If your tools are underlevelled for a ship - hint, if you were enjoying yourself smacking things just once on a level, next level you will no longer be enjoying yourself that way - you will be sitting there holding down your mouse button for quite a while. Your saw will go from having a blade installed to apparently having butter installed as you grind slowly through metal. Your hammer, which could easily pop a rivet out with a single hit, will suddenly take four.

(Just do a lower level ship a few times, you say? Look, friend, the ships are already so similar to one another that you begin to wonder if this is a shipping industry standard or developer laziness. If I start repeating ships my brain might actually wander off and leave my shambling husk to hold down mouse buttons without it.)

Please don't take this as a "you should not play this game"! Look, I played the demo a lot, and I played the full game for 50+ hours at the time of this review - I am obviously a fan of mindless deconstruction. If you want that, this is a great source of it. When I'm stressed it's undeniably nice to have something really simple to unwind with, and this is certainly that.

Now, as for the jankiness of the thing... well. You're going to have to be cool with things being "close enough". The text is close enough to English. The hit boxes are close enough to accurate. The voices are close enough to understandable. If you don't mind constantly being a little tweaked by things, it's fine. If that sort of thing drives you crazy, maybe avoid.

Little things : There are only maybe six people in the world that purchase your items. Oh, sure, they give you different names and stories, but they have the same faces, they're not sneaky. The dirt you have on your arms makes it look like you have some kind of plague. No matter how prosperous you get, your shipyard will always look like it came from a Soviet post-apocalypse. You will sleep in a tumbledown shack forever and like it.

Big Things : . In a game that prides itself on tedium, this is easily the most tedious thing they have on offer. You have to sort colored items into boxes of the same color. The items roll down a ceaseless conveyor belt. There is no way to stop once you start. And if you wait until the end of a ship to sort the items, you will be there for approximately the entire childhood of your average human child. It's the only way to get materials (and thus money) out of the ships, so it's not optional. You will, in fact, be tempted to put a brick on the space bar and walk away to live a new life in another country. It sucks, guys. It's negative amounts of fun. Whoever decided this should be part of the game needs to be sent to their room without supper for no less than fourteen years.

So do the math in your head. How much do you like repeating tasks while your brain takes a nap +/- how much you love/hate janky games = whether or not you're going to like this game. Godspeed.

Posted: October 2
Firstly, the inventory system is horrible. While working on a "ship" every 10-15 seconds you'll get a popup saying you can't carry anymore and have to launch what you're holding into the truck. Even on the 3rd ship expect to have to make at least 100 shuttle runs to the truck to drop off resources. Utter madness.

I say "ship" because they aren't ships, they're small parts of ships that just magically appear on the beach. In the first game you watched the actual ships you'd be working on come in to shore for dismantling, rather than a chunk of a ship just appearing.

I feel like I've bought a demo. Where's the rest of the game?

Ship Graveyard Simulator 1 had loads more features: you could smelt resources into other resources, you got experience points you could use to improve your character and business, you could upgrade your buildings, you could hire staff. There were dozens of people about, some of whom offered quests. Where's all that? This game has none of those things.

The normal process for a sequel is to build on the success of the previous title. I've no idea what the plan was here. Whatever it was it's a bold strategy Cotton, let's see if it pays off for them.

TLDR - Just buy the first game when it's on sale. It's got way more to do than this has.

YouTube™ Video: Ship Graveyard Simulator 2 - Review

Ship Graveyard Sim 2 is basically a total upgrade. A removal of the fiddly metal fusion systems, the cumbersome and broken inventory system and the useless refueling systems basically mean that the game's much more streamlined in a very positive way.

It also helps that now you actually demolish and salvage the ship instead of salvaging the occasional fire extinguisher and chair while leaving the actual ship untouched.

There's some people who find the game... too game-like compared to the first game by having damage bars, but they also ignore somehow that a level 3 hammer breaks something perfectly while a level 2 hammer means that the fire extinguisher you're bashing is basically made out of some sci-fi unbreakable alloy.

This is nothing but a step forward in my eyes.

Posted: August 28
The graphics are nice and the game-play loop is fine (breaking down ships hulks). But the mechanics are too simplistic and there are some crucial missing elements for a proper simulator.
Tool use is simply point and click, for a game that revolves around using these tools it feels lacking in depth.
There is no player injury, so you can literally destroy the whole bottom deck of a hulk and thousands of tons of steel can collapse on top of you and nothing happens, no consequences for stupid actions.
There are other game-play mechanics that are totally immersion breaking but i can understand why they did them even though i don't agree with them.
Overall the game is too fast paced and too simplistic for a proper simulator. Its good if you want to play for ten minutes at a time but not if you want to play long term. Its a phone app game masquerading as a PC simulator game, seems like there are a lot of these around nowadays. Quick fix games that have no longevity because there is no skill required to learn how to play and therefore no challenge to keep you coming back in the future.
Sad.

60 hours in, I think I can review the game now. First, this is a huge improvement over the original. I do like the way the changes are done. I have completed the final ship, now just to finish upgrading tools, and earning the $$$ achievements.

Overall, pretty bug free, but I did find some pesky ones. The final ship, I found the most difficult to remove large objects. The end of the ship had some floor pieces glitched into the actual pieces that were permanent, so I could not remove them, and those stopped me from removing the entire end piece.

The generators, engines, or whatever they are at the back of the ship, when I tried to remove them, the UI showed me that the crane could not access the objects because of the floor under the engines. I ended up using an explosive to remove the floor, which destroyed the engines.

When I opened up the cargo bay doors, at first I was like, yes, just drop in there and remove the floor anchors, and I will be good to pull them out. Nope. The walls next to them were keeping them in place, so I could not get to this until I fully disassembled that entire part of the ship. Which is very difficult to do if you don't realize you need to remove those tall walls before removing those giant divider things.

I did complete the contracts on the final ship, so it did not stop me from completing the game, it just stopped me from making a little extra profit.

Overall, I do recommend you buy this game, especially if you enjoyed the first one.

Posted: August 29
Game is not in a ready state to play, the core physics of how objects are supported makes you question what part of the structure is holding the rest up. On the larger ships, if you remove the hull sides, the structure still registers it as there. Meaning that there is a mess of floating structures that can often be hard to reach and require tedious dismantling as it's difficult to tell which part of the structure is holding it together. Even resorting to explosives doesn't work as it only blasts walls not beams.

Beyond which, the game turns into 'Pickup the trash' simulator. You are rate limited to how many items you can pick up at a time and how much weight until you have to throw the volume into your truck or away. You end up spending more time picking up junk than actually dismantling the ships. And even after upgrading the ability to pick up more weight and items at a time, it is still a taxing/unfun part of the game that takes up at least 30% of the time if not more.

Ship Graveyard Simulator 2 is a solid and polished, but not groundbreaking, entry to the genre. I can easily recommend this game to fans of Simulators that think they’ll like the ship aesthetic. People new to the genre will find it very approachable and reasonably priced so it would also be a good introduction to the genre, especially if you’re nautically inclined. If you’re more likely to see this as a tedium simulator, then I doubt this is the genre for you.

The game performs well on my system thanks to heavy use of dynamic scaling. The graphics are more than good enough for the genre, the sounds are adequate although the sound of depositing resources on your truck gets annoying fast. My primary technical problem with the game was a crash every couple of hours of play. Not the biggest problem since you can quick-save but it’s never pleasant having your “work” lost. The only other problem is the lack of the standard borderless fullscreen mode which should be in every game at this point,

Posted: November 16
I have been enjoying the game to a degree, but the quality of things leaves a LOT to be desired.
The music and sounds for the most part are really... strange? They don't sound like they fit the game at all.
The NPC voices sound like they're a text-to-speech engine.
I've experienced pretty regular crashes which in some cases can make me lose a lot of progress.
The gameplay doesn't really change much at all after the 2nd or 3rd ship.
The sorting facility is just annoying and makes irritating sounds.
I really wish that the glove upgrades increased your throw speed.
Most of the game is you just picking up items and throwing them in your truck, which would be fine if the time it takes to throw the box didn't always remain the same and be needlessly long.
I also really wish that the game had a way of showing you all the 'heavy' elements, because on the larger ships I scour them from top to bottom and still feel like I have missed one and that causing a collapse is going to make me lose one of them.
The prices for things seem really out of balance. Some ships you only get a tiny bit more back in resources compared to what the ship cost. Yeah there is also the contracts, but they're problematic in their own way in that they give you such a large percentage of the money you acquire, that it discourages you from actually fully stripping a ship and instead just completing the contracts and ignoring the rest.

There's a potentially very satisfying gameplay loop buried in this game, but I can't really recommend it at it's current quality, at this price. In Australia this game is selling for $29.50, which is about $20 USD. I'd be a lot happier with my purchase if it had only cost me half that.

Posted: August 16
Grade: 3/5

7 hours of gameplay for $18. I generally look for 1:1 hours played for $ spent. I could easily spend more hours in the game, but ive experienced all of the gameplay loops and now its just tedious for me.

Graphics suck. They just do. Textures are low-res in areas, and youll really notice it on your tools. Speaking of tools, the progression of tools will reward you with a different model which is nice.

I actually would still be playing except the game had a fatal crash.

Outside of the single crash I had, I only experienced one bug which happened twice. When I go to the recycling center, it loads the zoom animation twice and it gets stuck at the start of the zoom animation so I can barely see what I am sorting, making it really hard to sort properly.

From my point of view the game was very intuitive. Generally the physics works, though I did take some screenshots of floating walls (shared). The puzzle gameplay loop was satisfying. When you are taking an engine out from a bottom of a ship through 6 floors, with rooms that are electrified, etc... its a nice experience.

I can see where the game will get tedious very fast for some players. Repeating the same thing over and over can really grind you down. So here are some tips for those that will buy the game after reading this review. This is based on my experience of tearing down a $10, $20 and $400 ship.

1. Your tool rank scales backward with as ships get more difficult. On a $20 ship my 3 rank hammer could remove a bolt in 2 swings. On a $400 ship it took 4 swings and still took 4 swings after i upgraded to rank 4. Everything takes longer... welding, cutting... all of it. so if you rush to the expensive ships like I did youll feel the pain.

2. The trick to making the experience more efficient is figuring out what takes you the most time. I found that I spent most of the time using the hammer so I ranked that up first... but I think i should have ranked up my carry capacity and pick up speed too. On the $20 ship, which I tore down to the last piece, so.... much... picking up stuff time. The $400 ship had stuff that took up 40 wt and you start with 60. I actually leveled my capacity up to 100 which helped a bunch.

3. I think there is value on not tearing down a ship 100%. The 3 contracts you get is really where the money is at because you need the materials to upgrade your tools. ... so it depends on what your after, $ or materials for tools.

4. There are hidden rooms.. rooms with no doors or windows. Sometimes the thing your looking for to complete a contract is in a hidden room.

5. You can nearly dismantle a ship without actually sawing apart the beams. Just knock down all the walls, floors and ceilings and the beams fall apart automatically. Thats how I did the $20 ship... ceiling, walls, floor.. then everything falls down to the next level.

Anyway... to sum up. for $18 its nearly $2 per hour I got out of the game... which... even $60 games have a hard time matching now days.... so basically... its average. Graphics suck... omfg they suck, but the gameplay is decent enoug.

Posted: August 22
I am both very happy and very frustrated to write this review.

I didn't recommend the first game because of how removed the game felt from what was advertised. It felt like the "deconstruction game we have at home." I felt a great deal of frustration for how the game came out because there was so much potential and even other games in the same genera that could have been drawn from. In all, I wasn't angry. Just disappointed.

This game feels like what should have been released in the first place. It's not perfect and there's certainly other games that do it better, but for what it is? It's honestly very enjoyable to play. Tearing the ship apart is very satisfying and setting up and executing a massive domino effect as level upon level of ship collapses is a real treat. Everything works the way you would expect it to and they managed to keep the tool system simple without making every task simply point and click. They even added hazards that could hamper your salvaging mission. It really does feel like they saw the largest criticisms of their previous attempt and took them to heart. I give them major kudos for that.

It's definitely not perfect. The largest issue that carried over from the last game is the game's progression. The larger more difficult ships are only more difficult because the cut/impact points you need to hit to pull things apart have more health which require better tools which really just ends up feeling like a cheap way of introducing "difficulty". The introduction of hazards, while appreciated, is a little hollow as they are very easy to overcome and aren't actually dangerous. As far as I've seen, you have no health and no amount of excess kilos slamming down on your head from above will stand to challenge you. The only thing slowing your progress are the health bars throughout the ship and the number of things you have to deconstruct.

Unlike the previous game, however, I don't think the game's largest issues are beyond the scope of the engine. Future updates could add new ships, more things to do with your money, more reasons to look for hazards, and a greater concern for what's coming down on your head. If nothing else, a future installment could iterate further.

Final review score of a 6/10 (which could easily improve with later updates)

tl;dr: This is the game I wish they released to start with and it really does feel like there are serious incremental improvements being made. I hope they look to their peers to see what they could be doing better and find ways of putting a unique spin on it.

Posted: June 16, 2022
If you're a fan of Hyperstone Heist or Turtles in Time, scroll back up and buy Shredder's Revenge. Don't mull over it, don't read a cross section a reviews and don't leave it to the morning. This is what you've been waiting for.

Now, if you're still considering it, let me put a few things on the table. We've had a mini-Renaissance for the beat 'em up genre in recent times, with River City Girls and Streets of Rage 4 (and its DLC) being two particularly significant highlights of this. I can say with full confidence that Shredder's Revenge stands shoulder to shoulder with these two releases, but with a few important differences. At face value, this game may appear to lack content, with one run reportedly taking about 3 hours to complete, making it shorter on paper than the experiences the other two games offer. This is a gross simplification of what this game offers and it ignores its greatest strengths.

Aside from a multi-difficulty story mode and a traditional arcade mode, Shredder's Revenge offers a whole range of side content that significantly expands and lengthens the game experience. Each level in story mode not only has hidden collectables and side-challenges, it also presents an entirely new element in comparison to past TMNT games: character progression. As you play more and more as your chosen character (of which you'll eventually have 7 options), you will actually level up, boosting HP, access to multiple levels of special attacks and expanding your combat options. This progression is tied to individual characters and is linked to the points scored with each, furthering replayability.

But what is replayability without a game that warrants it? This is another strength of Shredder's Revenge, as the combat is fast, fluid and above all damn fun. I've only played about 2 hours of the story mode so far (completing 10/16 of the main levels), but every part of the game has felt more-ish, and the moment this review is finished, I will indeed be diving back into the game. This is further reinforced by gorgeous pixel art, great graphical effects and some catchy music.

On a subjective note, I have a deeply personal connection to the Genesis/Megadrive TMNT game Hyperstone Heist, and I spent many an hour playing with a dear friend during my childhood. I was apprehensive that Shredder's Revenge might be good, but just wouldn't feel 'right', given this experience. I'm eagerly looking forward to the Cowabunga Collection later this year, but this new entry is absolutely a worthy successor.

There are reports that the net code for co-op is still in the process of being refined, but that's something subsequent patches will hopefully iron this out. My perspective on the game might change after a few more runs (and eventual co-op with local and overseas friends), but at the moment, I'm having an absolute ball, and this is shaping up to be one of the best beat 'em ups I've played.

Absolutely recommended.

Posted: June 19, 2022
Back in the early 90s, as a kid, Beat 'Em Up games were among my favourite genres. Not like we had much choice on the matter but I thoroughly enjoyed games like; Golden Axe, Double Dragon and Streets of Rage.
(for the purists: Yes, I know some of those games are from the 80s but I did not play them in the 80s). None of them however, hold a candle to the best (or most fun) Beat 'Em Up game of all time: "TMNT - Turtles In Time".

I am a bit biased though since the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles were my (and many other kids') favourite cartoon series.

Naturally I was filled with joy, knowing there would be a spiritual successor to Turtles In Time in 2022; "Shredder's Revenge". Ready for some trip down memory lane, I decided to spend way too much money to play this game and I can safely say that it did not disapoint.

Graphically the game looks amazing, most likely one of the best looking pixel-art games and in combination with the great soundtrack it surely will give you that 90s vibe.

When playing Shredder's Revenge you will notice everything in the game is made in homage to Turtles In Time without adding anything to attract a wider audience. Virtually every TMNT character (bad guy) makes an appearance in this game.
There are some new features compared to TIT; Aside from the 4 turtles, you can choose 3 other playable characters: April O' Neill, Splinter and Casey Jones (after finishing the game). There are quite a few new combat moves + you can dodge roll this time + your characters level up over time.
Also, there is an online mode so you can co-op with strangers (or friends) up to 6 players to extend game length.

Which brings me to probably the only real 'negative' thing about Shredder's Revenge, which is that the game's story mode does not take that long to finish. There are 16 levels, each taking around 7-8 minutes but to be fair this game is still longer than TMNT:TIT ever was.
However, playing with friends, harder difficulties, the arcade mode and achievements can keep you busy for quite a bit longer.

Since the game's price is quite steep at the moment, I do not recommend this game to anyone NOT familiar with 'Turtles In Time' or TMNT in general. For the people that are, it's a fun nostalgic game which you no-doubt will love.

Posted: June 10
This is, hands-down, the best Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles game.

The game looks and plays much like how some remember the earlier games played (NES, SNES/Genesis, and Arcade), but with higher-fidelity visuals, a better art direction, and with more actions the players can take. Additionally, allowing for 6-player co-op and allowing people to play as April, Splinter, and Casey Jones is a huge bonus. If anyone is itching for some TMNT, this is the game for them.

Things that could be improved: the "story" mode is kind of weak. It's padded by collectibles and character-levels, It's unfortunate that they had artists spend time on a fantastic world map when it is barely used. Also, the game is rather "safe" in its approach. If anyone is looking for something more than just another TMNT game that's a 2D beat 'em up, then they will likely be disappointed. On the technical side: some of the audio is lackluster. The music is fantastic, but sound effects and voice lines are rather muted.

All that said, I still think this is a worthy purchase especially if it's under $20.

Posted: June 21, 2022
Heroes in a Half Shell

Follow our Curator page, Summit Reviews, to see more high-quality reviews regularly.

Visiting the American arcade scene in the mid-to-late 1990s always featured two staples: beat ’em ups and the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. There were two main Turtle arcade cabinets: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and then later, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Turtles in Time. Both cabinets served to legitimize the particular arcade they were held within. Eventually, a beautiful symbiosis began to emerge from the Turtles and their trendy beat ’em up grouping. These were quick games with limited buttons, so they were efficient in both moving people on and off machines swiftly and being simplistic enough for everyone to play.

But nothing lasts forever. Eventually, the arcades shut down and the kids who grew up loving these characters, well, grew up.

Now, 31 years later, we finally have a sequel.

Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder’s Revenge took on the monumental task of creating a follow-up from a genre mostly considered dead, for a property that’s popularity peaked around 1992. So, how did they fare?


Beat ’em ups died for a reason. The evolution of video games from an arcade market to a home console market led to the advent of more nuanced intangibles. This paradigm shift necessitated longer playtimes and more intricate systems within the games themselves. But the genre’s problems are no less true today. So, the success of Shredder’s Revenge would always, and ultimately, be determined by how well it navigated the genre’s inherent pitfalls.



The issues are twofold: 1) Beat ’em ups are short, so where is the value? 2) They’re repetitive, so what keeps you playing?

To combat the length problem, the game comprises 16 different levels that can be completed in or around 2.5 hours, which is very long for a traditional beat ’em up. To address replayability, the game utilizes seven playable characters that all featured prominently in the comics, cartoons, and movies: Leonardo, Michelangelo, Donatello, Raphael, Splinter, April O'Neil, and Casey Jones (unlockable upon the completion of the story). All of which play differently from one another.

Both the longer-than-traditional playtime and the option to select from an abundance of different characters manifests a holistic approach to addressing all of the above pitfalls. Especially in conjunction with the ability to punish baddies with five additional friends within the confines of interactive, exceptionally colorful environments, to the tune of radical ’90s synth beats.

Like Dotemu’s Streets of Rage 4 (2020) offering prior, everything just works.


As mentioned, Shredder’s Revenge makes an outstanding effort at keeping gameplay fresh. Every character will have a unique playthrough, not only via small differences in their moveset, but also because of their different statistical capabilities. Each selectable turtle (or rat, or person) is assigned ratings based upon their range, speed, and attack power. And if you’re familiar with the IP, then the attributes make sense—Leonardo is the best all around, Michelangelo has the best speed, Donatello has the best range, Raphael has the best attack power, etc. There are 21 set moves that each toon employs with added power-ups and team attacks, taunts, and situational nuances (like hitting a shuriken back in the face of its sender). And your timing on each move is essential to your survival in later levels when the enemies become their most varied, as every enemy (differences usually denoted by color) has different tells, attacks, speeds, and aggressiveness. The developers understood that enemy variety was the simplest way to keep things fresh, and Shredder’s Revenge unleashes tons of variability.

In Story Mode, each character will level up the more you use them. Additional perks come in the form of new attacks, added hit points, or extra lives. Moreover, this pads the game’s length because completionists will want to pursue leveling up all their heroes to max level.

More attuned turtles become particularly important in the endgame when simply mashing the attack button no longer suffices. In these situations, you’re going to have a much easier time, especially solo, with your highest-leveled toon.

I ended up getting “shell shocked” on level 13 because my turtle simply wasn’t ready. Poor Donny…



But fear not, Shredder’s Revenge uses a world map in Story Mode. This assists the player in leveling up turtles by allowing players to revisit previous levels, move on to new ones, or check on their statistical progress (and achievements) in the “Turtle Lair.” This is not earth-shattering stuff, but for a beat ’em up, it’s still unexpected. More than just being practical (and fun) it adds, granted superficially, an RPG element that previous entries did not/could not consider.

The game also features an Arcade Mode, which many fundamentalists will consider the “true” way to play. Characters are given a limited amount of extra lives, and they’re tasked with completing the game in order, start to finish, with a Game Over being just that—game over.

Nostalgia, along with the fear of death or losing progress, is paramount in making this genre viable. Arcade Mode encapsulates both.


While Shredder’s Revenge is no doubt one of the best in its category and, more specifically, the best Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles game, there are areas that could have been improved immensely simply by their expansion. Ironically, these issues are only evident because Shredder’s Revenge implemented the concepts in the first place. Things like collectable side quests, leveling up, and achievements are all minimalistic in scope. Which is odd when one considers that the developers took the time to draw so much attention to them.

The collectable quests are reduced to easily found items hidden under trash cans, doors, or fire hydrants you’ll likely break on accident without any real attempt at sleuthing. Once you collect them, you turn them in. And then…that’s it. A few points are rewarded, and you get one extra line of script, but nothing substantive. Separately there are 30 achievements in-game, which is a fine amount for a beat ’em up, but when the game places major emphasis on completing them (via the Turtle Lair), the amount suddenly feels unusually lacking.



Then there’s leveling up, which is a wonderful touch that I am happy (and surprised) exists. But it's precisely because it exists that the rigid linearity of its progression becomes very noticeable. If it’s going to be there, it would have been preferable to have some choice on how our turtles evolve. Shredder’s Revenge is simply not interested in providing that.


It’s remarkable that a game like this can be so fun, refreshing, and relevant in 2022. Especially given that the IP has reached such an advanced age so many years after its popularity peaked. But it does. In fact, it manages to wholly squeeze every last drop of “turtle soup” out of the franchise and establish itself as the best version of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, in gaming, to date.

Without the slightest hint of a doubt, this is one of the greater beat ’em ups of all time.

Considering the additions brought into the fold, the ability to access six-person co-op, the lovingly implemented tweaks to illuminate its pertinence, along with its sincere mixture of nostalgia, this is (weirdly) as good a time as any to play a Ninja Turtles game.

Posted: July 31, 2022
I've been looking forward to playing Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder's Revenge ever since it got announced and I'm going to be 100% honest with you; my expectations were pretty low due to Tribute Games. I've played another game by them last year which is called Panzer Paladin and it was pretty generic with repetitive level design and game mechanics. At the same time, I was kinda hopeful since beat 'em up genre overall is repetitive and I felt like they finally found the direction they should aim for and I've gotta give it them, they did a pretty solid job with this title.

It's mostly based on the 80s cartoon and it feels like watching several episodes of the show. It starts off with Krang setting up a trap for the turtles and Shredder's running the show behind the curtains to get his revenge. Why he wants revenge from the turtles? I have no idea since his motives were never explained. However, it's Shredder afterall and it's pretty clear why he has beef with the turtles, nonetheless, I've been trying to find a real reason behind his hatred specifically for this game but I guess it got something to do with the cartoon and it's been a long time since I watched that one.

Gameplay is your typical beat 'em up. Nothing more, nothing less. It's only natural that it will get compared with Streets of Rage 4 by many people since Dotemu is the publisher but let me tell you that sadly, it doesn't have a revolutionary gameplay like Streets of Rage 4. So, it's safer to set your expectations based on that fact. You get to play as 7 characters and all of them have Ninja Power bars that start with 1, and goes up to 3 as you level up your character. Ninja Power is used to unleash special attacks that I consider very broken at the moment. When you fill up all 3 of your bars, you get to enter a Super Saiyan state which gets obsoloted by regular specials since it's impractical to use it when your regular specials deal more damage in more guaranteed way. This is, of course, a personal preference. Levelling up is also pretty easy and fast which is a plus in my book. However, taunting fills up your Ninja Power bar and it's the most broken thing in the game. It can be cheesed to melt down your enemies easily.

So, how does it compare to Turtles in Time and other TMNT games you ask? It's been a long time since I played that one but I can safely assume that Shredder's Revenge is the best beat 'em up TMNT title out there at the moment. Its gameplay, soundtracks, story and its nostalgia elements do what they're supposed to do very well. The only thing I ask of Dotemu to make the soundtracks of their games available to buy on Steam. They are really good and they fit with the gameplay very well. Whether you're a TMNT fan or not, I can almost guarantee that you will find some enjoyment in this game. Co-op also works very good, at least on my end.

I remember watching the 1987 show when I was very little. It was airing at the 90s at that time and I could still remember that show. I even played the 2 arcade games of it. When they announced the game that was based on that show, I immediately brought it at the first go and when I played it, I do not regret even a bit into buying it.

All the things that were shown on the 1987 shown were there. The antics of the bosses and the enemy soldiers. The 90s things that we had before like Game Boy, VHS, Pizza Power, etc. Heck I even cried at one point because of the nostalgic that overflew towards me.

Now on to the game play. The fact that we could now play as April and Splinter in addition to the 4 turtles is a big thumbs up. Each character has different stats which gives the replayability value. We can pull out some crazy chain of combos and air combos as well as pulling out special attacks even on mid air. Heck you can even taunt and I really liked the taunt stance of different characters. The main thumbs up is the co-op where you can heal the other player when they get knocked out and can even cheer at them. The graphics really remind me of the 1987 show with the touch of some modern standards. All the characters that were on the 1987 show were there in which made me really happy. And let's talk quickly about the music and I will say that the opening theme and the Panic in the Sky Stage music are absolutely my favorite.

It's a must have for those who have memories of the show and its games. A big thank you to the developers for making this awesome game which brought my memories back of the 1987 show and games.

Pros
+ Really captures the essence of the Turtles and the 90s vibes
+ Controls are smooth
+ Animations are great
+ Integrated multiplayer works well enough

Cons
- Taunt system is poorly designed. Every taunt gives you a full super. Devolves into run away, taunt, then super over and over at times.
- Charge attacks are super restrictive to the point you never use them
- Throw attacks have no invulnerability making them too risky

Honestly just play the game on Gnarly difficulty from the start.

Posted: December 3, 2022
This is going to be my very first review ever written on Steam but I just can’t stay silent about this particular game anymore. I’ve been playing this game almost everyday since launch and I still have not gotten tired of it. Not by a long shot. What can I say other than it’s just a flat out masterpiece. Rarely do I ever get so enthralled in a beat em up game that I play at least one session (most of the time multiple sessions) almost everyday for months. I really only have one major complaint about the game and I’ll get to that. But first I want to point out all of it’s good points.

Game play
The game play is fantastic. Even though I must have beaten the game all the way through over 100 times by now I still don’t get tired of running through the game. One of the biggest draws is of course the 6 player online co-op. If you manage to get into a game with 5 other people it can get really chaotic in the best of ways. Maximum fun for everyone weather it’s with friends or just other players looking for a session. Easily hop in and out of a game with little to no complications from what I’ve seen. Combos are fun to execute and there’s always enough Foot Clan members for everyone to pummel into the ground. Bosses always offer a challenge even with 6 people together. Never a dull moment with this game.

Graphics
Animation is great to watch. Characters and settings are beautiful and vibrant. Really brings a sense being back in the 80s. This game has some of the most beautiful pixel art I have ever seen in 2022. All characters look and feel completely different from each other no matter what they happen to be doing. Even when they just stand there I’ve never felt like I was looking at a copy/paste of anyone. I never get tired of watching the fights that go on at any point in the game.

Sound and Music
Along with the game play this is another huge draw for this game. The music is just fantastic. Again really brings a sense of going back in time to the 80s when coupled with the animations. Each piece was masterfully created to suit each level and some of them even have lyrics. Tee Lopes really outdid himself with the soundtrack of this game and I’m hard pressed to find another game this year to rival it. I can guarantee you that some of these songs will be stuck in your head for a good long while after you’ve given them a listen.

Switching gears for a second. The voice acting is another thing I have to pay homage to because it’s just great. Everyone sounds almost exactly like they did in the 80s cartoon and there is tons of witty quips and commentary from everyone along the way. As well as a few call back lines from the show and even some of the old TMNT games. I had a blast listening to everyone banter and I’m sure anyone else who gives this game a try will feel the same way.

One Major Complaint
Now I mentioned earlier that I had one big complaint about the game. Keep in mind that this isn’t the fault of the actual game or developers but more of a community problem. But it’s a major one for me personally. That problem being the one particular hot headed turtle we all know as Raphael. It does me no joy to talk ill of Raph because he is my favorite turtle but I very much feel this should be addressed as it has easily ruined many sessions for me over the months I’ve been playing this game.

It’s no surprise that there is at least one overpowered character in beat em up games that can pretty much whip through the entire game with very little button work on the player’s part. That honor in this game goes to Raphael. Almost everyone who uses Raph plays in the exact same fashion which always has me cringe when someone enters my session as him and making me wish I could just ban him most of the time. He has the shortest taunt animation out of all the characters. It’s literally like 2 seconds. Then since his power stat is set to maximum, his Sai Cyclone super becomes a controllable death spiral that pretty much one shots any Foot Clan unlucky enough to be caught up in it’s path. It’s range is also quite large surprisingly covering a significant amount of the screen and as I mentioned before, it’s controllable. Meaning you can move around while using it. So for Raphael users it becomes a simple 2 button spam fest. Taunt then Super and repeat. They do this all throughout the level and boss fights making the game trivial and boring for anyone else in the session.

Of course it makes sense for Raph to be so strong because he is the hot head of the group so I don’t blame the devs. It’s the player base more or less that is at fault here and I’m sure many people who have played online before know what I’m talking about. Of course the easiest solution to this problem is to just kick spammers but about 95% of players play Raphael in this manner and if you like to play with a full party of people as I do then you’ll most likely have to put up with it for the most part. I kind of wish Raph’s Super would get toned down or nerfed a little bit or even make his taunt animation last a little longer (kind of like Casey or Donatello who have pretty long animations) but that will probably never happen sadly.

Other than that major flaw though I have no issues with this awesome game and I’ll continue to play it for a long time to come. If anyone is still on the fence about getting the game, don’t be. I can guarantee you it is will worth it to pick up. Don’t mind the Raphael Spammers. They are just one side effect to the awesome game play. As a person who has been playing since launch this game gets a solid A+ all across the board.

Edit: With the release of the new Custom Mode, the issue with the over spammers has been solved. You can now completely turn off the restoration of supers via taunting. I really now have no complaints about this game and fully recommend it to anyone who is still on the fence about buying it.

Posted: November 28, 2022
Product received for free

What more do you need to know about a Beat 'Em Up style game? Mash the buttons, knock out all the different colored Foot Clan members, beat mini-bosses at the end of each level and then save The Big Apple by 3AM - Or well in this case... 3PM!

TMNT Shredder's Revenge is easily a 10/10 for what the game offers in this small, well rounded package. Albeit my only tiff with the game at release was it's length and price. It honestly felt like a fair and justified complaint at first, but the more I played it, the more I noticed the clear and obvious care, love and passion the developers put into this game. It is a very polished and complete experience from start to finish. Collectibles of all sorts in each level and even an Arcade style challenge for those who want to go from the first level to the last level in one sitting!

Now I will say it is an absolute MUST that you bring the friends to the show! 4 people to me is the perfect blend of combined abilities and attacks. You can have up to 6, but having done so a couple times can get quite chaotic on the screen! You also can't go wrong with the classic SNES style 2-player mode, either! TMNT Shredder's Revenge has everything you would hope for and a few little extra added bonuses for modernization sake, too!

My last praise for the game is of course it's harmonious and nostalgic, sound kicking soundtrack. You will instantly fall in love with the tracks in this game. Every level has it's own unique track and the musicians did such a perfect job to make the game truly feel like it came out in 1993! If you want to feel like a kid again, then crank up the music volume to 100 while thrashing the Foot Clan! I highly recommend checking out the full soundtrack online.

Is there anything else that needs to be said?! It's the ideal game game for when you just want to sick back with the controller and mash those buttons like you did when playing with your friends and family back in the day!

Posted: September 23, 2022
Wow, a game that is actually good! This is incredibly rare. The art style is a faithful middle-ground. My recommendation has nothing to do with nostalgia, and everything to do with the developers understanding what a video game is supposed to be about!

- This game respects the player. It doesn't kill you instantly, and provides REAL entertainment.
- It builds faithfully on the pedigree of TMNT games.
- There's no "try-hard" BS designed for angry aimless teenagers.
- If something off-screen is about to hit you, you get a warning. But you can still die if you stop fighting.
- Gripes about the special attack are stupid. The special attacks improve on the original game by miles.

The last time I thought this highly of a video game was Shadow Warrior 2. It's quite possible some people will encounter lag / performance issues specific to their hardware + region, but nobody can help that.

The only thing I'm upset about? The glut of indie games with stupid Japanese-style try-hard gameplay clogging Steam caused me to believe that no good games were being developed anymore. It looks like I was wrong, and I'm glad I bought this game. It's definitely short, but in the current market, it's worth every penny.

Posted: January 13
This is hands-down the best TMNT game I have ever played! As a big-time fan of the original arcade/SNES/Genesis games, I can wholeheartedly assure anyone reading this review that Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder's Revenge perfectly captures the spirit of the older titles while masterfully improving on the existing formula in every way.

- The combat is faithful to older titles while implementing modern tweaks/mechanics that keep the gameplay feeling fresh.
- The visuals are masterfully crafted and serve the best era of TMNT stories/characters.
- The soundtrack is stellar and full of bops.
- The campaign/arcade mode is beefy and gives players their money's worth.

Even if you don't know anything about TMNT or give two hoots about the franchise, this game is a superb beat-em-up title in its own right and arguably one of the best in the genre.

Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder's Revenge is the perfect example of how older titles should be 'remastered/remade/revisited' for contemporary audiences. With how well this game turned out, I hope that the developer/publisher are able to take other game series of old and revitalize them with new life for new/returning audiences!
