Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder’s Revenge features groundbreaking gameplay rooted in timeless classic brawling mechanics, brought to you by the beat ’em up experts at Dotemu ( Streets of Rage 4 ) and Tribute Games. Bash your way through gorgeous pixel art environments and slay tons of hellacious enemies with your favorite Turtle, each with his own skills and moves - making each run unique! Choose a fighter, use radical combos to defeat your opponents and experience intense combats loaded with breathtaking action and outrageous ninja abilities. Stay sharp as you face off against Shredder and his faithful Foot Clan alone, or grab your best buds and play with up to four players simultaneously!


With Bebop and Rocksteady assaulting Channel 6 and stealing super gnarly devices to support Krang and Shredder’s latest twisted plan, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder’s Revenge sees the Turtles battling across a righteous range of timeless TMNT locations. From Manhattan and Coney Island, to city rooftops and dank sewers, help the fearsome foursome trounce Foot Soldiers, Triceraton Warriors, and Rock Troops all the way to Dimension X!


Enjoy stunning full-color pixel art graphics and a vintage TMNT vibe that will rock you straight back to the awesome 80s. Every character, vehicle, weapon, item, and background is directly inspired by the 1987 TV show, making you feel like you hopped into the television -- with a dope mix of killer humor and action-packed adventures!


Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder's Revenge, is a wonderful nod to the universum of the titular TMNT, and the whole thing it presents is schweet.
A magical time machine to the '80s-'90s.
Fantabulous audio-video style and atmosphere of humor and epicness, a mega enjoyable but challenging brawler.
Bodacious playability and above all - funky fun!
Pixel art, music that warms the heart with a warm glow of nostalgia.
Cult characters with individuated moves, I can't wait for coop to kick the ass of some bad guys.
Each character's repertoire of moves is broad, yet uncomplicated and intuitive - kicks, jumps, dodges, grabs, blocks, special punches and combat is a satisfying dance between the villains.
I played literally a while - but a sample is enough for me to judge the whole thing.
And the whole thing...
I will sum it up in one word -


● Gnarly game design takes you back to the ’80s
● Beautiful full-color pixel art graphics
● Old-school gameplay enhanced with super-fresh mechanics
● Up to six players simultaneously
● Play with iconic TMNT characters and vehicles in diverse gameplay options
● Radical new story mode
● Title delicious as the pizza of a thousand cheeses!

AN AWESOME BLAST FROM THE PAST

This side-scrolling beat-em up brings back all the elements that defined gaming in the 90's - the nostalgia is unreal XD

Playing solo is an enjoyable enough experience with awesome retro graphics, a great soundtrack, and polished mechanics. The multiplayer however is where the game really comes to life with up to 6 friends or random online players kicking butt all over the screen (at times it can be difficult to tell where you are amongst the madness!). Finding a group is easy enough and I've been able to hop in games as well as have people join my games.

The story mode has some 'side quest' type elements as well as brief story snippets with a map you can navigate around. Arcade mode is just a straight-up jump in and whoop some ass experience.

10/10 no question.

The game is really good, the only negative thing that people complain about is that the game is short. Beat em ups are short games, and if you rush through the game you will beat it very quickly. The game is meant to be for fun and enjoy in groups. It's not meant to keep you busy. If play it for a while, blow of some steam, and then your done. Plenty of things to unlock in story mode, and it's where the game shines the most.

Now when it comes to it's source, this game holds true and if you like TMNT, you will love this game. If you like beat em ups, then you will love this game. If you are looking for a game that will last 100 hours, and it you consume your live, then this is not your game.

Posted: June 16, 2022
TMNT Shredder's Revenge is one of the best games i've played in the last 10 years. Its not trying to be anything else, other than just a fun game. If you played the original TMNT turtles in time, you'll find this an absolute joy.

The characters each have their own abilities, theres a slight progression system for each character. Coop allows for up to 6 players.

In the 3 hours it took my friend and I to finish the game in coop on the hardest difficulty, We ran into only afew glitches, at the latter half of the game, where my friend couldn't see Shredder and Shredder then couldn't damage him. But minus that, it ran perfect.

The art design is that of which you'd expect. This is just TMNT Turtles in Time but with a new coat of paint and afew new mechanics. The music of the game is fantastic and theres alot of callbacks to the show.

The only "real" complaint about the game and what'd prevent me from giving it a 10/10 vs a 9/10, is there isn't really "alot" to do, outside of just doing the 16 levels in the game. This isn't a game that you'll be sinking hundreds of hours into, after my first playthrough I finished with 17/30 achievements. And it doesn't change that much with each playthrough afterwards.

All in all, this is a perfect game for a friday night where you just want to sit down with your crew and have a blast for a night once you get that ocassional itch. It doesn't try to change the formula of the beat em up formula, instead it feels like a natural progression.

I hope that we get X-Men and the Simpsons that get this kinda love in the future.

Posted: June 18, 2022
I mean, you know why you're here. This is just a fun side scroller, nothing to add.


Positives:

- It's a great game overall, if you played the SNES game you're in for a treat. If you haven't, you're in for a whole pizza pie.

- Some new enemies to keep you on your toes, not as mashy as you'd think.

- Challenges are fun and make for extra objectives to keep an eye out.

- You can play with up to 5 mates. 6 player co-op madness.

- Super nostalgic and makes for a great love lettre to he original series and 90's pop culture.


Negatives:
- A bit short.

- Expected some branching paths when I read that there were multiple endings but it's just different endings with the characters you clear the game as.


Personal negatives:

- The new art is a bit of a miss for me.

- The npc side missions unlock nothing sadly, and aren't hard to finish if you're breaking everything.

- The addition of supers wasn't needed, they all do the same thing and my first play through was with a mate that spammed them. Reaching top score on every map. The salt was real as they say. If there is an option to turn them off please tell me.

Tl;dr: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder's Revenge is a successful throwback to side scroller beat'em'ups of the 90's. Get it if that is your cup.

9/10

Posted: July 17, 2022
Product received for free

I was curious to try out the game, as back in the day I've played a bunch of NES titles and watched parts of the TV show. By the time this review was written, I've finished the game 6 times, including playing on the highest difficulty.

Good Stuff
The combat has the right amount of audiovisual feedback, where all the character moves feel satisfying to perform. No matter which fighter you're picking, the animations are smooth and responsiveness is snappy. It's not too surprising, considering that animation keyframes are inspired by a variety of oldschool fighting games. One thing that does degrade with more players on screen is the ability to determine if you're being hit, as your character's yelp and sprite gets lost in the mishmash of effects and the most reliable way is force feedback, assuming that you're using a gamepad.

The art direction is solid with highly detailed, well animated, and eye-pleasing pixel art, that is consistent throughout the whole experience. It's easy to tell where the playing field is and the backgrounds, while are gorgeous, do not distract from the combat. Environmental hazards and destructible objects blend in well, it's possible to tell some apart by their animation or how they're marked, while a few others are more subtle in that regard. When there are a lot of characters on screen, especially during multiplayer, it's easy to lose track of yourself, but there's a dedicated button that briefly puts a mark above your sprite.

The soundtrack has a retro-feeling soundscape, featuring both instrumental and vocal tracks. Instrumental tracks sound like something out of an era-appropriate arcade cabinet or a home console, except without any channel or instrument limitations, so it's a combination of classic video game sound and modern techniques. The vocal tracks go all-out and aim for the early 90s feel, with professional production quality, so they are fitting and engaging. Example: "Panic in the Sky!".

The overall presentation of Shredder's Revenge remains at the top throughout your journey. The consistent high quality art, engaging soundtrack that fires you up for more action, all the references from the TV show, the fact that the original voice actors were hired to reprise their roles, responsive combat with a variety of familiar antagonists, the ability to blast through the game in a 6 player chaotic cooperative playthrough, all of it contributes towards making this a rather compelling game to consider.

The multiplayer system is fascinating, as it allows lobbies to have a mix of local and online players. I can't say I've seen a game before where the host plays, gives another gamepad to a friend, creates an online lobby and invites an online friend together with their own local friends. In other words, it's possible to populate 6 player slots without limiting the game to only online or offline players. This kind of approach to Co-Op alone should turn heads and is a commendable feature.

Shredder's Revenge is a short but sweet kind of experience. If you're looking for replayability, then the game offers character progression system, which is the grindiest part of the achievements. Trying out all characters and mastering the highest difficulty is the end-game and there's nothing beyond it, unless you're going for personal challenges like no damage runs. It's one of those titles that can be introduced to most people that game, so that would be a good way of occasionally revisiting the title.
I'm spoiled by the Streets of Rage 4's endless mode expansion and would like to see one here as well, but it's fine if the game remains as is: the original scope has been achieved, and it's a finished product.

The basic combat mechanics are shared across all available characters, and there are no distinct "classes". Since the basic fighting framework remains shared, you can pick whichever character you'd like, and you'll be able to perform more or less the same. Each character has their own speed, attack reach, a few changed attacks, and unique super attacks, but that's as far as it goes. After playing through with all the characters, I couldn't really pick a favorite, since the distinction was minimal.
There's no extra layer of depth that you can experience by having more varied character selection, but this also means that you can easily teach a person how to play effectively, and they're going to have fun within minutes.

Co-Op is a big appeal for a beat 'em up title, and Shredder's Revenge drops the pizza when it comes to online play. I wouldn't recommend playing this game through the online lobby system if you have a good internet connection with friends, as it would be a far better experience for everyone involved to use Parsec or Steam Remote Play.
This applies even if you're in the same country! The game de-synchs and the client's game is compromised: enemies teleport around in an attempt to "snap" back to their correct location, enemy thrown objects tend to hit way before they land on the player, bosses disappear or face the wrong direction when running, it's harder for the player to grab the pizza in the moving stages. As a pineapple on the pizza, the game's reported ping seems to be at least twice of what you'd expect to see.
Overall, the online play is not the worst experience ever, and you can finish the game like this even on the highest difficulty, but it leaves an impression that the game is far more buggy than it actually is. With Parsec, however, all of those problems go away and, aside from a bit of extra input latency, the game runs the way it should have been to begin with.

Haven't had any stability problems, no crashes throughout 20+ hours of local and online playtime. Xbox gamepads work well and the general input latency is excellent.
One nitpick that I do have is the scrolling smoothness. During most of my playthoughs I've noticed that whenever the camera moves, the motion contains microstutters, while the hardware utilization is rather low and even the reported frame time graph is often stable. This can be most easily observed during the stage selection screen by moving the turtle van around. I believe this also plagues the scrolling during the stages themselves. Depending on how sensitive you are towards frame pacing, this might be a non-issue for you.

Shredder's Revenge is easily the best TMNT game I've ever played: it's easy to pick up and play, the visual style is appealing and is inspired by the TV show, the combat is responsive and satisfying, the development team went through the trouble of having the original TV cast to reprise their voice acting roles, the soundtrack is period-appropriate, is engaging and fits the game nicely.
What I'd want to see addressed is the netcode utilized in this game, as it's the biggest weakness of this title and is not a fair experience to someone who is joining your lobby. Another nicety would be completely fluid scrolling smoothness. Unfortunately, by the time they will address these issues (if they ever will to begin with), I won't be playing the game anymore.
Finally, I know it's not really in their plans, but an endless mode like in Streets of Rage 4 would be a fun addition to the game. Have turtles be stuck in a new Temperstra arcade cabinet or something.

Review copy provided by Dotemu SAS.

Posted: July 3, 2022
Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder’s Revenge is simply joyful.

Having grown up watching the TMNT cartoon in the late 1980s and early 1990s, and played the arcade game and its console version on the NES, I’m definitely the target audience of Shredder’s Revenge. Thankfully, the game does a good job in stirring up happy childhood memories, and features quality of life improvements that befit gamers my age.

Sure, you can play Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: The Arcade Game on arcade and NES emulators, but that shouldn’t stop you from playing this game. Shredder’s Revenge combines elements of the first NES TMNT game and the arcade titles into an appealing package. From travelling in the Turtle Van on the overhead mission map, to the colourful TV animation art style, to combat moves like throwing Foot Soldiers toward the screen, almost everything about Shredder’s Revenge is designed to remind us of the golden age of video games.

Is capitalizing on nostalgia? Absolutely, but what’s wrong with that? When was the last time PC gamers had a good game? features a Story Mode that saves game progress, so I no longer need to finish the game in one sitting like I did with on an NES that’s on the verge of overheating. There’s also the option to play multiplayer via crossplay, so I can play with my friends who play on PC (via Steam or Epic Games) and Xbox. No need to buy multiple copies of the game for different platforms!



That said, this game is absolutely best enjoyed when played with other people. I had a blast playing with a couple of my friends plus a few random strangers who joined our session. The game rewards teamwork, allowing players to revive fallen teammates, share health, and execute team attacks. It’s a refreshing change of pace for online multiplayer. I also didn’t experience much lag during online sessions despite my at times questionable Internet connection.

However, I’m not completely blinded by the rose-coloured glasses that is nostalgia. At the time of writing, is lacking in a few areas. While I appreciate the ability to play multiplayer via crossplay, I couldn’t set up a private session so that my friends on Xbox could join. Sessions that I could join had no information about quality of connection and difficulty level. The setup for multiplayer could definitely use more advanced configurations.

As vibrant and charming the graphics are, the accompanying sound effects seem hollow. Dialogues, as well as sounds of hitting enemies and objects, and explosions lack depth, making the action less exciting than it really is. Hopefully the developers will patch the game up with better quality sound files in the near future.



Lastly, as one of my friends pointed out, what does offer after you’ve finished the game? As a team of five, we finished Story Mode at normal level of difficulty in about 3 hours. While I’m incentivize to complete the various side missions and try out other playable characters (especially with Casey Jones unlocked after finishing Story Mode), not all players would feel the same. As a result, as fun as is, I can see how some players would find the game lacking post-endgame content at the time of this review.

Flaws aside, I found easy to pick up and play. It’s a delight to play a game that doesn’t demand huge commitment of my time, but still delivers on the fun. At the same time, discovering new combat moves by button mashing, noticing nods and homages to previous games, seeing characters that I haven’t thought about since the 1990s, being able to finally play as Splinter, April O’Neil and Casey Jones in a game, working as a team to unleash super attack moves on enemies, and relishing the chaotic combat in six-player multiplayer sessions have also brought me much amusement. It’s very satisfying to play this game.

If you’ve ever been interested in as a kid, pick up and give it a go. I’m hopeful that the developers will polish and bulk it up with future patches and additional content or game modes. Still, even as it is at the time of writing, this game is worth your attention and time. What are you waiting for – go kick some shell!

Posted: March 8, 2020
200 character summary
Jackbox Party Pack 3 is another nice collection of party games for 1 - 8 players locally. Like the first 2 it has the same great narrator knows the right thing to say, A must have for party lovers.

Jackbox Party Pack
Like the first 2 games this game consists of 5 party games, Quiplash, Trivia Murder Party, Guesspionage, Tee K.O. and ♥♥♥♥♥' It. Like always some are awesome and some are a bit less amazing, I will write a bit about each one of them. I will start with the better ones and work towards the rest.

We have covered this game before in JBPP2 It is the same game, new questions. Quiplash 2 can be played with 3 - 8 players Here ever round every player gets 2 questions where there are no right answers, Just funniest answers, Afterwards everyone gets presented the questions one by one with the given answers. Everyone is able to vote on the best answer, Best is ofcourse relative, Sometimes the choice can be hard, Sometimes there is a split in the room, It is funny to see what other people think is funny.

This is the third Quiplash game, Quiplash 1 was the first and Quiplash XL was that game with all DLC and some extras, Quiplash 2 is a completely new game, So if you liked any of the earlier Quiplash games your should certainly get this one. It just gives you new questions, It is like they say; If it ain't broke, Don't fix it.

Guesspionage can be played with 2 to 8 players, The game is about guessing the percentage of people who do or believe something, It can be very personal or sometimes even holy, One needs to guess and then the rest can say it is higher, lower, much higher or much lower. The closer you are to the real number the more points you get.

What makes this game fun is the reaction, People mostly show a little faith in humanity but get disappointed in the end, But how disappointed will they be, It is very hard to guess what the general public thinks, It creates a lot of, Noooo, Really? Wtf.. moments. I don't know where they got these polls, but some results are pretty flabbergasting.

Tee K.O. can be played with 3 to 8 players, Here you have to design your own T shirts by drawing something and writing some text. There will be some voting and afterwards they will battle it out Mortal Kombat Style, Shirt vs Shirt. You just have to pick one of the 2 shirts on the screen and the shirt with the most votes wins. There is also a bit of a pokemon vibe in there somewhere.

The game can spark a lot of laughs, And some shirts designs are so good that they should be printed in real life, Maybe Jackbox should strike up a deal with T shirt printing companies. Mostly the drawings end up a bit primitive, but the punchlines are mostly funny.

Trivia Murder Party can be played wth 1 to 8 players, It is like a Trivia Pursuit game with a spooky horror theme, It is a great Trivia game with some extreme measures if you answer a question wrong. People get taken apart often to battle it out. Only 1 person can escape and be the winner

This game is a lot of fun, It has a lot of side steps compared to a regular trivia game, It is kind of brutal, Answering a question wrong can cost you one of your fingers or your life, It succeeds at creating a lot of tension, but blows it off with the funny comments of the narrator.

♥♥♥♥♥' it can be played with 3 to 6 players, Here everyone gets asked a few questions, But one person gets different questions which have the same type of answer, lets say the answer is a number or a month. It is up to the group to figure out who the faker is, If the faker does not get caught he scores a lot of points, The other players get points by voting on the real faker. Everyone will be the faker once, So it is important you do not reveal yourself if you did not get caught.

It is funny to see how people behave different when they are the faker, Some people can hide it pretty well, The answers might give you a clue, Things can look extremely out of place, It is a bit of luck, but a good way to get to know people.

The game runs fine, It is not that we need the framerate, but 30 fps feels like a slideshow when you are used to 120. The game has absolutely no issues, crashes or bugs, The online connectivity works great and using your mobile phone as a controller works just as fine, Surely there is a small lag, But it is barely noticable and it won't make a difference in first or second place.

The third game in this collection is a great one, I still think the first 2 collections where better, But this one is certainly not one to be missed, It has 5 more unique games to play with your friends. If you like party games it is a must have.

Posted: June 17, 2019
It's a very solid collection of party game. In short, there's a bit of everything: creative games, a trivia game, a more social one and I guess a nerdy one.

Quiplash 2 is as fun as ever (for those who don't know the first one, it's basically a game where you have to answer a prompt; like Cards Against Humanity, but with complete freedom on your answer). It's a bit more demanding on the creative side than the other games though, so it's best to play when everyone feels energetic.

♥♥♥♥♥' It is probably my favorite game of the collection, and the most "social" one. Each player sees a question on their screen and has to answer it after a countdown (it can be by raising your hand in a yes/no question for example). The trick is that one of the players is a faker and cannot see the question, so they have to try and guess what they should do. People have to find out who the faker is, so you might have to justify yourself if the others find your answer suspicious and very unlike you...

The Trivia Murder Party is a trivia game with people being eliminated each round or so, and playing mini-games in between rounds to see who should survive. The formula is fun, but I have to admit that my friends and I don't know the answers to most of the questions, so it's a bit annoying and it's mostly a guessing game (maybe it's because we're not Americans or that we're not the age target, I don't know).

Guesspionage is interesting. Players have to guess a percentage on a variety of statistics (they're not dull statistics, but things based on surveys like "How many people wear a hat on a bad hair day?"). The closest you are to the actual number, the more points you gain.

Finally, Tee K.O. is the weirdest of the lot. You have to design a couple of shirt logos, then write up a couple of slogans. Afterwards, all the submissions from all players are shuffled, and you're give different combinations. Find the funniest, and then people have to vote. It's not the most competitive game, and it's really unique.

Posted: September 28, 2017
Since there are 5 party games in one game I'm going to be reviewing them all and thankfully for me, I have tried out all the games whether that be sacrificing my friends' time to play some of these games or playing it with my family members.

Let's first start off with Quiplash 2: Whether it be family members, college mates or steam users this game is crowned as the best thing in existence. This just like the first predecessor is really fun and enjoyable, there are lot of new things that haven't been introduced in the first game, such as the fact that you can create your own prompts, I have so far 2 episodes I made with a lot of crazy prompts such as "help! A gargoyle stole my cheese pizza". There's also new weird characters that you randomly play as such as a weird turqoise cat or a gray vampire coffin or a yellow (demonic voiced?) star. They also changed The Last Lash level, instead of getting a prompt you're given either an acro prompt, a comic prompt or a word prompt and not only that players award the answers in medals so that is something new.

Up next is Trivia Murder Party: This game is one of those trivia fact game host show things that would see on your television. Only Trivia Murder Party takes place in a saw themed place where players play as plushies to try and escape, everyone gets a multiple choice trivia to answer, if one or more plushies doesn't the answer correct they would have to survive "The Killing Floor (not the game Killing Floor) where in The Killing Floor, players/player have to play mini games of death whether it would be answering as much easy math problems as you can or spinning the loser wheel or remembering patterns.

Next up is Tee KO: Tee KO is similiar to Quiplash but only instead of filling out prompts you are drawing t-shirts and filling out slogans for these shirts. Once you've done that, other people are going to use your as well as some other players artworks and slogans to make their T-Shirt. Once they've done that then it's voting time to see what T-Shirt is better than the other one. This game is pretty complicated in my opinion, a lot of people I showed this one were pretty confused by it.

Next it is Guesspionage: Guesspionage is a game that is all about percentages, how high or low it is. One player is given a question and has to estimate what percentage he or she thinks is appropriate for that question. Once they've done that, other players in the game are given two options of whether the percentage should be higher or lower. When they finish doing that the real percentage is given out to players to see if the player given the estimation was higher, lower or spot on. It has some pretty interesting gameplay, I must say.

Last but not least is ♥♥♥♥♥' it: ♥♥♥♥♥' it has a very 60's cartoon look, in this game players have to work together on finding the faker. Players are given tasks on their phones, tablets or laptops while one player (which that player is the faker) gets a different one, it is up to the faker's job to try and blend with the crowd. Some of these tasks are: pointing to one or another, making weird faces, holding up a number of fingers or raising your hand. Once players are told to stop doing these tasks, they have to vote on who the faker really is. This game is definitely NOT recommended to anyone who wants to play this game over online because of these tasks given on your phone.

And now the final conclusion on these games:
Quiplash 2 is great especially that they added the option of creating prompts, Trivia Murder Party is fun, Tee KO is pretty confusing at first but eventually you'll get used to it, Guesspionage is pretty good, ♥♥♥♥♥ it is alright but not terrible.

Overall: buy Jackbox Party Pack 3, buy some beer, buy some friends and have a wicked party.

Cheers

Jackbox Party Pack 3 is a massive step up in quality for the series, however I find it difficult whether to recommend it or not. If you were only able to buy one game in the series, this would be a great choice, however if you intend to buy multiple, there's only really one good game in here that you can't get anywhere else. The 3 major standouts are Quiplash 2, a comedic game where you answer funny prompts and vote for the best answers from your friends, Trivia Murder Party, a trivia game with survival horror elements, and Tee K.O, a game about creating the best T-shirt. However, the first two both have sequels later down the line, leaving Tee K.O. the only major exclusive. The other two games in this package are Guesspionage, a lacklustre trivia game, and ♥♥♥♥♥' It, a mafia-style game that has to be played in the same room, and is outdone by a similar game later in the series. So, if you are looking to get into the Jackbox franchise and want to start with one simple pack to try it out, I would recommend this game. However, if you are already a fan of the franchise and just want to expand your collection, I would just skip over this one. 6/10

Posted: July 4, 2017
So I’m going to base this review on my personal and my friends’ opinions when we got to play the game together, this is going to be a partial review because we didn’t play ♥♥♥♥♥ it as I’ve read from reviews that the game isn’t fun at all.

Overall, the game is really enjoyable to play with your friends for a couple of hours, this game brought us some laugh out loud moments and really gives you that feeling of togetherness when you have your friends over. What’s great about The Jackbox Party Pack is that you don’t need to prepare anything like extra controllers or anything like that to play with multiple friends on the couch; all you need is a laptop, an internet connection, and smartphones which I’m sure everyone has. What I also like about this game is that it caters to everyone; be it your family or friends, and is relatively easy to get into, as friends who watched for just a couple of minutes would already understand how each game goes (some of my friends aren't really good at english). Now, on to each individual game the pack offers;

Quiplash; This game is the ultimate source of laugh out loud moments that you can have with your friends since it gives you the option to make your own prompts where you can add some inside jokes that are sure to give your group a good laugh.

Trivia Murder Party; This game has the longest lasting appeal as me and friends have played this game over and over for hours without getting bored. However, as many of the consumers have stated, the trivias are mostly ‘American’ trivias that most people who lived outside the US won’t get. For example, the game asks which presidents were democrats and which of these people were once hosts of a show like Family Feud. It’s a damn shame because I really wanted my friends to not get confused 80% of the time by these questions and actually have a clue of what they should choose as the answer.

As you can probably tell from the name of the game, this is a game about guessing, as in guessing percentages. The guessing happens the whole game, it gets boring fast and it doesn’t really give you any sense of competition or achievement when you actually win the game since it basically crowns the best guesser.

My review for this game will be taken by a quote from my friend; “If we drew the shirts and make all the words, why is our shirt just mixed pictures and words taken from someone else’s efforts?”. This game isn’t fun because all your hard work will be used by someone else to win the game and even if you win, you won’t win by using your own drawings; this game is unsatisfactory and the scoring system is really confusing.

, Get this game for Quiplash and Trivia Murder Party, and get it if you have friends who aren’t really into games but is looking to meet up and have fun, or if you have any friends at all for that matter.

Posted: October 6, 2019
TLDR get this pack if you got none yet or you want a good variety of fun casual games to play at a party


Quiplash 2's a great introduction game, and people can understand the rules easily. You're given a prompt - answer it humorously, then fight off against another player who had to answer it. Whoever's the funniest wins by player vote. That's all there is to it - the final round gives every player the same prompt and people vote for the best three answers. A very simple game that does get stale quickly (unlike other player-prompt joke games like StI from pack 4), but one that defines what the Jackbox series is - simple and casual fun.

Trivia Murder Party's questions are varied, and unlike YDKJ, you won't be asked as many questions about obscure pieces of media - the questions are more casual trivia. The catch of this trivia game is that failing a question puts you into a minigame for survival. The more questions you answer correctly and the more minigames you survive, the more cash you get - cash puts you closer to the winning condition at the final round of the game. At first glance, it might seem like the goal is to survive - A catchup mechanic for dead players ensured that survivors and ghosts have the same opportunities to win the game, however. Don't discourage players that died, or they'll catchup and smack you.

♥♥♥♥♥' It is the highlight of this game, and a great cure for social anxiety. Sit around in a circle, preferably with a group of people you know well enough, and start the game. You'll be asked mundane questions, like "Raise your hand if you ordered food in the last week". The catch is that one of you doesn't know what the question was, and has to fake it. Figure out who's faking it, and you win. Fail, and he wins. You'll learn quite a bit about which one of you is a good liar, and which one of you would like eggs as a birthday gift. It's a game you should definitely try - even if you fumble or stress when you see you're the Faker, that's part of the fun.

Tee K.O. is arguably one of the better drawing games of the series - although it has little appeal to those who like winning. Players draw a shirt design, write slogans, then receive other players' slogans and drawings. From there, they make "cool" shirts and whoever combined theirs the best wins by vote. This game takes a bit more time to get to the fun part, so maybe run it towards the middle of the game night.

Guesspionage is definitely the black sheep of this pack - you're prompted to guess the percentage of a quirky question. Say, what percentage of the population sleeps with a nightlight on? 10? 20? 75? Guess, and the closer you are to the right answer, the more points you get. There's not much else to it, and it could be fun once or twice, but the lack of variety kills this game.

However, one bad game does not discredit the other 4. This pack is, simply put, good. The best one if you're looking to pick one up and you never played Jack before. Newcomers can play Quiplash and TMP, while more advanced players can play ♥♥♥♥♥ and TKO. And no one should play Guesspionage more than once.

Posted: October 18, 2020
DISCLAIMER: This review is written by a European player. My opinion might (and probably will) differ from a player from this game's target audience: The American player base. Please also note that this review was written in 2020, as though several other packs have released after that.

Do I recommend the Jackbox Party Pack 3?
- Yes, absolutely.

Individual game review:

Quiplash 2:
- A classic of the Jackbox Games.
- Simple to understand and fun.
- The third round isn't particularly excellent compared to the 1st, let alone 3rd game.
- Includes a mode where you can create your own prompts.
As always, Quiplash is this game where you can play and never get bored of it, as it is just fun no matter what. The 3rd round prompts however don't give as good of an experience, they are often restrictive and difficult to write over. The nice addition is a mode where you can make your own prompts for round 1 and 2 but not for the 3rd, again. My personal note is 7/10.

Trivia Murder Party:
- Trivia based as the name suggests.
- It can still be played around even if you don't know American trivia.
- Very cool, funny and cliche murder theme.
- Very competitive and tense (especially at the end).
Despite being mainly based of American Trivia that is beyond my European reach, the game still can prove very fun especially since you can get away with ignorance thanks to the mini-games that offer survival options. The last round is very tense and the whole game offers a lot of fun, very surprisingly. The 2nd one is even better though, if you have it. Note that the audience plays as an extra player and can win! Personal note is .


- Chill and easy.
- Note that it uses American data.
A good game to play when waiting for more players or in between two intensive games. It calls for the players to guess the percentage of what people do in their daily lives (in the US). Relatively fun and easy to understand. Note that if you're a streamer or just have at least 5 people in the audience, the data is based of the audience's answers! Personal note is .


- Drawing game.
- Can be very long.
- High replayability and unlimited creativity.
- Can be quite fun.
In this game you basically have to create tee-shirts by drawing and writing names then combining the ones of other players. A round can take something like 20~30 minutes, but when the players really put the best of their creativity, it can become hilarious. My personal note is .


- 6 players max.
- Really has to be played in a real life setting with all the players in the same room.
- Some of the tasks are unbalanced (some are too easy to fake, some are too difficult to fake).
- Fun once the players grasp the concept.
The game I unfortunately struggle to play even though it has to be one of my favourites because it has to be played with other people physically present. It really calls for people's knowledge about you to deduce who is the faker and catch them. The first few tasks don't explicitly state who is the fakerr and caught some people out about it, that could be fixed. Personal note is .
(note, Faking' it and fakerr is to prevent the automatic swear filter from acting in what are not swear words...)


An overall good and consistent pack of interesting games. Definitely not the best of them but a very solid one at that. Highly recommended to have at one point in your collection.

Posted: October 18, 2016
Again, as always, Jackbox has produced a great group of really fun games to play. Some of them are especially great

Trivia Murder Party is great fun and tense as well-it really makes you double guess your own actions and your friends actions.

Quiplash 2 is just as great as the original, probably better in fact. You can write your own prompts and the game is just improved in every way I can think of.

Tee K.O. is an interesting concept of a game, where you design a few t-shirts and then come up with a few random titles-someone else will pair the two and then it will be voted on and the person who paired them will win, not the person who designed it, which we found odd but interesting. This doesn't make the game any less fun though, it is a great game

♥♥♥♥♥' It is also a good game-however, you need to be able to see each other perfectly. Considering we were playing over Skype and therefore I could only see one person at a time because I was sharing my screen, this made the game a bit more difficult and so we agreed to say what we would do. It is an interesting game though, where there a different rounds that you can pick-for example, you will have to write something, hold up a certain number of fingers or point at someone. Everyone gets given the same prompt to do something, apart from the faker who either gets given a roughly similar prompt (for example in the writing round, one prompt was "the last book you read" whereas the fakers was "your favourite childhood book") or no prompt at all and they just have to try a persuade people that they are not the faker. However I am not entirely certain how the points system works.

Another good point is that once you have finished the game and select to play again with the same players, it will remember and you will not have to sit through the introduction again-in fact, in the Trivia Murder Party this is incoperated into the game and if you lost in the previous game-and thus "died"-it will add "Jr" to the end of your name.

As well as this when you log onto the Jackbox.tv website and join a game, the format of the webpage will change dependent on what game you are playing, which is a nice feature.

You also have the ability to look at the answers at the end of the game via the webpage. In Tee K.O. It even gives you the option of buying the T-Shirts that everyone so lovingly designed.

All in all, another great Jackbox Party Pack that is super fun to play with friends, with new more experimental games that are just great fun to play with your friends.

I was raised in a very Italian family. My grandparents spoke Italian more often than English despite them both being born here in the US. A very conservative and very Catholic sort of crowd, the whole lot of them. So when I went to visit my grandmother and she stopped me before entering the house to sit me onto a foldout lawn chair the last thing that I was expecting was the conversation that followed. She started by telling me (at the time a young boy of 13) that I might have hair on my balls... "What grandma?!" I replied. She continued "Just let me talk for a bit- You might have noticed some hair on your balls. I noticed that you have some puffy nipples and I was afraid that you were growing breasts."
"Wh-Why are you saying this, grandma? I don't have breasts" I asked.
"Well I asked my doctor about your puffy nipples and he said that you might have hair on your balls" she stated.
"Why are you talking about my balls and nipples?" I wanted to run away so badly.
"What was I supposed to do? Am I just supposed to have a grandson with boobs?!" She exclaimed.
"Can we stop whatever this is?" I pleaded.
"It's called poOOoberty and some boys get puffy nipples but not breasts" she continued.
"It's called puberty, grandma. And I know. I'm good. Thank you."
This is how nipples destroyed my family. Because before that day I had a lovely grandmother that didn't talk about my balls and nipples. Then I came of age. The age of adulthood where your grandmother with bad English talks to everyone about your nipples. Doctors, Aunts, Uncles, cousins- They all heard of my puffy nipples... I wish that I had grown breasts. It would have made the stress worth it.
Jackbox 3 is your puffy nipples. A coming of age tale that might possibly destroy your family. But if you're lucky you'll come out of it with a new set of breasts.... Or something.

Posted: August 16, 2018
The second best entry in the Jackbox Party Pack series, the third installmant yet again features five whacky party / trivia games which can lighten up the mood pretty much anywhere except within an Amish community. They hate computers and stuff you know

In Quiplash 2 you unleash your gift of gab even more than in the first entry, adding hundreds of new questions to the already quite vast title with the ability to put in even scores of your own custom questions.

Trivia Murder Party mixes the usual YDKJ trivia quiz with minigames if you answer wrongly, spicing up the quiz but ultimately turning out to be the weakest entry of this collection. Still, "weakest" means it is still lots of fun for quite a few rounds with friends.

In Guesspionage you guess about statistical values. Awesome for statistic nerds but might be mildly uneventful for most other people. The friendship ruination factor is minimal here

Tee K.O. combines elements from Drawful with elements from Quiplash. You design your own T-Shirt with a witty catchphrase and use it to battle other peoples designs. Extremely fun until creativity starts taking a downward spiral, which, depending on the people you're playing with, could take forever or mere minutes.

♥♥♥♥♥' It is a digital alternative to Truth or Dare, but just being Truth or Lie. Each player is assigned a role and has to answer depending on their role. The aim of the game is for the group to correctly guess who has been assigned the liar role. A really great title to embarass other people or just simply learn more about them. Usually both at the same time. The second best entry in this pack in my opinion and one of the most interesting games in the entire series.

The Jackbox Party Pack 3 has probably the most balanced out games of the packs and is definitely worth your time if you're a fan of trivia and party games.

i've played all four packs, and this pack is probably the second best one. i'll go over each game individually:

Quiplash 2:
in this game, you get a prompt and try to answer it in a funny way. pretty universal game if you're playing with normies. highly recommend this.

Trivia Murder Party:
pretty simple trivia game with minigames if you fail to answer the question correctly. most of the questions come down to pure guess, and some of the questions are way too easy. i guess it heavily depends on the people you're playing with, but overall it's not the best game in the pack, for sure.

Guesspionage:
an estimation game based on statistics. it's a pretty boring game, admittedly, but it's an interesting concept.

Tee K.O.:
a drawing game/write something funny game. the game starts out strong, but lingers off after the first round, and then becomes boring. might be fun if you're playing with a bunch of artsy people.

♥♥♥♥♥' It:

Posted: December 31, 2022
Summary:
Absolutely fantastic game pack. Trivia Murder Party and Quiplash are peak Jackbox, Tee K.O. is a hidden gem, Guesspionage is good, although ♥♥♥♥♥' It is badly implemented, but it does have a good idea. But buy the Jackbox Party Starter instead, believe me.

Ranking of games:
- Quiplash: Awesome
- Trivia Murder Party: Awesome

- Tee K.O.: Really great
(The average 5 and earlier Jackbox game goes here)
-Guesspionage: Good


-♥♥♥♥♥' It: Bad

Trivia Murder Party was born here and it's easy to see how it was such a hit. The horror aesthetic really gives it a fancy shine, it's a much better trivia game that You Don't Know Jack, and the challenges you have to do to survive are really varied and interesting. The final round at the end of a game is such a blast that will have your heart . Amazing game, don't skip it!

Quiplash is a classic, and has never been a miss with any group I've played with. At some point a prompt will bring the funny guy in each player, and when a glorious joke happens, it'll turn into an instant inside joke. I liked the final round, especially Comiclash. Definitely great fun for everyone!

Tee K.O. is overlooked by a simple reason: the start of each game doesn't have much going on, just people drawing and writing. That puts a damper on the fun, but the payoff is great: the combinations of the lines and images will sometimes throw out memorable jewels, especially when someone writes/draws inside jokes. Good for playing after Quiplash, then!

Guesspionage has a good concept, but for some reason, it hasn't been a big hit on any group. Regardless, it has been fun and entertaining. The last round is certainly the best! Oddly enough, sometimes the percentage guesses of the whole group are way off. Bias on maybe us, the sampling group (maybe not varied enough) or both?

♥♥♥♥♥' it has potential and not much else, because of really bad implementation. The concept: foolin' friends from knowin' you're the faker by tryin' to explain why you did an action, actions which are varied and will change the game a lot. Really good, right? Except the faker will almost always win because everyone has to choose them at the same time to catch them! The only way to have a chance is makin' a house rule, but that ruins the best sleuth prize and it's a solution outside the game...

9/10

We have to talk about The Jackbox Party Starter. It has the three best games from this pack, except the two best ones are in their recent, improved, final version. Not only that, because of the lower amount of games, it has a much lower price, allowing new Jackbox players to afford it, while being just as good as a whole and way better per game. It's a better deal on every way. Despite how much I love this pack, I would skip it if the Starter Pack was available when I bought it.

Posted: December 28, 2022
Jackbox Party Pack 3 is a collection of party games that can be played by a large group of people using their own devices (such as smartphones and tablets). It includes five games:

Quiplash 2: Players are given prompts and must come up with the funniest or most creative responses. Other players then vote on their favorite responses.

Trivia Murder Party: Players must answer trivia questions to stay alive, but if they get a question wrong, they must participate in a mini-game to avoid being "killed" by the host.

Guesspionage: Players must guess the percentage of people who have answered a series of questions correctly.

Tee K.O.: Players design their own t-shirt designs and then vote on their favorites.

♥♥♥♥♥' It: One player is given a secret task that they must complete while the other players try to figure out who the "faker" is.

Overall, Jackbox Party Pack 3 is a fun and entertaining game for a group of friends or family looking for a social and interactive gaming experience.

Posted: January 15
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I don't want to seem too giddy, but I think this has the potential to be what train simmers were waiting for. This is already a good train sim, and it is just the beginning - I am very excited for what is to come.
Dovetail Games had the monopoly over train driving simulation for years now, and we got used to the way they do things. But this is a whole other story, this seems to be a train sim that puts the community at the center.

After just three sessions of driving, I am glad for the many things this sim does right from the get-go. You can FEEL the weight of the train you're driving; the sounds are very good (some trains more than others but still). You have long, proper routes right away, routes that you can easily have a 2-3-4 hour session driving from end to end, none of that 25 minutes and you're out of track nonsense. And the graphics are good, the two routes provided seem detailed and lively. And this is just an early access release.
At first I was disappointed with the routes seeming to be deserted, but then I learned that there is no traffic in single player yet, and when you play multiplayer - you have the full timetable running always, whether driven by other players or by AI. Talking to real people manning the signal boxes, working together to solve issues - all of it is just a joyous experience. My attitude towards multiplayer in train sims was always "meh", but just a couple of sessions with this sim had completely changed my mind. It gives a sense of occasion to every drive, and it is probably mostly the way I will play this game going forward.

As for the weird people that are screaming in their reviews that this game is too expensive for early access - they must be delirious. This costs less than one single Train Sim World route addon, after DTG's latest price hike, and it comes with TWO full, long routes and four or five different drivable trains, As opposed to DTG's "one route one train for more money" policy. This is excellent value. And I hardly encountered any bugs in the 8 hours I've put into this game so far.

Negatives? No raildriver (or other controller) support, somewhat lackluster tutorials (I still don't know what is the proper set up order for the pendolino), lackluster single player mode (for now) with no AI traffic or ability to set the time, season or weather of a service. Track sounds, outside sounds and cab sway are important features that are not yet properly implemented. But seriously, most of this are things that just haven't been implemented YET, and are probably planned.

Big thumbs up. If the team keeps a steady development pace, this game is going to take over world of train simulation (no pun intended :)). Especially after the editor becomes available and user-generated content starts populating the game.

Posted: February 3
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
What is there to say?I've spent 20+ hours as a dispatcher, because I really enjoy the signalling aspect of it, and there's literally nothing to say except "wow, this FINALLY happened. TSW3 may have a very good competitor".Fair warning - especially if you're not Polish - you WILL have to do some basic reading to understand the regulations, signage, etc. However, I find it weird how people are complaining!Us polish people have always had to put up with sims that are based in the UK, USA, Germany etc and had to deal with a lack of internal documentation too! We've always had to look up guides, and you WILL have to here as well. That's tough, but the official forum has many incredible player-made guides.TSW, TS etc have one issue - replayability. Sure, you can do different scenarios, but after a while you'll get bored of a route - and buy another one (for money!). The multiplayer here is EVERYTHING I wanted, finally getting the ability to communicate with others and organise things - and wow has it been a joyous experience!Both on English and Polish servers, organising, calling and VC'ing with other dispatchers trying to organise peak times has been incredible. Being able to talk to drivers, help them organise - and from the reverse, being organised while also having to deal with driving is not something I've seen before. Having real people there allows for some really cool operations, like wrong-track driving, double platform departures and depot movements/schedule organisation.The fact that this game has over 300km of actually beautifully recreated track is incredible! Updates happen every 2-3 days with many bug fixes, new signalling zones among other things.CONSThere are some bugs. There aren't many locomotives. The game was meant to come out in full but came out in early access. There are **quite a few** server issues when the server is filled almost/full.MULTIPLAYER 9/10GRAPHICS 9/10PERFORMANCE 7/10 (has DLSS, LOD optimisation, render distance - really useful!)DISPATCHING 9/10DRIVING 7/10OVERALL: A solid 8/10, with improvements this could really be THE train sim.========================================================Update 24/2/23========================================================I have spent additional 60-odd hours on SimRail. Since then, new locomotives, dispatching boxes and improvements have been added. The server issues are now non-existent. The developers often talk on Discord and discuss with people, sometimes giving sneak peeks (especially the defacto community manager).This game, community and developer rock. Seriously. Updates have been released ~weekly, and each patch brings a lot of new things and improvements.The community is very welcoming and nice (at least the Polish side, can't speak for EN/DE/FR but I'm sure they're great too) and I've met people who I have been able to share my passion with outside of SimRail.========================================================Update 26/3/23========================================================Hello friends. I've basically made it my tradition to update this review every month. I've played an additional 50 hours - and although there isn't as much to report to in terms of improvements to last month, there have still been improvements and passenger simulation. A big update is coming probably this week, and I'll likely update my review **again** following it's release. Thanks for the awards and recommendations :D remember, comments are on so feel free to discuss.

Posted: April 3
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Yeah, it might be good to read this before purchasing the game. If you are used to having the world of the train simulators or anything from Dovetail.

I want to start that this game looks really good. The trains are well modeled. Same for the gameplay. It contains realistic sounds. And there are countless routes available for you to take when you start playing online. And to play dispatcher. Who wouldn't want that?

This train simulator is very unique because of its ability to play online. You literally run into each other. Sometimes you have situations where you are at a red signal because the train traffic controller sometimes has difficulty with the busy train traffic. I like that. And realistically done.

There are some drawbacks, it's an early access trial for a reason. The servers the game runs on sometimes need to be reset because it crashes. Also the game itself doesn't run smoothly, every 2 minutes (in my case) I have framedrops. And sometimes everything crashes. So be aware of cases like this, but the developers are actively working on it and patching the game very regularly. So I expect that these kinds of problems will be solved within a few months. Also, not all sounds are equally good in the game. For example, it's better to stay in the cabin with the camera, because that's when the sounds come out best. When you go out of the cabin with the camera, I think the sounds of the train become a bit fake. You don't really hear the wheels going over the rails outside, you don't hear the wind and the engine sound isn't really different from what it sounds like inside when you're outside. Something that will not really happen with Dovetail, because almost all sounds will be present when the package is released.

So all in all, don't think this is Dovetail's second train sim world, but this is a young simulator ready to take on the claim of being one of the best train simulators. I think this simulator has a great future ahead with many improvements, features and trains and routes. I'm very, very excited about what's to come.

Another small thing: the developers don't speak English originally, the tutorial are in English, just like the rest of the simulator. But sometimes they are quite confusing in that they sometimes miss a certain vocabulary to explain something (My opinion), and unfortunately not all trains have tutorials available yet. I therefore advise you to pay close attention, and to use the internet if you can't figure it out.

So I think I recommend the game, but keep in mind the things I've mentioned so you don't expect too much from it. Perhaps it is better to wait until the game is completely finished, and the problems are fixed, to fully guarantee that the game will continue to run and remain fun to play.

Posted: January 13
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Treat this as more of a neutral review. I don't think it deserves a thumbs down, but I'm not sure I want to give it a thumbs up yet, either.

I played several hours of the game's multiplayer playtest, and despite a tiny bit of jank, I enjoyed it overall. The simulation, graphics, and multiplayer functionality are great (despite some occasional disconnects). There's also a nice variety of complexity within both the locomotives and dispatcher stations.

However, I don't think the game was quite ready for release. The two trains they added since the playtest have no tutorials, some of the text and narration is still in Polish, the audio can be weird at times, and loads of stations don't yet have operable dispatcher booths (meaning the engaging ones are almost always taken). It's also a bit ridiculous how long some scenarios are considering there's no saving, but you can get around that by taking over trains in multiplayer.

These issues make it hard to say whether it's worth buying just yet. It definitely needs more content and polish, but I've personally had my money's worth of playtime already, and it's not overly expensive for what you get (especially compared to Dovetail's offerings). It's also good to support competition in such a niche market.

TL;DR: If you really like train sims and want something new, you'll probably be happy with this.

Posted: October 17
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
关于火车模拟品类
火车模拟品类始终是个比较小众硬核的品类，有着一群核心铁杆粉。本作的开发商PlayWay之前开发过不少模拟器游戏，这是第一次接触到火车模拟，这部作品可以说是对于Dovetail Games这样一个会在Train Sim World一部作品里出加起来接近上万块的接近上百个DLC的品类垄断者的革命。

欢迎关注 网易UU鉴赏家培养计划
极速畅玩，联机日友，加速社区，记得来UU哦_(:з」∠)_

火车模拟游戏的受众主要是火车迷、铁路爱好者以及对火车运输和铁路系统感兴趣的玩家。这类游戏通常强调细节和模拟的真实感，因此会有着较高的学习成本。

SimRail的最大卖点之一是其真实的游戏环境。玩家可以选择驾驶火车穿越漫长的真实线路，包括现代欧洲的高速铁路、长途线路，甚至还有上世纪波兰的沙漠铁路，这为玩家提供了各种时代和风格的体验。
游戏的图形质量很高，开车时窗外的草地和树木在风中摇曳，提速时周边风景掠过的感觉非常美妙，动态天气系统带来了积水和积雪，AI乘客也增强了虚拟世界的逼真感，在开车的途中甚至可以下座位去看看那些乘客。
总的来说，从启动到行驶，再到停车，玩家的所有行为都需要严格遵循真实世界的规则和步骤，这是这类游戏最大的乐趣，也是最为繁琐之处。

SimRail具有多人模式，允许来自世界各地的玩家一起游玩。玩家可以选择扮演火车司机或列车调度员，在实时的天气条件下协同合作。联机模式是火车模拟器中前所未有的创新，增加了游戏的社交和合作成分。成为列车调度员需要玩家在车站为列车准备路线，确保按时发车。如果能够找到同样喜欢这类游戏的同伴，相信玩起来应该还是挺有趣的，会产生很多像派队游戏一样有趣的混乱场景。不过可能存在的问题是，打一局的时间可能会有点久。另外对于多人游戏来说，恶意扰乱其他玩家游戏体验等现象如何处理也是值得关注的问题。

最大的问题就是引导不够完全，指示的操作物件有高亮强调，但是非常不明显，而且有时候甚至会没有高亮。而教程中也有流程bug，跳步骤或者回退步骤会导致卡住。整个新手教程的难度很高，手忙脚乱之下大概率会晚点到站，屏幕上方经常出现的扣分提示也会使得新手更加紧张，而且也没有鸣笛教学，但是分数照扣。繁杂的按键和键盘的映射不够直观，操作不够便捷，尤其是旋转型按钮，鼠标控制起来非常麻烦，经常导致开关门失误。各种按钮没有更加详细的说明，适合真正的列车驾驶员来玩这个游戏。

Posted: March 21
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Lets get the obvious out the way with first. Obviously simrail is not at the level of TSW in terms of content. From that perspective, the sim won't be ready yet. But even with this localised polish content, there is a lot of stuff that can be taken in, some of which is utterly fascinating.

Locos
+ The loco selection is really good here, you have choices between the express pendolino, early 1970s electric traction, or modern-day freight and passenger units.

+ The level of physical detail is actually pretty impressive here. Particular applause goes to the EU07, which has amazing texture maps. It utilises a mix of real photo-textures and substance-driven materials, which hold up with close scrutiny. It manages to avoid the clinical and plastic feeling of TSW.

+ Systems detail feels really good. I'm not a Polish-traction expert, so I won't pretend to act like I know the degree of accuracy of those systems. However it feels like a sim that prioritises learning the systems over accessibility, which I personally love. Almost every button is functional, including things like radios, fuses. Even washer fluid is simulated in some locomotives.

- Control mapping/Operation/Highlighting could be a bit better here. It's not bad, just really different. Sometimes a bit awkward, that using mouse controls is sometimes easier.



+ Environment here feels like a halfway between TSC and TSW. It feels pretty good and natural, and is an amazing demonstration of what Unity can do.

+ Long routes never feel boring like TSW

+ Specific details inlcude grass density, interior signal-boxes make this game stand out more

+ Lineside detail, tends to be a bit more polished that DTG

- Sometimes the sim can have a "bleached" look or a bare look. Some platforms make use of lower quality textures, or materials with no weathering... which contributes to this effect.

- Sometimes I feel like I'm seeing the same vegetation types, and need more variety.



+ Really damn cool! After years of excuses from DTG, Simrail just... did it. Trying both as a dispatcher and driver, it really does add a new dimension to see actual people running a railway. I can't wait to see how this evolves, well done Simrail!

+ Very frequent updates

+ Incoming editor

+ Incoming new regions



You may not want to get stuck in yet, and that's fine. But from what's presented here... I'm actually really excited to see how Simrail evolves in the future!

Probably the best train sim I have ever experienced. With the way this is progressing, it could quite easily knock DTG off that top spot. A few bugs here and there but I am sure these will be ironed out throughout EA. The multiplayer mode really is next level. I feel that the singleplayer mode is more of a improve your skills. The real fun is in MP. You can communicate with other players via a radio system (which you can tune yourself) or if you are a dispatcher, make a phone call. Or if voice chat is not your thing, you can use a text chat system instead. Really has catered for all. The only thing missing now is a passenger mode (but I believe I read somewhere that this is coming further down the line). Plus a map editor is also in the works. This train sim is exactly what people have been asking off DTG for YEARS.

The price is 100% worth it. You get four types of train, a massively long route that is about 2 hours end to end I believe. A multiplayer experience, live train dispatching, a 24 hour timetable, a live weather system, and more!! All for £29.50!! Compare this to DTG where for £29.99 you can get the base game which includes three routes which is about 30 minutes to an hour end to end, one or two types of train per route, single player only, and often riddled with bugs and oversights.

If you are debating between SimRail and Train Sim World, I would honestly say with 100% certainty that SimRail will not let you down.

Awesome job SimRail, keep it up!! :D

Posted: October 31
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
For only £/$/€ 30 you get:

500 km of tracks to drive over in 6+ loco's / emu's (plus lots of different coaches and freight wagons), 30+ dispatcher posts to run, with a multiplayer system that brings dispatching and driving trains together in real time, it even has a working train radio system to talk to the dispatchers, just as in real life.

Plus some basic single player stuff that i don't bother with (there are plenty of single player train games out there, SimRail really shines in multiplayer mode)

You get a nice selection of passenger loco hauled and EMU type trains, plus different freight trains to choose to drive over a 24 hour timetable.

No 2 runs will ever be the same due to the human element and the way the Ai works.... and they have not yet turned on the 'random events' feature!

The dev team includes real life train drivers and dispatchers on the Polish railway, and the parent company 'SimKol' makes training simulator rigs for the Polish railways.
So almost everything is represented as it is in real life, the current map is set in 2018 and reflects operating practises at the time.

The 2 main routes are reproduced as they are in real life, so to drive a service from Katowice to Warszawa Wschodnia takes almost 3 and a half hours if you are driving an EP08 loco hauled train with a vMax of 140 km/h, and that's if you get green lights all the way, you will be put into sidings to let higher priority trains pass you,
So if you are driving a slow freight, be prepared to run late and be held in most sidings to let other trains pass, just like in real life.

The graphics are pretty amazing, i play on a Lenovo Legion gaming laptop at 2K resolution (RTX 3070-Ti GFX card) and have all my settings on max except for 'Vegetation Density' i wind that back to 80% because it reveals more content around the tracks that is hidden with it on 100% and gives me an extra 10 fps.

I get an average of 60fps, it does drop to around 30 fps in one or 2 locations, but this only lasts for a few seconds, just remember, this is a train sim and not a fast paced shooter type game, so high FPS rates and low pings are just not required.
Worst that will happen with a high ping is you hear the other players horn as they pass you a few milliseconds later than they did.

Occasional i see a bit of rubber banding of other player trains when passing at high speed, but this in no way breaks anything, and most runs i do not see this at all.

For the original purchase price we have had a few updates, some new loco's added, an extra length of derivable line that is an extra route off the main one, and a few bug fixes,

::::::::::::::::::::

There is something you must understand about SimRail tho, the dev's will not release updates until they are ready for release, so if you are used to another train game where you get 'paid for' updates every few months which are half finished and break existing content, and you actually like that concept, you may not be happy,

The SimRail dev's have been working very hard on a massive update for the last few months, this will give us, amongst other things:

() A completely new EMU (the EN57)
() A core game update (to unity 2023) with updated graphic engine,
() A completely new input system which will allow many more key binds, modifier keys for key binds, multiple bindings of one key for different tasks (walking, driving, dispatching) and the ability to assign functions to joysticks,
() New weather systems and seasons (autumn and winter)
() New signal boxes,
() Drivers timetables based on the real ones used by PKP drivers, viewed in the train on the timetable holder or on screen,
() New loco re-paints / variants,
() Level crossing cameras ..... and so on.

Obviously that is a lot of hard work to implement, but SimRail do not release half finished updates, they were almost ready to release the new input system 2 months ago, but it was discovered at the last minute that it broke some new features they were going to release afterwards.

So they did the correct thing and postponed the input system update.

You will see negative reviews suddenly appearing on steam, this is because a load of impatient people are mad that the latest update was not released in the month they hoped to release it in,
so they think that by leaving negative reviews it will somehow magically make the update ready for release sooner!!

Way i see it, i'd rather wait for the update to be ready for release and as bug free as possible, than get an early update that ruins my SimRail experience.
Just imagine the reviews if that happened.

And don't forget, the cost of the update mentioned above, for this
game is....


It's a free update you are getting for your original purchase price, other train 'game' makers happily charge you the same price as SimRail costs just for an update like that, they call it a 'DLC'

Posted: January 18
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game sets out with a noble ambition: to challenge the monopoly on 'mainstream' train simulators that Dovetail Games have snoozed their way into having.

For the record, my favourite train simulators are: Run8, Derail Valley, and Diesel Railcar Simulator. SimRail has elements of all of those and brings them together, to my mind, very well, and more accessibly.

With all that being said, though, it's important to understand that this is early access, and what the game currently does and doesn't have.

What SimRail doesn't have:
Single player. Not really, no. There's not really any AI traffic to speak of in single player mode, it's just a selection of runs along the two sections of route in a variety of trains. I'll explain later why this isn't so big of a deal as you might think.






Expectations sufficiently managed? Here's what SimRail has to offer:






What's it like to play? Setting up the train is fairly involved, but quickly becomes second nature. Actual driving can be done either with the mouse (hover the cursor and you can see what position the power and brake controllers are in) or with the keyboard. Each train takes some getting used to, with the modern ones having a number of different slots on the power controller, that you need to tap up through with Numpad+ and then hold at the top to continuously add power. Likewise, it's a little too easy at first to accidentally hit Numpad- repeatedly to try and get into braking, and instead throw it into the emergency brake. All that said, it doesn't take long before you're cruising along without any problem. You can optionally display reminders of upcoming speed restrictions and signal aspects, with distance counters to each as well as to your next station or waypoint.

Multiplayer is what it's currently all about, and where the signalbox play comes to the fore. Each of the current signalboxes has a telephone for speaking to neighbouring boxes and to train crews, a computer showing that day's scheduled services through your location, and either a computer screen or electronic panel for setting routes. If you're of the right temperment (I am), this is surprisingly compulsive. Clicking to set signals, switches and routes, and watching the trains roll past your window. One box features two level crossing that you control, and you can watch the barriers come down after activating them for an approaching train. After a train passes or departs, you are encouraged to send a message to the receiving signalbox confirm the train number (headcode) and time that it passed so they know what to expect next. There's also a more complex procedure for accepting and sending trains to and from single-track branch lines. I am ex-railway and got to visit a number of different signal boxes in my time, mechanical, power and computerised, and in my opinion, the operations depicted are very realistic and accurate.

The fact that any train, and any signalbox, might be controlled by other players adds a whole layer of interest and unpredictability to the game. What you do has an impact on other players, and that is something only a handful of other non-flight simulators can offer. The internet being the internet, there is the potential for troublemakers, and there have been reports, both during the multiplayer beta test, and now that the full game is live, of people taking over signalboxes and bringing traffic to a standstill. The developers have tried to mitigate this: the more complex boxes can only be operated after you've racked up a certain number of hours on their simpler counterparts, and there are functions to report or mute troublesome players, but the general view of the community is that these don't go far enough yet. For what it's worth, I have yet to encounter any malicious behaviour from other players - only a few instances where another player operating a signalbox was late clearing a signal for me.

It's also worth noting that you can just drive a train in multiplayer and never have to speak to anyone. If you're concerned about the currently thin singleplayer, joining a multiplayer server will let you drive a train for as long or as little as you want, and you'll have plenty of AIs controlling both the signalboxes and other trains that are not being operated by other players. You can get on with what you want to do and for all intents and purposes be left alone.

Overall, I love the game, both what it currently does, and the future potential it holds. My top three are all fairly specialized simulators, with Run8 in particular not being for the faint of heart. SimRail promises to bring more of a comprehensive railway experience to more people, and to with any luck, shake up the genre.

Posted: January 13
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
A look:

YouTube™ Video: SimRail | OUT NOW! | Pendo & Dragon2 Tutorials (ENG) | #simrail 
Views: 20,370
Officially available for sale now on the Steam store - SimRail! A long time coming and one helluva start to 2023 with a brand-new train simulator.



========================================================




The short and skinny of it as a train and train-sim enthusiast.... I'm happy there's a new contender for the genre


Visually SR looks great, some of the best lighting in the genre. Night/Day/Fog/Rain - it looks great. The assets and units themselves look great as well. Things didn't look so much when the first demo came out, the community gave feedback and the devs listened. The general lighting in this is something to behold


Sound-wise its quite top notch as well. The units sound as they should via power/braking/interior etc. The outside ambiance is nice as well with platform chatter and announcements as well as church bells ringing in the distance and crossing arm bells to name a few. The only quirks I've got w/ the base game is some of the horn sounds aren't as clean as they could be.



Playability is enough to keep you going for a while. Commuter, inter-city, regional passenger services as well as freight with a dozen or so single player timetables ranging from 30 mins to 3+ hours for a full run via several hundred miles of operable track. Then there's the multiplayer aspect, which lets be frank not many train sims have... play with pals or rando's operating trains and speaking to one another with PTT/text or run the show as a dispatcher with very in-depth fully integrated tools. Then there's the soon to come editor....


Physics are some of the best IN ANY train simulation barring a few 3rd party products from ye-olde train sim classic or a few niche train sims.
Simple as.


Performance is good for me (of-course with diff machines YMMV)
I've got a 5800x with a 6700xt, 32gb mem loaded on SSD and it runs buttery smooth on max graphical setting with a few hitches here and there but NOTHING like the lack of performance within Train Sim World as an example.
There are plenty of options and settings to get you where you need to be.



I've played the Demo, the MP Play-test and now this EA release and the devs have immensely listened to feedback and updated the game. They seem to actually care about their product and not just cash grab - it's humbling and refreshing as he||



All this being said, this is deemed an 'early access' (what isn't nowadays) so there will be bugs and hiccups but currently imo its a very enjoyable product.
It's currently a Polish only rail network and rolling stock (the devs are Polish..) which may not be 100% my cuppa tea but if this is the canvas on what future content will be displayed upon - we're in luck. They've already mentioned addons possibly in Germany, USA inc. Alaska & Hawaii etc.







I absolutely recommend this

This is what a train simulator should be like in 2023
