Posted: January 27
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I thought long and hard before buying this as I am not really fond of multiplayer games, but I decided to give it a try and I am really happy that I did.
The single player is really just a place to familiarise yourself with the trains and their controls ATM(although I am sure that will be developed further with time) before you head into multiplayer where the fun starts. You choose a server to join there are about 60 with some dedicated to different languages time zones and skill level etc. You can choose to play as a driver or a dispatcher and if a driver pick a train that floats your boat and join. The train will probably be already on its journey and when you jump in its controlled by a bot. When your happy you can take over and control the train. The route is cut up into sections that can be controlled by either an AI or real dispatcher. Real Life dispatchers have different skill levels which makes life interesting at times but its really great fun and the very fact that things go wrong at times makes it all very fresh and interesting.
The community is very friendly and trains with real drivers will hoot you as you pass them etc. The controls will be quite familiar if you have played other train sims and the loco models are really good with good physics etc. I have not really had any issues with lag but I have been dropped from the sever a couple but if you know the service number of your train you can log back onto the same server and take over from the bot again that will take over the service when you drop. If you need a cup of tea or have a long wait at a red while a dispatcher gets their A game sorted just hit Esc and enable the bot to take over for you while you go have a brew or just sort your life out. You can take over again at any time you want to.
The graphics look really good to me and the route is like a few of the TSW German routes together and driving a freight train from one end to the other can take up a lot of your day with a high possibility of unforeseen stops etc (you just never know what might be up the line waiting for you).
So all in all a fantastic experience and so much potential to become a world beater. I have been playing train sims for over 10 years and I have never been to excited about the future of the genre.
Its a sensible price (just look at the cost of a single DLC now in TSW) and I see it as a great investment in the future of train simulation software

dispacher part 2, now the kid inside has left this is the more serious review for dispatcher. as a dispatcher you job is to make sure

in depth 3. if you have a train coming through which is 10m early and you have a train which is 5m late but need to cross through the other trains path, its your job to decide if the late train has to wait or set him through making the other train wait.

now all that out of the way. being a dispacher in this game is fun but can be boring some time sif you in one of the less used railine.
other then that if your thinking of getting this game its a 10/10 for me, all i hope to see is more people of the english speaking decide to pickup this game as the dutch and polsih server gets filled quite fast, 76 slots all round. but us english pb are left behind bearly reaching 40 some nights at peak while pol and dutch reach 70 every night

Posted: January 17
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
So, having played the Progolue, the Playtests and now the EA release, I can fairly say I can write a proper review.

Long story short: It's good, even with the bugs.

First things first, there are bugs, yes, some still ported from the playtest. But, looking at the big picture and ignoring the bugs, what we have in Simrail is a diamond in the rough.

The MP experience is top notch. People are already making community events where the communication between dispatchers and drivers is key in order to minimise delays. And there have already been situations where some bugs created problems that had to be solved by the players.

The world is beautiful. The amount of trackage in the EA is astonishing (30€ btw), and it all feels incredibly realistic, and unique. The line between Katowice and Warsaw (mostly flat and high speed) feels incredibly different from the line between Katowice and Jedrzeszow (hilly, full of turns and slow speeds).

Physics are very satisfying, but some controls in some trains feel a bit clunky, like there's a delay in your in-game driver's hand between you pressing the button, and the control moving (hopefully improved in the future). However, driving the trains feels very good. A small passenger regional EMU, an old 1980s locomotive pulling an intercity and a freight train all feel different. You need to pay attention to the particularities of each train.

With all that said, there's no easy way of learning some of this stuff. The tutorials put you straight to driving, without even learning the route signals and sign boards. And while most bugs aren't game breaking, some even being minor inconveniences, there are bugs that went away in the playtests and came back during the EA release.

All in all, it has incredible potential, and I can't wait to see what's next in store for Simrail.

At this point I really DON'T want to recommend buying it without pointing a few things out. Even for an Early Access Title there is A LOT to be desired, but it still is a fun experience. If you don't mind many of the issues and you crave a decent train sim with a fun multiplayer, then this is for you.

I wanna list the bad, rather than repeat the good:
- Bad Tutorials (give the player an overview of the cab BEFORE you let him push many buttons) and maybe have some for absolute greenhorns with simplified signals and not too many slowzones. Properly explain how handles work! Introduction in cruiste control, hm???
- Performance is somewhat all over the place, it's playable but I experience many stutters and framerate issues while the game doesn't look exactly great
- Why not give the player a control layout overlay to memorize them, instead of having to go to the options again and again?
- Server list is awful. Joining a server and picking a train needs more filters...
- Being thrown off a server every time you finish a route is annoying. Ask me a pick a new train!
- Some of the sounds are crackling sometimes
- Getting very low XP even though you HAD to sit at a red signal for 10 minutes, is somewhat annoyig! Give me XP for patience!
- Smoothness of some animations (getting in or out the train) is not nice
- Apparently in multiplayer passengers don't get on and off your trains
- The signal HUD could use a little reform. See Diesel Railycar simulator as reference (having problems of its own) So at least in this sim you don't have the problem of things being layed on top of each other, but they may appear in a wrong order.

Could graphics be better? Absolutely, this game is not going to win any awards compared to modern FPS, but in the train simulator genre this is definitely a step forward.

It's definitely early access though, as there's not too much content yet and a lot of room for optimization. But this is a good foundation, along with multiplayer and dispatcher gameplay. If the devs keep at it and hopefully add more tracks (maybe even other countries such as Switzerland, Germany, Austria, etc?) this could turn out to become a real gem. No VR support yet, unfortunately.

Right now, this is a buy if you're really into trains, and a wait for later if not or you're expecting a game with a ton of content ready for use.

Posted: January 14
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Let me start off with: ABSOLUTELY AMAZING!

Really, I'm highly satisfied with this. After playing the demo, I wasn't really sure about it. But after playing the playtests with multiplayer? It has become one of my favourite train simulation games! Do I recommend it to my friends and even Social Media followers? YES!! And here's why:

The playtests gave me an idea of what to expect. And boy oh boy, did I look forward to drive the Polish Pendolino that we were getting teased during that time! Of course, Pendolino was the very first train I drove in multiplayer as soon as the Early Access release was here.

Seriously, I'm very picky when it comes to train simulation games. And no doubt I've been having a great time playing this game. Meeting friends in-game, sometimes by surprise while driving a train?! You have no idea how awesome that feels. Or maybe you do! I do everything from flashing the loco lights, turning ON and OFF the cab lights, honking the horns, all things to just greet people on the way. I wish there was a way to make our avatars to wave at each other. In fact, people have seen to find a way to greet each other such as jumping repeatedly. :D No doubt, an absolutely fantastic experience. Have you even noticed that sometimes you can even hear train station announcements?! And they're not even random, they ARE announcing information about the exact trains. Even most station passenger information boards work ( there's still some bugs here and there on that regard ). What about overtaking a friend's train because his train was slower than my Pendolino?! Epic.

Sure, single player still needs improvements. I've already read that the devs are planning on introducing a save game feature which is definitely needed for single player mode. But honestly, with an epic gameplay we get on Multiplayer? I don't really care about single player here so much. It was something I was missing on my favourite train simulation games anyway.

Trains variety: For a release, I think this is pretty good. Some people complain that there isn't too much variety. I disagree - we've got the classic EP07 / EU07, Traxx MS2, Pesa EMUs, Newag Dragon and Polish Pendolino. And of course a rather good variety of rolling stock to pull with the locomotives.

Bugs: there's definitely some bugs, but knowing how the devs are keen to listen to feedback and keep on improving the game ( they even worked on Christmas 2022 and put out updates for us during that time!! ), I'm sure most bugs will be fixed in the meantime.

My personal wishes for this game, besides the avatar waiving gesture, are as follows:

- route expansion DLCs ( I do look forward to drive down to Kraków or even to Bohumín! )
- more locomotives ( Vectron please! But to keep that classic Polish train tradition, I think the game needs EN57s and at least an EP09 to drive with the EC trains faster )
- possibility to see your whole train schedule
- possibility to know your train weight and length information
- possibility to spawn in MP sessions as a guest to just roam around the map freely
- possibility to board trains as passengers... maybe also some sort of conductor feature at some point?
- preview of information in regards to server restarts ( although currently this has been improved, it is still unclear when are the servers due to restart and it is a bit annoying that you can't really continue the journey you were doing before )
- slightly more random train timetables
- introduction of ETCS ( and other safety systems as required )
- introduction of actually loaded freight into the wagons

And besides these wishes, the only thing I can look forward to is the SDK and mod support. I'm sure the community will find ways to improve and add content into the game. I also wish you could consider on allowing people to create their own servers and eventually also allow servers with custom-built routes / modded routes.

THANK YOU DEVS for your hard work. What a fantastic game so far. I really want to see SimRail grow and improve. Keep it up!

PS: And now off I go to bed, after my first complete journey from Warsaw to Katowice with an EC hauled by an EP07. Started at around midnight my time. It is currently almost 5 am. :D It took long but man, it was FUN!!!

Posted: January 14
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
SimRail is arguably one of the most detailed and complex railroad simulators currently on the market.

In singleplayer, the game has a lot less to offer, but it's still an interesting package. You only have a handful of routes and trains to pick from, all from Poland, which has led to a number of negative reviews. However, the UI design seems to suggest there's plans to expand on this, which I certainly hope is true, however, even if not, there's still a lot to offer. The routes are quite long, with some routes having expecting you to take around three hours to complete (the shortest, non-tutorial route I saw was about an hour). There are both freight and passenger routes, however, I have not tried the freight routes.

In multiplayer is where the game really shines though. Although still operating with the limited number of trains and routes, there are now other players and AI-controlled trains populating the world. Additionally, the multiplayer features one of my favorite and possibly the most unique features in this game, dispatchers. As far as I'm aware, there are no other games of this quality featuring dispatchers. In singleplayer, this is just an AI you talk to (similar to Microsoft Flight Simulator), but in multiplayer this can be a real person, which you can communicate with through either text chat or voice chat. Additionally, you can play as a dispatcher routing trains through your region. There are three main types of control systems for dispatchers. The most modern uses a computer to route trains, only requiring you to select the designating route. Older systems feature electric lights and switches, but require a little more work to route trains. (This feature isn't yet implemented, but I suspect it is in the works since they have screenshots of this type of system). This is something I don't believe is present anywhere else, and I absolutely love it. Multiplayer is pretty accessible since all interactions can be performed using either text or voice, and the design makes it so even these interactions *could* be avoided mostly. If you are unwilling or unable to play multiplayer, however, I honestly am not sure this is going to be the right game for you.

Being an early access game, there are also other quirks that can be annoying. Many more advanced features are not explained to you, and while most of the important commands and UI have been converted to English, there are still some Polish labels, especially for unfinished or rarely used components. These issues are easy to fix, and that's most likely why the game is in early access. If this will annoy you, you may want to wait a while before purchasing.

This is still an early access game, and it can feel a little lacking (especially in singleplayer) compared to other simulators, but the detail and complexity, as well as the unique features of this simulator, more than make up for its shortcomings. I would definitely recommend it.

Posted: January 16
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This is utterly stunning!

Absolutely deserving of the high reviews and I'm over the moon it's as good as I hoped it would be! This feels like the next generation of train sim. The physics and sound are gorgeous, and it's super easy to pick up as the tutorials (at least in my experience) are great - the buttons you need to press are all highlighted and the dialogue is friendly, upbeat and informative. Everything in the cab feels so satisfying to use - adjusting the combined power / brake handle in the Elf with the keys felt a little unusual at first, but after a couple of runs, I'm utterly in love with it. Being able to quickly dial the acceleration down to zero with two quick taps and just tapping once to slowly reduce it down to whatever setting you want is lovely! I also really enjoy watching the platform activity - passengers board the train and physically make their way through the carriage to a vacant seat and sit down. They feel less robotic than any other train simulator out there - they just seem more believable. And that makes a difference.

The sim runs beautifully even on a humble machine, and graphically it's lovely even on the lowest settings. It's sturdy and clearly built on great foundations with a huge amount of care, dedication and love. I haven't run into a single crash at all. I think you can really appreciate the passion fuelling this sim - it feels like the people that made it adore trains, and it really is a love letter to a global train simulation community that has been left wanting since the golden days of Microsoft Train Simulator. This feels like the true successor to that game, and providing the process of producing new routes, locomotives and sounds is straight forward, it'll absolutely dominate the market at this rate.

Obviously being early access there are areas the game needs to grow and flesh out, many of which have already been touched on in other reviews. I think for me, something akin to a Quick Drive would be excellent. Just a basic feature allowing you to select the train, the consist, the route, the start and end point plus the stations you want to stop at in-between. Being able to choose your weather (dynamic or a set preference) and the ability to pick the start time would be ideal too. I think an innovation here would be to add some kind of randomness to the signalling in this mode so it keeps you a little more on your toes.

But yeah, I'm extremely happy with it, I can't wait to jump back in! A huge well done guys - keep smashing it, the competition will really struggle to compete if you keep this momentum up. I can't wait for the editor and thank you so much for introducing us to your wonderful railways and trains! You should all be incredibly proud of what you have achieved!

Posted: February 7

[Early Access version]
Content-wise you play on (currently) 2 routes in Poland between Kattowice and Warzawa / Sedzizow. In short: the tracks are astonishing real!

Ohhh - this turned out to be visual attractive, with loads of love for details and fun to play. On top - it works excellent with proton in linux. I now have 66 hour play time without booting up Win11 a single time!
Even if Single player mission editor is not released yet, inspecting the files already show so many options I can't wait to make use of, like weather setting (you must try the thunderstorm setting!), car type, load, brake mode, weight, travel path etc.
In Multiplayer it is already open for a certain degree of mods - so you can see the map of the server with all the players - where they are and what they drive. Also - you can pick the role as dispatcher and route trains from a dozend more or less complex signal boxes of various types.

If you enjoy Run8 for US railroads, SimRail is similar for European Railroads. Currently minus industry but the scenery already offers massive tracks in industrial areas, switching yards and intermodal yards. Big difference: while in Run8 operation is self organized once industries are set up, in SimRail all traffic goes along timetables.

For me it turned out to be a bit addictive, something that Railroads Online, TS, TSW not managed to do. I will spend a few more hours with this game!

Posted: January 15
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
If this review could recommend "neutral" or "potentially wait and see", I'd have chosen that option.

The simulation itself has clearly been created with love. The single route currently available (indicated as two separate routes in single player, but combined as one in MP) is detailed and lengthy (hundreds of route miles of track). Similarly, while only five types of locomotive/MU are available, each is a fully detailed recreation - ranging from modern EMUs with "press forwards to go" controls, to the EU07's 1960s-style control scheme with its incredibly atmospheric mechanical clunking and clattering of relays behind the cab as you notch up. The signalling and dispatcher controls also show a very rarely seen level of attention to detail - down to having to break the seals on mechanical releases if you mess things up.

The multiplayer is relatively well designed, and reasonably stable - other than logging in and not moving/dispatching trains, it seems resilient to most forms of intentional harm. Passing a signal at danger will reset your train (rather than messing up gameplay for others); the server will prevent the most harmful misroutings by player dispatchers; and the AI is (generally) capable of filling any role not covered by a player. This is in contrast to some competing games, where client-server desyncs were very common and harmful, and where the simulation would feel very empty if players weren't around.

Where the game currently lacks somewhat is in content. In singleplayer, only a small handful of scenarios are available, with no free-roam, "choose a train from the timetable", or ability to use the editor. Multiplayer is, unusually, more fully-fledged, with players able to pick any train on the timetable. For drivers, the number of servers is generally sufficient, although some language communities have quickly filled up the couple of servers available to them, and players have no ability to host their own sessions.

The well-simulated dispatcher mode is, sadly, very limited. It is available in multiplayer only, with only a small number of locations available to players (13 per server, with 27 servers offering dispatcher mode, reduced to between 1 and 7 servers if you wish to play in your own language). The majority of dispatcher positions are also very simple, with no stations, junction, or activity other than a handful of passing trains per hour, leading to even worse competition for the few interesting spots. This is then worsened by an in-built time-gating system, preventing new players from accessing most non-trivial locations until they have *hours* of playtime in dispatcher mode. This has led to repeated issues with new players simply logging in to a boring location and leaving their computer, stopping play for others - even if kicked after 30 minutes, it counts towards their hours.

The initial release has a number of bugs on its opening weekend - ranging from tooltips going missing and controls not being quite right, to the server AI occasionally managing to get itself into a complete mess needing a restart. Hopefully these will be patched quickly - devs have at least been responsive in acknowledging reports on the forum, and a couple of game-breaking bugs in singleplayer scenarios were attended to quickly. Game performance is also somewhat of an issue, particularly frame drops when new models are loaded in, though perseverance with settings can at least give consistent (if not amazing) performance.

Posted: February 22
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Driving a diverse set of rolling stock. Dispatching at station signalposts along the mainline. A full mainline from Katowice to Warsaw... Plus a secondary line and multiple connections between them. A proper, deep simulation for the vehicles and the dispatching. And a fluid, well-functioning multiplayer environment that requires collaboration.

This simulator is the new dominating force in train simulation. With US and German routes already in development by outside studios, there's going to be expansion beyond Poland. As well as the functionality still being added through the early access program, which includes seasons, random events/disruptions along the line, AI improvements which will further allow in-route turnarounds as well as further expansion to timetables; and a secondary route set in the 1980s in which you'll take control of steam locomotives.

SimRail has been baking for a long time. And the release has been an absolutely astounding example of how to do things right. Open communication, an engaging team, and a continued showing of dedication to improving SimRail as a platform has provided an expanding, immersive experience that I can't honestly find an equal to.

And they don't try to rate you or force medals of skill on you like some others. However you can 'level up' in a way that generally shows progress, much like the Truck Simulators. It's nice.

Posted: February 13
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I thought driving a train would be a chill, relaxing experience. Well, let me tell you, the routes currently available are very hectic and engaging. Aside from the vigilance system making sure you are awake, there are so many things to pay attention to. Are you going the speed limit? Are you behind schedule? What side of the train is the platform so you can open the correct doors? Are you moving into a different radio zone and have to change the channel on your radio? Is there a crossing ahead so you have to sound your horn? Is the track damaged ahead meaning you have to drive on the left track? Well don't forget to change your lights to the right mode! Windshield is dirty and it's getting hard to see? Where was that switch for the wipers and windshield washer again?

There's so much to do, and most of the buttons, levers, knobs and switches of the various trains are able to be interacted with. The displays all show realistic data. Oh, and did I mention that everything is realistically modelled with INCREDIBLE attention to detail?

That's before you even get into the multiplayer modes where you share the routes with other players who, by the way, can also take over the station switches and control the routing.

Overall, this is just an amazing simulator. If you like trains at all, I highly recommend picking this one up.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Really good train simulator! I've played 'Maszyna' for some time. But the controls were not easy to understand. Now here is a well-developed Polish train simulator. Train physics is superb. Also, the sounds of the carriages and locomotives seem authentic. Unity graphics have a peculiar color tone, but it's beautiful. But I have some suggestions, like: 1. the ability to see signals from a distance; some enhancements are needed for the signal lamps. 2. Interactive driver/passenger cabin cameras and trackside cameras are needed. Now it's all static. Some speed limits are wrong. In one instance, 40 KPH was shown, but when entering the limit zone, it shows 20 KPH and overspeed. The brakes seem to be overpowered for a train! I hope the developers will fix these bugs and improve this sim. A must-have for train simulator fans

Posted: June 24, 2017
Not just a brilliant concept, but also simply an amazing game all around. The lovely artstyle and the playful soundtrack perfectly fit together, but the game can also be brutal and hard. It is a completely different game depending on who you play with and against. Every level has it's own soundtrack with two different versions for each phase, and every single of those tracks is so catchy and awesome, but even though the tracks are very different because they are supposed to fit the level they are playing in, they still have a consistent style. And each level brings a unique twist to the game too.

This game is pure slapstick and even though I played it so much already, I still can't stop laughing when I play this with friends. I wish I had this game when I was a child, this is exactly the kind of game you can get addicted to as a child (in a good way) and grow up with and have fond memories. If you have children, this game is bloody perfect too. It channels creativity, is family friendly and can be played in a variety of ways. Honestly I would even go as far as giving this game a 10/10 rating, and I say this as someone who owns over 430 games on Steam.

Big thank you to the developers for delivering this unique, brilliant and fun as hell experience.

Product received for free

PROS:
+ Very funny/enjoyable
+ No bugs (I haven't encountered any)
+ Moving and jumping "feels" good
+ Can create a lot of fun memories with your friends
+ Local multiplayer
+ Trap layouts and ways to solve them are almost always unique and different (see cons section)
+ Soundtrack is great
I can't really find any cons with this game, but here are some that I thought of...
CONS;
- Doesn't feel the same when playing with random people
~ get kind of repetitive depending on what you do (i.e playing the same trap layout over and over again) when playing

All in all, Ultimate Chicken Horse is a very fun party game to play with friends and family, but (for me) loses its charm when playing online with people you don't know. It's always funny to hear various screams, profanities, and laughter from the floor below when playing with my siblings.

Posted: February 26, 2020
"What is 'Ultimate Chicken Horse'?", you ask. I ask you "WHY AREN'T YOU PLAYING IT?!?"

There's tons of reviews and such on this game, but the basics are this:

Grab friends, pick an animal you wanna play as and then pick a stage. Stages are broken into rounds where you each first grab a device, mechanism or block that is offered, then place it someplace on the stage. Some are helpful, some are traps. Then play swaps to where you all run the obstacle course you've just built in a race to the finish line. Next round, repeat and build onto the previous. Then keep going until an 'Ultimate' Animal is awarded. There's tons of unlockables and the devs have been s upporting the game non-stop since the game was 1st introduced. To this day, they're still adding new stuff!

This is an ULTIMATE party game!

Posted: March 12, 2016
I fell in love with this game's concept (and presentation) when I first saw it being played by the Giant Bomb crew. After months of impatiently waiting for the release, my friends and I had to wait a bit more before the online functionality was available. Today it came, and even though there were bugs, the gameplay shone through and proved to be just as fun as I expected.

This is a great game to play with your friends. 2 players is fun but it gets exponentially better with more. The best part? Your movement is client-side, meaning you can comfortably play this with people across the world.

The gameplay is the real selling point, but the presentation deserves special mention as well. The art style fits the hilarious quirky gameplay very well, and is well animated. The sound effects are a perfect compliment to the visuals, from the UI to the sound of your character's head bumping a ceiling. And the sheep makes adorable noises!

Aside from the bugs which the developers are working hard to eradicate, this is a great example of how to make a fun online party game. Don't give this a second thought if you're looking for a good time full of laughs with friends.

Update: Aforementioned bugs were eliminated long ago, this game is polished and there is more free content on the way.

I can't articulate how much I love this game. It's so unlike anything else I've ever played. Just buy this game. Don't even think about it. Online is steadily being improved. And for the couch it's a blast.

It's like a competiive Mario Maker where you take turns screwing each other.

The amount of complexity that can be made is actually astonishing. Parts can interact in ways you wouldn't expect, adding virtually infinite replay value to the game. Plus it's damn charming with adorable animals dying horrific deaths.

I've played 10 hours and have nothing but good things to say about it. The controls take a little getting used to and a controller is probably best, but i've gotten really good on a keyboard with practice.

Posted: April 26
Ultimate Chicken Horse is the perfect game for those who love to party and punish their friends. This game will have you laughing so hard that you might even forget you're playing a game. You'll start by selecting your favorite animal, and then it's time to get creative with building the ultimate obstacle course.

As you lay down traps and platforms, you'll find yourself giggling like a schoolgirl as you imagine your friends falling into your devious traps. But be careful not to fall into your own traps, or you'll look like a total chicken.

The best part of Ultimate Chicken Horse is watching your friends struggle to navigate your insane course. It's almost as fun as watching a group of toddlers trying to figure out how to share their toys. Plus, the victory dance at the end is priceless.

Overall, Ultimate Chicken Horse is a game that will leave you in stitches. It's perfect for parties, family gatherings, and any occasion where you want to humiliate your loved ones in a fun and playful way. So, grab some friends, a few drinks, and get ready to laugh until you cry!

Posted: September 17, 2017
Ultimate Chicken Horse is a really fun multiplayer game with some bugs and online issues.

Ultimate Chicken Horse (UCH) is a Level Designer-like Platformer. When you're in a level with other people, you can add platforms and traps each round. When everyone's done placing their objects, you then play the level. Your job is to be the only person to get to the goal, and prevent the other players to also succeed. If everyone makes it to the end, nobody gets points for that round (unless someone got an object called a Coin.). If everyone dies, nobody gets points for that round.

The controls when the level you're in takes some time to get use to. To me, they were really floaty the first time I played the game, which caused some accidental fails (like accidentally falling through a small gap). While they do need to get use to, the control layout is simple and easy to learn. I played this game with my Ps3 controller (I did some thing that makes my computer think my Ps3 controller is a Xbox 360 controller.), and the controls never got confusing, but since they're floaty in this game, again, they need to get use to.

When in the Build-like Mode, you can place 1 object every round (but I think you can change the amount of objects you can place down in the rules). In Party Mode, you and the other players get 4-5 random objects to choose from every round. If you see an object you want, you need to be quick, since the other players can take that object away from you. In Freeplay Mode, you get to select 1 object of your choice every round. If you want to place down a trap? You can do that if you want! Want to delete an object someone placed? You can do that if you want!

If you're the host, you can change the rules for your game. You can increase rounds, change the Game Mode, etc. So if you want your game to be different or more interesting, you can try to do that.

At the start of the game, you only get 3 levels, 4 characters, and no outfits. In order to get more levels/characters/outfits, you need to find these boxes with a "?" on them in the levels you have. If there is a box, a ? appears on a level in the Lobby. In order to get the boxes, you just need to touch them or put a trap next to them. It's easier than it sounds.

The Soundtrack and Artstyle are really good. Can't say anything else.

There are problems with the game: Bugs and Online Issues.

-When I was playing with other people I don't know, one of them said that they couldn't select an object, even though he was pressing the left mouse button on the object he wanted. Because of this issue, he/she couldn't put any objects down, only the the two players and I.
-I put stairs on a rotating object that had honey on it. At first, the stairs rotated like I wanted to, but then the stairs stopped rotating and was at a different place the next round.

I've encountered more bugs, but those are the bugs I can think of right now.

-When playing Online, things are out of sync at times. Like for example: I jump into a saw that's rotating, and I fail. The next player jumps, and even though it looks like he/she touched the saw, he/she is still going. Or like an arrow hits a player, and he/she's still going.
-Some things do disappear from a player's view. Sometimes an object disappears on a player's screen, which might screw them over.

Overall, if you want a really fun party game, Ultimate Chicken Horse is for you! Don't want to get 4 copies of the game? No worries! You can hook up 4 controllers to your computer and play the game together, just like that. In my opinion, 15 dollars is worth it for the super fun gameplay that never gets old.

Highly Recommended!

Nominated for the "The Even Better Than I Expected" Award:

When I first saw this game I thought it was a bit silly and ridiculous just from the title alone. The simple graphics and cartoonish nature of the game was different everything I've seen from the recent years, but after watching the store page video I thought it looked pretty fun.

The game is a simple platformer with the purpose of getting from Point A to Point B. The craziness really shines when you play with three or four friends as everyone plays a part in forging the empty space into a gauntlet of terror. Posted: March 28, 2021
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Okay! Time to eat my own foot. It's also a city builder now, but not quite.

Yes. This is a puzzle game. Not quite a city builder like everyone else has claimed, but the Creative Mode update has changed that, and I think that is an interesting thing to look into, hence the update. This is no Sims and it sure as hell doesn't need to be. For a small group of german game design students, this game definitely shows their skill at game design. It's exactly as advertized. Relaxing, fun and surprisingly challenging. I still haven't gotten to 10,000 points bare minimum yet, and there are people who have hit 24K, which is impressive in its own right.


Yeah... This game is uh... It's addicting. DAMNED addicting. Like, you actually lose your sense of time while playing it which is impressive, and I have unfortunately caught myself dreaming of detailed hexagons thanks to the game because I'm clearly in need of another clinical cure to my sanity. I'll let that, again, be its own indictment of how good this game is. It's a fun game, but I definitely recommend short play times with a maximum of two-hour intervals so you don't burn yourself out or end up playing until the dawn has come to burn your vampiric, ghost-white flesh from your sorry bones.


Answer: The pieces.

You have puzzle pieces with six sides that can have all sorts of items placed on them. The side types are as follows:

Plains
Wheat Field
Household
River/Ocean
Railroad

You basically put the pieces together while fulfilling challenges to keep the fun going. The further you get, the higher your score and the more of a colossal bird's-eye continent you have that you can just examine at your leisure. This game DOES NOT rush you. You can take as long as you like to place a single piece. You also get bonus points for matching the pieces together like you building the continent of Mata Nui from the Bionicle board game (Look it up).


Well, the Creative Update fully released, and as such I only thought it would be fair to update my review to reflect that and clean up errors people had brought up in my review to reflect that. Creative Mode adds a lot of new ♥♥♥♥ to the game that makes it more fun for people wanting a more free-form experience. Again, it's not QUITE a city-builder, but Creative Mode lets you play around with the game's tile generation settings to get more results that you'd like for use in making an endlessly large map. I spent about an hour playing around with it and had some fun. For once, I finally got to make an ocean, so that foot in my mouth is tasting at least something like a toes-and-philly-steak sandwich. I got a real out of the little boost of playtime the new mode provided to say nothing else more concise.


So... This game is currently a piddly little 396 megabytes in size. Yeah, it's about half the size of Diablo II. Which is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ impressive. Being fair, it's not exactly consuming any real resources so the size is to be expected. The music is a recent addition, and it helps with the relaxation. The colors are bright, but don't assault your eyes. In short, it's a joy to play,


Gameplay: 8/10
Music: 6/10 (Relaxing, but not outstanding/doesn't need to be)
Graphical Fidelity: 6/10

OVERALL RATING: 7/10

In short, it's a very fun, relaxing game. IT doesn't set out to do more than it desires to achieve, and in an age of indie games that always over-promise and in cases more often than not, under-deliver or don't deliver at all, Dorfromantik is a fresh breath of air in a vein similar to Slime Rancher for me.

The graphics aren't impressive and don't need to be. They're good enough to be enjoyed and the simplicity of how everything appears is perfect. The music, while relaxing, kind of makes me think of Minecraft... which hilariously makes sense, given the kind of direction this game was aimed at. Minecraft on peaceful has very relaxing music you can build and mine to. If that is the goal, it has been reached.

In short, I definitely recommend Dorfromantik. Buy this game while it's still 10 dollars, or get it on sale. It's surprisingly good. Seriously.

I love this game! I had a stroke which left my right hand non-functional where games are concerned, so I end up stuck with turn-based games. I've clocked in an embarrassingly high number of hours on Civ VI and really don't like story driven games (I'll just go read a book!), so am always on the look out for something I can play.

This game is appropriately challenging and engrossing. It also checks off my 'easy to learn, hard to master' requirement, though I do often get burned by RNG often enough.

Eventually, it does get a bit monotonous. I'm honestly not sure what the dev could do to make the game life longer. I suspect this will be fun to come back to and play a game or two every few months for quite a while, though. It's very relaxing, and when the RNG isn't being outrageous, far more engaging than frustrating. Definitely recommended if that's the type of game you're into.

Posted: April 18, 2021
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game has become my 'second job'. It takes a while to get your head around all the possibilities but once you do. Even at 158 hours in I just learned/realized something that allowed me to get my new high score – 17770. Now I’m looking forward to playing again with my newfound knowledge.

The game is a mix of so many others, The obvious settlers of Catan, memory (where do I need that tile with one house next to one forest?), matching (I got a perfect perfect tonight! That’s 7 perfects at once). So much planning and very high stakes; one wrong click could ruin your entire game (I understand the debate but an undo button would really change the game).

I’m a lifelong player of video games (I refuse to call myself a ‘gamer’). This game has brought together so many things I love and have missed in video games. From a simple idea, with simple rules comes a game with such depth and complexity; its replay value is astronomical (see 158 hours in 19 days).

It is a steal for the price, get it, play it, enjoy it and play again.

Posted: April 11, 2021

Dorfromantik. On the surface a simple, tile based puzzle game. But hidden behind it's cute, cardboardy art style is a menacing demon of complexity. If you enjoy puzzles, this game will tickle your brain in the best and worst ways. With an extensive selection of randomized tiles, you will soon find yourself entrenched in creating tiny villages, giant forests, winding rivers and interconnected systems of railroads. The amount of discoverable "secret" tiles that you can unlock through in-game quests are astounding, and make for an incredibly compelling experience. If you enjoy brain teasers I would throughly recommend picking this up.

Posted: November 24, 2022
This game has become one of my favorite games to sit down and be challenged as well as being able to have a relaxing game at the same time. Another easy to learn game that really provides a challenge without overtaxing your brain.

The premise is to match 6 sided pieces of varying make ups, including: water, railroad, forest, houses, grass and field, as you are giving one piece at a time to match onto the playing field. You can rotate pieces to fit them together with an already placed piece. You do have a limited amount of pieces to start a regular game but you can add back to your total by completing quests. Trying to get a high score is the goal in a classic game.

As you play a game another goal is to build out to a piece that is away from the main starting area, doing score gets you score and special pieces to unlock. The game has seven modes to keep you occupied with a change of pace. A tutorial is first, then classic, creative, quick, hard, monthly and custom. The tiles can be customized to certain looks with the use of biomes, which you unlock as you play. You can choose what biomes you want to appear in a game.

This game is really a no rush game, you can take your time as much as you like to find the best location to place pieces. You really have to way the pros and cons of piece placing as getting perfect placements can get you big scores but you have to continuously complete goals/quests done to keep getting more tiles.

A great addition to the game is the awesome music, you kind of lose yourself in it as you play. Very original, and enough tracks to not get bored of any of them. I now have to talk about the art style, it's AWESOME! It fits this game perfectly and is conducive relaxation. I just love the little animations that begin with some of the tiles when you place them.

This game is highly recommended if you love strategy/puzzle games that let you work your brain while also relax. You will be spending many hours blissfully gaming with Dorfromantik.

Posted: March 25, 2021

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Dorfromantik is a wonderful city builder game that aims to provide the most calming and relaxing experience possible by keeping the gameplay minimalistic yet extremely addictive. Since ISLANDERS was released in April 2019, several other games using more or less the same mechanics appeared on Steam, but none of them managed to capture its inner brilliance. After having experienced Dorfromantik fully, I strongly feel that it has the potential to be a worthy competitor, if not even better than ISLANDERS in some ways.

Dorfromantik 
A Screenshot of Dorfromantik
By: 🍒 Lilly (🌸◠‿◠)

The core ideas of the two games are the same: you begin with an empty environment that contains an already set default tile, then you build up your landscape by placing down title by tile, expanding in all directions and gaining points by arranging them in an optimal way. While offers a choice between two packs of buildings belonging to the same type as long as you don’t have enough tiles, in you are by default given a stack of random tiles, with only the topmost one always being usable. The gameplay is thus simplified a lot, and the decision making shifts towards determining what the optimal spot for placing this tile is, based on the existing configuration.

The tiles are randomly generated mixes of five different elements (houses, fields, trees, water, railroad), featured in various shapes and amounts, but most of the times it's a combination of 2-3 different elements, with the water and railroad bits being more difficult to handle than the rest. Some of these tiles give you a quest when they're placed on the map, requiring you to connect a certain amount of tiles to them.

The core gameplay basically consists in -ing these in such a way that they form separate areas, in preparation for upcoming quests which are essential for game progress. Completing quests is what gives you survivability (they add new tiles to the stack) and increase the score, together with placing tiles in optimal spots for bonus points. Just like in , you might want to group related tiles together even outside quests, building up those points in preparation for the moment when you receive a quest tile that you can place down nearby for instant or almost-instant completion. However, one crucial difference between these two games is that the placement of building in is done based on the radius of the master building, while in the tiles can be chained together over any range, as long as the elements keep the connection among two adjacent tiles. In , gathering points is done through pixel-perfect placement and cramming together the maximum amount of buildings of the same type, both horizontally and vertically, while in the hexagonal grid expands only in 2D, allowing only a strict placement but the points can be collected from any amount of linked tiles.


There are two types of quests: those that require you to have a minimum amount of elements in the connected tiles, and those that ask for an “exact” number. While the ones from the first category are pretty easy to complete initially, those that appear mid-game towards the end game have considerably increased requirements. For example, the first quests are connecting 10-30 trees - easily doable with only a couple of tiles, while later this value scales towards several hundreds, requiring you to already have connected several tiles with the same elements. The quests that require you to have an exact number of elements linked are substantially more difficult because you will need to wait for the right tile to drop. That’s where you truly become a slave of the RNG, praying that you get a tile containing not 5 houses, but 2 only - because that’s what you need in order to complete the quest (and connecting a 5-houses tile would ruin it). For some of these quests, there's an optional requirement to close the opened edges, which further complicates things due to the fact that you’ll need to preplan the positioning so that you can easily close these off for extra tiles.

Completing quests will not only award you points, but also add new random tiles in your stack - and without tiles you can’t progress further. Therefore, finishing as many quests as possible should be your main priority, in order to generate the maximum amount of tiles in the stack. In practice though, because the RNG is what controls your gameplay (more or less), you’ll end up having several quests that can’t be completed and in the end you’ll just run out of tiles, while waiting for those fitting ones. Unlike in , where you need to reach a certain score in order to progress to the next island, here you can start as many game sessions as you like, with the score having an influence only on the additional challenges that you get in one gaming session. There are always 3 random challenges attributed (like building a water chain that is 50 tiles long or reaching 5000 points) which are made available in a progressive manner (as soon as you complete one, you unlock the next tier of the same challenge). Additionally, special tiles exist on the map - if you expand enough to reach them and complete their quests you will receive a random reskin for an existing tile.

In my opinion, one thing that is missing from the game is the ability to undo your moves, even for a limited amount of times. It happened more often than not that I misplaced a tile, thus breaking my existing configurations, and there was no way out from that. Several other people requested this functionality but the developers agreed to take this into consideration only in a later update. Also nice-to-have would be the ability to postpone some tiles for later use, thus saving some of these randomly generated tiles for quests with exact requirements, instead of wasting them on the current configurations. However, the devs are inclined to keep the gameplay unchanged, in order to not overcomplicate it with such features.


The game can be played with the mouse only or with a combination of mouse and keyboard that you use to rotate the tiles and the camera. The quest requirements are visible
on the map above the quest tiles and are instantly updated when you hover a potential placement spot with the currently active tile. This way you can easily see if you can get progress towards a quest by placing it on that spot, plus, all the tiles connected to the current one are highlighted. The opened edges are also highlighted on hovering the quest tile. The game makes it as easy and comfortable to you as possible and gives you all the information you need, leaving you only with the decision of where to place the tile.

In terms of achievements, prepare to spend at least 40-50 hours in it, if not even much more. The achievements are awarded for completing the challenges which grow exponentially in difficulty as you progress through the game, plus several challenges (reaching highscores for example) will have to be completed multiple times.

is a game worth playing and playing again. It never gets old, there's always a new goal to pursue and with each new gameplay there's a soft nudge towards bettering your strategies, while still keeping everything casual and chill. It's a game in which you can lose yourself for 20 minutes or for hours, in short bursts or in lengthy sessions, and you can play it as casually or as hardcore as you choose. Also, a Creative mode is in the works - I for one am excited to see how that will play.

Posted: April 24, 2021
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Yes, Dorfromantik is cute and charming.
Yes, this game is for puzzler masterminds for some brain training.
Yes, this experience is worthwhile for casual players too, but don’t expect an exceptional high score then.
Yes, you can rage during this game, no matter how relaxing it is. Once you realize there is no UNDO button and you misplaced a tile while just trying to drag the map then you could turn into a raging machine. Please don’t go outside and don’t interact with others when this happens. Ignoring this suggestion could cause reputation loss with humanity, world, neighbours, friends and family members.
Yes, Countryside Romance is addictive, so I decided to try the game after I obtained it. My initial plan was to do one or two games then play a strategy game which had a new DLC. Then 3 days and 48 hours later I realized I totally ignored all other aspects of my life.


Dorfromantik is a simple but genial puzzle game. You start the game with 40 tiles and you need to place them on the board/map. Each tile has 6 edges and random objects placed on all of the edges. These could be: grassland, water, railroad, forest, house(s), some agricultural object (wheat probably). You can’t choose what tile you get, you will get them randomly and you need to build up an as big as possible countryside idyllic world using those tiles.

How to do that?

Eventually you would run out of tiles so you need to finish quests, like create a connected system of 50 houses, 10 railroads, etc. These quests show up on tiles you could place, but it keeps increasing and its required number is in relation with the size of your current biggest, expandable area. So when you have 50 connected houses and you could still expand that, then you will get quests which ask for 60-75+ houses, when you have 200 it will ask 220-250+. The additional amount is asked keeps increasing as you progress in the game.
Don’t be afraid, if you closed your forest with 1500+ trees and now your biggest expandable forest has only 200 trees, then you won’t get a tile with 1700+ trees quest requirements, it will be again only 250-400+.

The reward for solving quests is 5 new tiles and when you place tiles perfectly (all 6 edges bordering the same type) you will get an additional tile too.

Loving it! Well worth the cheap asking price. Don’t hesitate if you like puzzles or relaxing games, just click the buy button. 97% of the players could be wrong, but I don’t!:-D
Visuals: 10/10

Sound effects/tracks: 9/10, very relaxing
Atmosphere: 10/10
Difficulty: 6/10, well, if you are trying to get a 30k high score and do all challenges.
Amount of crash: zero on win10
Games, similar to Dorfromantik: I didn't remember for any Joe The Eskimo suggested Islanders is similar.

Perfection time: ~80h+. Really depends on skill. There are some challenges and a few grind achievements. You can “work” only on 3 achievements in a single run, as only 3 active unearned challenges available during each run. Some, like a 75 size long railroad line, 100 size long river/water system and 30k high score are very challenging, but once you have patience for it you can do it too. Posted: June 11
Relaxing? Yes, but also... strangely stressful. Under this whole aesthetic of idyllic central European countryside there's a surprisingly deep game of matching tile edges, managing groups, closing off regions, fulfilling quests. You can, of course, ignore all of that and play creative mode exclusively, but I'd feel like this would be a waste of game.

There are two reasons to pay attention to these systems. One - score. That one might not seem that important, but it's fun to try to beat your own high score! Besides, it often leads to achievements, which in turn unlock new tiles and biomes. And two - it replenishes your tile pool. See, your pile of tiles is always limited - and once you run out, it's session complete. So if you want to keep expanding your little world, you have to keep paying attention to these things.

The mixture of those systems and the incredibly chill aesthetic - both in terms of look and the soundscape - create a very unique and potent brew that just washes your worries away. And I think this is the main reason why the game is so beloved by many.

For example: this one time, I had a mental breakdown so severe, my entire concept of reality collapsed and even thoughts of suicide didn't bring any solace. I got out of it with the help of therapy, philosophy and some research, but what kept the mortifying existential dread at bay was this game. The chill feeling was strong enough to make me forget I spent too long gazing into the abyss, and undoubtedly made my recovery quicker.

With all that said, I wish the game had more object types on the tiles. There are only 3 common ones (there's more, but they're much less common): houses, trees, and fields. I get it, that's rural Europe for you, but we also have mountains! Meadows! Swamps! Admittedly, the devs are from Berlin (I think), and the state of Brandenburg is almost completely flat - so maybe that's what they were going for.

I wasn't sure if I'd like Dorfromantik, but it entered my life when I needed it, and returned some kind of peace to my soul. I won't claim it would do the same to you, but I'd say it's nice to place a few tiles every now and then.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Experience the euphoria of creation in this high-octane, top-down build-'em-up. Contend with the ever-more-extreme demands of the Brandenburg Rural Development Committee for yet more lush wheatfields, serene forests, and cozy woodland hamlets, all to feed the insatiable hunger of the German peace machine. Deploy the hexagon, nature's perfect shape, to construct a sprawling network of countryside fixtures. Erect dread monuments to your terrible might, such as the Maze of Endless Maize and the Three-Tile Circular Railroad To Absolutely Nowhere. Learn to fear and respect the hidden power of the otherwise-innocuous river, as its conniving curves and bewildering bends ruin round after round after raging, tearful round. Experience the nail-biting thrill of wondering if the tile you need for that one spot you've left vacant for the entire game even exists in the first place. Realise that it doesn't. Lose. Quit the game in childish fury. Come back for more.

This game has it all. If you don't buy it, then your brain is stupid.

Posted: March 25, 2021
Product received for free

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Follow our curator page: IndieGems if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.

is the perfect casual and relaxing tile-placing/landscape-building game to spend a few hours, except for the hours might feel like minutes and the weekend is up before you realized. At least for me there was such a strong drive to place a few more tiles or to try to finish up a few more quests before quitting. Before long, I was starting another game right after the previous one just ended, and I was having a blast.

is simple, you start with a preexisting blank hexagonal piece and you can join its adjacent edges to tiles that spawn randomly. You can see your current tile plus the next two in the stack, along with the stack size that's easily visible. Once you use up your final tile, the game is over.

Many tile edges can join up if they don't match. Houses, fields, trees, or open space can meet up with each other as your world expands, while river paths and train tracks must meet other compatible tiles to keep linking together on the appropriate edges.

Occasionally, you may see a tile spawn that is more versatile, a water tile or a water train station. The tile that's entirely water can be matched with adjoining land or any water edge, as long as there's not a hindering edge. The water train station is the wildcard tile that you want to see, because often it will resolve a tight situation.

Some tiles will also spawn quests, such as joining so many houses together, or maybe tress, fields, or water-containing tiles. Completing each quest will earn you 5 extra tiles added to your stack, to keep the game going a bit longer. Starting with 40 tiles may not seem like a lot, but you can make your game last hundreds of turns if you play carefully and with a bit of extra luck.

The game does a good job showing you at any time where you can place the current tile in your hand by highlighting all available spaces, so you won't be left wondering. This feature is great and I found myself subconsciously using it a great deal.

The game gives you a good starting interactive tutorial to get you going. After that, it's entirely up to you to do as you wish.

After playing for a while, I began to see more complexity in the game itself. I started to choose placements very carefully, trying to achieve higher scores or to maximize the effectiveness of the placed tiles. Quests become more scarce and more difficult to complete, as the world expanded and the tile stack dwindled quickly due to increasing demand from multiple regions of the map.

The high score can be something that you go after, and locally the game tells you what your overall high score is so that you can try to beat it. Maximizing the number of compatible edges makes each tile score higher, a feature I only started paying attention to after playing a few hours in.

Expanding outward with branching arms may come with a risk, one that spreads your resources out too thin without being able to complete enough quests to keep your game going. Or maybe you could have used some of those tiles in a tighter and well-placed cluster to give some significant points.

There's a risk-reward system of closing off groups of like-joined tiles. Sometimes you will see a flag pop up in a group and that means if you close off the group so that the cluster cannot further expand, you will get a points bonus. But keeping that grouping open might mean an easier way to complete the next quest.

My advice is still to keep it simple, don't over-think it, go and have fun.

The game will display 3 objectives on the screen for you whenever you start a new game. It's a random set of 3 from the ones available to you. If you complete these objectives, you will unlock some tiles and some skins that you might see in subsequent games, expanding overall visual appearances, while the overall game stays the same.

To obtain more objectives, you will notice some tiles out in the unexplored areas on the map show a clear outline as you get closer. Even closer, you get a gray tile pop up but it's only revealed when you place a tile adjacent to it. These are all quests that once you complete, you will unlock new objectives for subsequent games. Once again, it's really for people who really want to go after them. These objectives are people who want those extra diversely appearing tiles or the different biomes available on the overall map.

If you just want to casually play the game without worrying about these objectives, that's fine too. Like I already mentioned, the game does not change a lick in basic mechanics no matter how many objectives you finish.

My first-look video is here. It's the first game I played after the tutorial, and it lasted almost an hour:


Mouse is all you need. There are some keyboard controls for camera movement, but after your world gets bigger, the mouse is much more efficient to use by itself.

The game has really adorable visuals, you can see right away from the screenshots and videos. You have some degree of zooming in and out also.

The music is very subtle, it's nice but if you are playing for hours on end, it might get a little old. It's okay to play your own music. If you zoom into the tiles that have moving locomotives or boats, you can hear a bit louder sound effects. Zoomed out, they are not really audible at all.

Anyone looking for a casual and relaxing experience that's also a strategic puzzle game.

Launching into Early Access, the price is quite reasonable at $9.99 with regional pricing. The game is definitely worth it and has the polish needed to already not feel like it's still in development.

Of course any game can use some improvements, and so these are a few things I have identified as of writing at the beginning stages of Early Access that would make it a better game for me:
1. Wider zooming/movement possibilities. When the map gets rather sizeable at times, rotating and moving to and from different parts of the world can start to feel cumbersome. It would be nice to be able to have a wider zoom or a mini-map toggle that allows the player to click and go to another part of the map.
2. Quest tracker. Sometimes quitting a game and restarting later I feel overwhelmed by the number of quests on-going and have trouble keeping them straight in my head. An optional tracker would be fantastic.
3. Tile saving. I would love to be able to save a tile for later, from time to time. Just a personal wish, nothing more. The game mechanics work fine the way they are.
4. Infinite/Sandbox mode. The completely stress free, no end, just simply building more and more, shaping without worrying about the tile stack dwindling.
5. Optimization. The game runs smoothly, and the playing goes well. But when games have increasing complexity with more tiles added to the map, it starts to really use up computer resources.

is pure awesome fun even on Day 1 of its Early Access period. I cannot wait to see the additional updates and further development that may add more content or make it more polished. Its user-friendly interface and family-friendly appearances make this a game that anyone can play and enjoy. And, should you want some challenges, they are there too.

Get this game and start shaping some really neat looking worlds, one tile at a time!

Score: 9.5/10

I love RTSs and city builders, I have since the early days of Sim City and Warcraft II. I always wanted that sort of gameplay, but without the upkeep/conflict.

This is a relaxing, soothing game. It's not here to measure your epeen, it's not here to prove how much better you are than the computer/ai/opponent. This is a game to play when the day has been too much and you need to UNWIND.

Remember unwinding? Remember playing games for fun instead of endless challenge? Remember games as an escape from the horrors of reality? Dorfromantik does.

The gameplay is very similar to a hexagonal Carcassonne, where the challenge is in the tile laying not the upkeep and maintenance, but without Carcassonne's ridiculous point counting system.

I think even full price is well worth the enjoyment you can get from this.

A sweet little timekiller. The rules are simple (just match the tiles' edges to create large fields/villages/forests), but that's not a bad thing — the complexity comes from the sheer number of possible combinations.

I like how there are different styles of play. Building, say, a huge field is chill and relaxed, while trying to score a chain of perfect placements demands concentration and can become challenging.

However, this game lacks interesting goals. Sure, they nudge you towards slightly different playstyles, but mostly it's just more of the same. Build a long road, then a longer road, then an even longer road. it gets repetitive after a while, and the game does nothing to spice it up.

Then again, I'm perfectly content with getting 20 hours of chill fun from a game like this.

Dorfromantik, could be romantik, but its not, its real GEM of a game, very addictive, relaxing, the music is very peaceful and a pleasure to listen to while playing. This game described in my own personal words is a score chasing puzzler and a very addictive , relaxing and enjoyable one at that. You get a random stack of hexagon tiles to place, place then carefully. so you get the best out of scores, turning them for best group placements, if you get a cross dont place, look for the best scores to get ticks. You can get good runs and bad runs, I just get lucky so I base my runs on good placements and luck. Sorry I cant describe this Gem of a game, but based on my play time and enjoyment, the game will not disappoint young or older players. I hope to see more options added to this game, like maybe saving a tile you cant place yet, by placing in another pile, and undo feature for poor placements perhaps, and maybe more biomes and animals to unlock. The game is great as is YES, but more would be even better. Game is EA and more will come Im sure.

Posted: July 8, 2021
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I did not find this game relaxing.

It bills itself as a relaxing puzzle game in the style of Carcassonne - take the next tile, place it where it fits best, and continue until the end of the game. It's the "until the end of the game" part where the relaxation turns into stress.

Each game you're provided a limited number of tiles. When you run out of tiles to place the game ends. To increase the number of tiles in your stack you're given "quests" to complete. These quests fall into two categories: "get N or more tiles of this type in a group" or "get exactly N tiles of this type in a group". A river with exactly 5 tiles, a city with 10 or more houses, a forest with 30 or more trees, etc. These quests grow in magnitude as the game progresses (River with 20 tiles! City with 100 houses! Forest with 400 trees!)

Instead of trying to place tiles to where they best 'fit', matching their features with the terrain, you're forced to cultivate large groups of like features to appease the quest system. You can't have a handful of small towns, you have to have a massive metropolis (that 300+ house goal isn't going to complete itself!). You can't have a countryside with sporadic forests, you have to have a dense wilderness. You can't have several small farms, you have to make an industrial-scale agricultural zone.

This is made worse by the "exact number" quests. You'll simultaneously be dealt a quest for a 200+ group of houses at the same time as a group of 12 (no more, no less) houses. You need to place the tiles close enough to eventually satisfy the former goal while not yet connecting them lest you sabotage the latter. Here's hoping the tiles are contiguous and of the right type: not too large so as to go over the exact number needed, yet not too small so as to "cap" the group and prevent it from expanding further.

The result is a micromanaging nightmare, trying to place your tiles in the exact ways needed to satisfy the quest system while at the mercy of the random tile generator. There is no time to relax, you have to worry exactly how best to place the next random tile so as to put a stopper in the ever-dwindling count of tiles left to place. All you can do is hope that the next tile has exactly two houses so you can complete that 12 house group quest and get 10 more tiles to complete the 200+ grain quest in order to get 10 more tiles to complete the 400+ forest quest which will give you 10 more tiles to complete the 30+ river quest which will get you 10 tiles to

Everything in the game from the art style to the music is designed to be relaxing. Everything except the game itself.

I refunded my purchase.

Posted: May 29, 2017
A Roller Coaster Theme Park Sandbox Game
YouTube™ Video: Planet Coaster Workshop Spotlight || The Walking Dead Roller Coaster 
Views: 1,163
If you own Planet Coaster you can download the park here: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=883697908&searchtext= 🌟-Join my Steam Group:...


There's a lot to love about this game, but i'm just going to mention a few things that surprised me.

+ Workshop support. Some people have created some unbelievable roller coasters and theme parks that are absolutely amazing! Even if you don't care about designing your own park or own rides you can easily find user created ones and ride them yourself which to me was extremely entertaining! ( I suggest checking out the Walking Dead Roller Coaster, Alice in Wonderland, and one called "Dread Horror Roller Coaster" which has it's own custom music )
+ You can import your own sound or music files for any ride in your park, and it's extremely simple to do so.
+ Designing my first roller coaster was surprisingly simple and very intuitive. It'll take maybe 5-10minutes to learn, but once you do you will be able to build anything you can imagine and test them out.
+ First person view for every ride in the park! There's also multiple other camera angles, and for me it was a joy to just watch people ride all the rides in the park.
+ Water raft rides and Go Karts!
+ Loads of other rides all of which you might see at real theme parks
+ A sandbox mode with unlimited money
+ A variety of challenge levels that have you fixing up a not-so-good pre-built park.
+ The soundtrack of planet coaster which plays in the main menu and in-game is absolutely wonderful. Very relaxing and uplifting.



- If a ride is too scary people won't ride it. While this may be "realistic" I was very disappointed in this. I like to build elaborate insane roller coasters, and it's a shame no one in the park will ride it...even if it's free... :,(
- There's not very many pre-built shops or decorations. The one's that they give you at the start also have wildly different themes, and don't seem to fit in very well unless you design your own.
- Strangely enough, I didn't really get into the whole thrill of designing my own park. Once you get a few shops, some rides, and plop down some staff the game plays for you and there's really not very much "management" to be found.

Posted: April 3, 2017
Going into Planet Coaster I had high expectations. I hadn't played theme park games for a while and heard great things about Planet Coaster. Besides that, It's from the developers of Rollercoaster Tycoon 3. Starting out I decided to try the career mode, something I recommend all of you to do. It explains the basics of the game throughout all of the missions and shows you a bit what the game has to offer. At first, the game seemed flawless. Everything about it was perfect. But although Planet Coaster is one of the best games i've played in while, it has it's flaws.

So what exactly are these flaws i'm talking about and are they really that important for your experience? Well.. That depends on why you're buying Planet Coaster.
The main flaw with the game seems to be the management system. At first it seems great, but soon enough you'll find out it doesn't really have that much depth in it.
Now is it really all that bad? No. there's still a decent amount of management to be done. From choosing the prices of your rides to deciding how much salt you wanna sell on those delicious frites. Unfortunately sometimes you get the feeling not every decision you make in the management part of the game really matters all that much.

The game is more build focussed. With a ton of scenery items you can pretty much create/recreate everything you want. And building is really well done. Yea it has it flaws, like objects needing to be split from a building in order to rotate/place it properly etc. but overall it works really good. Often enough i found myself casually building looking at the clock only to realize i've already been working the whole night on this small building since the game offers you so much options. A few downsides to the building system however are: Water being really hard to place and creating coasters can be difficult thanks to the Fear/Excitement/Nausea ratings.

Now 1 thing needs to be said when writing a review about Planet Coaster. the game looks absolutely gorgous! The cartoonish style, the water effects, the lights at night, the details and animations. It's just looks perfect. The game runs really smooth aswell, until... you start building a real park from scratch. At first everything seemed to run great, but after a couple of thousand objects the game starts to lagg/stutter especially when zooming in or out. And yea, you will have thousands of objects in your park. Creating a ride will easily put you at 1-2 thousand objects. But i still found myself walking/flying through my own park often enough just because everything looks and sounds so amazing. Because yea, the sound in this game is amazing aswell. People cheering, the water and all of the different ride sound effects make it feel like a real theme park.

The support this game gets is insane, and it gives me hope. Apparently there are still developers out there that care about their game after release. Lots of free updates with bug fixes, new scenery, new rides/coasters and even new mechanics are are being released every couple of weeks. Next to these amazing updates, the developers actually take time to interact with the players. They listen to what their fans want and every week they feature the best creations placed on the workshop in their stream.

Before buying, just keep in mind, this game is aimed mostly towards building. This requires you to be a bit creative otherwise you'll find yourself with a lack of ideas since the game doesn't have that much premade scenery/rides. However, the workshop makes up for that part in my opinion. Besides that i highly recommend this game. It's probably one of the best, if not the best theme park game you'll found out there, atleast for me it is.

Posted: April 20, 2017
I abslolutely LOVE this game. I am in my 40s and I actually design attractions for real parks for a living. Alot of people talk about the lag and the game play. I have found that if you keep simplicity in mind and create large parks with only scenery where the guests would see it in reality, keep your que lines decorated with simple landscaping and flora, use only a few props for decorating purposes and keep a nice clean and open approach, you will have seamless and enjoyable play. It is very realistic in it's management, marketing and security features, as well. If you start with a small area, only allow 200 in your park, let it become popular, then add an area, allow another 100 people in and so forth. You will find that the park almost runs itself with very little problems.

I am an old school RCT player. I have created rides and content for RCT3 for a long time. This game made all of that so much easier and the ability to share creations with others is one of the best features of this game. Would I change anything? Not really. Frontier seems to be on top of things and the updates and customer service is near perfect. So in closing, remember this: There are folks like myself out here using this program to create the new and exciting things you see in the real world every day and using it to test reactions and popularity. It is truly a theme park creator in the most literal sense.

I absolutely love theme park simulation games. The entire RCT series I adored. I am happy to confirm, that is game is in fact a great game and makes a good spiritual successor to the RCT series. However I can absolutely NOT recommend you buy this game.
