Even to this day I look at a DLC pack thinking "Wow, that is a cool ride and would make a great addition to my park". Then scroll down to see it is a whopping 16 DOLLARS FOR A FEW NEW BLUEPRINTS AND A COUPLE EXTRA RIDES? It is absolutely unbelievable. This game had so much potential, but Frontier's shameless greed has turned this game into a micro-transaction cash-grab. Let me rephrase that- a MAJOR-transaction cash grab, because for the deluxe edition (all of the DLC), it totals 110 dollars for a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ theme park sim.

Come on Frontier, I desperately hope you read this review. You have buried this game in unacceptable DLC-based bullcrap and I am started to lose the itch to play it. It is absolutely brutal how many features in the DLC should have just been added to the game. If you even do update the game that is, because lately it seems you have only been adding new DLC.

I could rant about this for so long but I should probably stop now. Frontier has lost my respect for this disgusting materialism.

EDIT: This review was posted 4 years ago; however, I still have absolutely ZERO shame in writing this. Go take a look at Planet Zoo if you haven't. The amount of DLC for that game has already surpassed the amount for Planet Coaster and the game hasn't been around nearly as long. RCT 3, which was arguably the best theme park management game, only had 2 DLC which completely innovated the game. Frontier chose the contemporary micro-transaction model for their games, introducing high-priced DLC for a low quantity of content.
If you want to disagree with me and pay enormous sums of money to enjoy these games completely, that's fine. But I would start re-evaluating why you're meat-riding this company when they are malicious enough to allow you to USE the DLC, but not save it in your park. DIsgusting.

Posted: January 19, 2017
I played this game and thought it was gorgeous. Then I realized I had it on the lowest graphics setting.

I want to call this a worthy successor to the Roller Coaster Tycoon series. Worthy, yes. Actually, Planet Coaster is so good it utterly eclipses anything that's come before it. But a "Tycoon" it is not. Those games emphasized management, and while Planet Coaster has that, it's not the focus. Planet Coaster is all about building. It reminds me of the earliest Sim City titles, where you lost yourself expanding your city--zoning, power plants, density and all that. The hurdles of tax management was more a welcome speed bump than the reason you play the game.

That's what Planet Coaster feels like. It's 1 a.m., and you're putting little lanterns in your digital castle, but you bite your lip and second-guess those stone colonnades. Are they tacky? Do they clash with lintels? Technically, you're only supposed to be doing this for some scenery rating, but it was 100 percent thirty minutes ago and now you're planting Tuscan Cypresses everywhere. It's sounds like a pain in the ass, and the first time you do it, it is, but you learn the keyboard shortcuts, get a bit patient, and then it's pure zen. Later, sleep.

Is Planet Coaster a great game? Kinda. You can't teach a computer (yet) what makes good aesthetics, so the Roller Coaster Tycoon games have always relied on their players to be wacky perfectionists who are willing to build real parks rather than exploity thingamajigs. Because, for all the intricate details, slaving over a coaster station for hours is the same as zapping down a few Golden Chests, beating the dust off your hands, and calling it a day. You can play Planet Coaster like that, just throwing down random scenery pieces in a big pile until you get 100%, doing min-max shenanigans. In another context, this spammy behavior would be considered a weakness of the game. Only a game like Planet Coaster is it considered a weakness of the .

But that's all OK. Because Planet Coaster isn't supposed to be played. It's an experience, like hanging out in your zen garden, spreading happiness and joy for the fun of it. Not to mention it's gorgeous, and runs as smooth as cream on high graphics settings.

I'm working on a "starry kingdom" themed park right now. Meanwhile, I'm trawling their youtube, hoping to get a glimpse of what else is coming out. I got my fingers crossed for hotels, a Halloween theme, and restaurants.

Posted: April 9, 2019
Ever since my mom bought me a one dollar copy of "Roller Coaster Tycoon 2" at Dollar General when I was 12, I've had a special place in my heart for theme park sims. The feeling of unbridled creativity and freedom that RCT2 was unrivaled for quite some time... games like RCT3, NoLimits, and Parkitecht were and are fantastic games/sims, and I enjoyed them (and continue to enjoy them) immensely. However, none of them ever lived up to my experience with RCT2.

Until now.

I'm going to start with the things I don't like about the game and gush about it near the end.

1.) The organization of building and scenery pieces is confusing. There doesn't seem to be much logic in the way "Scenery" is separated from "Building," even though you can find similar objects in both categories. It seems to me that the two tabs should be merged into one, and then subdivided for better organization.
2.) Some objects are stuck to a grid, and others are not. This makes it frustrating when you find the perfect piece to use, but it's constrained to a grid and cannot be turned upside down. A better solution would have been to give EVERY piece in the game a grid constraint and a free form constraint, then let us choose when to activate grid movement.
3.) There is no underwater effect.
4.) There is no weather.
5.) Park management from a financial perspective is really cut-and-dry. It isn't bad, it's just that the "sim" element of the game doesn't have much meat on its bones.

Okay, now that we got that out of the way, what's good about it?

The variety of coasters, rides, transport rides, shops, scenery, building items, music, and path styles is amazing. The graphics are incredible. The lighting is insanely good. The terrain tools are the best on the market. The level of detail and freedom you are given is astounding. The music and sound design are top notch. I'm running out of synonyms for "really really damn good."

On top of that, there is Steam Workshop support and the new Theme Makers Toolkit, which allows you to import your own 3D models into the game. Not to mention that Planet Coaster has one of the most amazing and helpful communities out there.

Just buy the game. Trust me.

Posted: November 21, 2016
The Rollercoaster Tycoon games were near and dear to my heart growing up. I love management and tycoon games, and for whatever reason the magic of theme parks made a really great video game. I’ve lost hours and hours to the scenarios in RCT 1, building in the sandbox in RCT 2, and playing with various trainers to break the game how I see fit. RCT 3, however, marked a rough transition into 3D. There were a lot of problems with the game, and I honestly never enjoyed them very much.

There’s business drama of some sort with the ownership of the name of the game, and there actually is an Atari published successor to RCT 3 called Rollercoaster Tycoon World, but apparently the verdict is that the entire thing is a hot mess. The folks who developed RCT 3, Frontier Development, went on to create Planet Coaster as a spiritual successor to the RCT series.

Although I didn’t enjoy RCT 3 very much, I’ve really loved my time with Planet Coaster, and I can already tell that I’m going to be spending a nasty amount of time with this game. There is a lot to digest here, and I think that a lot of the criticisms I have won’t apply to the majority of people who would be interested in buying this game. I think it is necessary to give the game two ratings – one for casual folks who are looking for a fun tycoon game, and one for people who have a Drexler patched copy of RCT 1.

It really seems as if Frontier aimed to make this game primarily a sandbox game with a dependence on user-generated content. The campaign is amazingly short, and some missions can actually be finished in a matter of seconds on accident. There are tons of coaster types, shop types, and scenery objects but very few ploppable pre-built options. The shops you can place down are little 1x1 generic box-shaped grid pieces that are clearly meant to be built upon, and the game also defaults you into a building view for constructing something around it. Very few sample coasters exist to play with. There are tons of generic scenery and building blocks for building cool stuff, though. If you’re willing to spend hours building things, you’re in luck!

The workshop support is really easy. You open it up in the shift+tab menu, subscribe to something, and it is immediately in your game. The workshop tagging needs a lot of cleaning up right now, and it can be difficult to find quality content. Even though the integration is pretty simple, it isn’t very fun to go hunting for good content to use in your maps. The really complex workshop items also sometimes come unfinished due to built-in limits the workshop has, which makes me wonder because this game really emphasizes the user-created content aspect. I’ve downloaded more than one item that requires me to build the roof, or place the paths, and it can get really frustrating to finish these things sometimes. Downloading maps and other things that people have worked on is a lot of fun, there are some really incredible things out there.

A huge problem I had with RCT3 is that building precisely in a 3D space is difficult. I have similar problems with Cities: Skylines when compared to Simcity 4; 3D spaces end up with weird curves and other buggy moments when building things. Planet Coaster is also victim to this. You’ll probably end up with lots of oddly shaped pathways and coaster supports. This is a difficult problem to explain but it becomes really evident when you’re trying to connect curved pathways together that are at slightly different angles. They’ll never couple together cleanly and leave weird gaps.

I have a lot of Quality-of-life problems that I wish this game had. I wish I could have my coasters constantly testing without a janky workaround, and I wish I could run ghost trains instead of constantly crashing real trains. If I’m in a scenario trying to build a coaster, it’s goofy that I can keep crashing my trains and hitting the peeps and nobody seems to mind. I feel like nobody on earth wants to delete their entire roller coaster when they hit the “delete” key while placing paths after they built a coaster. The UI is really ugly and feels like it is in beta still, and it is tough to navigate to find what I need.

I feel like the way the game measures stats for rides is somewhat broken, because I’ll have a coaster that has a great rating up until the last ten seconds where it brakes going into the station and slows down, and that little section will kill the average of my coaster making everyone think it is boring. I had a coaster in one map with a 135mph top speed and a 100 meter drop with tons of twists and lots of great moments, but because the last thirty seconds were a slow moment to ease back into the station, people in my park thought it was boring and avoided riding it. I used to be able to build incredible coasters in RCT1/2 (9+ excitement), but I can’t seem to break 5 excitement in Planet Coaster.

I have a lot of things I could say about this game, but ultimately Steam has a review limit, so I’m going to wrap it up.

I would not recommend this game if you are looking for a management game, or if the scenarios were the meat of your playtime in RCT1. You’ll likely blow through the scenarios very quickly, and you’ll definitely be frustrated at the lack of ploppable coasters and buildings. If you don’t enjoy sitting down to work on the right angle to bank your coasters, I would probably recommend skipping this game.

If you’re looking for a really hardcore sandbox to spend hours building the monster roller coaster of your dreams, this is probably your game. After all of your hard work setting up trigger points, banking turns, measuring speed, you can sit down and ride your coaster. Riding things is pretty damn fun after all your work is done.

If you also like to download things from the workshop, and think you could get a lot of fun out of downloading crazy things that people have spent hours working on, you could probably eek some good time out of this.

I have a tough time giving a good rating to this game, but I also don’t feel like it is a bad game. I feel like it is a lazy game. I don’t get why they didn’t include more ploppable samples for players to use. There are tons of coaster types, at least two dozen, and then there are something like seven sample coasters. That’s just silly, and these depressing numbers carry over to every part of the game. I don’t get why there are only nine measly scenarios. The sandbox maps the game ships with are boring flatlands. The whole thing feels janky.

But I know the potential this game has. With very little time since the game has released, folks have already build some incredible stuff. I’m very curious what is to come.

Whether or not you'll like this game boils down to whether or not you like intense creative sandboxes. This is not a good management game, even if the game makes an attempt at being one. The potential is certainly here, since you have some pretty powerful control over certain aspects of the park, such as opening times (which doesn't seem to change anything), staff management, and customizable options with vendors. The management side of the game can be totally trivialized by putting down a cluster of shops and rides very close to your entrance. Congratulations on the money farm.

If you're the kind of person who played Rollercoaster Tycoon, placed a balloon shop, and thought to yourself about how annoying it was that the balloon shop was a few pixels taller than all the other shops requiring an entirely special setup to fit it inside a building, then Planet Coaster just might be the game for you. This is the spiritual successor to those hundreds of hours we spent as a kid playing RCT1 with the Drexler patch and a trainer, or building sandbox coasters in RCT2, and even riding your custom rides in RCT3.

Posted: November 21, 2016
I expected a sequel to RCT3, and I got it, from the same devs, under name of Planet Coaster.

This is absolutely a great title for every fan of RCT franchise, it has everything it should, and support for Steam workshop which is truly great, opening doors to nearly every single thing you could ever ask for. I must admit that initially I was sceptical as making a sequel to a successful game usually leads to disappointment and overhype, but in this case I simply couldn't expect anything more - the game has exactly what I imagined, and while some extra content such as extra campaigns, rides and coasters are welcome, I can't really claim that there is not enough considering that there will be only more content in future, both from developers and the community.

I give it strong 9/10, and suggest to grab ASAP for every RCT fan that expects RCT3 in 2016.

Posted: December 6, 2016
Great Creative Game / Not So Strong Management Game

The creative side of this game is incredible and while building you really feel as though there are no limits.
The management side of the game is shallow and is basically the same model as the old Chris Sawyer RCT games. There is certainly a lot of room for improvement on this front and although the scenarios are generally quite well built, they lack the variety in their challenge. I imagine that this will be improved upon with updates down the line, but even without bolstering this side of the game, I can see myself getting more than my value out of the money spent.
Well worth it so long as you go in with the expectation that this is mostly a creative outlet and not so much a strategy/management game.

Posted: August 18, 2020
I have no one to blame but myself for getting my hopes up; but, this is definitely not Roller Coaster Tycoon, it's not even really a "tycoon" game.

The store page quite clearly states this is a simulation, and simulation it is. You build a theme park and simulate some rides, but it's very much the sandbox without the game portion. Yes there is endless, potentially 100's of hours of messing around and building things just to watch it all flow like a fishbowl in front of you.

I can't slam the game for successfully doing what it claims to do, this is a very in depth and dare I say amazing simulation of a theme park. Unfortunately for me I was looking for more of a tycoon/management game so I'm a little disappointed; but that's not the games fault.

So, if you want a theme park simulation that let's you build roller coasters, I don't know of any that I could recommend that are better than this. But it is very much a simulation/builder.
---

Posted: October 26, 2017
If you prefer video version:
YouTube™ Video: My thoughts on Planet Coaster 
Views: 2,562
On sale now at Frontier Store (steam key): https://www.frontierstore.net/usd/games/planet-coaster-cat.html I originally did not buy this because reviews said it was too easy.


Originally, the reviews for this game came back, and I wasn't interested. The reviews were not bad, I just noticed a recoccuring theme that the game was not hard, it did not provide a challenge.

Well, I'm here to tell you that my concerns were faulty, because of two reasons.

1. The game has a challenge mode, and the "harder" difficulty is definitely a challenge. It may not be quite as brutal as some other games, but it gave me what I needed.

2. Probably most importantly, I found that difficulty did not matter. The game challenges me in other ways. It didn't matter if the threat of looming bankruptcy from making one mistake was there or not. I need that in other games, like Transport Fever, for example. However, in Planet Coaster, I was challenged by making my people happy, and that is really what the entire game is about.

It is so much fun to build a good roller coaster. It is a huge challenge and there are near infinite possibilities. I found that you cannot just slap a bunch of pieces together. There is a true art to making people excited, but not too fearful and not too nauseous. You typically want a moment or two after some crazy loops or high-G turns to let their fear die off, but you have to time this properly otherwise their excitement will die off and then the ride will be a bust.

The above might be easy, if you didn't have to deal with darn natural laws, like gravity. So many times, I'd have the perfect combination setup, but then realize, that I didn't have enough speed for the track piece or combo I needed. By putting in a second chain lift at the wrong time, you could doom your ride to boredom.

I found it immensely pleasurable to craft a masterpiece to fit in with the terrain, or loop around buildings, all in an effort to strive towards making that "perfect" ride that is ever eluding me.

I would recommend this game to perfectionists or really, anybody who enjoys building games.

Posted: June 24, 2021
Ok, I had a LOT of fun with this game. I never player roller coaster tycoon but some compare it to that.
I was a bit confused when first loading it so I will try to help
The game has 3 modes
Career, Sandbox, Challenge.
Career is like campaign mode in other games, you start with a very mini park and you have to improve it to earn stars, that's it. You look up the objectives and try to meet them. Eventually you get into a grove.
Sandbox is wide open just build a park, no monetary constraints
Challenge is Sandbox but within a budget, you have to earn money in order to build things
I had the most fun with the career challenges. I finished most of them.
Quick tip, open sandbox to design your coaster for each level, then save that blueprint then use it in career. Trying to build the coaster WHILE running the park is hard.

Posted: January 12, 2019
This game is absolutely fantastic! A true love letter to Theme Park Sim enthusiasts and I very much love it!

So why am I not recommending it?

The large ammount of DLC.

As of today (12th of January 2019) there's 80€ worth of DLC, you could buy the base game TWICE with that money. Not only that but I feel that some of the DLC content should've already been present with the base game. The DLC rarely goes on sale and even if it does it's still far too expensive for what it is.

I know that I'm probably gonna get feces throw at me for saying these things by the more hardcore fans of this game, but what I'm saying is absolutely no lie. There is absolutely nothing wrong with supporting your favourite developers, but ever since Frontier figured out that "Hey, we can just throw any DLC out there and people will buy it!" they've gone down a "Sims 4 DLC" path.

I love this game, I may have not have spent as much time with it as I would have liked yet but I'll continue to play it on and off. I want it to succeed but if it continues on this path it'll simply be seen as another Paradox/EA game due to its DLC practices, losing a lot of possible customers and attention in the process.

If you enjoy designing beautiful parks with a little bit of management on the side, this game is great for you, bear in mind however that without the DLC you'll be pretty constricted with what you can do in terms of themes and rides and will have to use your imagination/creativity to their full potential (Which thankfully are still free on this day and age).
I don't recommend that you enable this excessive DLC practice by Frontier, thus you should stay away from the DLC.
But If you really want the DLC, make sure to get it heavily discounted, even if it means getting them outside of STEAM like on Humble Bundle.

Thank you for reading and have a wonderful day! :)

Posted: October 11, 2017
Design, build, manage

Wow this game. It’s what I’ve waited for after Theme park, which was one of my favorite games of the genre along with Theme hospital.
First I want to say if you’re a creative person just buy it, don’t think, just throw your money at developers and buy this amazing game. It’s designed for creative people, you can build anything, you can choose even the smallest details, design your park as you wish.You can design absolutely everything. Your rides, your shops, your paths etc. I'm not a creative person, i don't use everything the game has to offer but i still love it.

The game has different modes. Career where you’re given the map and partly built park and you must achieve the given goals. It starts from the easy goals and goes to challenging ones later when you progress further in career.
There also are challenge and free play mode where you could spend many hours.
There are different maps/locations and themes. You can build a fairy tale park or a pirate themed park or buy a DLC and build something else. Yes it has DLC, but developers are constantly updating the game and adding free content so I don’t see anything wrong with it.

Graphics are outstanding. I’ve never seen such graphics in this type of game. It looks better than some adventure/fps games. You can zoom in and see every detail, everything looks so nice and detailed, no pixels or anything. Park visitors are well detailed, park feels alive, people even have face animations which are on the level of Sims probably. Knowing there are hundreds or even thousands of people in your par it’s really impressive.
There’s night and day cycle, with correct lighting decorations the park at night looks beautiful, you can stare at it and forget that someone’s just got pickpocketed or someone just quit their job.

Of course the graphics come at a price. To see all the beauty you’ll need a good PC. I’m not saying it’s badly optimized, in my opinion optimization is very good, it’s just with such detailed graphics you can’t expect a big park to run on steady 60fps. But the performance is far better than cities skylines or some other games.

Sound pleases your ears from the moment you start the game. And park sounds just great. When you zoom in to a ride you feel like you’re really there. Developers done a great job in sound department.

Of course the game doesn’t end with designing and building your park. It has management. But this is what developers could improve. The management isn’t bad but not very good either. I would like to have deeper management system where you could really think what to do and how to improve your profits. Now it’s mostly increasing/decreasing the prices, taking loans and hiring staff. You still need to adjust these things but the whole management just not deep enough.

And don’t forget the workshop support, you can download tons of content from there.

I definitely recommend this game, the price is just right, developers not abandoning the game and constantly improving it. It will suck you in and after an hour you realize you’ve played for 3 hours.

Posted: November 11, 2019
If you are trying to decide between this and Parkitect, be aware that they are two entirely different games with only a few similarities. Both are sims set in amusement park worlds and both use the Workshop to greatly enhance the play experience (although Planet Coaster goes well beyond that, which I talk about below). That's pretty much all that's shared between these two games which seem, on the surface, to be virtually identical. I play both of them and prefer Planet Coaster, although I have nearly 120 hours played in Parkitect as well (at time of update). Parkitect is a much more streamlined and slimmed down simulation and management game, whereas Planet Coaster is something that can go as far and deep as you want. PlanCo also runs on a powerful engine, so it looks amazing, but you will need to have at least a relatively modern GPU/PC that can handle the latest shaders and Direct X extensions and features. Planet Coaster goes big in the graphics department as well as the customization department, including a ridiculously huge Steam Workshop with nearly a quarter million blueprints available as I write this, but Frontier went even further than that...

As I mentioned before, PlanCo also offers the completely free Theme Maker's Toolkit, which allows you to import 3D objects that you download or create directly into the game and become usable game assets in the game library (as well as being a shareable blueprint for the Workshop), all automatically done by PlanCo's web app. Yes, you can literally create anything you want in this game as long as it meets some size and scope requirements. That is the of micro-management sims, in my opinion. However, it does take time and skill to create objects with Blender (free) and GIMP (free), but there are millions of free, compatible and completely ready-to-submit object renders out there, free to download. Not everyone has the time or desire to learn 3D object modeling for a Steam game, but someone out there has probably already made whatever it is you are thinking of (free or otherwise).

If you want to go down the rabbit hole of amusement park creation and simulation and want Challenge modes, Career modes, and micro-customization abilities in even a normal Sandbox environment, this is the game you want. If you don't want to spend so much time learning a game and handling the tiny details, but want to run an amusement park, look into Parkitect.

Posted: October 14, 2021
I came down with a stomach condition last year, wasn't able to eat much and when i did, I often ended up in a lot of pain, which also kept me from sleeping. When I was in a lot of pain one of the few things I was able to enjoy, and took my mind off it, was this game.

I'm not a super creative person and usually in games like this I just can't find where to start, or where to get inspiration. The pre built assets were really helpful to me and I enjoyed building coasters way more than I thought I would. Being able to get the block section times perfectly lined up with the load/unload times, and always having a car sliding into the station right after one leaves, feels amazing. The AI in this game are actually really good, they rarely get caught up on geometry, they load in the same way everytime. It's actually really reliable. The assets are gorgeous, and have a pretty timeless style, this game still looks good, even in the messed up way you're going to place things. There's isn't much music, but what's there is great. The main theme makes me feel really comfortable and safe. I don't know why, but when I launch it and I hear that music I just feel better. The attitude of this game as a whole is very positive, friendly and welcoming, and I think that is a large part of why I enjoy it so much.

It's not a perfect game, I do have some small gripes. It would be cool just to be able to paintbrush pathways and have big paved areas for seating and stuff. When you setup block sections you can only select how many trains you want running on your track, not which block sections you want them to start at. Which would be hard to do, but would be nice. It feels like the block sections are just kind of a happy accident if you can get the ones populated that you want at the end of building the coaster.

All that said, It's one of the best designer/simulator games I've played. I got it on sale, but I feel like it is worth full price. It's a comfort sort of game, if you're in a lot of pain, or in a bad situation, I highly recommend getting lost in the joy and nostalgia of building your own theme park.

Just as a tip, larger is rarely better. Scale down your rides and keep things a little simpler, and you'll have an easier time

Posted: May 27, 2020
On one hand i absolutely adore this game. It's almost everything i & others wanted in a theme park builder after having to wait so long after RCT3 & avoiding the rubbish from that other company. It's gorgeous, full of content, can be challenging if you choose, full of nice details to create a realistic park etc.

However i can't not mention it's glaring faults;

1. They made the totally wrong decision to build on DX11 & not DX12. They've said themselves that's the reason for the poor performance once the park gets a little bigger & with more guests. It's so frustrating to have a game this good but unable to do anything decent with it. No matter what your specs. It's bottle-necked due to DX11 & the way it uses the CPU.

2. The management aspect isn't on the level it should be for a game like this. It needed more depth. Something they corrected mostly with Planet Zoo.

3. Due to the performance limitations (i think), the campaign parks they built all feel underwhelming, sparse & unrealistic.

4. Not as important but the water tech used could've been better (DX11 performance limitation decisions i imagine). It's better then nothing but it's not dynamic or fluid. Doesn't react to anything unless it's baked in. It would've been nice to use the great terrain tools to create realistic waterfalls/flowing rivers etc.

Don't get me wrong, i love this game. But every time i go back to it, i feel a little disappointed & frustrated knowing it could've easily been far better then it is.

I'm not holding my breath but i truly hope they make a second one sometime & correct these issue's. What a game that would be.

Posted: November 19, 2016
I love this game. I can already say it is the best theme park game i ever played.

This game is so great because it is limitless in regards to building and creativity.
The amount of themes looks okay but once you start combining items from other themes together you can basically make any theme you can imagine.
Lovely graphics, art design and the detail is extraordinary and looks so realistic.

There is a good amount of Flat rides, a great amount of Coasters, 2 Transport rides and they even added some water rides like the log flumes and river rapids.
You can also make Darkrides and there are options to set trigger events to your rides and coasters.
For those who like their own music better then the ingame music, wich is great, you can add custom music to the rides and speakers.

The park management is very in-depth and allows you to do just about everything you need as a park manager.

My final verdict (based on theme park games): 10/10

Posted: November 28, 2016
Planet Coaster is one of those rare gems which hits that balance of strategy, management and creativity. Whether you're building a crazy rollercoaster, or creating a storefront piece by piece, you're going to find yourself sinking hours into this game, and loving every moment of it.

The career mode is a great place to start with the game, as it gives you very specific scenarios to overcome. It's a nice intro to learning all of the mechinics. There are a handful of scenarios to deal with, and each one gives you multiple tiers of accomplishment (bronze/silver/gold) to finish. I do wish there were more career scenarios, but the game has other modes which compensate for the lack of "missions".

Challenge mode is sort of an expansion on career mode, but is more free-form. You start a park that has specific goals, but it's almost sandbox in nature. Challenges are dynamically given out, and you must spend your limited income to build a successful park, and gain more revenue for future additions. There is technically no "end" to these challenge missions, from what I can tell (at least as far as I've gotten into them).

Sandbox mode is the ultimate creative senario. No monetary limits, no building or research limits. You can building anything you want, anywhere you want, and not having to worry about fiscal management. It's a great place to create structures or coasters that you can then save out as Blueprints, to print into your challenge worlds.

Building in the game is very fun. Building a coaster is accomplished via a system of dynamically generated spline sections, as well as pre-build sections of spirals/corkscrews and the like. There are many different types of coasters, from old wooden classics, to superman-style, catapult-launched modern coasters. Pretty much something for everyone.

The bigger artist element comes with the PBP (piece by piece) building method. There are a ton of individual assets in the game (sconces, lights, wall sections, pillars, and more) each fitting a general theme (wood/scifi/stone/etc) that gives you a plethora of choices for you to modularly snap things together, and create something new and exciting. Kind of like more refined Lego building.

There are minor gripes I have with the game, like how the coaster splines sometimes behave, or if they had more verbose feedback from guests. Giving the designer more information about what affects partk beauty, and how, would also be nice. Some inconsistency issues, like decorations only affecting guest feedback when placed around queue areas. Minor building issues as well. Nothing super major, and things that will hopefully get patched in the near future

Overall, a very fun game for people of all ages, and I would definitely recommend it for anyone who is a fan of the genre, or just being creative in general.

Posted: December 14, 2017
I've been meaning to make a review for this game, but I've just been too busy playing the damn thing than to make time to give it it's well deserved praise! I'd like to give this a proper review so hopefully I don't get too drawn out with it.

TL;DR: Planet Coaster is the Disneyland of Theme Park Simulator games and playing this game gives me the same feeling as watching a fireworks show at the park or even hearing the music being played just as you enter the gates! that feeling of childlike abandon coupled with goosebumps and feelings of nostalgia!

Like many fans of this genre I was introduced to it by Roller Coaster Tycoon, this game had a huge effect on my life that I became obsessed with Theme park design, coupled with the fact that I live nearby various major theme parks fueled my obsession. I've always created parks I wanted to visit or rides of my favorite TV shows/ video games that I hope I could one day ride myself. I've had all past games of Roller Coaster Tycoon and each of them fed my hobby of Theme park building. Then came a game I was so eagerly awaiting to be released(I won't be mentioning any names) it promised limitless possibilities (and grid-less building!) and couldn't wait for it; Then I saw the first trailer, lets just say I was distraught with the result and thought the genre was dead but then came Planet coaster

This game gave me the same feeling as watching the fireworks at Disneyland. from the first trailer onward each news of this game added more potential for that perfect theme park builder/simulator I've always wanted! There's just so much care and detail that has been put into this game, not only that but you can tell that the team that made this game are fans of Theme parks themselves! This was made by the same company that was hired by Disney to make a 1:1 recreation of Disneyland for a video game so of course this game has good Theme Park design under it's belt!

The emphasis on theming you parks is what really drew me in. Sure you can plop down a few Rides and call it a park, but they added a game mechanic that boosts your rides if you take the time to actually theme and decorate your rides for your guests enjoyment. Speaking of the guests, the animation and design of the people really brings the park to life, you can zoom right in with the guests and walk along side them as if your actually there in the park! I remember playing RCT3 and zooming down to the guests view, but I don't feel as if I'm actually there. With Planet coaster those rides really tower over you, and going down one of the hills on a roller coaster feels more real than riding POV in RCT3.

If your a fan of Theme parks this should definetly be in your library.

Posted: August 21, 2017
This is basically RCT3, but better looking and with nicer scenery. If you liked RCT, you'll probably like this.

PROS:
- It's BEAUTIFUL. No, I'm serious. Even on low settings, it is absolutely stunning.
- Creativity is rewarded in Planet Coaster. Search up such creators as Silvarett, Rudi Rennkamel etc to discover just how amazing your coasters and scenery can look.
- EASY to pick up, HARD to master.
- Very addictive. For reference, I am someone who rarely plays a game to completion. My top most played games are multiplayer/creative games, and this absolutely hits the spot. Each session I play can last almost a whole day if I don't watch out.
- Smooth (at least to me) coasters. Some usage of the smoothing tool, imo will absolutely hit the spot in terms of smoothness. Ofc you could play No Limits if you really want the smoothest, most realistic coasters, but this is perfectly between old school RCT and realism for me.

CONS:
- I get 40-60fps on medium with a 1050Ti, and 20fps with a laptop on low. Still playable, but pretty badly optimised, especially once there are more people in your park.
- NOT THAT MANY COASTERS. If you absolutely NEED to experiments with such things as bobsled coasters and those things with movable tracks, Planet Coaster doesn't have those. It just has fairly normal steel, wooden, hybrid coasters.
- NOT THAT MANY FLAT RIDES. Yes, I know there's like 20 or 30. But they ALL just spin around, albeit at slightly different speeds and intensities.
- MANAGEMENT IS NOT A CHALLENGE. If you like park management, again, not the game for you.

Posted: November 17, 2016
Anyone who liked RCT3, refrain from buying RCTW, I REPEAT, REFRAIN FROM BUYING RCTW. It is not created by the same devoloper and is essentially a half assed attempt to cash out. PC is definitely the true successor to RCT3, and its made by the same developer! By far one of the best games Ive ever played. Not just best theme park game, but one of the best games period that I have ever played. You will not regret purchasing Planet Coaster, I can guarentee it.

Edit:

(The following is a response to comments by Nameless1 and XDeadzX that I fell are important to include in my review)

While I agree that the management aspect of PC is missing a few features in comparison to RCT3, which, in my opinion, had a stock career mode with time wasting capabilities Sid Meier would be proud of, there is the wild card of the Steam Workshop. It is worth noting that RCT3, at least from what I've seen, did not have a particularly strong modding community. That is one reason why I believe that the passion of both Frontier as well as the community built up around PC will soon make up for that lost depth in the career mode, very much in the way Cities: Skylines has drastically improved through the community and developer to rise as the "king of city builders", dethroning the dissapointing SimCity in the process.

Now, thats not to say that Frontier slacked on this game whatsoever. Having participated in both the alpha and beta of PC, I came to the conclusion that what PC lacks in career mode depth, it definitely makes up for in the overhauled construction system, sense of freedom to create whatever you want, and overall atmosphere and customizability. The forums during alpha were extremely active, with alpha testers and developers regularly mingling to share ideas and make a game that would shake the very foundation that the RCT brand sits upon. In a way, I see this game as a form of revenge by Frontier to stick it to Atari for not being involved in RCTW.


Anyways, to sum up that cluster♥♥♥♥ of an answer, my conclusion is that, in terms of the base game career mode, RCT3 won by a landslide, despite being a 12 year old game. However, I see PC as having an exponentially higher ceiling than that of its predecessor thanks to the modding community and active developer-consumer collaboration.

That, and challenge mode is essentailly an infinite career mode, where youre constantly given challenges that encourage the growth and development of your park. If the career mode is lacking for you, I definitely recommend giving challenge mode a try.

Posted: July 30, 2022
This game is VERY fun. It has a LOT of good things going for it, the ability to "Craft" coasters of whatever on the fly, and entire theme parks, is a LOT of fun. However there is a massive glaring flaw this game has that i dont see many other people discussing, and im not sure why. A large part of this game is getting people into the park and to expand and make your park better.
THIS DOES NOT FUNCTION
What do I mean? The AI is coded in DX11, it sets all AI to run off a SINGLE CPU CORE - This is absolutely debilitating for a game that your purpose is to get more people in. 2k people? 15fps. This is not joking, even on a VERY strong system the games engine / coding is just screwed because of this. The best thing you can do to keep the FPS up is to fire everyone, and never open the park, just create 1-2 creations and move on to the next coaster.
The devs have stated they will not be fixing this massive flaw, given that I cannot recommend anyone to buy this game, which is a damn shame.

At first, I thought this game would be Roller Coaster Tycoon 4 and because of that I bought it without hesitating.
However, the game has some features that makes it a lot different than expected.

Firstly, the graphics of the game are amazing for the type of game it is. It is very realistic, the Roller Coasters' physics are amazing and so are the ones from the other rides. Everything looks more realistic and believable
Unlike the other Roller Coaster tycoon games, this one offers a huge variaty of possibilities when creating roller coasters, which makes the game a little more professional than the Tycoon series. Is that good or bad? Well, at first it might seem bad because of how hard it is to do everything. It will take a while for the player to get used to the new mechanics and some may give up on the game; that marks the contrast between players that like the game to the ones that don't.
Furthermore, the game offers a significant smaller amount of types of rides that can be put in your park. This is what made me dislike the game at first. However, I am very glad to see that new rides are being added in updates (which are quite frequent).
Also, the new mechanics made it a lot easier to build custom structures, which the older fans may have bad memories about. Now it is much more simple and there are many more options than before. The same thing goes for the terrain. It is a lot easier to shape the terrain and the Ctrl+Z tool was (finally) added, which means no more backup save files of the game.

It should be noted, though, that you must not trust the pictures. You might see some pictures of huge castles or amazing roller coasters and think: 'Man, that's what I want to do.' - It is very hard to do it. Custom structures, as mentioned before, are build piece by piece, which means that building a castle takes a lot of time and hard work, especially for those used to the older games' mechanics. It is easy to understand why people don't like this game, the development team definitely tried something new in this one, something that appeals to a very specific audience.

In summary, it is safe to assume that this game is more 'professional' than before. It is more of a simulator than the fun game you used to play when you were 14. And most importantly, if you want to buy this game just because you think it is the 4th installment of the Roller Coaster Tycoon series, don't do it. You might get disappointed.

Posted: January 6, 2022
This game saved my life.

I am 41.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

Posted: November 28, 2018
So I bought this after having it for a long time in my wishlist.
I've played it for a couple of days now, and I must say I enjoy it, but it is a very frustrating game if you have a playstyle like mine. [Total OCD freak that is a sucker for details and functionality]

So on to the bad stuff first!
(Mind you, I haven't read any of the devs plans for the future, so there might very well be
fixes coming up on some of these... or not. Are Frontier good devs with big ears? :P )

The instant I start up the game I get a news window telling me to buy their DLC. Eff you, is what I think and promptly close it down.
Once in the game I mess about with the decorations and building parts and, again, get told to buy the DLC packs, and I have to spend a couple of minutes figuring out how to turn it off. (Hint: it's next to the filter list)

After a couple hours of playing I open up sandbox mode and decide that I'm gonna make a fairytale/medieval themed park.
I begin to build my custom structures, and quite soon, I notice there are parts missing from the sets... Some sets have a certain angle to their roofs that doesn't match up with another sets walls ect. It would have been lovely if they had just added a couple more pieces to make the sets interchangeable.

Placing foliage is a pain. There is no option to place several in a row (tree brush or similar), there's no option for random rotation or size, and there's no colouring options for the trees either (which I think is a huge missed opportunity.)
You also can't place a lot of trees down by clicking really fast. They just won't place at all. You got to hold down the left button for a short time for anything to be placed down. That goes for both trees and objects.

The pathway tool is just... ugh! I hate the fact that you're limited to a certain width to the path. I wanted to make a town square, and I finally figured out that you can lock onto the grid and place square paths in an area to get that effect. YAY! But why isn't this doable from the start!? Maybe I actually want a round square!?
Nope, says Frontier. You no have no-square square.
I also found out there's no nice, efficient way to place stairs down a slope, without digging a 1 meter ditch underneath it.

And again with color options... I can't save custom colors for the workers, nor for the buildings, nor for the objects. Which means, every time I want an object with a certain color, I need to go and manually change it every time and then painstakingly copy-paste it over and over. Oh, and I have to mention the fact that when you duplicate an object and place it down, it is not automatically renewed so you can place down one after the other.
You got to spam CTRL+D... a lot!

Back to pathways for a short bit... Objects that snap to the path. Why, oh why isn't the light posts also snap-able?

The overall theme I'm sensing with this game is that there is a *lot* of small things with efficiency that add up to a big, fat annoyance-factor.

I haven't even attempted to build a roller coaster yet, (Got stuck building a medieval town *facepalm* )
so can't say anything about that tool, but if it's anything like what I've already experienced, it's going to be frustrating!

Hmm... anything else to complain about? Oh yes!
- The HUD is unacceptably slow at responding. Just pressing ESC to open the options menu takes about .5 seconds.
- When starting up the game there's a Cobra logo that takes ages to go away. (won't respond to any user interference)
- If the object you are trying to place is obstructed, you have this annoying voice shouting at you as if you're about to walk out into oncoming traffic.
- It seems that there is no way to see a detailed list over the maintenance and condition of your rides. I noticed this while trying to make my repairman less bored (giving him more to do).
- Building custom stalls is less fun, when the disk is a huge ugly box. Why wasn't it made into a single disk that you add walls to? I had hoped to make a market with small tents selling various goods. Quite impossible with the way it is now.
- Some textures don't line up the way they should.
- Certain pathway textures aren't usable for queues, and vice versa.
- You can't choose style for the pathway rails.
- No fence-placing tool. Got to place them down, one by one. Just give us "click n' drag", pretty please!?

I can't help but compare it to RCT3, and I feel like there was way more management options in that one. I'd rather have too many than too few details and options about my park.

So, what's good about this game?

Despite the huge amount of pet peeves, I do enjoy it.
I love building structures and use them for stalls, or make them a part of the scenery for a ride, and watch the guests reactions.
The graphics are great. Love the voxel terrain editing. I wish there were more terrain textures, but I believe that you can make custom themes in the main menu somehow.
I love the music. Reminds me a lot of Mumford & Sons. The music for the rides are great as well, and you can also add your own music.
Blasting System of a Down to the Merry-Go-Round is a must, right?

Overall, the looks of the game is fantastic. The HUD, though slow in response, has a clean look that I like.
When it comes to park decorations, there's lots of details you can add, like smoke effects, animatronics, water cascades, spotlights ect. and it really spices up your scenery.
The themes are interesting and fun as well. I was pleasantly surprised when I started a pirate themed challenge. Never expected there to be so many things, big and small. Animatronics especially, was fantastic!

I'd definitely recommend this game if you're not a detail-freak like me, and mostly get your stuff from the workshop and just pop them down in your park, no hassle.

I would not recommend it if you are a sucker for micromanaging everything. If there at least was a way to mod the functions in the game... *sigh* The modding community would make the game better a lot faster than I think Frontier would ever manage.

Hoping for improvements in the future.

Posted: October 10, 2020
Planet Coaster has it's ups in downs. While, Planet Coaster is the best amusement park sim that I have ever played, there's a couple things that I do not like.

Pros

Excellent graphics: They really look amazing. Sometimes, you forget you're even playing a game. This is no joke at all.
Tons Of Content: With all DLCs, you get endless content. You'll never run out of stuff that you could build in a park. Let's not forget that there's Steam Workshop content that you can add as well.
Custom Senarios: You can build huge parks. Basically, big until your PC can no longer handle the simulation. Better have a good CPU.
detailed Building: With Customizable terrain, tons of scenery, and mods, you can really get specific with how a park looks. You can even model actual parks.
Realistic Coasters: If you're a coaster enthusiast, you're in for a treat. You can build coasters from most major coaster manufacturers. This is indicated by the track design. You'll recognize the manufacturer as soon as you start building.

Cons

Glitches: Sometimes, when moviung the camera, you can become "stuck" on the ground. You need to click on your notifications and click on the button that takes you there in order to get "unstuck" Another thing that I have nocticed, when building coasters, when you're clicking on your track to place additional track, the game will think you're clicking on the track behind the one you clicked on. One more thing, the research items feature is very buggy when it comes to researching a shop. It takes several shop researches for things to even show up
One Major Flaw: When the park closes, the time speeds up and the next day begins. The same guests stay all night. This is a major flaw as not only are most of these guests already low on money, if you're basing your park off an entry ticket and free rides like most major parks are in real life, you will not make any money. This is very unrealistic. Guests should automatically be speed up with time while the night ends and leave. Then return the next day.

Fix the glitches and this major flaw and, you WILL have the ultimate park/coaster simulator.

Posted: September 14, 2019
Planet coaster is really fun to play when you just want to do really basic things, but the second you try to do anything advanced, the cracks in the spline system start to show. After playing planet coaster for 200 hours, I have gained a serious admiration for the grid system in the old RCT games. You couldn't do much with a grid, but you could do exactly what you wanted to do without any fiddling around.

Want to create a plaza system with wide open paths? Nope, can't do that. What you can do is randomly place wide path pieces and hope that they will connect in some sort of half decent way. You can try using a grid system but when you connect a grid path to a non grid path, the grid path becomes curved. Have fun with your tiny little gaps between path pieces.

Want to construct a path that runs along a gentle hill? Nope, can't do that. Your hill will look really sloppy from one angle and the path tool will pester you with TERRAIN TOO UNEVEN FOR PATH. You can try using the smooth tool, but it won't help at all. There is no hill tool, you can only push and pull terrain. Unlike in the old games, there is no plopping down a hill and path in a few minutes. Making a hill in PC takes hours, and it will never look right.

Want to create a smooth coaster with elements that feel right and look well? Nope, can't do that. The preset elements can't be manipulated very well, and they often force you to use jarring transitions that don't lead to a smooth ride. You will have to create your own loops and twists, then spam the everloving ♥♥♥♥ out of the "smooth all" button until you get something that half resembles a coherent object. Again, this is something that takes way too long to do compared to the older games. Credit where it's due, though. The heatmaps are pretty helpful although some explanation is needed on exactly what causes excitement, fear, and nausea.

What makes these issues all the more aggravating is that there isn't enough content in the base game to justify this trouble. You get a small amount of flat rides, coasters, and scenery, and the rest is locked behind DLC. The icing on the cake is that you can't filter out DLC when you use the workshop. If you don't have the DLC you can't use workshop blueprints that do, so your searches will usually contain blueprints that you can't use. After the career mode ends, you need a lot of imagination to keep playing. Of course, that imagination will never actually match the reality of what you can do ingame, unless you spend dozens of hours fighting the game's systems.

Posted: April 27, 2020
As a coaster enthusiast, this game is amazing to me. This is essentially a RCT rebirth kinda in that it improves upon the original trilogy, as well as the garbage RCTW. There are lots of custom scenery pieces and rides, and with how much stuff is in the base game alone, it's insane. For the coaster aspect of Planet Coaster, I would say its extremely fun to build up crazy coasters that go upwards of 300ft, 400ft, or even higher that would normally not exist in the real world. Speaking of which, this game's coaster selection is based off of real life models, which I think is cool. However, I would like to see even more in the future, maybe like launched or shuttle wooden coaster variants, TOGO Ultra Twisters, or coasters with drop tracks. The coasters featured though already though are amazing, with well known models such as the B&M Hyper, S&S El Loco, RMC I-Box Hybrid, and much more. Of course, this is not No Limits 2, and this is a tycoon game, so you will have to manage your own park empire. The guests are extremely interactive with everything you do in your park, including adding attractions, new sections of park, new shops, scenery, or anything at all that can be interacted with. Now, if you are hardcore into this game like me, I would also grab the DLC, as the base game can feel lacking after you feel like you have done and seen everything there is to offer. If there was one DLC pack I would recommend, I would get the Magnificent Rides Collection just because of how many rides it includes. If you want more scenery to work with, then go with the Studios Pack. Or if you really are dedicated to this game, feel free to get all of them ;p

So, do I recommend this game? Definitely, especially if you are a roller coaster enthusiast. This is easily in my top 10 games ever, and I'm really excited to see what is in store for this game, and the entire Planet series as a whole. Keep up the good work guys!

Posted: December 23, 2016
Should you buy this game?

If you want a 'Minecraft' experience ... ie you have total freedom to build what you want, you can unleash your creativity ... then yes! This is truly a beautiful game. This half of the game, I've absolutely loved.

If you want a 'Simcity' experience ... ie a realistic simulation game, when there is realistic logic behind how guests act, where your decisions determine whether your park thrives or dies ... then no. Sadly the guest logic is very underdeveloped which causes them to act in illogical ways. A current example is say balloon gift shops - if you open one of these shops, every single guest will stampede to this store and they will ignore all your attractions. They will ignore their hunger/thirst needs and prefer to starve in their madness to purchase a balloon. Then there are issues like the complaints about queues (regardless of how long or short they are), how no-one buys priority passes, how adjusting food prices has almost no effect on demand etc.

From the above, you can draw your own conclusion whether the game would suit you.

The reason I ended up with a 'not recommended' rating, is that the game is prominently advertised as 'create' and 'manage' which is what I was after ... but in reality only the 'create' half of the game is complete. Planet Coaster is a disappointment as a park management simulation game.

EDIT: Someone posted a list of the management issues on Reddit. I'm posting the link here if you want to get a good starter list of some of the bigger issues:

Posted: December 26, 2020
I was in the shower washing suds off my girthy chest when suddenly, I heard someone shouting. I immediately drew back the shower curtains and I leaped out, like a frog escaping a pit of boiling, frothing water. Who could be shouting so late, against the indomitable silence of the night? It sounded like it came from my bedroom, where I thought nobody else had entered for years. Something was wrong.
Galvanised to action, I broke down the door and infiltrated my room. I heard the shout again. Only this time, it was clearer, and I understood everything. Cries of "UNO!" ruptured my computer speakers. And I was happy.

Ladies and gentlemen, UNO is not a game. UNO is an experience.
UNO is life, yet it is also death. It is the light at the end of the tunnel, yet it is also the darkness. It is the applause at the end of the play, but also the cold rejection of a beautiful woman.
Comrades, those of you reading these reviews to determine whether your hard-earned money should be spent on UNO, you have two simple choices; to buy or not to buy. This is the ultimate test of a man's values - do you believe that the money you have worked hard to earn is equivalent to the potential experience of UNO for Windows?
Some may be hesitant. But to quote poet Robert Frost, "In three words, I can sum up everything I've learned about life: it goes on". Whether you buy UNO or not, the worst case scenario is not life-destroying. Life will go on if you spend money on UNO and it is not for you. Yet there is so much that awaits you if you buy UNO and, like millions of others, you find yourself utterly absorbed in the magic of UNO.

I would go further and argue that everyone reading this should buy UNO for Windows. At the time of writing, 30% of reviews are negative. Yet do not be deterred; by finding yourself here, you have demonstrated an interest in this game, and the only way to truly know whether you like a game or not is to play it yourself. Reviews are useful to a point, but in the words of Frank Sinatra, do not be "one who kneels" to popular opinion. Do not pretend for an instant that any review here will define your experience of UNO. There will be some who despise it, and others who are utterly enraptured by it. You must find where on this colourful spectrum you fall, and only you can decide that.

I hope that every potential player reading this searches deep into the labyrinths of their heart and soul and finds the answer.

Posted: December 15, 2022
Chicken Casserole
Cheesy chicken casserole with potato bake is one of the best casserole recipes ever! Ingredients are chicken, potatoes, cheddar cheese, bacon and cream.

PREP TIME
10 minutes
COOK TIME
1 hour 30 minutes
TOTAL TIME
1 hour 40 minutes

Ingredients
1/4 teaspoon salt or to taste
1/2 teaspoon sugar
3 dashes ground black pepper
1 tablespoon Ranch dressing
1/4 cup heavy whipping cream
2 medium-sized potatoes, peeled and cut into pieces
8 oz. (226 g) boneless, skinless chicken breast, cut into cubes
2 slices Canadian bacon or bacon strips, cut into pieces
4 tablespoons unsalted butter, cut into small pieces
1 cup shredded cheddar cheese
1 stalk scallion, green part only, cut into small rounds

Instructions
- Heat oven to 350°F (176°C). Lightly grease a 9" x 9" baking pan with some oil or butter.
- Add the salt, sugar, pepper and Ranch dressing to the heavy whipping cream. Lightly stir to combine well.
- Spread the potatoes, follow by the chicken, in one single layer.
- Sprinkle the bacon, butter, and then top with half of the cheddar cheese and the scallions.
- Pour the heavy cream over top of casserole. Cover with aluminum foil and bake for 1 hour.
- Uncover the pan and bake for another 30 minutes. In the last 10 minutes, sprinkle with the remaining cheddar cheese and bake until the cheese is slightly crusty.
- Remove from the oven and serve immediately.

Posted: January 28, 2022
nietzsche once said, "if you gaze long enough into an abyss, the abyss will gaze back into you."

close friends or complete strangers, the line begins to blur in UNO, where every face begins to look like an enemy's. the temptation of the +4 wild card lures you, the large red SKIP calls out like a siren, and even an inconspicuous green 5 can be the one weapon you need for an indisputable victory. in UNO, any pawn can become a king, and any king can be overthrown - by luck, deceit, or miracle.

where do you draw the line? do you accept defeat gracefully, patiently? do you continue the chain of +2s, hurting those you play co-op with, knowing they have no defenses? do you save your own skin by letting them bleed?

"whoever fights monsters should see to it that in the process he does not become a monster" - maybe, UNO shows us, the monster is already inherent; maybe we are the monster as much as we are our ability to control it - but when victory is so close, what's one more WILD card? what's one more body left in your wake?

a profound psychological horror especially intensified by the "rabbids" dlc (highly recommended). would be enjoyed by girlbosses who would tear down the world to win, and men who related a little too much to joker (2019). 10/10.

Posted: December 26, 2018
So this game is tons of fun, I gotta say, it's fantastic to play with a group of friends because, as always, Uno is great fun. The card packs and new rulesets are also fantastic and really change up the pace of the game and make it even more fun, beyond what normal Uno can provide.

That's about all it's got going for it though. The coding of the game itself and the networking are absolutely atrocious. For absolutely no reason, people will drop from games, be incapable of fully loading into games, crash on startup, etc. etc.. Many core features (like calling out Uno) are broken to a degree that makes a potential win into a complete loss. Needless to say, the entire game is pretty much broken somewhere somehow despite the fact that it's literally just Uno. I have no idea how you screw up Uno this badly, but these developers apparently made that a reality. If it was just one or two of these bugs in isolation, I could put up with it, but the quality of this game makes me feel like unpaid interns created it and that it's literally just a project for Ubisoft interns to work on that generates them some cash on the side. There's no care at all for quality put into it, which I mean sure, it can't be that popular of a game and isn't a flagship, but it still flagrantly displays it's made by Ubisoft and is grossly broken. Not that I expect anything else out of Ubisoft, but for god's sake, it's just a damn card game, how do you make it so that just to play an online card game it can take 20 minutes of restarting games just to get it to work, only to then have people just disconnect at the start or mid-game for no reason despite them having no connection issues at all on their end?

The game's a hot pile of trash code cobbled together into something that got tested literally once by the devs before initial release and never fixed since. I know teenagers that could make Uno better than this. Maybe not as good looking, but at least the damn thing would be stable, especially 2 years after release.

I'm still gonna play it, cuz man I love me some Uno with friends, and I can't return it now, but I will for the rest of my life state that Ubisoft doesn't give a damn about their product quality if they can't even make Uno stable.

Posted: October 29, 2015
Go ahead and try to find something to criticize about this game.

Maybe graphics scalability? Can you even be offended at that? The game does use polygonal graphics and what appears to be vertex lighting, but I think most integrated graphics chips can handle this amount of detail. Don't quote me on that one. Most systems out there can run this game no problem... If they are Windows systems.

Maybe the friend requirement? Flipping through the manual yourself still provides an interesting experience. The entire game can be beaten with one person or with the participation of 20 or more people. How many games are like that?

Lack of voice chat feature? The game has full Steam support, making this a non-issue.

Lack of netcode? The design of the game makes this irrelevant. You don't even need an internet connection, but to initially download the game.

Frustration? You can pick up or close the game at any time. Learning to play it without griping at others or being discouraged is probably good for your social health. It's far less frustrating or "cheap" than many modern games, too: bounding boxes in Dark Souls 2, spawns in flanking in Call of Duty, unreasonable level design in Hotline Miami 2. Bombs are self-contained puzzles and you lose only seconds if you make a mistake, not hours of effort. In fact, the more level-headed you are, the better you will be at the game.

Brevity? This one I could see, but the main collection of bombs is only to introduce the mechanics and give some gimmicky setups in the first place. Once you complete it, you can free play whenever you want, as the design calls for well over 11^11 (that's about 2.9 * 10^11) variations. It's unlikely you will ever play the same bomb twice if your objective is variation.

Cost? It's $15 right now; if you go in with friends it's a drop in the bucket. I don't feel too bad about the development:cost differential, but I suppose that's up to personal preference.

Keep Talking and Nobody explodes is an accessible, inexpensive, tightly designed game. Even if you've never played a party game or don't care for them, this one is a glimmering example. After hours of consideration, the only problem I can think of is that it seems to be Windows-only at the moment. Do you have Windows and some fraction of $15? Do you like fun games that reward skill, intelligence, and cooperation? If you said yes, it's time to buy.

Posted: June 3, 2017
Most of the time writting reviews is quite easy. You point out the strong and bad points of the title, sum everything up and giving a final judgement at the end. Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes doesn't have strong or bad points... It's great game all throughout which makes writting review of it extremely difficult.

Uniqueness of the game doesn't really help either. The concept of trading information between the manual-wielding "Expert" and bomb interacting "Defuser" with the constant pressure of timed exploding device is as silly, fun, exciting as you could imagine. The constant shouts, the struggle to correctly describe the contents of many different types of bombs and that tension when the timer runs out and there is that one one wire to cut... It's a great, original idea for the game that focuses on good communication, reading comprehenion and quick thinking and analysis. You rarely see something like that on the market and I'm extremely happy that it works like the charm.

As for the game's content, there are is a good variety of different parts from which bombs can be generated and learning to solve those modules in reasonable pace gives tons of satisfaction for both players… without consideration of which one used the manual or was interacting in the bomb. During my playthrough with a friend, we were constantly switching roles while going through the main campaign and we found out that both roles are fun to play as and require a similar amount of engagement. As you will learn all the basic rules, game starts throwing you many different and creative curveballs to catch you off-guard or present an interesting challenge. This in result keeps the game fresh for quite some time.

You can trust me that all of that what I just described works as well in practice as it seems on the paper and with a good friend you will definitely have a blast. Right now we managed to clear most of the Challenging difficulty bombs, going both as Expert and Defuser on the each bomb and it took up around 7 hours so far. There have many tasks still ahead and we aren't playing on giving up just yet.

If you have a friend and a microphone, you really cannot go wrong with this game. I wholehearthly recommend it for all the hijinks and cathartic satisfaction it provided. Just keep talking and have fun blowing up together.

Posted: October 11, 2015
Concept: 10/10
Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes is an asymmetrical party game for 2 or more players, where one person defuses a bomb, while everyone else tells them what to do. Pretty innovative, yet a natural fit for its genre. Also, you only need one copy of the game for as many players as you want, which gives it great value.

Gameplay: 38/40
The game doesn't waste any time getting to the action. The game feels tense right from the first bomb, even if you end up with plenty of time left. The defuser's job is to tell the experts what kind of wiring and such is on the bomb, and the experts look them up in the manual. The experts then tell the defuser what to do to disarm each module. Usually the game consists of a series of questions and instructions. This might sound boring to some people, but the modules are very well designed to make it fun. They range from simple wires that require going through a list of options until you get to the correct one, to "who's on first" modules that require careful enunciation. The modules that are the least interesting also take the least time.
I think most people would progress in skill quickly, but fortunately, so does the game. There are quite a number of scenarios that excellently pace the players through all the mechanics, and each one is procedurally generated. There's also a custom bomb mode that could provide theoretically endless hours. One would think that the game would become repetitive, but it literally takes five minutes, so it never feels grindy. The one thing I could see to improve the game would simply be more modules. But there's certainly enough as it is.

Aesthetic: 20/20
The game isn't the most realistic looking, but it's in that zone and feels super appropriate. Everything looks nice, there's no extraneous clutter, and the sounds are perfectly suited to the atmosphere. The details are nice too; occasionally the lights will turn off for a few seconds, but the lit screens on the bomb stay visible. Great job here.

Length: 9/10
While the game provides a mountain of different possibilities, it does have a limit. That limit won't be reached for a long time, but it's there. It's kind of like a Rubik's cube: once you've mastered it, then you can only refine your skills. But it has like ten times the fun and complexity of a Rubik's cube.

Technical: 20/20
The game runs smoothly. I haven't run into any bugs whatsoever, and the manual is easily available online as a pdf, a webpage, or printed. The controls are tight. Not much to say when there's nothing wrong. :)

Total: 97/100
Keep Talking and Nobody explodes is one of the best games I've picked up this year. It's simple, but that simplicity is one of it's strengths. It's a pure rendition of a great idea, and will surely bring a lot of laughter and yelling.

Posted: October 11, 2015
This is an awesome puzzle game for two or more people. It will certainly test your friendship or marriage, lol. At first glance, I questioned if there was enough game here to merit the pricetag, but oh boy is there. There are tons of levels, and even a puzzle generator where you can alter various puzzle dynamics. The levels increase in difficulty nicely.

There is a manual that you print out, and you are free to study it as much as you want. One person works with the bomb - they are the only ones that are allowed to see the screen. The other person(s) is using the manual as a tool to help you solve the puzzles on the bomb. It is helpful to play with more than two people - we had an extra person and you could divvy out puzzles to save time. The average time they give you to solve a bomb is 5 minutes.


+Awesome fresh take on a co-op puzzle game
+Puzzles are really well done - it would take a long time to 'memorize' the manual or be an expert at this game
+Lots of room for future DLC (ie. a new manual version, game modes, etc.)
+Controls are minimal and work well


-I am not certain that you could complete every bomb with just two people
-I prefer this in short bursts rather than long play sessions
-People seem to have strong opinions on which role they like playing - for example, I literally refuse to be the expert with the manual. Thankfully my friends want that role, and they refuse to run the computer. That could be a factor.
