Posted: August 20, 2022
I'm a long time fan of theme hospital. I bought Two Point Hospital on day one and loved it. I played every DLC and loved it. I Really *really* wanted to like this game, but I just.... don't... After beating the first two campuses I simply have no desire to start a third and my time with TPC is probably already at an end.

The style is very similar to TPH, with the same cute graphics, the same radio presenters and ( possibly unpopular opinion ) many of the same jokes forced into a slightly different context to sound more "university'y" Once I noticed this it bugged me more and more.

For some inexplicable reason they've also added a tonne of menu options and icons that add a never ending cascade of popups and panels for you to scroll through. The result was that I spent more time squinting at button tooltips than playing the game. Despite all the extra UI buttons I still can't find what I'm looking for most of the time (I'm looking at you events organiser screen)

What really lets this game down though is the core gameplay loop. Its just dull. You set up some rooms, click the "start year" button and survive a barrage of whiny requests for "a new bench" or "a guitar poster" (once you've filtered out the incessant monthly profit/loss mails - what was wrong with the TPH style popup!? ) which you dutifully plonk down (literally anywhere) to push a happiness bar up. The academic year ends, some more bars fill up. your progress to "X/10 students passing whatever" goes up and you rinse and repeat until you get your next star.

I was able to define a winning strategy for this game which was to start the year, leave it running in the background for 5 minutes whilst I did something else, return and fulfil all the requests, repeat the cycle until the end of the year and repeat. In my opinion, any game where you can spend half of your time not playing the game and still win is doing something wrong

You also spend an inordinate amount of time designing rooms to be nice looking. For people who enjoy the sims, that's great, but I've never wanted or cared about attractive rooms. I'm much more interested in playing the game and beating its management challenges. Two Point Hospital was great in that it gave you the choice - want to deck all your GP's offices out with posters? go for it! Want to completely ignore it and occasionally crank out a prestige 5 room to stop a staff member leaving? That's cool too! Being forced into becoming an interior decorator was really not what I wanted to spend my time doing.

After TPH's fast-paced, challenging and complex, but intuitive, overlapping game systems, TPC feels like a "dumbed down for casual gamers" clone that somehow manages to port across all of the individual parts of TPH whilst completely losing the heart of what made it great. What a shame

Posted: August 14, 2022
I am a fan of Two Point Hospital (TPH) and I love this game even more. Let me count the ways:
1. The game's art and humour is similar to TPH which I love.
2. However, unlike TPH, Two Point Campus (TPC) comes with an expanded build mode. I love that I can now build and landscape my own lot, something that I wish I could do with TPH.
3. The theme is different: running a university instead of a hospital but the interface feels familiar and thus, easy to learn. There are lots of tabs and stats to monitor (which is a good thing).
4. Most importantly, this game manages to make me care for my students (which TPH does not. I only care for my patients as means to improve my cure rate). I cheer inwardly when my students make friends/fall in love. I want them to have the time of their life. I care whether or not they complete their assignments/ace their courses.

So yeah, love the game. I pre-ordered the game and didn't regret it at all.

Posted: July 28
What I think made Theme Hospital so great was how much you were forced to think on your feet and come up with creative solutions to often difficult problems that always threatened to catch you off guard. There was always the option to achieve just a passing result in that game with little effort, but to do it with flying colors required something extra. While it pushed you to succeed, Theme Hospital also gave you excellent feedback about exactly everything you were doing wrong and how you needed to improve, from the positioning of different rooms relative to each other and to the entrance, even down to the layout of your hallways and the placement of the furniture and equipment in the hospital's various rooms.

Two Point Campus, just like Two Point Hospital before it, doesn't do any of those things. It has the recognizable shell of screwball duncery (a better word than dunceishness) from Theme Hospital, but it doesn't seem to know why it's doing any of the things it's doing. Everything in the game comes easily, (except Kudosh, which is proof that hell exists) your students get A+ grades and in general live exemplary, overjoyed lives with little to no input from you. The game more or less plays itself. Make a new room for a new course, start at a new campus, it doesn't really matter what you do, none of it changes anything that happens and it will all go off without a hitch. You can, technically, be creative, if by creative you mean rotating a bench at 45º instead of 90º, but the game at no point will request you to perform the action of thinking. If you love playing games in order to be bored by them, then consider this an overwhelmingly favorable recommendation.

Instead of Two Point Campus, I recommend naming this game Kudosh purgatory.

Posted: February 13
Unfortunately I can't recommend Two Point campus because it doesn't really do anything well very well aside from having a lot of visual polish. It isn't an interesting or challenging management game, it doesn't use it's university theme effectively, and it doesn't really work as a relaxed building game if you're more interested in designing an attractive campus. All of this is made worse by the bad UI, which is fiddly and annoying. It's really not up to the standards you would expect for a relatively simple management game these days. Also the internal game clock runs way too slow for the pace at which the game happens, so a large amount of my playtime was pretty passive or even spent in tabbed out waiting for a in-game year to run down.

To expand on these points:

Management:
Two Point Campus is fairly simple, very repetitive, and doesn't have much challenge. Each level involves constructing a set of core structures (lecture rooms, dormitories, toilets, etc) which gradually expands as the game progresses. There is some thought that goes into placing them (e.g. make sure every building has at least a few toilets, make sure dormitories are placed somewhere relatively central) but you figure these out quickly. So each level plays very much like the last. Spend the first year placing enough of the essential buildings to make the campus function, then spend subsequent years expanding whatever elements the game wants you to expand to meet the completion goals. Repetitive game loops aren't uncommon in management games, but usually when that's the case they make up for it by using a combination of varied level goals and distinct level design and modifiers. Two Point Campus doesn't do that. Most objectives are very similar to each other, and since every aspect reinforces every other aspect a level that asks you to meet a certain level of student happiness, or campus attractiveness, or average grade all involve basically the same thing. Level design and modifiers also fail to make the repetitive loop feel fresh. Since you can modify the buildings that the individual rooms go into level design is very rarely something you need to give much thought to - just extend the main building's wall until you can fit what you need, no problem (and even deliberately not doing this to challenge myself on the later levels the variety that the pre-made structures introduced was pretty minor). The level modifiers are also too minor to provide much variety, and some of them are just tedious to deal with. The game is also extremely easy. I had maybe a dozen students fail their courses out of thousands over the course of the game, and the only student who dropped out did so because their AI broke and they stood in a hallway not bathing or eating for six months.

University theme:
I think that a good management game should have the theme incorporated into the mechanics, and doing this well can make up for a lot of other shortcomings. Two Point Campus doesn't do anything interesting with the university theme. For example the problem of balancing research and teaching is completely absent from the game, with research a pretty insignificant mechanic that unlocks upgrades instead of a key university activity. Other things that could have made for interesting mechanics like grants, alumni relations or student politics are also absent. I'm not saying they need to have the specific things I just mentioned, but some effort to make the mechanics match the theme would have gone a long way.

Relaxed builder:
This is more subjective, but I don't think Two Point Hospital does a very good job scratching the itch for light management games that let you build attractive things. Most of the items are unlocked with a secondary currency called kudosh, mostly earned by completing objectives. This means that if you want to decorate a place nicely you need to spend kudosh or use a very limited set of options. But kudosh is also used to unlock key items, so focusing on decorative options will cripple your progression in the game. The other problem is the game encourages you to place the maximum number and variety of items. Each item contributes to room quality and items that haven't already been placed contribute more. So the optimal way to play is to do things like cover the walls in posters, most of which will have absolutely no relation to what gets taught there, or to cram all of your students into one giant dormitory so they get the biggest exposure to item effects. Students will also periodically demand that you buy things and place them on campus, and if you don't buy them you can expect to be spammed with the same request repeatedly until you give in. Don't think a giant pink car-themed seat is a good fit for your grounds? Well to bad, because they'll never stop asking for one. Why you have to use specific items rather than item categories (like in the sims, which lets sims dynamically ask for things without forcing the player to give up their creative freedom) is beyond me.

Posted: August 13, 2022
So. After fully beating the game, with a few two stars, and a few three stars in various places, I shall finally give this a review.

First of all, the game is genuinely quite fun, if you are relying on the humor, and gimmick's that made Two Point Hospital great. Otherwise, if you are buying this, expecting a fully different game, don't. It is indeed, exactly like the first game, without very much difference, except that you are building a college, instead of a hospital, and that comes with a few new quirks.

The game is a solid 8-12 hours, to complete, depending on if ya rush, though I'm sure someone could do it a lot quicker. I didn't encounter many bugs during that time, aside from students and rarely, a staff member, just walking around, both needing to take the biggest dump of their lives, and also smelling astoundingly bad, but apparently not having enough time to do that inbetween the entire school year. It's able to be worked around, but it certainly needs to be looked at by the Dev Team.

It's very easy to cheese this game, and admittedly, I most certainly did for the Archeology mission (Thanks SpiffingBrit!) but for the most part, no cheese is needed. You really don't feel inclined to add other courses during a mission either, cause you don't really need to unless the game specifies that you to. Just go at your own pace the entire game, as there isn't really anything time limited.

Overall I'd rate the game a low 8/10 for me personally. It needs a bit more character, and a fare bit more additions for it to go up in my book, If you didn't like Two Point Hospital, don't buy this. You won't enjoy it.

Posted: August 16, 2022
Short story, to channel Sir Nigel Bickleworth, I give it three 'Meh's out of five. I suppose it's over half, so thumbs tentatively up.

The longer story is, although this is essentially Two Point Hospital with a college instead, that is exactly the problem. The hospital one was a continuous affair, where at any moment the composition of the patients could start to change, or you'd just get more of them, so it was a continuous action and reaction. The college format splits it into school years and vacations, with the courses (and thus number of students) only changing between years, and thus no real reason to build more classes or hire more teachers other than between the years. The game also tells you exactly what rooms and what teachers you'll need over the next year, so again, it's not a dynamic do this and react to that affair like in TPH. Just meet those requirements and then sit and watch for a year.

Worse yet, although the game doesn't force you to, it strongly rewards sitting on your butt during that vacation, dismissing employment candidates until a more qualified one shows up. I mean, you could hire the first teacher that pops up, and then spend a small fortune and two years training them to level 5 in whatever course they're teaching, or sit and wait until a level 5 on shows up. Which is very boring.

The gaining experience and levels from TPH is also gone, basically giving you one less thing to react to.

Add to that such tasks as "make 5000$ a month profit" to clear the last star of a level. Since one time stuff like research don't count, essentially you may find yourself just waiting for a month where the student experience bonus pushes you just over the threshold. Since xp is gained faster at low levels, AND you can only add more students for a new year, essentially that tends to be one of the very first months of a year. Then you'll twiddle your thumbs for the rest of the year, hoping you can do better the next one. Again, that's very boring, and I consider including such tasks to be simply bad game design.

Now add some more niggling details, like that the AI seems a bit... lobotomized. I've repeatedly watched such stuff as a janitor just running back and forth because it can't seem to decide between two tasks, and ending up doing neither until something else to do appears.

Now also add such... bizarre decisions as that you can't increase a lecture room's capacity by adding more chairs, nor does there seem to be any obvious way to increase the number of lecture rooms for a course and year. You can and will literally end up with stuff like 31 students for year 1 and the fixed 8 students capacity for the lecture room. I realize that they had to make other stuff like the private tuition and library and upgrading other rooms too useful SOMEHOW, but it seems bizarre that adding 8 more seats in the lecture room doesn't actually increase its capacity.

Etc.

On the whole, it's not the worst game, especially during the summer draught of new games, and you can get some enjoyment out of it. Hence the tentative thumbs up. But if you haven't played Two Point Hospital yet, I would recommend buying that one instead.

Posted: August 10, 2022
Two Point Campus (TPC) like Two Point Hospital (TPH) with a more streamlined (maybe too streamlined?) control scheme. Upgrades are better handled and staff management feels a bit easier. The change in flow from calendar year to academic year is an interesting change.

I enjoy the flow, and if you liked TPH, you'll definitely like this too. However, temper your expectations and don't expect anything transcendental. It also feels a bit "bare" although I'm still going through the maps and I'll update this as time goes forwards.

It's a good to excellent "Space Management" game.

Update: 8/11/22 - There are a total of 12 maps available in Sandbox mode (once Sandbox mode unlocked by finishing the 4th map or about 4-8 hours of game play or so. ) Sandbox mode, if I can recall correctly, was unlocked once you did a few maps in Two Point Hospital as well.

Update: 8/24/22 - Sandbox opens after finishing the first map with 1 star.

Given one of the achievements is for 36 stars, I would assume this would be the case in the campaign. However, because you are given maps drip-by-drip by finishing objectives, it does initially give the impression that it's fairly "bare." Again, it does open up as time goes on, and it does have further content potential, and thus coming from TPH to TPC does give it that "less than" initial feeling.

The controls do seem "console-fied" and the menus do seem a bit confusing coming from TPH, but you will eventually get used to it. I do miss the older TPH menus though.

Again, give it a chance! Most people won't regret it.

Posted: August 9, 2022
Where am I getting from
There are many out here, who played Two Point Hospital before. I am not one of them. I'm also not a frequent management game player. But the humour and the university theme itched a nerve for me and after the first trailers and then reviews I had to get it. So take this into consideration.

You're managing a University. But is it just one? No! The game has a story mode and a sandbox mode. To get to the sandbox mode you have to play through the first few levels though (I haven't unlocked it yet after finishing the first two levels, but I took my time and got three stars in both of them, you only need one per level, so you might unlock it a fair bit quicker).
So, about the "story" mode. You start with a small campus in England and have two establish two different courses. The game uses this to softly get you to learn the game's mechanics. For me - as a novice - this was very welcome. In each level you have to achieve certain goals to get a star. You do this over the course of a year, you have to build student facilities, class rooms, all these things. And you have to make sure, your students pass their classes. But that's not been to challenging so far.
Once you have the first star you can choose two tackle the next challenges to get up to three stars, or you move on to the next campus.
The different campuses (?) have varying themes. The second one is in an old Italian-like town for example and you focus on cooking courses with giant pizzas. Over the course of the game you can expect knights, wizards, sports, robots and all kind of stuff.
As I am still early on in the game I can't judge all of it, but to me it seems to be very diverse and fun! The game doesn't take itself to serious. On that note, there's also an in game radio with Bri'ish comments that are quiet funny.

Apart from managing and building rooms you also have to take care of your staff.

What you probably shouldn't expect is a hard game. It is very beginner friendly. In the second university I had to look a little more on the money at first, but that passed rather quickly. For me as a novice in this field this is nice and feels right.

In the Italian town, which might actually be French as well, now that I'm thinking about it, the rain contains frogs. Apart from that the only books I've met so far are book worms.

On a serious note:
- apparently the A button can't be mapped differently to move left. I didn't note this, as I use my mouse to move.
- One time I wanted to move a room and a bunch of other objects in other rooms would show they can't be placed like that anymore, which would have required quiet a bit of work. In the end I just didn't move the room and in other instances I didn't have the problem. But there might be some challenges to the placing system.

As I use my mouse to move and move the camera, I would prefer to be able to move the camera both up and down and turn left and right at the same time (like in The Sims for example). Like this I have to stop one movement and start the next. You get used to it and it might be very specific to me, but I would like it differently.

And when you place all the objects, some of them require to be accessible for the janitors to be serviced. This mechanic isn't bad. But getting it just rights can be a bit tricky. You can user Ctrl. To fine tune it, but it still is a bit icky.

In general the UI is very nice and works well. But you can toggle specific actions per person, like sending them to 1 on 1 tutoring and I couldn't really tell what was on and what was off, as for this there was no fly over as there is for other things, telling you what something does/is.

I think the game has a very nice flow. When you build new rooms it immediately shows you all the fitting and suitable furniture for example. Also it has a good pace for me so far. One year doesn't take to long. I'd say it's about an hour in real life. Then you have the summer break to prepare your campus for the next year, build new rooms for new or upgraded course. Here you can take as long as you like, before you start back into the school year. And then you still have the option to actually pause your game.
So far this all works very well for me with a good feeling of progression.

Yes, absolutely. I've had lots of fun so far and unlike other (micro)managing games this has an entrance that hooked me instead of spooking me. It's fool of humour and crazy ideas. Not your everyday university life.
It's not a hardcore game. This is for a relaxed evening and watching your fantastic university and all the life it contains. It's also fun to just watch that.
So give it a go!

I might update this further down the line, but for now that's it folks!

If you want to learn more, you might check the coverage by Rock Paper Shotgun, which I found to be very good:

Posted: February 6
Putting the game aside for now. I've played sims like this since the early 1990's, but it didn't "mesh" with me. Basically stopped at lower levels as I got bored as hell and it wasn't improving. It's not like the many others over the years where you have to constantly react and "build up" to meet challenges. You get a grace period between years to do most of your major work and basically sit on your tush after that.

If you played hospital, it's basically the same theme with some improvements. Some of those improvements are for the better, some make you wonder what was going through the devs mind when they implemented it. You can reach higher levels on both workers and "class levels," but they raised it to the point that it basically doesn't make sense. All you're doing is cutting and pasting the same rooms over and over especially with their "dimishing returns" where the classes basically handles 50% less. And that takes up a lot of room. And unless they have major league sized maps on the end, you're just basically following the same theme for one type of class throughout your building or you're doing low levels trying to create a mix of classes to make the game more interesting... It's as far away from hospital as you can get where you try to make enough money to max out personnel and equipment/rooms/treatment. I actually fell asleep playing a couple times which is not regular for me so about 3-4 hours you can deduct from gameplay time... Personnel is basically the same way, you got far higher levels you can reach, but you'll quickly end up bankrupt if you try to push the max as your income is limited to students tuition and "bonus"
(more on this later.)

Buildings, you can actually build your own. No real challenge in that anymore except the issue of class level and what you're trying to accomplish. Pathing seems to have taken a hit in this game where you end up having students bouncing back and forth in front of classroom doors and you don't have the ability to pick them up to break the cycle. So they'll keep bouncing until things get screwed up like missing class or they graduate. It isn't common, but it isn't rare either. I've had at least 2 incidents per game/replay and I end up just saving game and reloading last save. Puts them back on track... Harder to ignore is the janitors becoming stupider then before. I tried to post on the Steam discussion forums, but it got deleted. Not because it was a rant or used foul language, but because they want people to create an account and post it on their website. Usually, I wouldn't have any issue with that, but I have too many games and I'm not going to create an account for every one of them where I have an issue. You sold on Steam, it's a common site for both consumer and devs, then make use of it... I posted to a drop box with video's showing the issues with the computer losing track of people and erroring as well as the DX error log, and it got deleted within 6 hours. I contacted Steam with a copy of what I posted and they said there was nothing wrong to get deleted by them, and they said they have no log of deleting it themselves. As the devs have access, they had to have done it (according to Steam so don't bite my head off as I'm going off of what I was told.) One video was showing the ricochet rabbit action of one of the students, the other videos showed full energy/happiness janitors walking up to the room and turning around and going elsewhere allowing the room to become trashed and nothing getting fixed. Had the error logs for the specific video as well. Oh well, not going to worry about it as the game as it stands right now isn't going to be started much.

You supposedly get more "students" then you got "patients" in hospital. It sounds good until you think it through. In hospital, you had 200 patients cycling through when you push for that level of care/gameplay. You get around 300 students one shot at the beginning of the year according to posts I've read making it seem like it can handle more when you build up to that level. But, due to how the gameplay is, it feels like you're dealing with far less. And with the dimishing return issue that I really can't see a point to (it may be somewhat realistic, but it's annoying as the game isn't a "realism" game,) it basically just eats up space with no real point having to create a bunch of unneeded classrooms that sit empty most of the time at the level I got bored with and exited out. If they allow scheduling classrooms/classes at far higher levels, just disregard this section as I allowed my boredom to get the better of me before I reached a more challenging stage that allows you to maximize usage.

Heating/cooling is basically the same as hospital meaning it can be more of an annoyance then a help at times. They fixed the gold certificate spam on university (good!!!!!!) so you can't just spam one item to get your room ratings up. I regularly took every room up to 14 except the bathroom and the shower room even without the ability to spam. Trying to get to 15 looks like it would be a bear to reach, but I didn't finish the game so I don't know what other things "pop up" later in the game to add for decorations that may make it easier..

In order to offset the continual income made in hospital, they basically pay you the tuition to you monthly as well as a bonus from students improving or liking space they're in. It levels up the university and can bring in funding as well. I can see why they did it with the limitations as you only have the same "customers" for the entire year, but it can be an annoyance especially if you're not throwing parties or bringing in live bands for them to give them an extra "boost" and shake the purse some more.

Like I said, I just can't get into it as my playstyle is for more "interaction" then this game has. If I comment on a game, I usually have hundreds of hours into it before I comment on it. But, maybe I'll jump into it at a later time and have a different opinion and give it another chance as I've still got about 8 games and DLC's for games I already own I purchased at the same time as this that I haven't played yet. I don't like to leave a game unfinished...

It´s a very uncommon bug, but if it hapens to you, don´t do nothing with the game, just contant support.

Two Point Campus is the second installement in the Two Point series after Hospital, but it´s a completely different beast. You are now tied to a 12 month period, your students won´t leave (hopefully) for the whole year, and it´s your job to provide them with the items and rooms that will help them improve their notes for tose 12 months. While a lot of the difficulty on Hospital was releated to placement of rooms, in here that´s less relevant and it´s money the biggest learning curve, you have to build your campus slowly or you are gonna end up asking for tons of loans, which is a feature I never used on Hospital.

There´s also more improvements in the system, now buildings are not fixxed and you can modify them as you please, and outdoor enviorements take a huge role. I particularly like the staff training improvements, you will no longer pay for a classroom, now you will have machinery and staff will go automatically when they are free, and they can come out of the machine without loosing progress on their leveling up.

If you enjoyed TPH, I´m sure you will do the same for TPC, although it´s true it´s a little bit easier, some of the new mechanics are very interesting and it´s great to see the team being able to translate the gameplay into different micromanagement styles. This game makes me excited about a third installement on the series and many many more.

Posted: May 29
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I've played almost 20 hours and yeah, I enjoyed it. But after a certain point, there's nothing left to do. Yeah, it's buggy, but it is early access still. Just glad the saving bug appears to be fixed. I probably won't be playing it now until more stuff has been released.

Some of the achievements don't appear to be working either, which I have submitted as a bug. These include, buying your first car. I've bought many cars, and they are not triggering. I do hope that a lot more features will be added, perhaps making stuff a lot more difficult to unlock so it is something to build up and work towards. Once you start buying the expensive cars, its very fast to make money and unlock all you need.

I do wish the audio for the cars were better. Some of them sounded a bit trash and unpleasant. There's one car, I can't think of what it is now, no matter what colour you pick, it doesn't add the colour. Every other car does though. Going to the bar is fine, but there's nothing to do apart from Blackjack. Not sure the point of getting drunk either.

If there is a minimap in the game, it didn't appear for me, nor was there an option to turn it on. Not to worry though! Quite a small map.

I do hope that more neighbourhoods are added, more gas stations, etc. The day cycle is pretty short too, like, way too short. I wanted to have like 15 cars in my lot before opening but I couldn't buy, upgrade, paint and wash all cars before night time came. Unfortunately, after each night cycle, the cars are dirty again. I tried cleaning all the cars at the gas station before opening again, but, even doing that, the night time came too quickly and yet, once again, all cars were dirty again.

Like I say, its a good time-passer. I enjoyed it but, there's still a lot more to be fixed / added to make this game truly banging.

Posted: August 29
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Needs a ton of work and improvements.

This game has potential and I want to really like it, since I am really into cars/vehicles. However, there is just too much in terms of bugs and lack of content to do much even with the recent drag race update. What you basically do in this game is run a car dealership, along with customizing the cars you buy and you can also customize the dealership site and your living areas. There are quite a few cars ranging from dodge chargers to BMWs and the like just without brand names/ licenses to approve for using their official names in game. You can sell the cars you buy off for profit and do it all over again or keep some cars for yourself.

Where the game falls short is the lack of customization for all of these features. There is a limited amount of customization options you can do for the cars and both the dealership/office area and for your living quarters as well. I feel as if there is just limited options and personality to make these how you want them to be.

The controls for this game are awful. I am using an xbox controller and while there is support for it, there is no rumble/force feedback... For a game with cars, you would think while driving around and taking cars from point A to B to get fueled, go racing or crashing there would be some type of feedback... but no this is not to be found whatsoever. If I play a car game, I expect no matter if I am using a wheel or controller to have feedback as I like that type of emersion. The button commands for xbox do show up on screen as guidance but are rather confusing to me as they remain as keyboard buttons rather than switching over to for instance, A,B,X,Y with circles. This did confuse me quite a bit and I mistakenly pressed the keyboard buttons on some inputs thinking the keyboard mode was still enabled. There is also a lack of a "look around" camera inside and outside the car specifically for the xbox/controllers that are not an actual mouse and there is no way from my knowledge that this can be fine tuned in settings to have it set to the left or right sticks. But this camera mode works fine on foot and walking with the xbox control stick normally as you would expect. There is also no way to adjust the cars sensitivity to your liking as well. You are stuck with however the cars handle by default.

I also know that there is a alcohol/gambling "mini game" I guess you would call it. Not sure what that has to do with running a car dealership. If you try buying alcohol and drinking a few beers and go out and drive a car, it just acts as if you didn't drink anything at all, there is no emersion to that, unless your at the bar playing blackjack or walking around on foot. The drag race is a good feature though beyond that as a mini game as well as the other open areas you can go via the tow truck down the road from your dealership premises.



Then on to the bugs in game, its just quite horrible and messy as of the drag race update. With the AI, Either there are some ai, or not enough on the map and roads. The ai in places randomly gets stuck or just randomly piles on top of each other or they just go real slow most of the time. No ai appears driving during the night as of the recent update in my experience. Then, when you take the cars in for repair at the repair shop and it goes up on the automated lift, the arms clip into the doors of most cars... There is also a ton of pop-in for the background scenery both at the day and night cycles, that is very annoying. I have everything on ultra settings but it looks everyday in game especially during the day it is either foggy or the horizon is too bright...

The photo mode also needs a little bit of fine tuning as I would like to see options to hide the UI and to be able to take custom photos and upload them directly to steam. Also, the day and night cycles are too fast and seemingly last only 10-15 mins to barely do anything. There should be an option to slow down or speed up the time in 1x-100x like in farming simulator for your preference.

Overall, there needs to be improvements on the controls, customization options and the bugs I mentioned. Hopefully these can be sorted out in the next update with the UI overhall and the office customization update that the devs announced already. For now in this games current state, I just cannot recommend.

Posted: October 30
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I tried. I really tried to give this game a chance. Played over 100 hours...Endured the Developers disappearing act, where most people thought the game was DOA. Then the "Big Update" came...Drag racing. The game is called "Car for Sale". The developers didn't take 2 minute to search that there are SO MANY racing sims done better that the one they jammed into the game instead of focusing on their basic premise. In fact about 2 weeks after that release, the NHRA released their licensed version of their own drag racing sim. But the final straw for me wasn't the mess surrounding the customization of the lot. or the fact after all this time they still couldn't get characters to walk / look like humans. It was the "new" economic system they created. It was an unrealistic price for an assessment of a car, but then change the repair and paint costs based on the type of car? So by the time you're finished customizing the car, and getting it ready for sale, there is almost no profit left for it to sell (especially the high end ones). So buyer beware, this game was not ready for early release, is FAR from ever leaving early release. I would look for a more organized polished game with a competent staff and clear road map. I'm more disappointed than angry. The game concept had potential.

Posted: May 27
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Seriously, has our expectation of games become so low that we pass this sort of rubbish on as "Mostly Positive"? Standards need to be so much higher. If a game is Early Access, that's fine but price it as such. This game is similar in price to Car Mechanic Simulator 2021. That's how absurd the pricing is compared to the quality of what you get. Hell, the very first screen when you load the game shows "Cars Purchased" and "Cars Selled"....

I'm not about to refund and blast a game because of a few typos. The game stutters on my fairly high end PC. Sensitivity and movement is beyond whack. I was pleasantly surprised to see that I could drive with my wheel until I found the brakes didn't work and I ended up bumping a pole. Oh well, i'll just drop into reverse. Oh wait, you can't reverse your car, at least not with any of the buttons I tried pressing (every button on wheel and keyboard).

There's some slight potential there. Maybe the gameplay makes up for some of the mess. But let's get serious. This isn't an Early Access game. Not unless it has an introductory price of $5 until they figure out the bugs and clean it all up. My 8 minutes of gameplay found more bugs than content. Anyway, i've refunded the game. I'll find another copy a different way a year from now and if it's at a reasonable level i'll buy again.

So dissapointing. Stop leaving positive reviews for games that don't deserve it.

Posted: May 20
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This is a great fun game that as loads of potential, However it is is fun to play right now but there is some issues that you may want t know before buying right now.

1. when saving you get a black screen quite often causing your game not to save so you can lose progress
2. it can be hard to make money to start with and you need pateince when selling cars as alot of the time customers dont offer you a price for what you paid for the car.
3. barguin skill level 1 and 2 dont really make a difference when trying to get best price for vehicle

There is a scrapyard place where you can get junk and sell, This though takes time and you do not get alot of money for it but can be useful in a pinch, but me personally dont see the need for in the current state
There is also a Bar which you can buy booze and do some gambling, Again unless you really need some cash this isnt really worth it in my opinion as it can be so easy to lose your money, That said some people have found this useful and been lucky and earned alot of money from it.

overall it is fun and seems to be recieving updates so should only get better, There are small other bugs with the game but apart from the black screen issue and not saving they are not game breaking

Posted: June 25
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Just bought this game and played this for over 5 hours at the time this review was done. Yes it is an early access game and the price reflects this. There are bug at times but the developers are working on fixes and we all need to help them by reporting these bugs. The bugs I have experienced is that the game doesn't always respond when I click the mouse and I have had to Alt+F4 to force close the game at times. Then it works okay when reloaded. That is the only major bugs I have experience so far.

Good bits I like about the game. I like the open free world map and its explorable. The improvements I would like to see here would to have a minimap like in GTA V in the bottom left corner with icons for the player and the locations of the car dealer, garage, bar, junkyard and so on.

Things I dislike. There is only one thing I do not like about this game. The time goes too fast and I would like it to be slowed down to half speed so we get longer to buy cars, fix them up and all the exciting stuff that this new game has to offer. Perhap add this as an option to use "real time" mode as well as 1.5x to 5x time speed that would give us players a choice.

Feedback to the developers.
I would like to see improvements to the handling of the cars and trucks because some of the cars have steering that is too light for a car and there is a lack of the "feel" when cornering. I would like to improvements to understeer and oversteering when driving. Something similar to how Gran Turismo would be like.

I would like to see more variety in the AI traffic with vehicles like garbage trucks, buses and emergency vehicles like fire trucks, ambulances and police cars driving about in the traffic. At night time. Police cars should patrol the neighborhood area and the player should be able to report scammer sellers to the Police in the game so if they sell a dodgy car to the player. The AI Police can and will arrest them.

I am sure this feedback will be helpful to the game developers and I am so happy to have the experience of playing this game. I look forward to supporting its progress!

Keep up the great work team!

A good game if it were $4.99

Pros:
The progression is well paced. The grind to get money at the beginning quickly turns into an addicting race to become a multi-millionaire.

Posted: July 3
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
As a real life car seller I can recommend this game, the idea is great, however here are some flaws that I noticed and tips that would increase the audience for the game.
- On your tablet, there's no way of deleting old pictures of cars that you already sold, for new cars you have to repeatedly take pictures so they appear in the gallery.
- A lot of console errors (which is normal since it's early access, but would be great if there's an option to remove the notifications & errors) other than that 4 hours straight of playing 0 bugs with driving, drinking, etc.
- Would be really unique to have in the database history of sold cars.
- Some more technical stuff would be fun too, transmission failures, engine problems, instead you get other '' major '' problems like that your car is dirty and perhaps a cracked fender.
- Bigger world, options to travel to other states, import cars from a different country as an example.
- More fluent interactions when negotiating and a bigger variety of cars.
I can go on and on, but of course there's a lot to be mentioned, I have high hopes on this one, we'll see how it'll age.
UPDATE:
- Now there is a way to delete old pictures
- No console errors
- 0 crashes, I'm at day 65, no issues with saves, nearly 20 hours of gameplay.
With each hour, I'm enjoying this game more and more, still 2 things that need to be fixed :
- As shown in the trailer that you can buy totaled cars or use them for scrap, there is no such option available, I hope we get it soon.
- Still can't save the overall data of sold cars and points for the global ranking.
Go ahead and buy this game, it's getting better.
There are not many games out there with this price tag that would make you spend so many hours in them.

Posted: July 4

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
TLDR: Wait until the full game is released to purchase.
Okie dokie.
For those of you who have seen my reviews, I typically wait until I've had a good amount of time played before making a review; this is a change of form. I didn't play this game for long because, admittedly, I was rather disappointed.
+Pros:
+The game is exactly as advertised; you go to a car show or neighborhood and try to swindle customers for cars. There's a lot of diversity in the cars you can find while out hunting.
+Car customization: being able to change the color and sheen of the car is a nice touch.
+It's a relatively simple game with the loop of: buy car, fix it/customize it, sell it, sleep, repeat. Time progresses independently so there is a day night cycle.
-Cons:
-Unfinished*: The game is largely unfinished; human sprites are wonky, some of the interfaces don't work correctly, the driving can be described as buggy and overly sensitive. *Now, I understand that this is early access, so hopefully some of these things will be fixed in the full release.*
-Expectations aren't met: I came to this game after watching Markiplier play Gas Station Simulator and I wanted something more in depth. Now, these are not at all the same game, but this is definitely more of a dealership simulator (like I wanted), but for the price I paid for it, it didn't do it for me; I wasn't immersed in the game.
-Price: So, I bought this game when it was on sale for $10.79, but the normal retail is around 20 bucks usd! This game feels, to me, that it's still in its playtesting phase; that this should be a release to playtesters to work out bugs and improve the experience, but, instead, it is up to the public to purchase this game and find out for themselves.
*Conclusion*
*This game is exactly as advertised, with a simple game loop that may keep some entertained, but that did not do it for me. Developers, I encourage you to continue working on this project, it seems like a labor of love and will do well with some TLC. It's just, for me, this game isn't worth the money (as of the games current release).

Posted: May 23

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I get that it's still in EA and It has a lot of potentials. All the ideas they have shown are cool as hell.
Although the gameplay loop feel pretty grindy and the game is buggy, it is entertaining and enjoyable.
But I don't think It's worth buying at this stage.

I mean, the devs clearly know how to use AI when it comes to pictures for loading screen. Why can't they just use AI to have at least half decent translations for the text?

Aside from the translation errors, the car models' quality is all over the place.
Some of the model looks way better than others.
Some cars have the actual rolling wheels laying on top of the wheel model fixed onto the body itself.
Some even have their break calipers spinning with the wheels while driving.

I think I don't have to talk about the bugs since a lot of the reviews already mention them.

I do see the possibility of this game being good in the future. I will keep it in my wishlist.
Or I might buy it back when I'm bored.
But if you're looking for a smooth and extensive gameplay experience, it's not worth your money for now.
